Alterations in the cellular immune compartment of patients treated with third-party mesenchymal stromal cells following allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation R.

Adoptive transfer of third-party mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) has emerged as a promising tool for the treatment of steroid-refractory GVHD. Despite numerous in vitro studies and preclinical models, little is known about their eff ects on the patients' immune system. We assessed immune alterations in the T-cell, NK-cell, dendritic cell, and monocytic compartments of steroidrefractory GVHD patients 30, 90, and 180 days after MSC (n=6) or placebo (n=5) infusion respectively. There were several indications that MSCs shift the patients' immune system towards a more tolerogenic profi le. Compared to placebo-treated patients, the infusion of MSCs was associated with increased levels of regulatory (FOXP3+ and IL-10+) T-cells, reduced pro-infl ammatory IL-17+ T-cells (Th17), and skewing towards type-2 T-helper cell responses. The frequency of CD25med-hiCD127loFOXP3+ CD4+ regulatory T-cells (Treg) was signifi cantly increased in the MSC group at one (p=0.003) and three (p=0.037) months. The Treg/ TH17 ratio at three months was 4.96±5.25 in the MSC patients compared to 0.64±0.44 in the controls (p=0.036). Furthermore IL-2, which has been recently shown to exert an immune modulating eff ect in GVHD patients, was 9.04±8.89 pg/ml in the MSC patients three months after MSC-infusion, as opposed to 0.83±1.22 pg/ml in the controls (p=0.008). Overall, our fi ndings will contribute to the refi nement of monitoring tools, for assessing MSC treatmenteffi cacy and increase our understanding regarding the MSCs' in vivo eff ects.

Immunoproteomic identifi cation of naturally presented epitopes presented on primary myeloid leukaemia cells and their potential as targets for T-cell receptor gene modifi ed donor lymphocyte infusions R.

The bone marrow niche contains diff erent cells including osteoblasts and endothelial progenitors which form a unique microenvironment necessary for proper function of hematopoietic precursors. Additionally the cytokines involved in niche-cell interactions take a major part in angiogenesis. The role of angiogenic cytokines in the mobilization of hematopoietic stem cells is not clearly understood. The aim of our study was to evaluate the levels of osteopontin, secreted mainly by osteoblasts, as well as angiopoietins 1,2 (ANG 1,2) and circulating endothelial cells (CEC) during mobilization of hematopoietic stem cells.

Methods: Forty-eight patients were enrolled to the study (24F, 24M) at median age 56.5 years. The group consisted of patients with multiple myeloma (34), lymphoma (13) and acute myeloid leukemia (1). Blood samples were collected before chemotherapy and on the day of the fi rst apheresis. CEC were evaluated by 4-colour fl ow cytometry and cytokines with ELISA assay. Results: ANG1 was signifi cantly reduced in peripheral blood at the time of apheresis (Median, Me=2, 7vs7, 8 ng/ml at baseline, p <0,001). ANG2 signifi cantly increased during mobilization procedure (Me=3, 6vs2, 8 ng/ml at baseline, p=0.001). Osteopontin measured at the time of apheresis did not diff er from pretreatment values. Median number of CECs at baseline was 10.5/μl and decreased at the time of fi rst apheresis (Me=8.0/μl, p<0.001). Patients were divided according to the number of days of G-CSF treatment before fi rst apheresis into 'early' (<Me=11 days) and 'late' (>Me) mobilizers. The baseline CEC was higher in 'early mobilizers' than in the 'late mobilizers' (Me=12.5vs9.9/μl, p=0.04). Group of 'early mobilizers' presented also higher baseline ANG1 (Me=11, 6ng/ml) than the 'late mobilizers' group (Me=6, 0ng/ml, p=0.05). Correlations: Adverse correlation of duration of G-CSF treatment with baseline ANG1 level (r=-0,39, p=0,006) was observed. There was a trend for adverse correlation of baseline CEC number with the number of days of G-CSF treatment before I apheresis (r=-0.33, p=0.06). Correlations of osteopontin with ANG2 level (r=0,35, p=0,014) and ANG1 with CEC number (r=0,34, p=0,04) at baseline were observed. Conclusions: Higher baseline ANG1 levels as well as CEC counts are associated with shorter time of G-CSF treatment required for successful mobilization. Our observation indicates that the angiogenic factors can infl uence the timing of mobilization probably by their protective eff ect on endothelial and hematopoietic cells. body_text.text: Γ/δ T cells are innate immune cells with strong anti-tumor activity and provide anti-tumor receptors that are interesting tools in immune therapy against cancer. The introduction of γ/δ TCR genes into α/β T-cells allows the adoptive transfer of T cells that are not limited by HLA-restriction, in any patient with any cancer. Combinatorial γ/δ TCR-exchange (CTE) has been applied to design a gamm9δ2 TCR with strong and broad anti-tumor reactivity, referred to as TCR γ9-G115/δ2-cl5. Here, we prepare this attractive candidate γ/δ TCR for clinical application. First, we introduced both γ and δ chains into the retroviral vector pMP71, separated by a 2A peptide sequence. Gene-engineered human α/β T-cells expressed the γ/δ TCR and recognized tumors of diff erent hematological origin as well as solid tumors. Second, we tested expression and function of the γ/δ TCR after addition of suicide genes which will enable in vivo elimination of therapeutic T cells. Following the introduction of either CD20 or EGFR separated with another 2A sequence from the TCR transgene cassette in pMP71, TCR expression and function was greatly impaired and as such this approach is not suitable for clinical application. Third, we tested the infl uence of the γ/δ TCR transgene cassette and the particular 2A peptide sequence. Interestingly, the orientation of the γ and δ chains and the 2A peptide sequence infl uenced TCR expression as well as anti-tumor function as previously demonstrated for α/ β TCR genes. All together, our results demonstrate that currently available suicide genes severely impair expression of introduced TCRs and functional avidity of engineered T-cells, thus are not useful for clinical application. In addition, modulating 2A sequences and the sequence of receptor chains allowed a deliberate choice for the most potent clinical γ/δ TCR receptor cassette that will be used in our next TCR gene therapy trial.

Sleeping Beauty system-mediated expression of chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) in CIK cells: a novel tool towards the cure of childhood leukaemia C. Magnani (1) , G. Giordano Attianese (1) , S. Tettamanti (1) , N. Turazzi (1) , V. Marin (1) , L. Cooper (2) , A. Biondi (1) , E. Biagi (1) (

Stable gene transfer of chimeric antigen receptors (CAR) is a powerful tool to redirect antigen specifi city of eff ector T cells for adoptive immunotherapy of tumours. The development of effi cient and safe nonviral vectors would rescue the safety and manufacture concerns that limit so far their clinical application. The ex-vivo use of the latest generation Sleeping Beauty (SB) Transposon-mediated gene transfer off ers a valid alternative to viral vectors for human gene therapy. Here we used nucleofection of SB system and an optimized clinical-grade stimulation protocol to generate and propagate cytokine-induced killer (CIK) cells genetically modifi ed to express CD123-specifi c 3rd generation chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) to redirect antigen specifi city towards the acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML) CD123+ blasts. Indeed, CD123 overexpression is well known to be a poor prognosis marker in AML. With this system, the average transfection at 24hours was 68.9% (±1.0, n=6) and mean survival percentage was 34.8% (±5. 6, n=5) . Electroporation with the optimized stimulation protocol did not aff ect the phenotype of CIK cells, preserved their naïve and stem cell memory populations, and resulted in a fold increase of 15.7±3.3 at the end of the CIK culture at day 21. Transposed CIK cells displayed stable expression of Tr scFvCD123.3rdCAR (39.4%±8.6), effi cient lysis of AML target cells, and CAR-specifi c cytokine secretion. Finally, long-term expansion (fold increase 423.8±301.4, n=2 at day 40) upon stimulation with AML cells in vitro promoted effi cient selection of CAR+ CIK cells with potent cytotoxic activity towards AML target (92.9±1, n=2), suggesting long-term persistence of functional CIK cells in vivo. Effi cient transfection of CARs together with a feasible manufacturing practice (GMP) strategy to select and propagate CAR-expressing CIK cells will be instrumental in defi ning novel therapeutic approaches to target childhood acute myeloid leukaemia.

Chakraverty UCL (London, GB) Adoptive immunotherapy with TCR-redirected T cells has potential to treat Cytomegalovirus infection or Epstein-Barr virus-related post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder. Immune suppressive drugs used to prevent rejection, or graft-versus-host disease, may inhibit adoptively transferred cells. We have evaluated the potential for gene transfer to T cells of mutated inosine-5'-monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH2R; T333I, S351Y) which confers resistance to the immune suppressive drug mycophenolate mofetil (MMF). IMPDH2R and IMPDH2 catalytic site mutant (IMPDH2CS; C331A) were cloned into SFG retroviral vectors fused to eGFP reporter sequences. Cells were transduced with each vector, their phenotype and function evaluated in the presence or absence of mycophenolic acid (MPA), the active metabolite of MMF. IMPDH2R-transduced murine thymoma (BW5147) cells exhibited less apoptosis in response to MPA than IMPDH2CS-transduced cells (ratio % Annexin V+ MPA:no MPA IMPDH2R =1.2; IMPDH2CS =2.9, p=0.01). IMPDH2R-transduced cells overcame MPA induced cell-cycle arrest (Ratio % in S-G2/M phases MPA: no MPA-IMPDH2R = 1.0; IMPDH2CS = 0.3, p=0.03). Human peripheral blood mononuclear cells transduced with LMP2 TCR and either IMPDH2R or IMPDH2CS were stimulated with cognate peptide-loaded T2 cells. MPA exposure selected IMPDH2R but not IMPDH2CS-transduced cells. Selection persisted following subsequent stimulation without MPA. To assess in vivo selection, sub-lethally irradiated B6.PL (Thy1.1) mice were injected with a 1:1 mix of OT1 TCR transgenic CD8 T cells transduced with IMPDH2R or IMPDH2CS diff erentiated from each other and the host by congenic markers. Transferred cells were stimulated by cognate or irrelevant peptide in adjuvant and MMF or dextrose was given by daily ip injection. IMPDH2R-transduced Current therapeutic regimens for AML are still associated with high rates of relapse. Immunotherapy with T-cells genetically modifi ed to express chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) represents a valid and innovative cell therapy approach for haematological malignancies. In this study we developed a new CAR molecule specifi c for the IL-3Rα (CD123) target antigen, which is overexpressed on AML blasts, CD34+ leukaemic progenitors, and leukaemic stem cells (LSCs) compared to normal haematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs), and whose overexpression is associated with poor prognosis. CIK cells were transduced with an SFG-retroviral vector encoding an anti-CD123.CAR. The effi cacy and safety profi les of transduced cells were characterized in vitro by short and long-term cytotoxicity assays. Their potential reactivity against HSPCs was evaluated by colony-forming unit assay after 4-hours co-incubation. Anti-CD123.CAR+CIK cells strongly killed CD123+ THP-1 cell line (60%±5.4%, Eff ector:Target -E:T-ratio of 5:1, n=3), as well as primary AML blasts (59%±5.4%, E:T ratio of 3:1, n=4) in 4-hours citotoxicity assays. In long-term cytotoxicity assay we observed a leukaemic cell recovery for THP-1 of 3.5%±1.5% (n=5) and for primary AML cells of 2.4%±1.4% (n=3) when co-cultured with anti-CD123.CAR+CIK cells, compared to an average survival of up to 80%, when co-cultured with unmanipulated (NT) CIK cells. Interestingly, secondary colonies experiments after co-culture of cord blood-derived HSPCs with anti-CD123.CAR+CIK cells demonstrated that anti-CD123. CAR better preserved the normal haematopoietic reconstitution in contrast to a previously generated anti-CD33.CAR (total number of colonies of 146.8±6. 6, 66.4±5.1, 117 .6±4.6, after co-culture with NT CIK cells, anti-CD33.CAR+CIK cells, anti-CD123.CAR+CIK cells respectively, n=4). Furthermore, a limited killing of normal CD123+monocytes and CD123-low expressing endothelial cells was measured. Taken together, our results indicate that anti-CD123.CAR strongly enhances antileukaemic CIK functions towards AML, while sparing HSPCs and normal CD123-expressing tissues, paving the way for the development of novel immunotherapy approaches for the treatment of resistant forms of AML. T. Erkers, S. Nava, J. Yosef, O. Ringdén, H. Kaipe Karolinska Institutet (Stockholm, SE) Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (BM-MSCs) have been used to treat GvHD, but maternal stromal cells from term fetal membrane (FMCs) have many advantages compared to BM-MSCs, including an increased allosuppression, unlimited supply, great expansion potential and high expression of integrins. We introduced the use of FMCs in patients with steroid refractory aGvHD and the overall response was 75%. In this study, we are elucidating factors of importance in the reduction of alloreactivity by FMCs. We found that FMCs need to have cell-cell contact in order to mediate suppression in mixed lymphocyte reactions (MLR) (p=0.01, n=11). This distinguishes FMCs from BM-MSCs, which can suppress the MLR without contact to the MLR. The frequency of CD4+CD25highFOXP3+ regulatory T cells (Treg) was increased (median 2.3-fold), whereas the proportion of total CD25+ T cells was decreased (median 1.4-fold) when the FMCs were added to the MLR cultures (p=0.03, n=10 and p=0.03, n=6, respectively). This was only observed when cell-cell contact was allowed between the MLR and FMCs. Blocking the activity of indoleamine-2,3-dioxygenase (IDO) (median 2.6-fold increase in proliferation compared to MLR+FMC-control, p=0.01, n=8), IFN-γ (median 2.0fold increase, p<0.01, n=11), Prostaglandin E2 (median 1.26-fold increase, p=0.01, n=12) and PD-L1 (median 1.23-fold increase, p=0.03, n=7), signifi cantly impaired the anti-proliferative ability of the FMCs in MLRs. Neutralization of molecules such as IL-10, IL-17, TGF-β and HLA-G had no eff ect on proliferation in MLRs. Inactivation of IDO also reduced the frequency of Tregs. In contrast to BM-MSC, pre-treatment of the FMCs with high concentrations of IFN-γ (100 U/ml) decreased their function to suppress alloreactivity (p<0.01, n=16), but stimulation of FMCs with MLR supernatants containing low levels of IFN-γ had no eff ect on the suppressive capacity in the MLR. To conclude, FMCs diff ers in several aspects from BM-MSCs and needs proximity to allo-reactive lymphocytes to mediate a suppressive eff ect and increase the frequency of Tregs. Thus, FMCs may not only use paracrine factors for systemic immunosuppression, but more specifi cally target T cells locally in aff ected tissues.

body_text.text: It has been previously shown that treatment of diff erent leukemias by allogenic hematopoetic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) followed by the administration of donor lymphocyte infusions (DLI) can induce remissions in patients with residual leukemic cells or relapse. The graft versus leukemia (GVL) activity mediated by DLI could be increased by genetic modifi cation of the DLI with T cell receptors (TCR) recognizing epitopes naturally presented on primary leukemia cells. We used an immunoproteomic approach to identify such epitopes, expanded peptide specifi c T cells with the selected candidates and isolated TCR recognizing those epitopes. Cells of patients with chronic and acute myelogenous leukemia were lysed in detergent containing buff er and human leukocyte class I (HLA I) molecules were subsequently immunoprecipitated by the W6/32 antibody. HLA I associated peptides were eluted by acid treatment followed by sequencing via mass spectrometry (MS). Peptide lists were established selecting epitopes originating from genes with expression restricted to hematopoietic cells or cancer testis like expression profi le according to database and literature research.

Amongst the candidate peptides were several epitopes from the myeloblastosis viral oncogene homolog (c-myb) and the myeloperoxidase (MPO) which are both known to be highly expressed in many cases of myeloid leukemia. Candidate peptides were synthesized and naïve cytotoxic T lymphocytes were stimulated with semi-allogenic dendritic cells pulsed with the respective peptide for expansion of epitope-specifi c T cells. By sorting with HLA I multimers we could so far isolate a high avidity TCR specifi c for a HLA-B*0702 restricted epitope of MPO. The TCR shows reactivity against peptide pulsed target cells and leukemia cell lines endogenously expressing MPO.

body_text.text: In conclusion, the analysis of peptides directly eluted from HLA molecules on the surface of myeloid leukemia cells resulted in the identifi cation of attractive target candidates for the development of novel cellular immunotherapies in leukemias. A high avidity TCR specifi c for an HLA-B*0702 restricted epitope of MPO could be isolated that shows tumor reactivity in vitro. This TCR could serve as a therapeutic tool in a HLA-B*0702 mismatch transplantation setting and is further tested in a preclinical mouse model to show tumor reactivity in vivo.

body_text.text: Effi cacy of platelet-rich plasma for the treatment of chronic wounds V.N. Obolenskiy (1) , D.A. Ermolova (2) , L.A. Laberko (2) (1)Municipal Hospital #13 (Moscow, RU); (2) RRMU (Moscow, RU) Objective: to assess the effi cacy of platelet-rich plasma (PRP) for the treatment of patients with chronic wounds (CW) of various etiologies. Materials and methods: Analysis of the treatment outcomesof 81 patients with CW of various etiologies was performed: trophic venous ulcers (TVU) -8, ulcers of combined etiology (CEU) -20, related to diabetic foot syndrome (DFS) -20, post-traumatic and post-surgical scar-trophic ulcer (STU) -19 and bedsores (BU) -14.

After the bacteriological investigation all patientsreceived treatment of the underlyingdisease and the topical treatment, aimed at the wound cleaning and decontamination. For the treatment of the 44 patients (experimental group: 17 males, 27 females, the mean age -56.0 ± 3.1; VTU -3, CCEU -8, DFS -12, STU -14 BU -7, the mean CW area was 90.2 ± 14.1 cm 2 ), we used PRP fl at clot therapy starting from phase II of wound healing process. Flat clots were obtained by one-step centrifugation using special BTI equipment (Spain). The volume of collected blood depends on the size of the wound and should be between 5 ml and 40 ml at a time. Platelet growth factors were activated with 10% CaCl2. The time from blood collection to ligation was 20-30 minutes on the average. PRP is placed on the top of atraumatic mesh bandage and covered with secondary dressing. Frequency of dressing changeis once in seven days, which allows patient transfers to outpatient care. For the treatment of the 37 patients (control group: 17 males, 20 females, mean age was 69.5 ± 2.2; VTU -5, CEU -12, DFS -8, STU -5, BU -7, the mean CW area was 79.6 ± 12.3 cm 2 ), traditional topical agents were used starting from phase II of wound healing process. Evaluation of the treatment outcomeswas performed within 3 months. Results: Mean number of PRP applications was 6.0 ± 0.6 per patient in the experimental group. In 3 patients following 3-4 applications autodermoplastics of wound was performeddue to a large area of the wound defect; 35 patients (85.4%) achieved complete CW epithelialization within 46.4 ± 4.3 days; and for 6 patients this treatment method was not eff ective. In the control group autodermoplastics of wound was performed in 3 patients, and only 4 patients (11.8%) achieved wound epithelialization within 3 months. Mean duration of hospital stay was 11.0 ± 2.5 days in the experimental group and 23.1 ± 1.5 daysin the control group. Conclusions: Treatment of patients with CW using PRP is safe, clinically benefi cial and cost eff ective.

Experimental justifi cation for clinical use of platelet rich plasma V.N. Obolenskiy (1) , N.V. Borovkova (2) , M.S. Makarov (2) , D. A. Ermolova (3) , L.A. Laberko (3) (1)Municipal Hospital #13 (Moscow, RU); (2)

Objective: to asses in vitro the effi ciency of platelet rich plasma (PRP) for clinical use. Materials and methods: Blood collected from a peripheral vein of the patients with chronic wounds of various etiologies was usedas a biological material. PRP was obtained by separating blood with the use of BTI equipment (Spain). Whole blood platelets were stained with vital fl uorochrome dye for further morpho-functional analysison a fl uorescence microscope. Concentration of plateletderived growth factor (PDGF) in blood serum was determined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) using reagents «Qantikine, Human PDGF-BB Immunoassay» (R & D Systems) and system «Multiskan ascent» (Thermo). Proliferative activity of human fi broblast culture (M-22) was assessed in the wells containing diff erent amount of serum PDGF and also using fl uorochrome vital dyes. Results: A direct correlation between concentration and morphofunctional parameters of whole blood platelets and concentration of PDGF in the serum has been observed. Degranulation of platelets is associated with the massive release of PDGF. The study fi nding was that the content of PDGF in one well equal to 150 pg is associated with the maximum gain of proliferative activity of fi broblastswith their viability being preserved; at the higher PDGF concentrations fi broblasts viability decreased and cells death was observed. Conclusions: These data allow recommending the clinical use of PRP for stimulation of the regenerative-reparative processes.

Cytokine-induced killer cell derivates with reduced risk for graft-versus-host disease eradicate acute leukaemia and soft tissue sarcoma cells in vitro and in vivo in immunodefi cient mice E. Rettinger (1) , V. Meyer (1) , H. Kreyenberg (1) , S. Kuci (1) , A. Willasch (1) , G. Bug (2) , W.S. Wels (3) , H. Bonig (4) , T. Klingebiel (1) , P. Bader (1) (1)University Children´s Hospital (Frankfurt, DE) ; (2) Internal Medicine II (Frankfurt, DE) ; (3) Chemotherapeutisches Forschungsinstitut Georg Speyer Haus (Frankfurt, DE) ; (4) Institute for Transfusion Medicine and Immunohematology (Frankfurt, DE) Objectives: Pre-emptive immunotherapy using unmanipulated cytokine induced killer (CIK) cells or CIK cell products with reduced risk of graft versus host disease (GvHD), i.e. CD56-enriched (CD56+) or irradiated CIK cells derived from IL-15-expanded CIK cells may off er a novel therapeutic approach for patients with high risk acute leukemia and soft tissue sarcoma relapsing after haploidentical stem cell transplantation (haplo-SCT). Methods: This study was performed to evaluate the cytotoxic impact of CIK cell derivates in vitro and in vivo. Mice injected with malignant cells, either received a single dose of unmanipulated CIK cells or serial injections of unmanipulated CIK cells or CIK cell products, and were randomly assigned for analysis of CIK cell treatment in terms of disease free survival (DFS) and engraftment of malignant cells compared to untreated controls. Results: CIK cell products showed reduced proliferative capacity in vitro compared to unmanipulated CIK cells. But, in vitro cytotoxicity of CD56+ CIK cells was signifi cantly improved against soft tissue sarcomas compared to unmanipulated and irradiated CIK cells, whereas no diff erences occurred against acute leukemias. In vivo analysis demonstrated that inoculated leukemias responded to infusions of unmanipulated CIK cells but not to administered CIK cell products (CD33+ primary AML cells [%] , w/o 91.0±2.0; w unmanipulated 26.3±22.9 (once) and 0±0 (repetitive); w CD56+ 43.7±40.7; w irradiated 89.3±0.6). Sequential infusions of unmanipulated CIK cells resulted in an eradication of leukemia cells. In addition, treated mice showed an increased DSF (median survival [days] , w/o 182; w unmanipulated 337 (once) and >340 (repetitive); w CD56+ 220; w irradiated 200). In contrast, in rhabdomyosarcoma-bearing mice, one infusion of unmanipulated CIK cells was suffi cient for eradication of malignant cells (engraftment [RFU] , w/o 77.3±27.0; w unmanipulated 1.2±2.9; w CD56+ 41.9±11.4; w irradiated 30.4±13.8) which resulted in an increased DFS (median survival [days] , w/o 59; w unmanipulated >100; w CD56+ 84; w irradiated 92). Further analysis confi rmed that unmanipulated CIK cells were detectable in signifi cant numbers compared to CD56+ or irradiated CIK cells. Conclusion: The non-restricted anti-tumoral cytotoxicity and the limited risk for GvHD may suggest serial infusions of high numbers of unmanipulated CIK cells as a promising immunotherapeutic approach for high risk patients even in the context of haplo-SCT.

Preferentially cytotoxicity CD27-CD45RA+ subset decreased in all the experiment groups, while preferentially IFN γ-secreting CD27-CD45RA-subset obviously increased in dasatinib IC50 group, which may at least in part explain our previous fi ndings. Conclusion: Dasatinib IC50 concentration not the other BCR/ABLinhibitors enhanced gd T cell antitumor eff ect through a shift to CD27-diff erentiation and IFN γ-secreting responses without aff ected gd T cell proliferation. body_text.text: Important pre-requisites for anti-tumor adoptive cell therapy (ACT) include the possibility of obtaining CTLs able to reach tumor sites and effi ciently kill neoplastic cells. We have previously developed a methodological approach to ex-vivo expand anti-tumor CTLs by stimulation of eff ector cells with dendritic cells (DC) pulsed with either apoptotic malignant cells (anti-leukemia CTL) or WT1-peptides as tumor antigens. Recently, it has been described the potential antitumor activity of IFN-alfa and its capacity to induce the diff erentiation of monocytes into DC highly effi cient in mediating cross-priming of CD8+ T cells. The aim of the present study was to evaluate if the induction of either anti-leukemia or WT1-specifi c CTLs, using IFN-alfa during the maturation of DC and/or the priming of eff ector cells, lead to an improvement of their specifi c anti-tumor cytotoxic activity. Four WT1-specifi c and 8 anti-leukemia CTL lines were generated from 5 donor of HSCT. DC were generated culturing CD14+ cells in the presence of GM-CSF and IL-4 (IL4-DC) or IFN-alfa (IFN-DC). During the priming, PBMC or CD8+ T cells were stimulated with IL4-DC or IFN-DC pulsed with irradiated tumor cells or WT1 peptides in the presence of IL-7 and IL-12, with or without IFN-alfa. IFN-DC displayed a set of membrane molecules involved in antigen presentation even though their morphologic aspect was more monocyte-like than DC-like. In all CTL lines we observed that cytotoxic activity against leukemia blasts was higher when IFN-DC were used as APC instead of IL4-DC (mean lysis: 48%, range 32-61 and 31%, range 17-39, respectively at E:T ratio of 25:1). Specifi c lysis was further enhanced by the addition of IFN-alfa during the priming of CTLs. In spite of an increase percentage of NK cells in IFN-CTLs, we did not documented a loss of their specifi city, in that the reactivity against non-malignant cells was less than 15% at the E/T ratio of 25:1, and the addition of cold K562 in cytotoxicity assay did not cause sizeable reduction of anti-leukemia cytotoxic activity.

body_text.text: These data confi rm the possibility of effi ciently generating antileukemia CTL lines using IFN-alfa in order (i) to improve DC's ability to act as APCs and (ii) to stimulate T-cells to recognise, during the priming, either leukemic associated antigens on the surface of apoptotic leukemic blasts or specifi c peptides. This approach will be useful to improve ACT strategies to control or prevent leukemia relapse after HSCT. A. Chauchet, R. Vallion, F. Bonnefoy, A. Daoui, S. Kaminski, B. Lamarthee, P. Saas, S. Perruche INSERM UMR 1098 (Besancon, FR) Introduction: Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (AHCT) is a curative therapy for hematological malignancies. However, such a therapeutic is limited by graft-versus-host-disease (GvHD) occurrence. New strategies are therefore needed and our laboratory showed that the use of apoptotic cell has immunomodulatory properties to favor engraftment and limit GvHD. These eff ects are TGF-B and regulatory T cell dependent. However, since apoptotic cell injection favors tolerance, the infl uence of apoptotic cell injection on leukemia development has never been evaluated. Methods: To examine whether graft-versus-leukemia (GvL) activity of T cells was maintained after AHCT in the presence of apoptotic cells, we developed an experimental mouse model of T celldepleted bone marrow (TCD BM) transplantation. Leukemic A20 luciferase+ cells were also injected the day of TCD BM transplantation (d0). A delayed allogeneic donor T cell infusion was given on day 6 to induce GvHD and GvL. Apoptotic cells were injected either on d0 or d6. Results: Eradication of leukemic cells was observed in all animals receiving delayed T cells injection. Indeed, all mice not receiving T cells died from leukemia before day 27 post-graft, as attested by tumor growth evaluation by luminescence (NightOwl technology). Then, we observed that T cell injection prevents tumor growth as attested by absence of luminescence, however all mice developed GvHD (according to Ferrara's score) and died before day 27 . In sharp contrast, 60% of mice receiving apoptotic cells on d0 survived at day 27. In addition, such mice receiving apoptotic cells that prevent GvHD occurrence, did not present leukemic growth as attested by the absence of luminescence at day 27 post-graft. No diff erence was observed for infl ammatory lymphocyte. Proliferation of CD3 (BRDU) and cytotoxicity of LT CD8+ vs receipt cells was decreased contrary to cytoxicity of CD8 vs A20 which was preserved with apoptotic cell on day 0. Conclusion: Our data clearly demonstrated that GvHD suppression by apoptotic cell injection does not abrogate GvL activity of adoptively transferred donor T cells. Thus, apoptotic cell injection should be considered in clinic to favor engraftment, prevent GvHD, conserving high GvL therapeutic activity.

Kvalheim (1) (1)Oslo University Hospital (Oslo, NO) ; (2) Helmholtz Zentrum (Munich, DE) We have previously shown that a new generation of fast DCs, using a maturation cocktail containing IL-1β, TNFα, IFNγ, PGE2 and the TLR7/8 ligand R848 was more effi cient than the standard 7 days DCs. To establish this DC method in our GMP-facility, we cultivated monocytes from 2 volunteer healthy donors. On day 3, the maturation cocktail was added. mDCs were harvested and electroporated on day 4 and frozen after a recovery period. The following parameters were investigated: expression of the S78 surface markers CD14, CD80, CD83, CD86, CD40 HLA-DR, CCR7, CD274 using FACS analysis, the capability to secrete IL-10 and IL-12p70 during co-culture with CD40L-mouse fi broblasts and the migratory capacity using a CCL19 gradient. In both preparations CD14 showed a complete negative shift in mean fl uorescence intensity after maturation while all other markers showed a complete positive shift. All tested cells produced IL-12p70 in the range from 138 pg/ml to 216 pg/ml. The IL-10 production ranged from 14 pg/ml to 60 pg/ml. All mDCs showed increased migration towards CCL19 compared to controls. Thereafter, two autologous DC vaccines transfected with mRNA hTERT and Survivin were produced for "compassionate use". DC phenotype, IL-12 /IL-10 production and migration capacity was similar compared to mDCs from healthy donors. Of the two patients vaccinated, one suff ered from metastatic lung cancer with a brain metastasis. Following diagnosis in June 2011 she was treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Since December 2011 she has been vaccinated and CT/MRI examination in November 2012 showed a partial response in the lung and no further disease development in the brain. The second patient receiving DC vaccination has a hormone resistant prostate cancer, but he is still too early to evaluate. Altogether, our results show that our new generation of DC vaccines can be a potentially useful immunotherapy for cancer patients.

body_text.text: Human platelet lysate and exosomes improve the in vitro osteogenic pre-diff erentiation of bone marrow-derived stem cells T. Lener, M. Oeller, D. Peckl-Schmid, D. Streif, M. Gimona, F. Rivera, L. Aigner, E. Rohde Paracelsus Medical University (Salzburg, AT) Rationale: Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem and progenitor cells (BM-MSPCs) are attractive candidates for cell therapy. Replacing bovine serum with human platelet lysate (HPL) for in vitro culture has been established as a safe procedure to maintain the multi-lineage potential of BM-MSPCs, and HPL has been shown to promote osteogenic diff erentiation in vitro and in vivo. Pre-diff erentiation of BM-MSPCs in vitro can improve bone regeneration when used for critical-sized bone defects. Thus we tested the hypothesis that progenitor cell-derived exosomes further enhance osteogenic diff erentiation. Methods: We employed cell counting, colony formation assays and the xCELLigence impedance assay (ROCHE) for determination of the proliferative capacity of BM-MSPCs in the presence or absence of exosomes derived from either MSPCs or Endothelial Colony Forming Cells (ECFCs). Osteogenic diff erentiation of BM-MSPCs was induced by dexamethasone, ascorbic acid and β-glycerophosphate in HPL-supplemented media. Flow cytometric analysis was used to monitor stem cell and osteogenic lineage marker expression. Fluorescence and phase contrast microscopy was performed to visualize exosome uptake and osteogenic diff erentiation, respectively. Results: Here we show that exosomes derived from BM-MSPCs, but not from ECFCs further potentiate the HPL-supported osteogenic diff erentiation of BM-MSPCs. In contrast, the proliferative potential of BM-MSPCs was increased by ECFC-derived exosomes only. In the presence of homotypic exosomes BM-MSPCs can be replated after ostogenic diff erentiation without osteo-inductive supplements, and maintain the secretion and deposition of mineralizing matrix. To our knowledge this is the fi rst description of enhanced osteogenic diff erentiation of BM-MSPCs by stem cellderived exosomes. Conclusions: Various procedures have been developed to promote osteogenic diff erentiation of mesenchymal cells in vitro, including growth factor and medium supplements, genetic manipulation or mechanical stimulation. Our results show that in the presence of HPL and exosomes BM-MSPCs can be diff erentiated in vitro towards osteoprogenitors that maintain deposition of calcifying matrix material. Establishing future protocols for the in vitro pre-diff erentiation of BM-MSPCs may contribute to improved stem cell therapy, specifi cally for critical size bone defects.

Jedema Leiden University Medical Center (Leiden, NL) Although profound graft versus leukemia (GvL) responses can be induced after donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI) and allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT) in some patients, the therapeutic eff ectivity in other patients is limited by inadequate induction of GvL reactivity due to limited numbers and/or inferior immunogenicity of (malignant) antigen-presenting cells of patient origin. Moreover, due to the broad repertoire of specifi cities within unselected donor T cells GvL reactivity often coincides with induction of graft versus host disease (GvHD). Adoptive transfer of selected populations of donor T cells directed against minor histocompatibility antigens (MiHA) that are specifi cally expressed on only hematopoietic cells of the patient may be an elegant strategy to induce therapeutic GvL reactivity without GvHD. In this study, we used an 'in-vitro vaccin' of hematopoiesis-specifi c MiHA peptides loaded on monocyte-derived dendritic cells of donor origin for in-vitro generation of MiHAspecifi c donor T cells. Naïve CD8+ donor T cells enriched from peripheral blood by magnetic bead separation were stimulated with peptide-loaded (10-7M ) autologous DCs. To enrich for T cells with suffi cient functional avidity, the immune responses were restimulated at day 10 with peptide loaded (10-7M ) autologous monocytes, followed by isolation of reactive T cells 36 hours later based on the expression of the activation marker CD137. MiHAspecifi c T cells were further enriched using peptide/MHC multimers and magnetic bead isolation. Clonal analysis of the isolated MiHA-specifi c T cells demonstrated the generation of MiHA-specifi c T cells showing signifi cant reactivity (cytokine production and/or cytotoxicity) against pepide-loaded target cells, but also against EBV-LCL, and normal and malignant hematopoietic cells of patient origin and no reactivity against cells of donor origin. This illustrates their specifi city for MiHA specifi cally expressed on cells of the patient and their relevant functional avidity allowing reactivity against target cells presenting physiological amounts of endogenously processed antigens. In conclusion, we here present a strategy to generate donor T cells directed against MiHA specifically expressed on (malignant) hematopoietic cells of the patient using an 'in-vitro vaccination' strategy. These T cells may be used to specifi cally induce GvL reactivity without coinciding GvHD in patients with relapsing or recurrent disease early after alloSCT.

body_text.text: In vitro generation of therapeutic haematopoiesis-directed donor T-cell products allowing broad clinical application in patients with diff erent haematological malignancies I. Jedema, C. Hoogstraten, M. van de Meent, T.S. Lam, J.H.F. Falkenburg Leiden University Medical Center (Leiden, NL) The induction of adequate anti-tumor responses after donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI) and allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT) is limited by inadequate induction of primary immune responses from the naïve donor repertoire, most likely due to the unavailability of suffi cient professional antigen presenting cells (APCs) of patient origin and the time required for immune responses to be induced and amplifi ed in-vivo. In this study, we developed a universal strategy for the in-vitro generation of donor T cells recognizing minor histocompatibility antigens (MiHA) specifi cally expressed on hematopoietic cells of patients with diff erent hematological malignancies. For this purpose, monocyte-derived dendritic cells (DCs) were generated from CD14 positive monocytes of patient origin and used as APCs for priming of naïve T cells from the HLA matched stem cell donor. Naive donor T cells were enriched by depletion of CD25+ regulatory T cells and memory T cells and stimulated with patient-derived DCs. After 10 days of co-culture the immune responses were restimulated with unmodifi ed monocytes of patient origin and patient hematopoiesis-reactive T cells were enriched 36 hours later using clinical grade CD137-biotin and anti-biotin beads (Miltenyi) . Clonal analysis of multiple T cell products demonstrated that the products contained oligoclonal populations of both CD4 and CD8 T cells that showed reactivity (cytokine production and/or cytotoxicity) against both myeloid cells and EBV-LCL of patient origin and no reactivity against cells of donor origin, illustrating their specifi city for MiHA expressed on patient hematopoietic cells of diff erent lineages. Although the repertoire of antigens expressed by monocyte-derived DCs was skewed towards antigens specifi cally expressed on hematopoietic cells, they will also include antigens with a more broad expression profi le on both hematopoietic and non-hematopoietic tissues. Therefore, potentially GvHD-inducing reactive T cells in the generated T cell products will be removed by stimulation of the T cells with patient-derived primary skin fi broblasts followed by depletion based on CD137 expression after stimulation. In conclusion, we here present a universal strategy for the generation of therapeutic hematopoiesis-directed donor T cell products allowing broad clinical application for the treatment of patients with diff erent hematological malignancies showing recurrence or persistence of their disease early after alloSCT.

body_text.text: Umbilical cord blood derived T-cells exhibit a higher degree of polyfunctionality and a higher proliferation potential after the addition of IL-7 to in vitro cultures S. Berglund, J. Gertow, I. Magalhaes, J. Mattsson, M. Uhlin Karolinska Institute/Karolinska Univ. Hospital (Stockholm, SE) Background: Umbilical cord blood transplantation (UCBT) is an increasingly used stem cell source for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. One disadvantage to UCBT is that treatment with donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI) is not possible. We wanted to explore if cultured lymphocytes from the UCB graft could off er an alternative to DLI in this setting, with focus on adding IL-7 to the protocol. Methods: T cells were positively selected with CD3+/CD28+ magnetic beads and cultured with IL-2 at escalating concentrations. In addition, IL-7 (20 ng/ml) was added to half of the cultures. After 7 days expansion the T cells were analyzed by fl ow cytometry to determine phenotype, and assess apoptosis and cytokine production. The statistical analysis was performed with Wilcoxon's matched pairs signed rank test. Results: There was a strong trend (p=0.063, n = 5) toward greater proliferation in cultures to which IL-7 had been added. The greatest proliferation was seen in T cells cultured with 100 IU IL-2/ml and IL-7. The CD4+/CD8+ T cell ratio was higher with IL-7 and high dose IL-2 (p = 0.031) compared to only high dose IL-2. A lower percentage of central memory T cells (CD45RO+ CCR7+) was seen in conditions with IL-7 and high dose IU IL-2 compared to only IL-2 (p = 0.016). In CD4+ T cells, this was the case for both high dose IL-2 (p = 0.008) and low dose IL-2 (p = 0.019). There was a trend towards less cell death (defined as % of AnnexinV+ 7-AAD+) with IL-7 and low dose IL-2 (p = 0.079). We assessed the intracellular production of IL-2, TNF-α, IFN-γ and CD107a after culture. There was more polyfunctional T cells (positive for three or four factors) in cells cultured with IL-7 (p = 0.049). In CD4+ cells the percentage of cells producing TNF-α was significantly higher in cultures with only IL-2, and there were significantly more cells producing IFN-γ in the culture conditions containing IL-7. Conclusion: There seem to be a proliferation advantage in adding IL-7 to a lower dose of IL-2. Addition of IL-7 might also have an impact on the diff erentiation status of the cells. T cells cultured in IL-7 had more polyfunctional traits, possibly increasing the activity of a putative future DLI.

body_text.text: Signifi cance of T-regulatory cells CD4+CD25+CD127low for the monitoring and treatment of graft-versus-host disease in paediatric patients after allogeneic stem cell transplantation E. Pristanskova (1) , K. Kirgizov (1) , S. Bykovskaya (2) , V. Muhin (2) , E. Skorobogatova (1) (1) The Russian Children's Research Hospital (Moscow, RU) ; (2) The Russian National Research Medical University named after N.I. Pirogov (Moscow, RU) Treatment of severe steroid-refractory "Graft versus host" disease (GvHD) is one of the signifi cant problems now. T-regulatory cells CD4+CD25+CD127low (T-regs) play the signifi cant role in the maintenance of the immunological tolerance. Purpose: To evaluate the role and signifi cance of T-regs for the recipients of Allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (Allo-HSCT). Patients and methods: Method of the native T-regs cultivation, invented by our group, allows to growth cells ex-vivo. Number of T-regs can be increased in more than 100 times in 7-10 days. This survey includes 22 patients after Allo-HSCT. Subpopulation of the lymphocytes was assessed in transplant source (TS) and in peripheral blood (PB) on days +30, +60, +90. Ex-vivo cultivated T-regs subcutaneous (SC) injection was performed for 5 patients with steroid-refractory GvHD in dose 5-7 X 106/kg 1-2 times per months. Mean number of SC injections -3 (2) (3) (4) . Results: T-regs level assessment in the TS showed the absence of the correlation between the number of T-regs and the risk of GvHD. Investigation of the number T-regs and CD4/CD8 ration in the PB at the moment of engraftment and the T-regs level in PB on days +30, +60, +90 showed the absence of correlation of the Tregs level and clinical signifi cance of GvHD. Possibly, the reason of absence of this correlation can be corresponded with prolonged immunosuppression. Signifi cant clinical improvement in GvHD and subpopulation characteristics (increasing of T-regs level (%) and CD4/CD8 ratio) was achieved at the patients who received ex-vivo cultivated T-regs. Some of the patients showed decreasing of absolute lymphocytes count connected with the corresponding immunosuppression, transplant hypofunction and CMV-associated therapy. There were no any side eff ects after the T-regs SC injection. Four patients are alive now (one patient died, cause of death -CMV disease). Observation period: 3-55 months. Patients with oncological diseases (n=2) is free from relapse now. Conclusion: T-regs level monitoring in TS and in the PB during the early post-transplant period with aim of GvHD risk assessment isn't informative and reasonable. Including of the injections of exvivo cultivated cells to the scheme of the steroid-refractory GvHD treatment is the perspective way of improvement of the GvHD therapy. T-regs infusions didn't show any side eff ects.

body_text.text: Donor lymphocyte infusions (DLI) are applied after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) of hematological malignancies against an impending relapse. DLI of haploidentical natural killer (NK) cells represent a novel strategy to enhance the graft-versustumor eff ect of HSCT in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and multiple myeloma (MM). Initial clinical studies by our institution and others indicated that cell dose and resting state of freshly isolated NK cells may limit the anti-tumor eff ect of NK-DLI in vivo. Here we describe the in vitro expansion of NK cells under good manufacturing practice (GMP) conditions for preemptive mega dose NK cell infusions and follow-up of cytokine-activated NK cells in vivo. NK cells were purifi ed from unstimulated leukaphereses (mean: 12.5L, n=4) by T cell depletion and subsequent NK cell selection using CliniMACS. Starting from 180 x 10e8 total nucleated cells, 7.2 x 10e8 NK cells were obtained with a purity of 95.8% and a residual T cell contamination of 1.8 x 10e5 cells corresponding to a T cell depletion effi cacy of 5.22 log. Purifi ed NK cells were expanded for 19 days in air-permeable bags in up to 13.4L medium containing human serum, IL-2, IL-15, anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody and irradiated autologous feeder cells. After 19 days NK cell numbers increased 50. 3-fold (range 22 to 75-fold) to 197 x 10e8 cells with a viability of 72% and with a minimal T cell contamination of 0.023%. The NK cell products were divided and cryopreserved as 3-8 (mean: 5.25 ) escalating doses ranging from 1.3 x 10e6 to 1.0 x 10e8 cells/kg body weight. Of GMP-expanded NK cells we determined the phenotype, size of alloreactive cell subsets and cytolytic activity of against K562 cells. Fourteen NK-DLIs were given to two patients and well tolerated without any acute adverse eff ects. The faith of infused NK cells was monitored by FACS analysis of discriminative donor-specifi c HLA molecules and by quantitative real-time PCR of donor-specifi c DNA loci in one MM patient treated with autologous HSCT and haploidentical NK cells. After all NK-DLIs with maximal cell dose, we detected NK cells of donor origin at one and 20 hours post infusion (1.87% and 0.12% of purifi ed NK cells, respectively) indicating prolonged survival of cytokine-activated NK cells in the recipient's blood circulation. These results demonstrate the feasibility of large-scale expansion under GMP conditions and multiple mega dose infusions of human NK cells as immunotherapy after HSCT for malignant disease.

Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (MSC) can be expanded in vitro to facilitate cellular therapies utilising the immunosuppressive activity of MSC when exposed to an acute infl ammatory environment. Extensive data has accrued in acute graft versus host disease (GvHD) where effi cacy in the acute setting is clearly demonstrated in a sub-set of patients, but to date a large scale clinical trial has yet to be reported. MSC are also reported to have effi cacy in applications such as infl ammatory bowel disease and solid organ transplant rejection. We have been manufacturing MSC since 2006 under ever more stringent good manufacturing practice (GMP) and regulatory requirements. MSC are Advanced Therapeutic Medicinal Products and we hold both a relevant Investigational Medicinal Products license and a Specials license to permit manufacture of MSC for clinical trials or as an unlicensed drug under prescription for individual need. We have given MSC mainly in acute GvHD and an abstract detailing the clinical outcomes has been submitted, but we have also provided cells for Crohn's Disease, hyperimmunity, acquired immune haemolytic anaemia and organ transplant rejection. Production of MSC utilises multi-level tissue culture stacks (636cm2/level). Foetal bovine serum (FBS) has been replaced by human platelet lysate (PL). In adult donors, PL (n=33) did not signifi cantly increase yield (4.8 ± 3 .9 x 10 6 /level vs 8.9 ± 9.7 x 10 6 /level, p=0.35) compared with FBS (n=10) but decreased time to harvest (44.1 ± 10days vs 23.9 ± 10.9 days (p=0.001)). Yield varies widely between individuals and declines with donor age, most marked in donors <10y.o or >50y.o. We cryopreserve pooled seed stocks from primary cultures and establish multiple identical fi rst passage (P1) cultures for clinical use. P1 culture yield is donor dependent (mean yield for two 5 years old donors is 15.2 vs 37.0 x 10 6 /level, n=23 vs 24, p=0.001) but the range of yields per pooled stock (representative donor 13.8-53.8 x 10 6 /level, mean 37.0) indicates that multiple factors are involved. It is likely that MSC manufacture will ultimately reach industrial scale. Until such time, we expect production effi ciency in small centres to continue to evolve with small scale automated systems, hypoxia and commercially-driven introduction of serum-free medias and recombinant growth factors all key factors. S82 6 of the 10 patients treated with fresh MSC also received freezethawed MSC at another time. Because of this, response has been evaluated per individual infusion, and we have refrained from comparing survival. 108 tissue samples from 15 of the patients have been analysed for engraftment using PCR for MSC donor DNA. A total of 72 MSC infusions, 10 from fresh MSC and 62 freezethawed, were evaluated regarding clinical response. 22 infusions, of which 6 were of fresh MSC, were evaluated regarding engraftment. Results: The clinical response to fresh MSC was 70% responders, similar to freeze-thawed MSC (66%). MSC used fresh were to a higher degree HLA-matched (70% vs 15% partial or total HLAmatch) and of a lower average passage (median passage 2 vs 3), which could potentially infl uence the outcome in favour of the fresh MSC. For engraftment, no diff erence could be seen. Of fresh MSC, 50% (3/6) could be found in one or more sampled tissue, in comparison to 54% (7/13) of frozen MSC. Distribution was about the same with exception of the lungs, where only frozen MSC could be found. Discussion: In evaluating clinical response and engraftment of MSC, no diff erence could be found between fresh or frozen MSC. This analysis is limited by the small number of infusions of fresh MSC, a power calculation shows that we would only detect a difference in eff ect size of about 50% and we might miss a clinically signifi cant diff erence. As other factors possibly associated with better clinical response were more common in the fresh infusions we can at least conclude that no dramatic diff erence in favour of fresh MSC was evident from our data.

Epstein-Barr virus-specifi c cytotoxic T-lymphocyte production for adoptive cellular immunotherapy Y. Wang, L. Aissi-Rothe, J. Stoltz, V. Decot, D. Bensoussan CHU de Nancy (Nancy, FR) Objectives: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection represents one of the major causes of morbidity following haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and can turn into post transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) associated with a high mortality rate although the use of targeted therapy, Rituximab. Adoptive cellular Immunotherapy using EBV-Lymphoblastoid Cell Lines (LCL) as stimulating antigen has proven effi ciency as it restored specifi c immunity. However, EBV presents a lot of immunodominant antigens and the challenge to develop a fast, clinical grade immunotherapy relies on the defi nition of a GMP universal stimulating antigen. Methods: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from 6 donors presenting a cellular immune response against EBV were stimulated with an optimal EBV antigen association including an EBNA-3 peptide pool for 9 hours and the immunomagnetic selection based on IFN-γ secretion was performed. After selection, cells were expanded within 14 days and functional assays were carried out with the expanded cells. Results: After immunoselection, a mean of 0.53 ± 0.25×10 6 cells were recovered consisting in a mean of 24.77 ± 18.01% CD4+ secreting IFN-γ and 51.42 ± 26.92% of CD8+ secreting IFN-γ. The ability of expanded EBV-specifi c T cells to secrete IFN-γ and to proliferate after restimulation with EBV antigen was confi rmed. A specifi c lysis was observed against autologous target cells pulsed with EBV peptide pools (57.6 ± 11 .5%) and interestingly against autologous EBV-LCL (18.3 ± 7.3%). A decrease of 94.7 % in allogeneic reaction against third-party donor mononuclear cells with EBV-specifi c T cells compared with the PBMC before selection was observed. Conclusions: Our results brought out that an association of peptide pools including EBNA-3 is mandatory to generate EBVspecifi c T cells harboring a good specifi c cytotoxicity and a lack of alloreactivity.

body_text.text: Generation of bi-specifi c cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTL) against Epstein-Barr virus and adenovirus Y. Wang, L. Fievet, J.-F. Stoltz, V. Decot, D. Bensoussan CHU de Nancy (Nancy, FR) Objectives: Human Adenovirus (ADV) and Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) infections or associated diseases are serious complications following allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantations which are responsible for signifi cant morbidity and mortality. Although available anti-viral drugs as cidofovir (ADV) and Rituximab (EBV), their effi ciency is impaired in absence of specifi c immune reconstitution and toxicity remains a concern. Furthermore, adoptive cellular immunotherapy with ADV or EBV cytotoxic T cells (CTL) has proven safety of use and effi ciency as it restored specifi c immunity. The concern is now to develop such an immunotherapy against the 2 viruses simultaneously. We focused on the generation of anti-ADV/ EBV bi-specifi c T cells and the comparison with the mono-specifi c T cells in respect of enrichment, effi ciency and toxicity. Such a comparative study was only reported once (Khanna et al, 2011) . Methods: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from 3 donors presenting a cellular immune response against ADV and EBV were stimulated with ADV or EBV antigens or both. Immunomagnetic selection based on IFN-γ secretion was performed and functional assays were carried out with the expanded cells. Results: After immunoselection, a mean of 62.3±18.08%, 39.9 ± 25.54% and 60.6 ± 20.25% CD4+ secreting IFN-γ and 33. 1 ± 20.46%; 26.3 ± 32.29% and 60.7 ± 20 .55% of CD8+ secreting IFN-γ were recovered for ADV-CTL, EBV-CTL and ADV/EBV-CTL, respectively. Virus-specifi c T cells were expanded in vitro and their ability to secrete IFN-γ and to proliferate after restimulation with virus antigens was confi rmed. A specifi c lysis for EBV-CTL and ADV/ EBV-CTL was observed against autologous target cells pulsed with EBV peptide pools (59. 3 ± 22.5% and 43.7 ± 32.6, respectively) and a lower lysis for ADV-CTL and ADV/EBV-CTL against autologous target cells loaded with PepT-ADV (31.0 ± 4.0% and 14.0 ± 6.1, respectively). body_text.text: Aim and Methods: The aim of our study was to generate DC/DCleu ex vivo from AML-pts in active stages of the disease from mononuclear cells ('MNC-DC' , n=42), heparinised whole blood samples ('WB-DC' , n=12) using standardized DC-generating protocols (MCM-MIMIC ('MCM'), Picibanil ('Pici'), Calciumionophore ('Ca') or IFNα ('IFN' , containing IFNα, GM-CSF and TNFα) or using combinations of 1-3 selected cytokines, antibiotics, bacterial lysates, or other clinically approved response-modifi ers in 9 minimalized DC-cocktails ('WB-mini-cock-DC' , n=11) and to study the role of IFNα. Moreover the infl uence of 'IFN'-DC' on the antileukemic functionality of T-cells was studied and data correlated with the clinical response to immunotherapy (SCT/DLI). Results: 1.Generation of DC:a) From 'MNC-DC' DC/DCleu could be successfully generated (>10%DC and >5% DCleu in the total cell fraction) with MCM-mimic (MCM, 31% of cases), Picibanil (Pici, 34%), Calcium-ionophore (Ca, 21%) and IFNα (IFN, 26%). b) From 'WB-DC' DC/DCleu could be successfully generated with 'MCM' (33% of cases), 'Pici' (20%), 'Ca' (25%) and 'IFN' (38%). c) Using 'WBmini-cock-DC' DC/DCleu could be successfully generated with cocktails containing diff erent combinations of response-modifi ers (20-50% of cases), but never, if IFNα was added to the cultures. None of the used DC-methods or cocktails induced blast proliferation. 2. Antileukemic functionality: T-cells stimulated with 'MNC-DC' using 'IFN' compared to 'Pici' or 'MCM' in 4 cases showed comparable lytic activity in the two settings (3 of 4 cases lytic activity achieved). Detailed data of DC-proportions in the context of functionality, response to immunotherapy and in the context of cytokine release will be presented. Conclusion: DC/DCleu can be generated regularily from blastcontaining MNC ('MNC-DC)' , from whole blood ('WB-DC') using standard DC-methods -including 'IFN'-methods. Heshmati Cochin Hospital (Paris, FR) Background: Cochin is a public University Hospital (AP-HP, Paris) with a therapeutic apheresis activity focused on extracorporeal photo-chemotherapy (ECP); 428 in 2011, and 438 other therapeutic apheresis procedures. 3 Cobe Spectra and 1 Optia devices (Terumo BCT) are currently used. Alcala Muñoz (1) (1)University Hospital of Jaen (Jaen, ES); (2) Blood Transfusion Center of Jaen (Jaen, ES) Introduction: Darbepoetin alfa (Aranesp ®) is an erithropoyesis stimulating agent (ESA) approved for the treatment of anaemia asocciated with chemotherapy in cancer patients.

Patients diagnosed of hematologic malignancy undergoing Autologous Stem cell Transplant (ASCT) show an anaemic syndrome due to conditioning treatment prior to infusion of hematopoietic progenitors. In our centre, we have administered through stipulated protocols ESA agents from day +1, dosing 300 μ g once every two weeks, regardless of the individual characteristics of each patient, to 14 months ago. Since then, we have not used this universal strategy, reserving this drug for specifi c cases. Objective: Compare transfusional requirements between two cohorts of patients undergoing ASCT, those who have received ESA agents versus Non-ESA agents and check the eff ectiveness of their use. Patients and method: 86 consecutive patients under ASCT have been performed in our center, 62 patients have received ESA agents (from Jan 2008 to Oct 2011), and 34 belong to Non-ESA group (from Nov 2011 to Jul 2012 . The characteristics of both groups are shown in Table 1 . There are no signifi cant diff erences between both groups according to sex, age, diagnosis and number of cells infused. Transfusion criteria was given by the discretion of Consultant Haematologist managing the patient. We have analyzed the period from day +1 to day +100.

S86 Results: For statistical analysis we used the test U of Mann-Whitney. There are no signifi cant diff erences (p = 0.065) in the number of transfusions received between the group who has received ESA on day +1 and those who have not received throughout the whole study period. It has also been analyzed platelet concentrates that have required in both groups, with no signifi cant diff erences (p = 0.387) between them. Conclusions: If we use the number of transfusions as a direct parameter of the use of ESA over red cell engraftment in patients undergoing ASCT, we can confi rm that its use does not provide any advantage as it does not decrease the number of transfusions. We also analyzed platelet transfusion as possible indirect parameter of the ESA eff ect over another series and bone marrow microenviroment. According to our analysis, its administration is not benefi cial as there are no diff erences between both groups. Therefore, we believe that the use of ESA in patients undergoing ASCT, may have a role in selected patients with poor quality of life or poor tolerance to anemic syndrome, but this should not be used universally.

The 'Swiss Army Knife' of leukoapheresis: granulocyte collection and leukodepletion with the electronic-interfacecontrolled Spectra Optia IDL apheresis device M. Schulz, H. Bialleck, K. Thorausch, B. Luxembourg, E. Seifried, H. Bonig German Red Cross Blood Service Baden-Württemberg-Hessen (Frankfurt, DE) Introduction: The apheresis device Spectra Optia (SO) which features continuous electronic interface monitoring was introduced to replace COBE Spectra (CS). Successively, protocols were released for plasma/erythrocyte exchange followed by a mononuclear cell (MNC) protocol for autologous/allogeneic "stem cell" apheresis and unstimulated MNC collections (e.g. donor lymphocyte infusions, extracorporeal photopheresis). Safety/effi cacy of the device for these indications were reported. Most recently, by introducing the SO-IDL platform, the portfolio was extended to leukocyte depletions and granulocyte collections. Performance data for these protocols are reported. Methods: SO-IDL diff ers from SO-MNC by use of a diff erent (exchangeable) fi ller, to accommodate the more voluminous IDL tubing set, and by depositing the product directly in the collection bag. For leukodepletions, we retrospectively analyzed data from 23 procedures in de-novo AML patients with symptomatic hyperleukocytosis performed between 6/2011 and 7/2012, 8 with SO-IDL and 15 with CS-MNC. For granulocyte collections, we compared outcomes from 70 aphereses, performed between 10/2011 and 9/2012, 35 each with CS-PMN and SO-IDL. Results: Epidemiology and blood counts of leukodepletion patients were typical for AML patients with hyperleukocytosis. Aphereses were tolerated without complications with both systems. Blasts were depleted with a mean collection effi ciency (CE2) of ca. 50% with both systems. An inverse correlation between blast count and CE2 was noted. Platelet attrition was modest (30%), erythrocyte loss minimal. Leukodepletion outcomes did not diff er in any relevant manner between the two technologies. Volunteer granulocyte donors received a single dose of G-CSF to achieve a neutrophilia of 26/nL (mean) and were randomly assigned to apheresis with SO-IDL or CS-PMN. High molecular weight hydroxyl ethyl starch was used as sedimentation enhancer. The procedure was well tolerated. Apheresis processing of 6.5-7 L of blood yielded a dose of 1x10E10 granulocytes (one therapeutic dose as per German transfusion guidelines) in 69/70 donors, granulocyte dose/product by the two apheresis systems was indistinguishable (3.4 vs. 3 .6x10E10, mean for SO-IDL and CS-PMN, respectively); some minor, clinically likely irrelevant diff erences in apheresis outcomes were observed. Conclusion: Our data indicate the suitability of the IDL-based apheresis protocols "leukodepletion" and "PMN" for clinical usage.

body_text.text: Mesenchymal stromal cells protect from complement activation in graft-versus-host disease A. J. Innes, B. Uttenthal, S. Marley, A. Hall, M. Botto, M. Pickering, F. Dazzi Imperial College London (London, GB) Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC) have shown promise as a therapeutic strategy in patients with severe refractory graft-versushost disease (GvHD) although their exact mechanism remains elusive. The role of complement activation in GvHD has previously been described, and recent in vitro data suggests that MSC may be capable of inhibiting complement activation by constitutively secreting complement inhibitors (such as factor H). Our aim was to investigate the eff ects of infused MSC on complement activation in patients receiving allogeneic MSC for steroidresistant GvHD. We investigated complement levels in 14 consecutive patients receiving allogeneic MSC for steroid-resistant acute (n=7) or chronic (n=7) GvHD. Serum C3, C4, factor H and factor I levels were measured immediately before and 30 minutes, 7 days and 28 days after the infusion. MSC were derived from third-party healthy donors and were expanded in human platelet lysate. Grading of GvHD was measured according to established Glucksberg and NCI criteria, and response was defi ned as a reduction by one grade or more of GvHD in at least 1 involved organ. All patients gave informed consent and the study was approved by the local ethics committee. Serum C3 and C4 levels 30 minutes after infusion of MSC remained unchanged (median C3 before infusion = 1.01 g/l, post infusion = 0.90 g/l, p=0.60; median C4 before infusion = 0.23 g/l, post-infusion = 0.24 g/l, p=0.89), suggesting no signifi cant complement activation. At day 7 following infusion both C3 and C4 levels had increased, to 1.24 g/l (p=0.07) and 0.28 g/l (p=0.03) respectively. This protection from complement activation was sustained until at least day 28, when C3 levels reached 1.26 g/l (p=0.007) and C4 0.27 g/l (p=0.03). In patients responding to MSCs (n=7) a significant rise in factor I levels was observed 30 minutes after infusion of MSCs (median rise of 16 units (p=0.04)) compared to a fall in non-responders (median fall of 47 units (p=0.09). This pattern persisted at day 7, although was less marked and did not achieve signifi cance. A similar pattern of rising levels in responders and falling in non-responders was observed in factor H, but this did not attain statistical signifi cance. Our data supports the notion that allogeneic MSC suppress complement activation by secreting complement inhibiting factors. Patients exhibiting such a profi le are more likely to respond to MSC. Increasingly sensitive methods of minimal residual disease detection leading to earlier identifi cation of relapse and registry data suggesting that 16-40% of HSCT recipients subsequently require DLI makes the safety of DLI from HLA-mismatched donors is an increasingly pertinent question. To address this issue we retrospectively performed high resolution HLA typing (HLA-A, B, C, DR and DQ) on stored genomic DNA samples of 58 consecutive patients receiving DLI for the management of relapse or mixed chimerism at our institution between December 1995 and August 2010. All patients received unrelated donor transplants following uniform alemtuzumab-based myeloablative, conditioning for leukaemia (CML n=56, AML n=1, ALL n=2). DLI was administered using an established escalating-dose regimen. The primary endpoint was acute Graft-versus-Host Disease (GvHD) within 100 days of DLI. Secondary endpoints were incidence of chronic GvHD, probability of remission and overall survival (OS). Thirty patients were fully matched at all 10 loci (MUD), while mismatches (MMUD) were identifi ed in 28 patients (HLA-A n=3, HLA-B n=4, HLA-C n=15, HLA-DR n= 8, HLA-DQ n=12). Mismatches were present at 1, 2 or 3 loci in 18, 6 and 4 patients respectively. The groups were comparable with regard to baseline and transplant demographics. The rates of grade II-IV aGvHD following DLI were low and comparable in both groups (17.2% in MUD and 23.1% in MMUD, p=0.59) . Similarly we found no signifi cant diff erences in the incidence of cGvHD (34% in MUD vs 42% in MMUD, p=0.51), although there was a trend towards more severe cGvHD in the MMUD recipients (27% MMUD vs 10% MUD, p=0.09). The probability of remission at 3 years was similar in both groups (62.1% vs 63.9% in MUD and MMUD respectively, p=0.89), as was the 5 year OS (89.8% vs 77.7% in MUD and MMUD respectively (p=0.22) ). The only identifi ed predictor of inferior survival was time from HSCT to DLI of less than 9 months (3yr OS, 33.3% vs 93.3%, p<0.01). Our data suggests that escalating-dose DLI can safely be given to mismatched transplant recipients following alemtuzumab-based myeloablative allogeneic stem cell transplantation without a signifi cant impact on GvHD, disease response or OS.

body_text.text: High rate of false-positive CMV screening results in healthy donors: implications for adequate stem cell donor selection B. Eiz-Vesper, C. Sukdolak, L. Goudeva, W. Puppe, R. Blasczyk, H. Heuft Hannover Medical School (Hannover, DE) Herpesviruses such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) are common and associated with increased morbidity and mortality after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) . CMV serostatus of donor and recipient infl uence the risk of recurrent CMV reactivation post HSCT. For CMV screening of stem cell donors and recipients the Abbott Architect chemiluminescent microparticle CMV-IgG immunoassay (Abbott Diagnostic Division, London, UK) is used. To get more insight into the CMV-specifi c memory T-cell repertoire, we analyzed CMV-specifi c T-cell responses using an IFN-γ ELISpot assay in 204 healthy donors. According to the initial CMV screening, 143 (71%) of the enrolled donors were considered CMV-seropositive and 61 (29%) CMV-seronegative. None of the samples of CMV-seronegative donors yielded positive ELISpot results after short overnight stimulation; but also 19/143 seropositive samples were found not reacting to either pp65 or IE-1 peptides. To validate the ELISpot and exclude false-positive CMV screening results, we performed confi rmatory serology testing by Western Blot (WB; recomBlot CMV IgG/IgM). WB testing was prospectively performed at the time of the baseline T-cell assay and at 4 weeks and 3 months of follow-up. The 19/143 ELISpot nonresponders were also non-reactive in the WB indicating a 13% rate of false-positive screening results. Additional confi rmatory WB testing was done retrospectively using 191 look back samples with a positive CMV screening result from whole blood or apheresis donations between 2006 and 2010. All donors without CMV WB-confi rmation were reevaluated with follow-up samples from further donations. For 128/191 (67%) donors the initial CMV screening result was confi rmed, 7 were indeterminate, 11 remained unclear because of missing follow-up donations, and 45 (23.6%) were defi nitely CMV seronegative. Conventional CMV screening is associated with a signifi cant rate (13-23% depending on the confi rmation strategy) of false positive results. If the CMV status of a specifi c HSC donor is decisive for adequate donor selection, confi rmatory serological testing or evaluation of T-cell reactivity to virus-specifi c antigens is required.

Mytilineos (1) (1)University of Ulm (Ulm, DE) ; (2) ZKRD -Zentrales Knochenmarkspender-Register für Deutschland (Ulm, DE) Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) has been established as a potentially curative therapy for hematologic malignancies or non-malignant immunologic disorders. Matching for HLA class I and II alleles is an important criterion for outcome of HSCT, in particular regarding non-related allogeneic transplantation. For patients with rare HLA-haplotypes mismatched donors often need to be taken into consideration. The HistoCheck (HS) algorithm provides a scoring value for comparison of HLA-disparities. This score is based on structural and functional diff erences between two mismatched HLA alleles. We validated the prognostic signifi cance of this algorithm by assigning HS-scores to 800 patients with single HLA-mismatched donors (based on high resolution HLA-A,-B,-C,-DRB1,-DQB1 typing). Assigned score values showed a bipolar clustering and therefore the patients were grouped into those with low and high scores, separated by the median value for the entire cohort (11.98, range 1.03-35.77). Overall survival (OS), disease free survival (DFS), relapse incidence (RI), and treatment related mortality (TRM) were assessed using Kaplan-Meier analysis, competing risks regression and extended Cox regression models. For any mismatch (i) and in subanalyses for HLA-Class I (ii) or HLA-Class II (iii) mismatches only, univariate analysis showed no eff ect of HS on OS ((i) p=0.396, (ii) p=0.964, (iii) p=0.186), DFS ((i) p=0.502, (ii) p=0.926, (iii) p=0.218), TRM ((i) 30.9% vs. 27.5%, p=0.402, (ii) 32.1% vs. 28.6%, p=0.401, (iii) 27.6% vs. 14.7%, p=0.303), and RI ((i) 31.7% vs. 32.4%, p=0.553, (ii) 29.2% vs. 32.0%, p=0.420. (iii) 39.7% vs. 37.0%, p=0.660). Multivariate Analysis also did not reveal any signifi cant eff ect of HS assignment on OS ((i) CI 0.90-1.32, p=0.390, (ii) CI 0.82-1.25, p=0.931, (iii) 0.81-2.48, P=0.217), DFS ((i) CI 0. p=0.477, p=0.923, p=0.129) , TRM ((i) CI 0.66-1.14, p=0.310, (ii) CI 0. p=0.290, p=0.489) , and RI ((i) 0.91-1.30, p=0.340, (ii) CI 0.97-1.66, p=0.420, (iii) CI 0.67- 1.87, p=0.660) . No diff erences in engraftment rates were seen for transplantations with low or high HS values (p=0.115). Furthermore, consideration of the HS value as a continuous variable in multivariate analysis also did not have any impact on survival outcomes. We conclude that HS did not provide any clinically relevant prognostic value and therefore its use in the HSCT donor selection process is questionable. Donor characteristics as pre-transplant predictive factors of long-term outcomes after allogeneic peripheral blood stem cell transplantation from HLA-matched related and unrelated donors in patients with haematologic malignancies S. Servais, R. Porcher, A. Xhaard, M. Robin, E. Masson, J. Larghero, P. Ribaud, S. Abbes, N. Dhedin, G. Socie, R. Peff ault de Latour Saint-Louis Hospital (Paris, FR) Optimal strategy for donor selection is still controversial. We evaluated the impact of donor type vs. matched related (MRD)) and other donor traits on long term outcomes of patients with hematologic malignancies after peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT). Methods: We analyzed outcome of 442 consecutive patients with hematologic malignancies who were treated with PBSCT either from MUD (n= 164) or MRD (n=278) from 01/2000 to 12/2010 at our center. Two-third of patients underwent PBSCT following reduced intensity conditioning. Antithymocyte globulin was used for 19% of patients. MUD and MRD PBSCT were balanced for patient age, disease risk and conditioning. Median donor age was 40 years. We assessed the impact of donor type, age, gender, CMV and ABO status on outcomes. As the upper age limit for voluntary stem cells donation was 60 years, we completed our analysis by performing 3 groups according to donor type and age (MUD, MRD<60y and MRD≥60y). Thirty-six patients were transplanted with MRD≥60y. Results: Median follow up was 36 months and 25% of patients had a follow up of at least 60 months. The cumulative incidence at 5 years (5y-CIf ) of chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) was 58%. In multivariate analysis, sex mismatch (female donor for male recipient) increased risk of cGVHD (hazard ratio (HR): 1.41, P=.02). The 5y-CIf of relapse was 34% and was higher with MRD than MUD (39% vs. 24%, P=.038). In multivariate analysis, only MRD≥60y resulted in signifi cant higher risk of relapse than MUD (HR: 2.46, P=.006) while MRD<60y had similar risk. The 5 year non relapse mortality (NRM) was 26%. MUD vs. MRD was associated with higher NRM (HR: 1.84, P=.005). The 5 year overall survival (OS) was 46% and was similar with MUD and MRD. MRD≥60y appeared to have notable low 5y-OS (6%, ±6%). In multivariate analysis, transplantation from MRD≥60y was associated with higher risk of late (≥18 months) mortality (HR: 4.36, P=.007) than MUD (Fig. 1) . Conclusion: Donor/recipient gender parity, donor type and age appeared as signifi cant predictive factors of long term outcomes after HLA-matched PBSCT. Female donor for male recipient was associated with higher risk of cGVHD. MUD provided higher NRM but better disease control and similar OS than MRD. We observed notable poor outcome for patients transplanted with MRD≥60y. One may thus question PBSCT with old MRD when a younger MUD is available.
