We evaluated the impact of the diff erent matching variables in addition to cellularity and other disease and patient characteristics on single(s) and double (d) umbilical cord blood transplantation (UCBT) outcomes in pediatric and adult patients between 1998 and 2011. There were 53 adults (37 dUCBT and 16 sUCBT) with a median age of 36 years (18-64) and 48 children (3 dUCBT and 45 sUCBT) with a median age of 2 years (0-14) and a median follow-up of surviving patients of 24 months . The median number of pre-freezing and post-thawing cells was for 1) TNC: 3.3x10 7 /kg (1.9-5.1) and 2.6x10 7 (1.5-4.6) in adults; 1.6x10 7 (0.5-4) and 1.18x10 7 (0.5-3) in children; 2) CD34: 1.89x10 5 (0.57-4.2 ) and 1.55x10 5 (0.5-4.1) in adults; 4x10 5 (0. 6-19.3 ) and 2.8x10 5 (0.26-19) in children with a respective cells viability of 54% and 58%. We built a scoring scale that took into account the matching variables (sex, ABO and HLA) between UCB units and recipient and between UCB units each other in case of dUCBT. The median score was 3.8 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) in adults and 3 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) in children; the detailed score calculation method will be communicated later. The multivariate analysis done separately in adults and children found a positive impact of infused CD34 ≥1.55x10 5 on neutrophiles recovery in adults [HR=2. 1 (1.16-3.8) , p=0.015] and infused CD34 ≥2.8x10 5 on neutrophiles and platelets recovery [HR=2. 5 (1.2-5) , p=0.007 and HR= 4.4 (1.6-11.6 ), p=0.002 respectively] in children; no signifi cant factor was observed on the cumulative incidence of acute GVHD≥ grade II. In addition, we showed a signifi cant negative impact of matching score > 3.8 on adults overall survival (OS) with a 3 years probability of 19% vs. 57% (38-84) for those with score ≤3.8 [HR=3.9 (1.5-9.8), p=0.003]. Similarly, score >3.8 had a signifi cant negative impact also on progression-free survival (PFS) only in adults with a 3 years probability of 13% vs. 21% for patients with a score p=0.04] . No signifi cant factor was found to infl uence transplant related mortality. In conclusion, cell dose remains a signifi cant impacting factor on short term transplantation outcome while the matching score appears to have a strong impact on adult long term outcomes mainly OS and PFS. These very promising results lead us to evaluate this score in larger number of patients for its validation and in order to include it in the UCB unit choice either in simple or double UCBT.

Bone marrow donor recruitment in students at Poitiers University: results of a survey and perspectives for development of bone marrow donation by young people L. Turcan (1) , J. Tourenne (1) , S. For the donors >16 y (n=29) and ≤16 y (n=63), the median NC count [0,17 x10 8 /ml (0,09 x10 8 /ml -0,72 x10 8 /ml)vs 0,23 x10 8 /ml (0,12 x10 8 /ml -0,51 x10 8 /ml); p<0,05)], CD34 count [0,14 x10 6 /ml (0,03 x10 6 /ml-1,01 x10 6 /ml) vs 0,40 x10 6 / ml (0,09 x10 6 /ml-1,46 x10 6 /ml);p<0,01] and CD34/NC [0,74(0, 34-4,19) vs 1,68(0,54-4,81) ; (p<0,01)] were signifi cantly lower in the older donor group. The single nucleotide polymorphisms of SDF-1 and CXCR4 and the outcome of haematopoietic stem cells mobilization in healthy donors T. Wang (1) , L. Wu (2) , K. Yang (3) , S. Chen (1) , S. Yang (1) , S. Chu (1) , Y. Wu (1) , R. Kao (1) (

Introduction: Recently, mobilized peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) had replaced bone marrow aspiration as the main source of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Infusion of suffi cient stem cells is the most important factor for reconstruction of hematopoietic system next to HLA matching. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) is now the predominant mobilizing agent used for HSCT. However, the number of CD34+ stem cells mobilized in response to G-CSF varies signifi cantly. The aim of this study was focus on the impact of genetic variation in hematopoietic stem cell mobilization by G-CSF. We compared the single-nucleotide polymorphisms of SDF1 and CXCR4 in healthy volunteer stem cell donors. Materials and Methods: This study was nested within a longitudinal cohort of 976 healthy donors who had mobilized by G-CSF for allogeneic PBSC donation via Buddhist Tzu-Chi Stem Cell Center from September 2006 to the end of December 2010. The G-CSF was given subcutaneously on the basis of 10ug/kg per day for 5 consecutive days. The outcome of mobilization was defi ned as the circulating CD34+ cells in peripheral blood after 5 days infection of G-CSF. A retrospective review of clinical records of donors, including donor gender, age, body height/weight, blood tests and circulating CD34+ cells in peripheral blood post GCSF injection was performed. The allele frequencies of the SNPs for SDF-1 and CXCR4, were compared between donors had high and low circulating CD34+ cells in peripheral blood. Results: Totally, 134 pairs of good and poor mobilized donors were included from this longitudinal cohort. The good and poor mobilized donors were selected from the top and bottom 10% CD34+ cell counts in each groups stratifi ed by donor age, body weight and gender. The allele frequencies of 6 SNPs in SDF1 (rs754618, rs2839693, rs266085, rs2297630, rs1801157, rs1065297) and 2 SNPs in CXCR4 (rs16832740, rs12691874) were tested. None of these SNPs showed signifi cant diff erence in allele frequency between good and poor mobilized groups. Conclusion: We did not fi nd any signifi cant SNPs by comparing the allele frequencies of the SNPs of CXCR4 and SDF1 in paired good and poor mobilized HSC donors. There are still many candidate genes need to be investigated. Further study to clarify the mechanism of moblization would be necessary to improve the effi cacy of hematopoietic stem cell mobilization and outcome of transplantation.

body_text.text: Introduction: The Italian Bone Marrow Donor Registry (IBMDR) was established in Italy in 1989 with the role of providing an unrelated volunteer haemopoietic stem cell (HSC) donor for haematological patients waiting for a transplant. The HSC potential donors are adults, who meet the minimum eligibility criteria for peripheral blood donor, according to Italian low, HLA typed and listed in the IBMDR. Donors and Methods: Peripheral Stem Cell collections are performed in the Peripheral Collection Centers (CCs-P) that are are located within public hospitals, authorized to perform aphaeretic procedures. Donor receives G-CSF (not biosimilar G-CSF), subcutaneously, at a maximum of 10 μg/Kg donor body weight. The characteristics of the collected PBSC (unit identifi cation code, nucleated cells parameters, volume) are certifi ed by the CC-P with Form CP201-p that must accompany the PBSC bags, and qualifi ed with serological and NAT tests for communicable diseases, according to Italian low. Results: From1989 to 2011 a total of 2.686 Haemopoietic Stem Cell Donations has been performed: 2.039 Bone Marrow Donations, and 647 Peripheral Stem Cell Donation, that are authorized as a fi rst stem cell donation from 2005. HSC units are been donated respectivelly for Italian and non Italian patients on 60% and 40% of cases. We compared the compliance of the CCs-P to Transplant Center (TC) prescription of Peripheral Stem Cells: TC required units with an average of CD34 5,2+1,1 x10e6/Kg, corresponding to 377+115 x10e6 CD34 and CCs-P distributed HSC units with an average of CD34 7,3+4,9 x10e6/Kg, corresponding to 491+203 x10e6 CD34 (Table I) . TC required units with CD34 >5x10e6/kg for 33% of patients, obtaining more than 72% of units with CD34 >5 x10e6/Kg; 97% of units contained CD34 >3x10e6/Kg, as show in Table II . Conclusions: This study show a good performance of CCs-P of IBMDR and a good compliance with the CD34 prescripted by national and international TCs, collecting more CD34 than requested in 40% of donations.

body_text.text: Impact of ethnicity on umbilical cord blood banking and outcomes following transplantation: a systematic review C. Akyurekli (1) , J. Chan (1) , H. Elmoazzen (2) , J. Tay (1) , D. Allan (1) (1)University of Ottawa (Ottawa, CA); (2) Canadian Blood Services (Ottawa, CA) Background: Umbilical cord blood (UCB) is used increasingly as a source of hematopoietic stem cells for transplantation to address shortages in matched donors, particularly in patients of non-Caucasian ethnicity. The role of ethnicity, however, on characteristics of units collected by cord blood banks and the impact of ethnicity on outcomes following transplantation remain unclear. Methods: A systematic search of published literature was performed using electronic databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE) . Studies that considered donor and/or patient ethnicity and included data concerning transplant outcomes or characteristics of collected UCB units were included. Results: A total of 403 published articles were identifi ed in our literature search of electronic databases and from experts' fi les. After removing duplicates, screening for relevance and reviewing in detail with regards to inclusion and exclusion criteria, a total of 21 studies underwent comprehensive review and data extraction. 11 studies addressed the impact of ethnicity on characteristics of collected units. Non-Caucasian ethnicity (African American, Asian, or non-Caucasian compared with Caucasian) was associated with a higher risk of rejecting the collected unit (4/4 studies), reduced total volume (3/9 studies), lower total nucleated cell count (5/9 studies), fewer CD34+ cells (4/9 studies) , and reduced colonyforming units (3/9 studies). Metanalysis was not possible due to lack of raw data reported in the studies. 9 studies reported worse outcome following transplant for non-Caucasian patients compared with Caucasians with respect to time to platelet engraftment (3/7 studies) , graft versus host disease (1/6 studies), overall survival (3/8 studies) and disease-free survival (1/4 studies) . The degree of HLA-matching, total nucleated cells infused, time to neutrophil engraftment and rates of relapse were not diff erent in any of the studies reporting on these outcomes. 1 of 3 studies that addressed the impact of mismatched donor/recipient ethnicity reported reduced overall survival for non-matched transplants. Conclusions: Non-Caucasian ethnicity may be associated with reductions in quality indicators of collected cord blood units. Transplant outcomes in patients of non-Caucasian ethnicity may be associated with delayed platelet engraftment and reduced overall survival. More research is needed to understand and optimize cord blood banking and transplantation to improve outcomes for non-Caucasians.

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation from unrelatedmismatched/familial-mismatched donors, which would be better? X.W. Liao (1) , C.T. Lin (1) , M. Yao (2) , C.C. Li (1) , B.S. Ko (2) , M.Y. Lu (2) , K.H. Lin (2) , S.T. Jou (2) , S.J. Wu (2) , D.T. Lin (2) , Y.L. Yang (2) , S.Y. Huang (2) , H.A. Hou (2) , J.H. Liu (1) , J.L. Tang (1) (1) National Taiwan University (Taipei, TW); (2) National Taiwan University Hospital (Taipei, TW) Objective: Allogeneic stem cell transplantation (Allo-HSCT) has been used to treat malignancies and immune and hematologic diseases for more than 50 years. According to a report by Buddhist Tzu Chi Stem Cells Center suggests that, only 25% of patients were able to fi nd an HLA-identical sibling as donors, while less than 50% of patients were able to fi nd an HLA -matched unrelated donor. For those patients who did not have matched donors, the question remains whether a partially matched unrelated donor or a familial mismatched/haplo-identical donor would be a better option. Methods: 151 patients who received Allo-HSCT between 1987 and October 2012 were analyzed, with 80 undergoing HLA≤3 mismatched unrelated donor transplantation (HLA≤3 UDT), 51 receiving HLA≤3 mismatched related donor transplantation (HLA≤3 RDT), and 20 having HLA>3 mismatched related donor transplantation (HLA>3 RDT). Time-to-event was assessed starting on the day of transplantation, and overall survival (OS) rates, cumulative incidences of relapse rates and treatment related mortality (TRM) rates for the 3 groups were compared. Results: Table 1 shows the patient demographics, indicating a strong similarity between the 3 groups in terms of age, gender, disease and pre-HSCT disease status, with the exception of a higher proportion of peripheral blood stem cell and ABO mismatch in the HLA≤3 UDT group. The 5-year OS rate after HL≤3 UDT was 53.9%, followed by 23.6% after HLA≤3 RDT and 13% after HLA>3 RDT (Fig 1) , showing a signifi cant diff erence (P=0.009). Comparison of cumulative incidence of relapse rates between the 3 groups indicated that the number for patients with HLA≤3 RDT was 74.1%, signifi cantly higher than those for HLA>3 RDT (69%) and HLA≤3 UDT (37.2%)(P=0.045). The TRM rates after HLA≤3 UDT, HLA≤ 3 RDT and HLA>3 RDT were 20.3%, 49% and 62%, respectively. Conclusions: Our study fi nds a relatively higher 5-year overall survival rate (53.9%) and a lower relapse rate after HLA≤3 UDT, signifi cantly better than the patients after HLA mismatched related donor transplantation. This could become a clinical reference for physicians when they choose donors for patients who have no suitable candidates.

Introduction: Since 2005, we used a reduced conditioning regimen associating fl udarabine, intravenous (iv) busulfan and anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG) before allogeneic stem cell transplantation to treat hematological malignancies. We report here the comparison of patients consecutively grafted with an unrelated or related donor after FBA RIC. Patients and methods: From July 2005 to December 2010, 109 patients with hematological malignancies were allografted using FBA RIC: for 51, stem cells from an unrelated donor stem cells (alloUD) were used while 58 patients received a HLA sibling (allo-SIB). FBA consisted of fl udarabine (30 mg/m2 5 days), iv busulfan (3.2 mg/kg 2 days), and intermediate dose of ATG (2.5 mg/kg 2 days). Peripheral blood stem cells were used in all but 4 patients, receiving marrow stem cells (alloUD group). Cyclosporine alone was used as GVHD prophylaxis. The two cohorts received an identical supportive care. Results: Patient characteristics were not statistically diff erent ( Table 1 ). The median follow-up of alive patients was 43 months S98 (range 19-76) . For alloUD and alloSIB grade 2-4 aGVHD incidence was 17% (CI 7-28) and 27% and cGVHD incidence was 39% (CI 25-53) and 28% , respectively (p= ns). For the whole population (n= 109), the 4-year PFS, OS and relapse incidence were 40%, 52%, and 47%; 1-year and 4-year non relapse mortality (NRM) were 12% and 20%, without signifi cantly differences between the 2 groups. Infectious complications were reported in Table 2 . Results were similar, except for bacterial infections, CMV infections and multiple reactivations which seemed more frequent in alloUD cohort. Conclusions: This retrospective study comparing unrelated to HLA identical sibling after a homogenous ATG-based RIC showed that acute and chronic GVHD incidence as well as PFS, OS, RR, and NRM were not diff erent. Infectious complications, mainly bacterial and viral, were more frequent after alloUD. Based on patient characteristics, this RIC regimen including "middle" doses of ATG, achieved a good balance between effi cacy and tolerance, and can be used as common platform before allogeneic transplantation from different kind of donors.

Does the 18 month survival rate following a haploidentical bone marrow transplant diff er from the 18 month survival rate following a mismatched unrelated donor transplant? O Fasan, T. Klumpp, R. Patel, P. Kropf, M. Martin, J. Ulicny, K. Mangan, M. Sharma Temple University (Philadelphia, US) Background: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation remains a curative option for adult patients with hematologic malignancies. About 30% of patients will have matched sibling donors. For the remainder of patients an unrelated donor will be found for 50% of Caucasians and for ethnic minorities the chances are much less. Alternative donor transplantation using related haploidentical donors and cord blood is an option for patients without a sibling or unrelated donor. Cord blood transplantation is not widely accessible and is resource intensive making haploidentical transplants the logical alternative donor source. However there are concerns about the survival following a haploidentical transplant. Goal: To compare the published 18 month survival following a myeloablative conditioned (MAC) haploidentical transplantation to the 18 month survival of mismatched unrelated donor transplants at our center. Subjects and methods: We retrospectively analyzed data on consecutive matched unrelated donor transplants for which we had molecular typing results at HLA -A, B, C, DRB1 and DQ. Subjects had a 10/10 or 9/10 unrelated donor and were undergoing their fi rst transplant. The data was extracted from our in house developed quality management database and analyzed using SAS software. Results: One hundred twenty two (122) patients met our inclusion criteria, including 77 males and 45 females. The median age on day of transplant was 50.5 years. The diagnoses were: ALL = 22, AML = 50, CLL = 7, CML = 13, MDS = 8, NHL = 10, others = 12. Ninety two patients had a 10/10 allele match and 30 patients had a 9/10 allele match. Forty eight percent received MAC regimens and 52% received RIC regimens. The 18 month OS for the 9/10 matched transplant was 43% and the published actuarial 18 month OS for MAC haploidentical bone marrow transplant is 62% (Railoa et al, BBMT, Article in Press) (p = 0.174). Survival for 10/10 matched transplant was 46% not signifi cantly diff erent from 9/10 matched transplants (p = 0.687). Conclusions: The 18 month OS for MAC haploidentical bone marrow transplant is not inferior to the 18 month OS for mismatched unrelated donor transplants at our center. We will be adopting MAC haploidentical bone marrow transplant as an option for our patients.

body_text.text: DRB1*11 alleles distribution in the Croatian population and implications for donor matching in haematopoietic stem cell transplantation Z. Grubic, K. Stingl, R. Serventi-Seiwerth, M. Mikulic, B. Labar, R. Zunec Clinical Hospital Centre Zagreb (Zagreb, HR) Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) has been established as a method of therapy for hematologic malignancies and other hematologic or immune disorders. Donor selection has been almost exclusively based on selecting a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) identical donor. The diff erences among populations arising from the HLA polymorphism also play a role and should be considered in establishing the matched unrelated donor (MUD) search protocol. The aim of this study was to address this question with respect to the Croatian population. In the period 2009-2012 (July), a successful search for MUD/CBU in the Bone Marrow Donors Worldwide (BMDW) was performed at our centre for 105 patients for whom a matched donor could not be previously found among family members. The donor was an unrelated individual in 103 cases, while for the remaining two patients CBU was chosen as a source of HSCT, double CBU transplantation in one case. The HLA typing criteria in our transplantation centre is high resolution typing for HLA-A, -B, -C, -DRB1 and -DQB1 loci. However, the 10/10 matching level was not achieved for 67 patients. For thirty-one patient 9/10 matched donor was found and for fi ve patients 8/10 donor was found. The highest number of mismatches was found at the HLA-C and -DRB1 loci (14 patients each). However, the most interesting fi nding regarding HLA matching was observed among our patients positive for the HLA-DRB1*11 gene. Namely, patients with HLA-DRB1*11:04 allele were more diffi cult to match than those with HLA-DRB1*11:01 allele. This was the case for fi ve patients in the group of patients mismatched for one DRB1 allele (N=13), and one patient who received an 8/10 matched transplant and in addition to uncommon DRB1 allele (DRB1*11:28) also had the HLA-DRB1*11:04 allele. All those patients ultimately received a DRB1*11:01 positive transplant. The explanation for this fi nding lies in the almost equal frequency of DRB1*11:01 (7.9%) and DRB1*11:04 (7.7%) alleles among Croats as opposed to the predominance of DRB1*11:01 in registries with largest representation in BMDW. In conclusion, this study revealed some specifi c characteristics of the Croatian population which should be taken into account while performing the donor search. The fi nding regarding the HLA-DRB1*11 alleles is an important example of how the diff erences in allele distribution between Croats and populations with potential donors can infl uence the search outcome.

body_text.text: It is generally accepted that HLA-C mismatched (mm) donors should be avoided for allogeneic HSCT. In the present retrospective study we analysed 382 patients undergoing HSCT between 1995 and 2011. Of these 115 patients received an HLA-C mm HSCT and 266 received an HLA-C matched graft. Only patients with malignant disease were included in the analysis with no signifi cant diff erences between patients with HLA-C matched or mm donors. Median age was 42 (<1-68) versus 41 (<1-65) years in the matched and mm groups respectively. Early/late disease was 119/147 and 51/64, respectively (ns). Reduced intensity conditioning was given to 100 patients (38%) among HLA-C matched patients compared to 42 (37%) in the HLA-C mm group. Myeloablative conditioning was similar in both groups. Female donor to male recipient was given to 20 (8%) in the matched group versus 19 (17%) in the mm group. Bone marrow was used as stem cell source in 74 (28%) patients in the HLA-C matched group compared to 45 (39%) in the mm group (ns). The remaining patients received PBSC in each group. Median CD34 cell dose (x106/kg) was 7.2 (0. 2-56.4) versus 7.1 (0.3-28.7) , respectively. GVHD prophylaxis consisted of CsA + MTX in 84% versus 85% of the patients in each group. ATG was given to all patients before HSCT. An HLA-C mm between donor and recipient has previously been associated with an increased risk of graft failure (GF). In the present material GF occurred in 9 (3.4%) in HLA-C matched group compared to 7 (6.1%) in the mm group (ns). In multivariate analysis for GF, major AB0 mismatch (p=0.03), RIC (p=0.01) and female donor to male recipient (p=0.002) were signifi cant risk factors. HLA-C mm was not found to be signifi cant (p=0.71). Neither had HLA-C mm any impact on mortality. Signifi cant factors associated to mortality in multivariate analysis were: disease stage (p<0.001), year of HSCT (p=0.015) and donor age (p<0.001). For acute GVHD grades II-IV CsA+MTX (p<0.001) and RIC (p<0.001) decreased the risk whereas the use of PBSC (p=0.016) increased the risk. HLA-C matched patients compared to HLA-C mm showed no statistical diff erence regarding TRM, RFS, mortality, acute GVHD grades II-IV and relapse incidence. In conclusion, in the present study we fi nd no negative impact of HLA-C mismatch on outcome after HSCT. The use of ATG in the conditioning could be one important explanation for this diff ering
S100 data compared to other centers. According to this our center will continue to use HLA-C mm donors.

The impact of high resolution hla and Kir-ligand mismatches on clinical outcome in unrelated cord blood transplantation L.E. Creary (1) , C.J. BRown (2) , S. Davey (2) , G. Miqueles (2) , I. Ionescu (3) , A. Ruggeri (4) , E. Gluckman (4) , V. Rocha (5) , C. navarrete (6) (1)NHS Blood and Transplant/UCL (London, GB) ; (2) NHS Blood and Transplant (London, GB) ; (3) Agence de la Biomedicine/Eurocord Registry (Saint-Denis La Plaine/Paris, FR); (4) Eurocord Registry (Paris, FR) ; (5) NHS Cord Blood Bank, NHS Blood and Transplant/University of Oxford (London/Oxford, GB) ; (6) NHS Cord Blood Bank, NHS Blood and Transplant/UCL (London, GB) Background: HLA incompatibility between patients and donors is one of the most important factors infl uencing the outcome of haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Although a less stringent level of HLA matching is acceptable in umbilical cord blood transplantation (UCBT), when compared to bone marrow, data on the HLA loci and the degree of resolution tolerated for good outcome is limited. Alloreactive donor derived natural killer (NK) cells, regulated in part by KIR genes, have also been shown to infl uence UCBT outcome. Our aim was to examine the eff ect of high-resolution (HR) HLA and donor KIR-patient HLA ligand mismatches (MM), and other prognostics factors on the clinical outcome of 86 patients transplanted with unrelated single cord blood units (CBUs) issued from the NHS Cord Blood Bank (NHS-CBB). Methods: Patients (n=86) of whom 61 were aged <15 yrs and with various clinical conditions including 47 patients with acute leukaemia were studied. Twenty-nine patients had received TBI with or without cyclophosphamide plus other drugs. DNA from patients and CBUs was whole genome amplifi ed when required and retrospectively sequenced at HR for HLA-A,-B,-C,-DRB1, and -DQB1 loci. Samples were also genotyped by PCR-SSOP/Luminex for the presence or absence of 16 KIR genes. Clinical outcome data was provided by the Eurocord registry and the NHS-CBB. Results: HR typing revealed additional HLA MMs previously not observed by low-resolution (LR) typing methods. Univariate analyses showed that both LR and HR MM in HLA-DRB1, and LR MM in the DQB1 loci were signifi cantly associated with increased risk of mortality (RR 2.3, 95% CI 1.1-5.0, P=0.042; RR 3.2, 95% CI 1.5-6.6, P=0.002 and RR 2.4, 95% CI 1.2-5.1, P=0.021 respectively). A single MM at the HLA-A gene typed at LR was associated with decreased rate of neutrophil engraftment (RR 0.6, 95% CI 0.4-1.0, P=0.05). Donor iKIR 2DL1 and patient ligand HLA-C2 MM were signifi cantly associated with acute GvHD II-IV (RR 3.5, 95% CI 1. 6-7.7, P=0 .006) and relapse (RR 0.03, 95% CI 0.0-13.4, P=0.020) Conclusions: Our data suggests that matching patients and CBUs at LR for HLA-A,-B and HR -DRB1 loci appears to be adequate for successful UCBT outcome but additional MM for donor iKIR gene-patient HLA ligand should be considered. Rezvani (2) (1)Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust, Hammersmith Hospital (London, GB) ; (2)Imperial College London (London, GB) Unrelated donor (URD) haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is a curative therapy for a variety of haematological disorders. It is well established that allelic HLA matching between recipient and donor at HLA-A, -B, -C and -DR improves success of URD HSCT. The role of HLA-DPB1 disparity is not well defi ned, with matching not currently performed at our centre. We examined the impact of HLA-DPB1 matching on overall survival (OS) and development of Graft-Versus-Host Disease (GvHD). Allelic HLA typing was performed retrospectively on stored DNA from 114 recipients and their donors who underwent URD HSCT following myeloablative conditioning. 89 (78%) of donor and recipient pairs were mismatched at HLA-DPB1, with 18 mismatched at both alleles. Of the 89 HLA-DPB1 mismatched recipients, 49 (55%) were matched at all other loci, while additional mismatches were identifi ed at class I (n=20; 22%), class II (n=8; 9%) or both class I and II (n=12; 13%). Of the 25 recipients matched at HLA-DPB1, 11 (44%) were fully matched at all loci, while additional mismatches were identifi ed at class I (n=5; 20%), class II (n=5; 20%) or both class I and II (n=4; 16%). Recipients were stratifi ed according to the presence or absence of an HLA-DPB1 mismatch and outcomes (GvHD and OS) examined. Recipients mismatched at HLA-DPB1 had superior survival at fi ve years (74.8% vs. 56.8%; p=0.023) than recipients who were matched at HLA-DPB1 but mismatched at other loci or 12/12 matched recipients (fi gure 1). In contrast, incidence of grade II-IV acute GvHD was not signifi cantly diff erent between the two groups (45% vs. 48% in matched and mismatched respectively, p=0.77). The median time to onset of acute GvHD was 27. 5 (range 8-74) and 20 (range 11-122) days respectively. Similarly, there was no signifi cant diff erence in rates of chronic GVHD between HLA-DPB1 matched and mismatched recipients (61% in matched vs. 50% in mismatched, p=0.37, median time to onset 256 days and 212 days respectively). As linkage disequilibrium does not extend to HLA-DPB1, it was considered possible to assess HLA-DPB1 matching as an independent risk factor. The inferior survival of patients matched at HLA-DPB1 supports the current approach which does not restrict donor selection based on this locus. Furthermore it raises important questions about the loci's role in the Graft-Versus-Leukaemia eff ect, given the superior survival of mismatched recipients without evidence of increased acute or chronic GvHD. A clinical audit was performed on adult patients removed from the list without having received an allograft to analyse the HLA testing performed during the process of donor identifi cation. Methods: 166 testing episodes from 156 patients removed from the list without having received an allograft between the years 2009-2011 who had received HLA testing for either siblings, volunteer unrelated donor (VUD) search or both were analysed by year, ethnicity and diagnosis. 10 patients were present more than once due to discrete testing episodes for sibling/VUD workup. Results : 64.5% of the patients were male and 35.5% female (107/59). Median age was 46.5 years (range 18. 1-69.8 ). The main ethnic groups were N.European Caucasoid 74.7% (124), Asian 9.6% (16) and Black 9% (15) . The most frequent diagnoses were AML 27.7% (46), NHL 12% (20) and myeloma 10.2% (17) . Median number of days on the list was 109. 5 (range 8-847) . 24.1% of patients (40) had an HLA-matched sibling, with a median of 28.5 days to identify (range 0-106). 47.6% (79) patients were considered for VUD allograft for which 76% (59) had an HLA-matched donor identifi ed. 24.7% (41) patients were removed from the list because a donor was not identifi ed in suffi cient time. A total of 244 siblings and 236 VUD were tested. 11 patients with a donor identifi ed (11.3%) received an allogeneic transplant at a later date, of which 9 were with the donor identifi ed at the time; 2 patients used a diff erent donor identifi ed at a later date. Conclusion: Substantial HLA testing was performed for this patient cohort, of which only a small proportion eventually received an allograft. In the current fi nancial climate, this audit will help identify for which patients, if any, it may be possible to postpone donor testing -specifi cally the more expensive VUDs -until dates when the patient is clinically closer to allogeneic transplantation. Any fi nancial saving must be balanced against the need for adequate time to identify a donor. This audit will be extended to analyse patients who received an allograft over the same time period to assess any diff erences present in time taken to identify a donor.

body_text.text: A rare but severe complication of G-CSF in healthy donor; splenic rupture G. Akyol, C. Pala, A. Yildirim, K. Demir, S. Dortdudak, L. Kaynar, A. Unal, M. Cetin Erciyes University (Kayseri, TR) Granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) is widely administered to donors who provide peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) for individuals who undergo hematopoietic stem cell transplants. G-CSF administration is associated with a small but defi nite risks of serious adverse events like splenic rupture. The donor, healthy individual with a body weight of 66 kg and height of 149 cm, had no remarkable previous history except a 10 year history of smoking (10 cigarettes/day) and any physical examination abnormality. Her complete blood count, biochemistry and chest x-ray were normal. Serologic tests for hepatitis B, C and HIV were all negative. We started G-CSF (fi lgrastim) therapy at a dose of 11μ/kg/day (twice daily administration) for 5 days. At forth day of mobilisation after 2 hours later of administration of G-CSF at 06 PM, she suff ered from a pain at chest bones. EKG fi ndings were normal. At 10:30 PM her pain began severe sharp and radiating to all abdominal regions. On physical assessment, she had left upper tenderness and rigidity. Tachycardia (110/min) and tachypnea (30/min) was present while signifi cant hypotension was not measured. An abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan showed splenic rupture and perisplenic fl uid. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the upper abdomen reveals irregular intrasplenic low-attenuation areas (arrows) consistent with ruptured spleen and perisplenic high density fl uid (asterix) compatible with blood (50 HU). HU: Hounsfi eld unit ( Figure 1 ). There was no sudden decrease in hematocrit and haemoglobin (Hgb) levels according to the blood count, so that at fi rst, splenectomy was not planned and she was followed up closely. We could not collect stem cell from our donor as expected risk of extra bleeding with citrate usage during aferesis and she refused collecting stem cell from bone marrow. When a Hgb decrease of 2 gr/dl and hematocrit decrased of 28.4% aschieved, we replaced one unit of eritrosit suspension. We should take care of splenic rupture in patients, previously administrated G-CSF and suff er from sharp and sudden abdominal pain.

We present our experience with 9 HLA-identical sibling donors mobilized with Bio-fi lgastrim that were compared with the previous 9 donors mobilized with fi lgastrim. Both drugs were given at a dose of 5μg/kg/day for 4 or 5 days with the fi rst apheresis performed on day 5. The target CD34+ cell dose was 5 x 10 6 /kg recipient body weight. Donor median age was 48 years (range 17 -77) . Median duration of G-CSF treatment was 5 days (5) (6) and the median number of apheresis was 1 (1) (2) in both groups. Side eff ects included mild bone/muscle pain all patients with no diff erences between the 2 groups. No immediate serious adverse eff ects were detected in either group. Bio-fi lgastrim seemed to have been well tolerated with no long-term adverse events reported. There were no signifi cant diff erences in mobilization outcomes between groups receiving the biosimilar or reference fi lgastrim. The median number of circulating CD34+ cells at day 5 was 70.2 x 10 9 /L (24-114) and 86.3 x 10 9 /L (42. 3-146.4) respectively. No mobilization failure was observed in either group. The median number of CD34+ cells/kg harvested was 7.2 x 10 6 (4-9.2) and 9.0 x 10 6 (6-14.3) respectively (p=0.12). So far seven patients have undergone allogeneic SCT with PBPC mobilized with bio-fi lgastrim with no signifi cant side-eff ects during the infusion. All patients engrafted at a median of 23 days (18 -28) for the bio-fi lgastrim group compared with 19 days (12-28) for the reference fi lgastrim group (p=0.11). Platelets engraftment occurred at 25 and 24 days respectively.

Our fi ndings suggest that Zarzio ® is well tolerated and safe as compared with Neupogen ® for PBPC mobilization of HLA-Identical siblings before allogeneic SCT. Given the similar eff ectiveness and their reduced costs, G-CSF biosimilars may represent a costeff ective alternative for PBPC mobilization. However, further studies are required to assess longer-term safety of G-CSF biosimilars.

Hristova-Dimceva (1) , S. Genadieva-Stavric (2) , S. Useini (1) , Z. Stojanoski (2) , A. Pivkova (2) , M. Grubovic (1) (1)Institute for Transfusion Medicine of RM (Skopje, MK); (2) University Hematology Hospital (Skopje, MK) Properly mobilized and harvested hematopoietic peripheral blood stem cells from (PBSC) at the appropriate time before stem cell transplantation (SCT) is prerequisite for a successful transplantation. Mobilized PBSC have become the preferred cell source for 99% autologous and 75% of allogeneic hematopoietic SCT. The aim of this study is to present our experience in apheresis of autologous and allogeneic PBSC in hematological patients and healthy donors in the last 11 years. Material and Method: This is a retrospective study performed in the Institute for Transfusion Medicine of Republic of Macedonia and University Hematology Hospital between 2001 and 2012 in patients and healthy donors. PBSC harvesting was performed with continuous flow cell separator Baxter C53000 and COBE Spectra using conventional-volume apheresis processing. Mobilization regimens included granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) alone in healthy donors, and G-CSF alone or combination of G-CSF and disease-specific chemotherapy in patients. Minimum dose required to ensure successful and sustained engraftment was 2x10 6 /kg CD34+ cells and 2x10 8 /kg mono-nucleated cells (MNC) . Results: There were 403 apheresis procedures in total, of which 317 performed (78.7%) in 141 hematologic patients (88 S103 males and 53 females, aged 18-63), and 86 procedures (21.3%) in 50 healthy sibling donors (32 males and 18 females, aged 20-54). Sufficient number of PBSC was collected with 2.2 apheresis in patients (range [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] , and 1.72 apheresis in donors (range [1] [2] [3] . The single procedure usually took 3-4 hours and the volume of collected stem cells was 50-220 ml. The tolerance of apheresis procedure in our patients and donors was good. The only adverse effects of the apheresis procedure were bone pain as reaction of G-CSF and numbness of the extremities as reaction of anticoagulant (hypocalcemia), which occur rarely and were very mild. The main indications for autologous SCT in our patients were: acute myeloid leukemia (28.4%), multiple myeloma (26.2%), Hodgkin disease (21.2%), non-Hodgkin lymphoma (12.7%) and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (7.8%); and acute myeloid leukemia (60%), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (14%) and chronic myeloid leukemia (7%) in allogeneic SCT. Conclusion: Autologous collection and transplantations of PBSC makes nearly 80% versus allogeneic (20%). All allogeneic donations are done by sibling donors. We should work on developing unrelated donation, National Stem Cell Donors Registry and become a part of Bone Marrow Donors Worldwide.

T-cell analysis via next-generation sequencing before allogeneic stem cell transplantation: a closer look at fi ngerprints J. Ritter (1) , V. Seitz (1) , A. Seegebarth (1) , R. Gary (2) , M. Wurdack (2) , S. Moi (2) , A. Mackensen (2) , S. Hennig (3) , A. Gerbitz (2) , M. Hummel (1) (

T-cells recognise antigenic peptides presented by class I and II molecules of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) via their specifi c T-cell receptors (TCRs). The enormous diversity of TCRs is in large part determined by the sequence in their hypervariable complementarity-determining region 3 (CDR3) which is generated by somatic recombination of the Variable (V), Diversity (D), and Joining (J) segments of the TCR-β gene and by insertion of random non-template bases at recombination junctions. Each single CDR3 region is unique and can be referred as the fi ngerprint of a T-cell. To determine the entire diversity of T-cells in the course of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (aHSCT) based on their unique TCR-β rearrangements, we utilized a multiplex TCR-β PCR-assay in combination with next generation sequencing (NGS, Illumina HiSeq 2000) . For this purpose, we isolated DNA from 60 samples of sorted CD4-and CD8-positive T-cell preparations derived from peripheral blood of donors before and after G-CSF mobilisation. Our TCR-β NGS-PCR revealed approximately 2 million sequence reads per sample which were intensively analysed by newly developed bioinformatics tools. After their alignment to germline segments (IMGT), we found a very similar Vβ-and Jβ-segment usage in CD4-and CD8-positive T-cells which was not signifi cantly aff ected by G-CSF administration. Despite this similar segment usage, two signifi cant and consistent diff erences between CD4and CD8-positive T-cells were detectable: (i) the CDR3 diversity is more restricted in the CD8-positive T-cells and (ii) the dominance of certain T-cell populations is much more prominent in the CD8positive T-cells. Our data provide a remarkable deep insight in the T-cell repertoire of CD4-and CD8-positive T-cells and in the development of T-cell composition of donors undergoing G-CSF induced stem cell mobilisation. In addition, our TCR-β NGS-PCR approach is an innovative tool to track single T-cells based on their individual TCR-β rearrangements.

Farina, F. Spina, A. Guidetti, P. Longoni, F. Ravagnani, A. Dodero, V. Montefusco, C. Carlo-Stella, P. Corradini Fondazione IRCCS Istituto Nazionale dei Tumori (Milan, IT) Backgroud: Plerixafor is a CXCR4-inhibitor that improves peripheral-blood-stem-cell (PBSC) mobilization when combined with granulocyte-colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF). Plerixafor 'on demand' after chemotherapy + G-CSF may be effi cient and costeff ective, but timing of administration and criteria for patient selection are under investigation. Objectives: Our study was aimed to assess the feasibility and efficacy of plerixafor 'on demand' with chemotherapy + G-CSF and to design an algorithm for the 'on demand' use after high-dose cyclophosphamide + G-CSF. Patients and methods. Twenty-seven lymphoma (n=24) and myeloma (n=3) patients were treated with chemotherapy + G-CSF and plerixafor: 19 patients had failed a previous mobilization with chemotherapy + G-CSF, 8 received plerixafor as fi rst-line mobilizing therapy. The decision of adding plerixafor was based on circulating CD34+ cells at hematopoietic recovery. To devise an algorithm for the 'on demand' use of plerixafor after a fi rst mobilization attempt we reviewed the data of 107 patients treated with cyclophosphamide + G-CSF: 51 myeloma patients received 3-4 gr/ms and 56 lymphoma patients received 6-7 gr/ms. Leukocytes and CD34+ cells were analyzed by a multivariate logistic regression model. Results: Twenty-six patients treated with plerixafor 'on demand' collected a median of 4,45 x 10 6 /kg CD34+ cells (range, 0,8-13) after a median of one plerixafor injection and one leukapheresis (range, [1] [2] [3] . Nineteen patients collected ≥ 4 x 10 6 CD34+/kg. The median fold increase of CD34+ cells after plerixafor was 4,8 (range, 1-52) . The median time from chemotherapy to plerixafor administration was 15 days (range, 12-25) . In our retrospective analysis on 107 patients treated with cyclophosphamide + G-CSF, having a CD34+ cell count < 10/μl on the day of leukocyte recovery (>1000/μl) or leukocyte count < 1000/μl after day +12 in myeloma and day +14 in lymphoma patients predicted the risk of failing PBSC collection by 2.7 and 2.8 times (p=0.001 and p=0.02) with a sensitivity of 89% and specifi city of 88%, respectively. Conclusions: Our results show that plerixafor 'on demand' can induce the collection of PBSC in > 90% of patients treated with chemotherapy + G-CSF. The retrospective analysis on 107 patients treated with cyclophosphamide + G-CSF showed that those with delayed hematopoietic recovery and CD34+ cells < 10/μl at recovery may deserve plerixafor 'on demand' , as fi rst-line mobilization therapy. Huang Peking University People's Hospital (Beijing, CN) Objectives: Until now, very few studies compared the clinical outcomes of transplant using granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) mobilized peripheral blood (G-PB) and a combination of G-CSF mobilized bone marrow (G-BM) with G-PB (G-BM&PB). The aim of this study was to fi nd a more suitable cell preparation for each patient based on a risk-stratifi cation system. Methods: This retrospective study compared transplantation outcomes in 98 consecutive patients with standard-risk acute leukemia. Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cells transplantation was used G-CSF mobilized bone marrow and blood (G-BM&PB, n=65) or G-CSF mobilized blood (G-PB, n=33) from HLA-identical sibling donors. Results: The G-BM&PB and G-PB groups had significantly different speed of neutrophil recovery (medians 15 vs 14 days, respectively; P=0.009), but similar rate of platelet recovery. Cumulative incidences of grades II-IV acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD) in the G-BM&PB and G-PB cohorts were similar (18.0% vs 21.8%, respectively; P = 0.697), but significantly different for grades III-IV aGVHD (5.5% vs 18.9%, respectively; P = 0.04). The G-BM&PB and G-PB cohorts showed similar cumulative incidences of chronic GVHD (cGVHD, 49.1% vs 42.7%, P = 0.467), 1-year cumulative incidences of treatment related mortality (16.2% vs 24.4%, P = 0.222), and 5-year cumulative incidences of relapse (13.8% and 26.8%, P = 0.115). The G-BM&PB group showed significantly higher 5-year probability of leukemia free survival (LFS) compared to G-PB group (77.8% vs 57.6%, P = 0.023). Multivariate analysis identified G-PB as an independent risk factor for III-IV aGVHD and LFS.

Here we report on 23 patients undergoing IB-CBT for advanced haematological malignancies. The study was a phase II prospective monocentric study approved by local EC and registered at http://clinicaltrials.gov/; the primary endpoint was engraftment rate. Conditioning regimen was myeloablative (Bus or TBI based); prophylaxis of GVHD was CsA, MMF 15 mg/kg/ bid and ATG-F (15-30 mg/kg, td) .CB processing was as described by Frassoni et al. Infusion on both iliac crests was performed in OR with monitored care sedation.Median age was 36 yrs, median recipients weight 63 kg (52-93); 17 were AML, 4 ALL, 1 MM and 1 CML. Phase at transplant was mainly advanced (for AL: 10 primary refr. or res. relapse, 6 beyond fi rst CR,5 fi rst CR; 1 progression for MM and 1 CB for CML). 3 pts had a previous allotransplant and 4 an autotransplant. All CB units were 4/6 except for 3 (5/6) . Median total cell infused was 2.06x10e7/kg and median CD34+ cells 0.53x10e5/kg. The CI of neutrophils recovery (>0.5x10e9/L) was 82+9% at day+60. The CI of platelet recovery (>20 or 50x10e9/L) was 82+9% and 70+10% at day+90 respectively. 2pts died before engraftment, due to CNS bleeding and myocarditis. 2 pts didn't engraft and a second unit, again via IB, was given. 1-year OS and NRM were 66+11% and NRM 20+9%, respectively. aGVHD was 39% with only 1 pt with grade III. We recorded 3 limited cGVHD and 1 extensive. All the evaluable pts achieved a CR, except for the MM pt, who obtain a nCR and a resistant AL pt who remained cytopenic due to persistence of blasts. CMV reactivation occurred in 13/23 pts (median onset day+38);1 pt reactivated EBV and developed an EBV-related encephalitis, successfully treated with anti-CD20 MAb. 6 pts had a hemorrhagic cystitis (median onset day+23,4/6 pos. for BK-virus). We recorded 3 possible/probable IFI. To our knowledge this is the fi rst prospective study confi rming the feasibility and the impressive platelet recovery of a new route of CB transplant, fi rstly reported by Frassoni et al. Even if these data need to be confi rmed on a larger population, plt recovery and the low amount of cell needed using IB route are important challenges able to propose CBT as a real alternative option when a matched donor isn't available much more rapidly than currently is. In addition, IB-CBT represents an ideal in vivo model to study and understand the biological phenomena regulating the function of stem cell niche.

Results: The allelic distribution in our cohort was representative with 133 (29%) and 15 (3%) donors heterozygous and homozygous for the A-allele, respectively. Median age and the sex distribution of the G/G-group and donors with the A allele were identical. The same was true for leukocyte counts at baseline and on day 5. Interestingly, the median concentration of mobilized CD34+ cells on day 5 was almost identical in donors with the A-allele (76/μl, range, 11-249) and G/G-group (71/μl, range . No diff erence in the overall yield of CD34+ HSPC in the apheresis product and in the number of CD34+ HSPC/kg recipient could be detected between both groups. In a multivariate regression model for the prediction of CD34+ cells/μl at day 5, only male sex (Regression coeffi cient (RC) 11.2 , 95% CI 1. 5-21.1, p=0 .023) and BMI as continuous variable (RC 3.5, p=0 .0001) but not age, smoking status and CXCL12 allelic status represented independent variables. Conclusion: Our data derived from a large well controlled cohort contradict previous analyses suggesting an association between CXCL12 allelic status and yield of CD34+ HSPC. Concentration of CD34+ HSPC in the peripheral blood, the most objective parameter, could not be predicted by CXCL12 genotype. Wiktor Jedrzejczak (1) (1)Medical University of Warsaw (Warsaw, PL); (2) Central Hospital, Ministry of Interior Aff airs and Administration (Warsaw, PL) The effi cacy of cyclophosphamide (CY) plus granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) mobilization regimen has not been evaluated in healthy hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) donors for ethical reasons. Experimental autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT) program in early type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), which was conducted at our institution enabled us to study the infl uence of CY on mobilization in this otherwise healthy population and compare it with healthy hematopoietic stem cell donors mobilized with G-CSF alone. This population of patients with T1DM is naïve to cytotoxic drugs, and mobilization is their fi rst contact with cytotoxic drugs (such as CY). The group of T1DM consisted of 25 patients aged 18 to 35 (mean 25). There were 16 males and 9 females. The matched unrelated donor group consisted of 40 donors aged 19 to 40 (mean 27) group adjusted for demographic characteristics to reach similar distribution of sex, age and weight. There were 25 males and 15 females. For the purpose of this comparison we evaluated only the fi rst collection day data. White blood cell count (WBC) on the collection day ranged from 1.5 G/L to 33.3G/L (mean 15.7 G/L) in T1DM patients. The values for URD were 22,8 G/L to 63.43 G/L (mean 40.72) (p<0.00000001, t-test). CD34+ cells accounted for 0.21% to 4.2% WBC in T1DM (mean 0.99%) and 0.04 to 0.59% WBC (mean 0.19%) in URD (p<0.0001, . In absolute numbers of circulating CD34+ cells, the data comprised of 26 to 477 per microliter in T1DM patients (mean 127 cells/ microliter) while in URD population the numbers ranged from 23 to 265 (mean 76) (p=0.028, t-test). In terms of collection effi cacy, the average yield of CD34+ cells during the fi rst leukapheresis was 332 x 106 (range 150 to 814 x 106) in T1DM group. For the URD group the average yield during the fi rst leukapheresis was 294 x 106 (range 42 to 873 x 106) CD34+ cells (p=0.35 , t-test) .

In conclusion, the CY + G-CSF mobilization is the standard protocol used in hematologic and non-hematologic patients. Our results show that CY+ G-CSF used for HSC mobilization in chemotherapy naïve individuals results in very similar numbers of circulating CD34+ cells, as well as collection effi cacy as compared to G-CSF only mobilization.

Prospective comparison of three diff erent donor groups -matched siblings, matched unrelated donors and haploidentical families -in allogeneic haematopoietic cell transplantation for acute myelogenous leukaemia in remission: a preliminary analysis K. Lee, J. Lee, J. Lee, D. Kim, Y. Lee, Y. Kang, M. Jeon, M. Seol University of Ulsan (Seoul, KR) HLA-haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) without ex vivo-T cell depletion using conditioning with reduced-dose busulfan, fl udarabine, and ATG achieved consistent engraftment with low graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and transplantationrelated mortality (TRM; Lee K-H, Blood 2011; 118:2609 -2617 . Therefore, we initiated a prospective study, where patients with intermediate-high risk acute myelogenous leukemia in complete remission (CR) underwent allogeneic HCT according to the donor priority of matched sibling (MS), matched unrelated (MU), then haploidentical familial donors (HF). Conditioning regimens for MS-HCT were busufan (3.2 mg/kg x 4 days)-cyclophosphamide (60 mg/kg x 2 days) or, for patients >55 years or with co-morbidity, busulfan (3.2 mg/kg x 2 days)-fl udarabine (30 mg/m 2 x 6 days)-ATG (Thymoglobulin 1.5 mg/kg x 3 days). Patients undergoing MU-or HF-HCT received busulfan (3.2 mg/kg x 2 days)-fl udarabine (30 mg/m 2 x 6 days)-ATG (Thymoglobulin 3 mg/kg x 3 days). GVHD prophylaxis included cyclosporine plus a short course of methotrexate, with cyclosporine taper initiated on days 30 (for ATG containing conditioning) or 60 (for BuCy conditioning). Between January 2010 and June 2012, 123 patients were enrolled. Of those, 6 patients experienced recurrence of their leukemia at the time HCT and, therefore, excluded from the analysis. The characteristics of remaining 117 patient-donor pairs were summarized in Table 1 . The median follow-up duration of survivors was 17.5 months (range, 4.2-34.4 months) . The donor-group eff ect on the HCT outcomes was described in Table 2 . In this preliminary analysis, patients undergoing HF-HCT showed higher frequency of grade 2-4 acute GVHD when compared to those undergoing MS-or MU-HCT. However, there was no signifi cant diff erence in terms of chronic GVHD, leukemia recurrence, TRM, event-free survival, and overall survival. These results corroborated our previous observations showing the feasibility of HF-HCT using a common reducedintensity conditioning regimen of busulfan, fl udarabine, and ATG. This study is ongoing with further patient enrollment and longer follow-up period.

body_text.text: The role of LTB4 receptor on progenitor cell mobilization by rh-GCSF in C57BL/6 mice C. Seong, Y. Mun, K. Lee, E. Yoo, S. Lee, J. Kong, J. Ahn, Y. Bae, S. Lee Ewha Womans University (Seoul, KR) Background: The mechanism on HSC seem to be complex including the role of SDF gradient between BM and PB, and the role of protease pathway. We previously had reported that LT(Leukotriene)B4 was able to mobilize HSC in the murine model within 4 hours without signifi cant side eff ects. Since there are possibilities of similar mechanisms during HSC mobilization, which are shared by rhG-CSF or LTB4, in this study, we investigate the role of LTB4 receptor by rhG-CSF during HSC mobilization. Methods: Peripheral blood samples were obtained via cardiac puncture. Samples were analyzed for TNC using trypan blue staining and FACS analysis using Sca-1, Lin, CD45R(B220), CD116, Gr-1, TER119 were performed. LTB4APA and U75302, which are LTB4 receptor antagonists were given to C57BL/6 mice at diff erent dose levels(0.5μg, 1μg, 2μg or PBS with equal volume in control arm) followed by rhG-CSF (5μg, IV). Results: The number of WBC and HSC were decreased in rhG-CSF mobilized mice, in which LTB4 receptor antagonists were given. Up to 1μg of LTB4APA or U75302, there were tendencies of blocking of mobilization in dose dependent manner. However, beyond 1μg of LTB4 receptor antagonists, the blocking eff ects were in plateau. Interestingly, the blocking eff ects on mobilization by LTB4 receptor antagonists were more dramatic by rh-GCSF than that of LTB4. Conclusions: LTB4 receptor is involved not only in the downstream pathway of rh-GCSF mobilization, but LTB4 mobilization pathway in C57BL/6 mice. The eff ect of rh-GCSF on LTB4 K/O mice should be studied further to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of progenitor cell mobilization. It is necessary to have the insights understanding more precise mechanisms on rhG-CSF and LTB4 mobilization for developing effi cient protocols in the clinic.

body_text.text: Alternative source of multipotent mesenchymal stromal cells: discarded bone marrow fraction M. Mantelli, M. A Avanzini, E. Lenta, D.M Ingo, A. Rimella, L. Catenacci, G. Quartuccio, G. Acquafredda, I. Nardiello, C. Gagliardone, A. Moretta, M. Zecca IRCCS Policlinico S. Matteo (Pavia, IT) Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC) are a very promising source for cell therapy. They can be isolated from various adult human tissues, but procurement is diffi cult. Therefore, research has focused on fi nding new, more convenient sources. A number of bone marrow (BM) processing and manipulation techniques have been developed to improve outcome of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. BM erythrocyte depletion is used to circumvent donor/recipient incompatibility for ABO blood group antigens. The erythrocyte portion, containing a viable number of stem cells, is subsequently discarded. We report on the feasibility of expanding MSC from this material. For this purpose, after obtaining patient written informed consent, we sampled BM from four HLA-identical sibling donors, RBC depleted for ABO blood group antigen incompatibility. ER-MSC preparations were in vitro expanded and compared to counterpart MSC obtained from the same units before manipulation (BM-MSCs) . We evaluated CFU-F, growth rate, morphology, antigen surface expression, capability to diff erentiate and reach senescence. The median volume of the four erythrocyte portions was 300 ml (range: 800-100 ml) with a median MNC recovery of 484x106. This yield, which we consider an adequate quantity for MSC preparation, is comparable to that obtained from the processing of 50 ml starting BM suspension, the typical starting material for BM-MSC expansion. After plating MNC from the two sources at the same density (160.000 cm2), we observed a comparable number of CFU-F (ER-MSC: 4.4±1.1, BM-MSC:6±2.12) after 7-days culture. ER-MSC were comparable with BM-MSC for morphology and proliferative capacity, expressed as calculated cumulative cell count, with an hypothetical average cell recovery of 129x109 and 143x109, respectively. ER-MSC as well as BM-MSC expressed high levels (>95%) of CD90, CD73, CD105, CD13 and HLA A-B-C surface antigens, whereas they were negative for CD34, CD45, CD14, CD80, HLA-DR and CD31 molecules. ER-and BM-MSC were similarly able to diff erentiate into either adipocytes or osteoblasts. MSC from both sources reached senescence at the same number of passages (median P18) and they did not show chromosome instability. Our data indicate that the erythrocyte fraction obtained after BM erythrocyte depletion, a material that would be otherwise discarded, may be considered a good source of MSCs. The elevated number of cells that could be obtained make it suitable for clinical grade MSC expansion.

body_text.text: A quality control score for cord blood unit selection A. Picardi (1) Background: Quality of selected Cord Blood Unit (CBU) strongly aff ects patient outcome after Cord Blood Transplant (CBT). Although the fi nal quality assessments (QA) are performed at infusion, QA are carried out during the whole process. Recently, the Cord Blood APGAR score based on the QA pre-freezing and at infusion has been identifi ed with promising results in order to optimize CBU selection. However, the role of QA at pre-releasing check remains undefi ned. Objectives: Aims of this study consisted of 1) comparing the QA in terms of cell dose and viability between pre-freezing, pre-releasing and at infusion and 2) defi ning a Quality Control Score System based on the CBU pre-releasing checks, performed on the attached segment before transplant, as predictive factor for CBT outcome. Methods: Our study includes 104 patients transplanted at 3 Italian Centres (Rome Transplant Network, Florence-Careggi and Bergamo-Ospedale Riuniti). Most of them (76/104) were aff ected by Acute Leukemia with median age and body weight of 28 years (0.6-66) and 54.5 kg (4-96), respectively. Pre-freezing and prereleasing data were collected from Cord Blood Banks and data at infusion from Transplant Centres. The Quality Control Score (QCS) was calculated as a sum of points related to the number of NC, CD34+ cells, CFU-GM and viability. Each variable has been classifi ed by quartiles. Each subset was weighted based on the value of correlation's coeffi cient. The degree of correlation between the variables was evaluated by the Spearman correlation coeffi cient. Results: Overall, our analysis has shown a signifi cant linear relationship between pre-freezing, pre-releasing and at infusion QA as number of NC (p<0.0001), CD34+ (p<0.0001) and CFU-GM ( < 0.01). Independently by the method used for the test, a significant correlation between pre-releasing and at infusion viability (p< 0.05) was found. Furthermore, 72 out of 104 patients were evaluable for the attribution of the QCS (ranged between 3 and 12) allowing the identifi cation of a cut-off of 9 as 3rd quartile. The patients who received CBU with a score > 9 showed a signifi cantly faster PMN engraftment (p=0.03), while the risk of acute GVHD (grade II-IV) was signifi cantly lower (p=0.02) for a QCS <9. Conclusions: The pre-releasing QA are predictive of cell dose at infusion and can be alternative to missing pre-freezing data. Finally, the pre-releasing QCS may represent a useful tool for optimizing CBU selection.

Impact of cell dose in BM and PBSC on outcome after allo-HSCT M. Remberger (1) , O. Ringden (2) , M. Uhlin (2) , J. Mattsson (2) (1)Therapeutic Immunology (Stockholm, SE); (2)TIM (Stockholm, SE) We studied the eff ect of the transplanted cell-dose on the outcome in 855 HSCT patients transplanted between 2000 and 2012 in a single center study. Most patients had a haematological malignancy. A sibling donor was used in 377 cases and a matched unrelated donor in 478 cases. Most patients (n=553) were treated with conventional myeloablative conditioning while 302 received reduced intensity conditioning. Bone marrow (BM)(n=366) and PBSC grafts (n=489) were analysed separately as the cell-dose are very diff erent. Median nucleated (NC) and CD34+ cell dose was 2.9x108/kg vs. 11.3x108/kg and 3.8x106/kg vs. 7.9x106/kg in BM and PBSC grafts, respectively. First the BM and PBSC groups were divided into four equally sized groups depending on the nucleated or CD34+ cell dose. Then the diff erent outcome variables (survival, TRM, GVHD and engraftment) were studied in these groups. Corrections were made for diff erences in characteristics between the groups. In the BM group we found that a NC dose <2.0x108/kg were associated to more chronic GVHD (p<0.01), a slower platelet engraftment (p<0.01) and a trend for higher TRM (p=0.12). A low CD34+ cell dose (<2.3x106/kg) were correlated to slower neutrophil and platelet engraftment (p=0.037 and p<0.01) and a trend for more chronic GVHD (p=0.12). The fastest engraftment and lowest cGVHD was seen in patients receiving a BM graft containing both >2.0x108/kg NC and >2.3.0x106/kg (n=182). In the PBSC group we found that patients given a NC dose <8.3x108/kg had less acute GVHD II-IV (p<0.01), a trend for inferior overall survival and relapse-free survival (RFS)(p=0.08 and p=0.12). A CD34+ cell dose >11x106/kg was associated to inferior survival (p=0.02), more relapse (p=0.02) and inferior RFS (p<0.01) but quicker platelet engraftment (p=0.02).

In conclusion, when using bone marrow as stem cell source a NC dose of >2.0x108/kg and a CD34+ cell dose >2.3x106/kg is needed to achieve a faster platelet engraftment and less chronic GVHD. When using PBSC as stem cell source a NC dose >8.3x108/kg or a CD34+ cell dose <11.0x106/kg were associated to superior survival and RFS, less relapse but more acute GVHD grades II-IV. A high CD34+ cell dose resulted in faster platelet engraftment.

Vallejo University Central Hospital of Asturias (Oviedo, ES) Background: previous studies have suggested that allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) from HLA-identical sibling using peripheral-blood stem cells (PBSC) accelerates the engraftment and decreases the relapse rate of high-risk malignancies, but increases the risk of acute and/or chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) compared to bone marrow (BM). In the unrelated donor (URD) setting, a recently published randomized study did not detect signifi cant survival diff erences between PBSC and BM transplants. In addition, the use of low-dose anti-thymocyte (ATG) might modify the pattern of events when comparing between both HSC sources.

body_text.text: [P506] S109 Objective: we aimed to restrospectively compare the URD-HSCT performed with BM and PBSC in a single center. Methods and patients: we report the outcome of 56 consecutive patients (pts) who underwent allo-HSCT from URD during the last four years in our institution. Pts receiving BM were older than those transplanted with PBSC. As expected, the number of CD34+ and CD3+ cells infused were substantially higher in the BM arm. The characteristics of the series of pts is showed in the table. Results: as is shown in the table, early acute GVHD and gr. II-IV acute GVHD were higher in the PBSC group. On the other hand, graft failure (GF) and overall survival were higher in the BM group. The 3 pts who had GF were rescued with autologous backup (2) and with a second transplant (1) , and are alive at the last follow-up. Conclusion: in our experience, BM exhibits better long-term outcome than PBSC URD transplant, and continues to be the preferred source of SC for the majority of patients.

Clinical outcome of single and double cord blood transplants performed using NHS-CBB units M. Guttridge (1), S. Watt (2) , R. Hough (3) , C. Brown (4) , G. Miqueles (4), B. Cash (1) , J. James (4) , I. Ionescu (5) , E. Gluckman (6) , R. Pawson (2) , V. Rocha (2) , C. Navarrete (4) (1)NHS Blood and Transplant (Bristol, GB) ; (2) Objective: The NHS-CBB was established in 1996 and has over 19,500 unrelated cord blood units (CBUs) stored of which around 40% are from ethnic minority donors. We have issued over 400 CBUs for transplantation to patients worldwide. The aim of this study was to assess the quality of CBUs stored from the clinical outcome of the transplants performed. Methods: In collaboration with Eurocord registry, we performed a retrospective analysis of the outcome of 190 single and 104 double cord blood transplants (CBT) from 1998 to December 2011. The clinical end points analysed were platelet and neutrophil engraftment, acute and chronic GVHD, overall survival (OS) and disease free survival (DFS). Median follow up (FU) for single CBTs was 33.8 months (3.1-144.4 ) and for double CBT was 17.6 months (1.2-85.1) . Results: Two different analysis were performed by graft type (single or double UCBT). The majority, 155 (81%) of the single CBTs were in children and 125 (66%) had malignant disease (MD). Median time to neutrophil and platelet recovery was 23 and 40 days, respectively. The K-M estimate of aGVHD (II-IV) incidence was 33±4% and 14±3% (grade III and IV). cGVHD was seen in 28 patients,10 (43%) extensive and 13 (57%) limited. OS was 61% in children and 30% in adults; 63% for HLA matched 6/6 or 5/6 and 43% in the 4/6 or less matched transplants; 64% in transplants with TNC >4.1x10 7 /kg and 42% in those with <4.1x10 7 /Kg, and 61% in those with >1.8 x10 5 /kg CD34+ cells and 46% in those with <1.8x10 5 /Kg. At 3 years, DFS in patients with MD was 44±5%. Cause of death evaluated in 81 patients showed 23 were due to relapse, 57 were transplant related and 1 was secondary malignancy. Of the double CBTs 93 (89%) were in adults and of these 90 (98%) had MD. Myeloablative conditioning was used in 39 (41%) patients and RIC in 57 (59%). Median time to neutrophil and platelet recovery was 21 and 40 days, respectively. The K-M estimate of aGVHD incidence was 29±5%. At 18 months, OS was 51±5% and DFS was 44±6%. Cause of death in 51 patients with data were relapse (31%) or transplant related (69%). Conclusions: The clinical outcome of CBTs performed using NHS-CBB units compares favourably with published studies indicating that the procedures in place at the NHS CBB contribute to safe and high quality products for transplantation.

Detection of microparticles in cord blood units A. Xagorari (1), M. Samalidou (1), D. Bougiouklis (1), D. Zacharaki (1), N. Leventopoulou (1), A. Siogna (2) , L. Economou (2) , D. Sotiropoulos (1) , A. Anagnostopoulos (1) (1)G.H. "G.Papanicolaou" (Thessaloniki, GR); (2) Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (Thessaloniki, GR) Objectives: The microparticles (MPs) are small membrane vesicles (sized around 0.1mm) relased from diff erent cell types after activation or apoptosis. MPs are considered markers of cell activation and apoptosis. Recently MPs were shown to participate in important biological functions and pathological processes, such as angiogenesis in tumor metastasis, infl ammation, thrombosis and haemostasis. The aim of this study is to quantify the MPs in cord blood units and to investigate their relationship with diff erent parameters. Methods: Collected cord blood units (CBUs) (n=30) were processed with SEPAX apparatus (BIOSAFE) and analysed based on their net volume, the absolute number of CD34+cells/unit and their viability by fl ow cytometry, the number of total nucleated cells (TNC) and the absolute number of nucleated red cells by microscope after Giemsa staining. Mononuclear cells were seeded in semisolid culture in the presence of growth factors (SCF, IL-3, GM-CSF, EPO) for CFU-GM, BFUe and CFU-GEMM colony growth. MPs were isolated after plasma centrifugation. The number of MPs was determined after incubation with annexin-V and anti-CD34 by fl ow-cytometry. Electron microscope photographs were obtained. For the statistical analysis used t-test, Pearson's and Spearman's depending on the normality of the distribution of variables. Results: The mean (± SD) number of annexin-V+/CD34+MPs was 73±22/ μl. Univariate analysis showed that the number of MPs had signifi cant negative correlation to the number of BFU-E (p<0,019; r=-0,426), CFU-GEMM (p<0,016;r=-0.435) and CFCs (p<0,015; r=-0,440). There was no signifi cant correlation between the number of MPs and each of the following: TNC, CD34+, CFU-GM the net units volume. CBUs were frozen and thawed and the numbers of annexin-V+/ CD34+MPs and colonies were determined. Univariate analysis showed that the number of MPs has strong negative correlation to the post-thaw number of BFU-E (p<0,0012; r=-0,988) and CFU-GM (p<0,038;r= -0.962). The number of MPs has strong positive correlation to the number of CFU-GEMM (p<0,0; r=1,0) after thawing. Concusion: MPs from haematopoietic progenitor cells were identifi ed in cord blood units. The number of annexin-V+/CD34+MPs showed a signifi cant negative correlation with the number of colonies (total CFUs, CFU-GEMM, BFU-E) as well as the post-thaw number of CFU-GM and BFU-E colonies. The role of MPs in CBUs and possible correlation with transplantation remains to be investigated.

Stem cell viability in umbilical cord banking; how good are our quality controls? R.C. Duggleby (1) Objectives: Umbilical cord blood (CB) is increasingly being used as a viable alternative to peripheral blood or bone marrow aspirates as a stem cell source in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Practically, however, it requires cryopreservation in large (25ml) volumes and establishment of an accredited CB Bank. Recently, we published (Transfusion 2012) that the standard flow cytometer assessments of viability, utilizing 7-Aminoactynomicin D (7AAD), do not detect early apoptotic cells. Significant numbers can be present following thawing, detected by labelling with annexin V (AnnV). In CB banking, the tubing used to fill the storage bag is sealed into segments and frozen with the rest of the unit (25 ml bag). These segments can then be thawed as quality controls. However, these more sensitive assessments raise the possibility that differences might arise between segment and bag, compromising their value as quality controls. Methods: Control thaws (n=18) of CB units were performed to reassess the effi cacy of using the segments as quality controls for the unit. Assessed were stem cell dose (ISHAGE guidelines), nonapoptotic dose by AnnV labelling, and functional cell dose (n=12) by 14-day, colony forming unit assay (CFU). Results: The paired bag and segments showed extensive evidence of loss of CD34+ cell viability with high proportions of AnnV (~ 65% in both) and 7AAD+ (10%) and morphology (30%). Despite this, viability and cell dose correlated in the bag and the segment, and there was no signifi cant diff erence in the median proportion of CD34+ cells present or absolute counts of viable CD34+ cells. In addition, the correlation between function dose (by CFU) and viable CD34+ dose (by AnnV) was very similar in the bag and the segment (R2= 0.546 and 0.549). Conclusion: These data indicate that, as observed previously, extensive apoptosis occurs post-thaw. However, the data also suggests that the segment still appears to behave similar to the bag, despite the diff erence in volume (~0.1ml to 25 mls). Reassuringly, this indicates that the segments remained a valid quality control for the remaining unit. It should be noted that the majority of these units were cryopreserved for less than 1.5 years, thus the stability of this relationship with time remains to be seen. Also this is an on-going process, larger sample sizes may detect diff erences. However, Our ability to assess the units that are banked is essential if we are to be able to guarantee the viable/functional cell dose delivered to a patient.
