CD34+ cells concentration kinetics after plerixafor in poor mobilizers: is time to change the schedule? Z. Koristek (1) , J. Novák (2) , I. Skoumalova (3) (1)University Hospital Brno (Brno, CZ); (2)University Hospital Kralovske Vinohrady (Prague, CZ); (3)University Hospital Olomouc (Olomouc, CZ) Introduction: Combination of plerixafor + G-CSF is approved for mobilization of hematopoietic stem cells for autologous transplantation (ASCT) in patients with lymphoma and myeloma whose cells mobilize poorly. The recommended schedule is to administer plerixafor approximately 10 hours before apheresis to collect the cells during the estimated peak mobilization. This recommendation arises from the fi rst studies phase I and II, in which the CD34+ cells peripheral blood concentrations after plerixafor were monitored. However, the data considering CD34+ cells concentration kinetics after plerixafor administration were studied in healthy subjects and patients who were not proven poor mobilizers. Our aim was to check whether the mobilization kinetics is similar also in poor mobilizers. Patients and methods: Nine patients (5 males, 4 females) of median age 53 years (19-63), treated for lymphoma (n=5) and myeloma (n=4), were given plerixafor for proven (n=7) or estimated (n=2, both after previous high dose chemotherapies) mobilization failure. Plerixafor was used in a standard schedule in 7 patients (G-CSF 10 ug/kg day 1-5/+6, plerixafor 240 ug/kg day 4/+5, apheresis day 5/+6), and on-demand in two patients during failing chemomobilization (plerixafor 240 ug/kg day before apheresis during WBC increase after chemotherapy + G-CSF). CD34+ cells count was measured in peripheral blood just before plerixafor administration and subsequently every 2 hours for next 16 hours after 11 plerixafor injections (2 patients received 2 doses of plerixafor). All patients signed informed consent with the study. Results: Seven out of 9 patients (78%) yielded at least 2x10e6 CD34+ cells/kg (median 4,81; range 2,01-6,71). The CD34+ cells concentrations in blood peaked between 2 and 10 hours after plerixafor administrations. If we consider the CD34+ cell count in the blood in the morning before the fi rst plerixafor injection as 100%, the percentage of CD34+ cell concentration increase was in mean between 399% and 426% during 2 and 10 hours after plerixafor injection and then started to quickly drop. Conclusions: The standard recommended schedule for plerixafor administration is derived from data obtained in healthy subjects and normally mobilizing patients. The late evening plerixafor administration is not very practical and, moreover, the peak mobilization could be missed in poor mobilizers. We can conclude, that plerixafor administration 2 hours before apheresis in poor mobilizers could be more effi cient and practical as well.

The number of mesenchymal cells from Wharton jelly is not aff ected by the fragment of the umbilical cord from which the cells were isolated M. Murzyn (1) Introduction: At present , the mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) are new and giving new opportunities for therapies of various inherited and acquired disorders. Wharton Jelly (WJ) as a source of MSC has all the advantages of cord blood and it is reachable in MSC. In the present publication we describe the results of the collection, culture, investigation, and cryopreservation of cells derived from the umbilical cord (UC) collected by the companies from the group controlled by The Polish Stem Cell Bank confi rmed by clinical application. Materials and methods: UC were collected after natural deliveries as well as caesarian sections. UC samples were packed in a special transport container. In the laboratory, plastic-adherent cells were isolated cultured, and enumerated, and their viability was evaluated. Then the cells were cryopreserved and placed in the vapour phase of liquid nitrogen. The repeated cell counting, viability tests, fl ow cytometric immunophenotyping, and functional in vitro diff erentiation assays were performed from thawed reference samples. Results: We reported a low contamination level . The fi rst adherent cells with fi broblast-like morphology were well distinguishable within a week after the initiation of the cell culture. We haven't noticed any diff erences in growth, cell number and morphology in primary culture between tissue fragments from placental, central and baby side. The average number of p0 cells from the 6-well plate dish was between 1,5 x 10 6 ± 0,2 x 10 6 . The fi rst adherent cells with fi broblast-like morphology were well distinguishable within a week after the initiation of the cell culture. The post-thaw viability was not lower than 85% and thawed cells give rise the new culture in less than 4 hours. The immunophenotype (CD45-/CD34-/CD19-/HLA-DR-/CD73+/CD90+/CD105+) was stable during the whole period of culture (15 passages) . Cells were capable for diff erentiation into adipogenic, chondrogenic and osteogenic cells. Conclusion: The results described above demonstrate a quick, repeatable and effi cient method for WJ-derived MSC isolation and propagation to get MSC units contained cells in a number hypothetically suitable for clinical use. Moreover, we have found that the effi ciency of the isolation and the number of received cells is not aff ected by the origin of the fragment of the tissue from which the cells were isolated.

Additional haematopoietic stem cells from placenta perfusion J. Placzkowska, M. Murzyn, I. Marszalek, K. Zagorska, K. Poteralska, J. Piskula, A. Orczykowska, I. Czaplicka, A. Olkowicz, D. Boruczkowski, T. Oldak, J. Baran Polish Stem Cells Bank SA (Warsaw, PL) Introduction: Today cord blood (CB) is widely recognized as a source of hematopoietic stem cells (HSC). For potential transplantations the major key is the number of CD34+ cells derived. The number of CD34+ cells derived from single umbilical CB is often not enough for eff ective transplantation in adults. The human placenta is a possible source of additional progenitor cells and/or stem cells. Some CB banks try to increase the CB volume collected by the additional puncture of the cord's vessels with a needle & syringe. The results of these attempts are not satisfactory, which is why we developed the new strategy of obtaining an additional pool of cells by fl ushing placenta vessels. Materials and methods: CB and placenta blood was obtained using specially constructed separate kits during natural deliveries. CB was obtained in accordance with standard procedures. After birth, the placenta was rinsed by the injection of a solution into placenta vessels and we got an extra portion of blood. The number of CD34+ cells, viability, total nucleic cells (TNC) and contamination in placenta blood and CB was determined. Results: Flow cytometry showed that HSC were in the placental perfusion blood. A signifi cant increase in CD34+ was observed. Additionally we received on average signifi cantly more TNC and CD34+ cells, whereas the averaged viability of the high level remained, and the percentage of contaminated units stayed unchanged. Conclusion: Based on our results we suggest that the CB collection with placental blood might off er an increase in the CD34+ number. Of course further studies are necessary, but in the case of allogeneic or autologous CB transplantations, today we can predict the increase of the recipient's body weight by about 15% -20%. These double portions may be used in a higher number of adult lifesaving transplantation therapies. We also showed that the method of collecting placenta blood is quick and easy for potential clinical use and safe for both, newborn and mother.

Afanasyev R.Gorbacheva Memorial Institute of children hematology and transplantation (St. Petersburg, RU) Introduction: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) may be the only curative option for patients with unfavorable acute leukemia's. Improvements over the last 15 years in conditioning regimens, graft engineering and pharmacological immunoprophylaxis of GVHD have substantially reduced the morbidity and mortality of HLA-haploidentical HSCT (haplo-HSCT). However the main reason of mortality after haplo-HSCT in this group of patients is recurrence of the primary disease. Aim: Evaluate diff erent post transplant strategy in patients with unfavorable acute leukemias after haplo-HSCT. Methods: Fifty seven patients (range from 1-56 y.o.) with unfavorable acute leukemias were included in the study. ALL-29pts, AML-25pts, acute biphenotype leukemia-3pts. The RIC regimen based on Flu received 34 pts, MAC based on GIAC protocol*-24 pts. G-CSF-primed BM was used as a graft source. Median CD34+ cell were for children 10,9x10 6 /kg b.w., for adults 4,78x10 6 /kg b.w. Prophylaxis of aGVHD: CsA-based -36 pts, Tacro-based -21 pts. Children and adults with engraftment survived > 90 days from haplo-HSCT without signs of severe aGVHD or infection complications were evaluated for post transplant strategy. Post transplant therapy received 19 pts (maintenance-6MP+MTX 2pts, immunoadoptive chemotherapy-RIST 5pts, DLI 12pts). Results: One-year and two-year overall survival (OS) was higher in patients who received post transplant therapy compared patients without post transplant treatment 73,7% vs 23,7% and 47,4% vs 13,2% respectively (p=0,001). In multivariate analyses predicted cumulative incidence for bone marrow relapse was 8% and 92% respectively (95% CI, 0,62-1, p=0,001). Conclusions: Haplo-HSCT is eff ective therapy for achievement remission in patients with unfavorable acute leukemia. Because of lack of treatment due to relapse which is the main reason of mortality it's necessary to use post transplant treatment for patients with unfavorable acute leukemia after haplo-HSCT. It's necessary to further investigation for study optimal types post transplant therapy.

body_text.text: Since 2011, Zarzio ® has been approved in our institution for all authorized indications including PBPC mobilization in autologous SCT. A total of 36 patients mobilized with bio-fi lgastrim were included in this retrospective study, and were compared with the previous 36 patients mobilized with reference fi lgastrim. Neupogen ® was given at a dose of 10 μg/kg/day while Zarzio® was given at a dose of 5 or 10 μg/kg/day (depending on the CD34 target). Both were given during 5 or 6 days with the fi rst apheresis scheduled for day 5. The target CD34+ cell dose was 2 x 10 6 /kg recipient body weight in Lymphomas and 4 x 10 6 /Kg in Myelomas. Median age was 53 years (range 19 -72). The median duration of G-CSF treatment was 5 days (5) (6) and the median number of apheresis was 1 (1) (2) (3) in both groups equally. Zarzio ® seemed to have been well tolerated with no long-term adverse events reported in our series. Side eff ects included mild bone/muscle pain in both groups. There were no signifi cant diff erences in mobilization outcomes between groups receiving the bio-fi lgastrim or reference fi lgastrim. The median number of circulating CD34+/L at day 5 was 58.8 x 10 9 (range 3.2 -256.5) and 31.3 x 10 9 (range 1.8 -119.1) respectively (p=0.01). The median number of CD34+/kg was 4.76 x 10 6 (2.04 -13.42) and 4.36 x 10 6 (1.04 -10.98) in both groups (p=ns). All 36 patients (100%) in the bio-fi lgastrim group achieved the target CD34 cell dose compared to 28/36 (78%) patients in the control group (p<0.001) To date, 26 patients mobilized with bio-fi lgastrim and 27 with reference fi lgastrim, have undergone autologous SCT. All patients engrafted within a median of 13 days (10 -19) for the bio-fi lgastrim group and 11 days (10) (11) (12) (13) (14) (15) (16) (17) for the control group. Platelet engraftment was at 21 and 20 days respectively.

In our group of patients, our fi ndings suggest that Zarzio ® is well tolerated and safe when compared with Neupogen ® for PBPC mobilization before autologous SCT in patients with Hematological Malignancies. However, further studies are required to assess longer-term safety of G-CSF biosimilars.

Use of plerixafor to rescue absolute and predicted mobilization failures: a UK and Ireland consensus K.W. Douglas (1) , P. Hayden (2) , H. Hunter (3) , P. Johnson (4), R. Malladi (5) , S. Paneesha (6) , R. Pawson (7), M. Quinn (8), K. Raj (9), D. Richardson (10), S. Robinson (11), N. Russell (12) , J. Snowden (13), A. Sureda (14) , E. Tholouli (15) Background: Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) is often used, alone or in combination with chemotherapy, to mobilise peripheral blood (PB) stem cells (PBSCs) from the bone marrow for use in stem cell transplantation. Despite established mobilisation strategies, many patients fail to mobilise suffi cient PBSCs to proceed to transplant. Plerixafor has been shown to increase the number of CD34+ cells in PB and can be used to salvage absolute or probable mobilisation failures in patients who mobilise poorly. While there is evidence to support use in poor mobilisers, there is no consensus on the most appropriate and cost-eff ective way to use plerixafor. Actions and Objectives: Working Group meetings were held with representatives from around the UK, to facilitate discussion on the use of plerixafor in bone marrow transplantation. The meetings aimed to review data and gain consensus on the most suitable method to identify poor mobilisers who should receive plerixafor. Results: The Working Group agreed that 15-20% of patients primed with G-CSF or G-CSF plus chemotherapy fail to mobilise suffi cient CD34+ cells, necessitating repeated mobilisation attempts, increased resource utilisation and a delayed time to transplant. Patients who fail mobilisation generally go on to receive plerixafor. Pre-emptive use of plerixafor in patients who are predicted to fail mobilisation can lead to fi nancial and effi ciency savings (vs requiring a patient to fail mobilisation and restart the process prior to plerixafor) so it is important to defi ne criteria to identify predicted poor mobilisers prior to failure. A patient is eligible for pre-emptive rescue with plerixafor when an established mobilisation protocol has been followed and on the predicted day of mobilisation the patient has a PB CD34+ count below 15/ μ L and a white cell count of at least 4x10 9 /L. This is not anticipated to increase the amount of plerixafor use as the same patients who would go on to fail mobilisation will simply receive plerixafor earlier in their treatment. Conclusion: The use of plerixafor to rescue absolute or probable mobilisation failures can improve resource utilisation and patient experience but an evidence-based protocol is needed to defi ne eligible patients. Following further discussion among the Working Group members, a consensus publication should be produced to provide information on plerixafor use and guide the use of plerixafor in absolute and probable mobilisation failures.

Dynamics of CD34 peripheral cells are predictive of stem cell mobilization success in patients with low count on the day before collection A.C. Gac (1) , J.J. Parienti (1), S. Chantepie (2) , C. Fruchart (3) , V. Lefevre (4) , O. Reman (2) (1)Université de Caen (Caen, FR); (2) Centre hospitalo-universitaire (Caen, FR); (3)Centre François Baclesse (Caen, FR); (4)Etablissement Français du Sang (Caen, FR) Autologous hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation is an eff ective treatment for patients with lymphoma. Unfortunately,

[P517] S114 15-30% of patients fail to mobilize a suffi cient number of HSC for the transplant. With the availability of plerixafor for stem cell mobilization, most patients are now able to yield stem cells successfully; however, because of its high cost, we have to select patients who might benefi t of its early introduction. Objectives: We identifi ed poor mobilizers in a homogenous cohort of patients with lymphoma and we analysed predictive factors before collection which can help us to determine the plerixafor's best indication. Methods: We report here 174 lymphoma patients who underwent cytapheresis between 2007 and 2011. None patient received plerixafor. 52 (29%) patients having less than 2.106 CD34/kg after the fi rst cytapheresis were considered as failure. Among these, 8 did not have cytapheresis because of peripheral CD34 positive cells count the day before cytapheresis was less than 6/mm 3 . The optimal count of CD34 positive cells allowing a successful mobilization was in our study 30 /mm 3 . Results: We fi rst analysed pre-collection characteristics of the 52 patients who failed to have more than 2.106 CD34/kg in order to predict the HSC mobilisation failure after the fi rst cytapheresis. Unfortunately, as it was described in the literature, only peripheral CD34 count the day before cytapheresis was the strong predictive factor of fi rst cytapheresis failure and any other predictive factors were found. Then, we selected 56 patients from the cohort who had less than 30 CD34/mm 3 the day before the fi rst cytapharesis. Of these patients, 41 (74%) had less than 2.106 CD34/kg after the fi rst cytapheresis. We showed that if the peripheral CD34 count the day before cytapheresis and more interestingly, dynamics of CD34 peripheral cells between the day before and the day of cytapheresis are predictive of a fi rst cytapheresis failure (respectively p=0.0133 and p=0.0108) (fi gure1 and fi gure2) and these factors are independent (p<0.01). Inversely, we can identify among these patients with less than 30 CD34 positive cells day before collection who had successful mobilization and for whom, plerixafor can be avoided. Conclusion: For patients having a count less than 30 CD34/mm 3 the day before the fi rst cytapharesis, dynamics of CD34 peripheral cells between the day before and the day of cytapheresis can select patients for who plerixafor is needed or not.

Assessing the HLA diversity of cord blood units collected from a birth clinic caring for pregnant women in an ethnically diverse metropolitan area J. Magalon (1) One advantage over registries of unrelated donors (UD) is that Cord blood banks (CBB) may off er more HLA diversity, and thus that suitable Cord Blood Units (CBU) may be identifi ed for a higher proportion of diff erent geographic origin individuals that are candidates for allogeneic transplantation. Thus, one of the goals of the Marseilles CBB that operates within the French network of CBB (RFSP) is to take advantage of the genetically diverse population that lives in the Marseilles metropolitan area due to its location on the Mediterranean shore and a long history of immigration. The Marseilles CBB principally works with one of the Marseilles University birth clinic that cares for an ethically, culturally, sociologically and ethnically diverse population of pregnant women. The aim of our study was to measure to which extent collecting CBU in these conditions would contribute to an increase in HLA diversity. Generic resolution HLA-A, -B, and allelic resolution -DRB1 genotyping was performed by SSO molecular techniques (oneλ) on 328 mothers and CBU collected between October 2010 and May 2012, as per standard SOPs. Observed HLA frequencies were compared with those from UD registered in southeastern France. Identifi cation of putative HLA haplotypes CBU was deduced using the maternal HLA typing and data published by Maïers et al in 2007. Finally, the enrichment of international UD and UCB registries in new HLA phenotypes was assessed: a CBU was considered as enriching the registry when no 6/6 matched CBU or UD was identifi ed in the respective registries. When compared to southeastern France UD characteristics, Marseilles CBUs display an increased frequency of HLA antigens that are frequent in populations of African origin, whereas antigens highly expressed in populations of European origin are proportionally less represented. Two putative HLA haplotypes were identifi ed as "European" for 129 CBUs (39,3%) while at least one putative haplotype was not present in Maïers' database for 142 CBUs (43, 29%) . This latter group enriched the CBUs registry in 93% of cases, and adds new possibilities to identify a suitable unrelated graft with 68% of HLA diversity enrichment in the BMDR. CBU with two putative "European" haplotypes contributed more modestly to increasing enrichment: 42% for CBUs registry and 7% for BMDR. We conclude that the activity of the Marseilles CBB increases the genetic diversity of banked CBU. In total, the clinical relevance of such HLA diversity CBU will only be confi rmed by their recruitment.

Experiences of autologous peripheral blood stem cell mobilization and engraftment after autologous stem cell transplantation with "biosimilar" fi lgrastim (Zarzio ®, Sandoz, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor) L. Gopcsa (1), P. Remenyi (1) , N. Adamkovich (2) Introduction: Biosimilar version of fi lgrastim (Zarzio ®, Sandoz, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, G-CSF) is now widely available. Biosimilar G-CSF has very similar features to the original recombinant G-CSF and has comparable quality, safety and eff ectivity profi le. Methods: In our study, 70 patients with diff erent hematological malignancies scheduled to receive biosimilar G-CSF after autologous haematopoietic stem cell transplantatation (AHSCT) for facilitating engraftment. Furthermore, 21 additional patients with lymphoid malignancies scheduled to receive biosimilar G-CSF following chemotherapy for autologous peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) mobilization were included. Results: Among 70 patients who recieved AHSCT the median age was 56 years, including 42 male and 28 female. The diseases were: 41 multiple myeloma (MM), 19 Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), 10 Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). The conditioning regimen was mainly high-dose Melphalan (N=41) or BEAM (N=21). At time of AHSCT, the median number of reinfused CD34+ cells was 6,33x10 6 /kg (range 2-17,4x10 6 /kg). Median time of > 0,5 G/l absolute neutrophyl leukocyte engraftment were 9 days (range 8-11 days). Median time of 20 G/l platelet engraftment was 10,5 days (range 7-19 days). Twenty one patients with planned AHSCT received chemotherapy followed by administration of biosimilar G-CSF after the last day of chemotherapy for PBSC mobilization. The median age of patients was 55 years, including 13 female and 8 male. According to diagnosis, the diseases were: 11 MM, 8 NHL, 2 HL. Mobilization regimen was following: 10 patients with Cyclophosphamide+biosimilar G-CSF, 11 patients with salvage regimens+biosimilar G-CSF. 19/21 patients were harvested successfully. Median time interval between day 1 of the cycle of mobilization-chemotherapy and fi rst leukapheresis was 12 days (range 9-27). The median yield of CD34+ cells was 3,0x10 6 /kg (range 0,81-24,7 x 10 6 /kg) in one leukapheresis collection. In the autologous PBSC grafts, the median number of the CD34+ cells was 5,83 x 10 6 /kg (range 2,22-24,7 x 10 6 /kg). Conclusion: Biosimilar G-CSF after AHSCT showed as eff ective as our earlier results with G-CSF in the engraftment setting. Biosimilar S115 G-CSF is comparable to G-CSF for kinetics of PBSC mobilzation and yield of stem cells collected.We emphasize that use of biosimilar G-CSF is eff ective in PBSC mobilization and facilitating engraftment after AHSCT as well.

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor with or without chemotherapy is the most commonly used mobilization treatment. The target CD34+ harvest for a single transplant is 4 x 10 6 /Kg, but current mobilization regimens yield inadequate CD34+ cell doses in 5-40% of pts (To L. Bik et al., Blood 2011) . Despite known prognostic factors negatively aff ecting successful stem cell collection (i.e. age, underlying disease, previous alkylating therapy, prior irradiation), predicting poor mobilization is current challenge. Objectives: To defi ne predictive parameters of inadequate stem cell mobilization. Material and Methods: A total of 438 mobilization procedures (170 MM and 268 lymphoma pts) performed at our institution in the last 17 years were retrospectively analyzed. The following parameters were considered: CD34+/ul and CD34+% (ISHAGE protocol) from the fi rst day of WBC≥1x10 3 /ul (day 1) until procedure end or failure. The overall CD34+ yield for each collection was calculated as the sum of all the apheresis. Less than 2x10 6 CD34+/Kg was considered a collection failure. Linear regression (R test) for correlations, Mann-Whitney test for diff erences between medians and ROC curve analysis for identifi cation of cut-off levels were used. Overall 438 procedures were done: 69 (16%) failed, while 78% reached the target of CD34+/kg>4x10 6 . There was a linear correlation between CD34+ harvest and levels of both CD34+/ul (R 0,58, p<0,0001) and CD34+% at day 1 (R 0,65, p<0,0001), with lower median levels of CD34+/ul and CD34+% in patients who failed mobilization (4 vs 42/ul and 0,06 vs 0,83%, respectively, p<0,0001). Ninety-eight percent of pts with CD34+/ul>20 at day 1 harvested more than 4x10 6 CD34+/kg. For pts with CD34+/ul<20 at day 1, CD34+%>0.5 predicted an adequate mobilization in 97% of the cases and CD43 less than 0.05% an inadequate mobilization in more than 80% of the cases. For CD34+/ul<20 and CD34+%<0,1 at day 2, NPV was 88%. Conclusions: Our results indicate that CD34+/ul<20 and CD34%<0,05% at day 1 are predictive of failure. When CD34+/ ul<20 and CD34+%<0,1 at day 2, the use of alternative strategies (i.e. plerixafor) could represent a way to actively mobilize in an otherwise diffi cult setting.

body_text.text: Prediction of poor mobilizers allows for early plerixafor administration: the Pamplona protocol M.P. Sanchez Anton, M. Antelo, A. Zabalza, S. Zalba, M. Aznar, E. Vicente, I. Aoiz, E. Olavarria Complejo Hospitalario de Navarra (Pamplona, ES) The role of Plerixafor in routine peripheral blood progenitor cells (PBPC) mobilization in Myeloma or Lymphoma patients remains to be established. In our institution we have developed a mobilization guideline (The Pamplona Protocol) to assess the safety and effi cacy of Plerixafor + G-CSF in patients predicted to be poor mobilizers (PM). The Pamplona protocol classifi es patients according to PM risk factors including: a) previous mobilization failure; b) advanced disease; c) prior extensive radiotherapy; d) prior Hyper-CVAD, Fludarabine, Lenalidomide or alkylating agents; e) extensive BM involvement; f ) >2 lines of chemotherapy; and g) age > 65. Patients with ≥3 risk factors classify as PM and a PB CD34+ cell count is taken on day 4 of mobilization. All other patients have a CD34+ cell count on day 5 immediately before the apheresis procedure. Plerixafor is administered at 6pm subcutaneously (0.24 mg/Kg) to: a) patients with a circulating CD34+ cell count < 10/uL (on either day 4 or 5) and b) patients with a fi rst apheresis yield < 1.0 x 10 6 CD34+/kg. G-CSF continues at the same dose (5-10 ug/Kg) and an apheresis is scheduled for the following morning. Since October 2009, a total of 146 patients were managed according to the Pamplona Protocol. 11 out of the 13 patients (85%) who were classifi ed as PM before mobilization (9%) had a circulating CD34+ cell count < 10/uL on day 4 and received Plerixafor as planned, demonstrating the high positive predictive value of the protocol. In addition, 9 patients (6%) failed to mobilize on day 5 despite having a median of 0.77 risk factors and also received Plerixafor. The diagnosis for the 20 patients that received Plerixafor was MM (n= 7), NHL (n=11), HL and Amyloidosis (n=1 each). We observed a median of 3 fold increase in the number of CD34 circulating cells. The median CD34+ cell dose harvested was 2.86 x 10 6 /Kg (range 0.32-5.69). There were no diff erences between the CD34+ cell dose in patients receiving Plerixafor on day 4 (median 2.6 x 10 6 /Kg) and day 5 (median 3.1 x 10 6 /Kg). The median number of apheresis was 1 (1) (2) (3) . Only one patient failed to mobilize suffi cient CD34+ cells. G-CSF and Plerixafor treatment was well tolerated. Adverse events were grade 1 in severity and were mostly gastrointestinal. The Pamplona Protocol was able to predict PM before G-CSF administration allowing for early Plerixafor administration. Despite a 13.7% of PM in our series, 145/146 (99%) patients were able to harvest suffi cient CD34+ cells for autologous SCT.

Chemnitz, S. Theurich, N. Skoetz, C. Scheid, M. von-Bergwelt-Baildon University Hospital Cologne (Cologne, DE) Background: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is an established treatment option for haematological malignancies. In the last two decades peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) predominantly replaced bone marrow (BM) as stem cell source due to faster engraftment and immune reconstitution as well as practicability issues. As transplant indications and conditioning regimens have changed, it is still under debate whether the choice of the stem cell source may have impact on the transplant outcome. Objectives: To assess the effect of BM versus PBSC transplantation in haematological malignancies with regard to overall survival, incidence of relapse and non-relapse mortality (NRM), disease free survival (DFS), incidence of GvHD and time to engraftment. Search methods/ Selction criteria: We searched the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE (from 1948 to present), trials registries and conference proceedings. The search was conducted in 10/2011 (update 11/2012) for randomised controlled trials comparing BM and PBSC transplantation in haematological malignancies. Data collection and analysis: Two review authors independently screened abstracts, extracted data and analysed the data. We contacted study authors for additional information. Results: In this meta-analysis we included eight randomised controlled trials involving a total of 995 participants. The primary outcome overall survival was not signifi cantly diff erent between the study groups (HR 1.21 Conclusion: Overall and disease-free survival as well as NRM are not aff ected by the stem cell source although there was significantly more chronic GvHD with PBSC used. This Cochrane analysis confi rms older analyses with a longer follow-up and a larger patient cohort.

body_text.text: Skeletal disease in myeloma patients is yet another independent risk factor to predict poor mobilization in myeloma patients: need for upfront plerixafor? P. Lokireddy, A. Hunter, S. Gribbin, S. Ward University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust (Leicester, GB) There is increasing use of Plerixafor, a novel CXCR4 inhibitor in mobilizing Peripheral Blood Stem Cells (PBSC) particularly in patients who failed with conventional methods. The safety and preliminary effi cacy of Plerixafor in combination with chemotherapy and G-CSF has been established. (1) There are many known factors, which infl uence poor mobilisation including bone marrow disease, multiple treatments, age and certain chemotherapy. (2) There is some data to suggest Plerixafor delays platelet engraftment. We are authorized to use Plerixafor only in failed harvests, as per our local guidelines. We have performed retrospective analysis of patients who underwent PBSC collections from July 2009 to April 2012. We specifi cally analysed data for reviewing neutrophil and platelet engraftment times. We also examined characteristics of the Plerixafor group in terms of risk factors for failed mobilisation. Out of 134 autografts, 113 received conventional mobilisation and 21 Plerixafor mobilisations (15% of total autografts) and Only one patient failed to harvest with Plerixafor. Neutrophil engraftment is established when the neutrophil count reaches 0.5x 109/l, Platelet engraftment is achieved with a platelet count of 50 x 109/l and above. Neutrophil engraftment time for Plerixafor is comparable to the non Plerixafor group (median time to engraftment is 16 days in both groups), 75% of patients have shown neutrophil engraftment within 20 days in both groups. Fifty fi ve percent of patients had platelet engraftment in the non Plerixafor group compared to forty six percent in the Plerixafor group with in thirty-day period. The median platelet engraftment was 33 days in the Plerixafor group compared to 37 days in the non Plerixafor group. There were no reported side eff ects noted in Plerixafor group. We specifi cally looked at the Myeloma group who required Plerixafor and analyzed known parameters to look for the cause of failed mobilisation. Out of twenty-one there were only two patients with multiple treatments and only one patient in the cohort had cytopaenia. There was no documented evidence of sepsis and none had prior exposure of Lenolidamide or Melphalan. Not all patients had a bone marrow aspirate prior to harvest or at the end of treatment, hence we could not correlate marrow hypoplasia with failed mobilisation. The striking parameters were patients with extensive disease at presentation and with skeletal disease and Plasmacytoma seems to correlate with poor mobilization. Sixty four percent of plerixafor group had extensive skeletal disease compared to forty percent in non plerixafor mobilised group. Risk adapted strategies for pre-emptive (3), salvage use or upfront use of Plerixafor as a fi rst line PBSC mobiliser for high risk patients like high tumour burden, skeletal disease, multiple treatments, patients with poor marrow reserve will prevent delays and unnecessary anxiety to patients. Optimizing plerixafor use in poor mobilizers. Should remobilization or 'on demand' use be preferred? A single-centre experience I. Marton, Á. Báthori, Á. Bereczki, D. Földeák, N. Adamkovich, S. Modok, T. Gurbity -Pálfi , A. Szoke, K. Piukovics, É. Trucza, É. Pósfai, Z. Borbényi University of Szeged Albert Szent-Györgyi Medical Center (Szeged, HU) Objective: The most common stem cell source of autologous stem cell tranplantation is the mobilized peripheral blood. To assess plerixafor use in poor mobilizers to survey the incidence of patients with poor mobilization and to evaluate the eff ectiveness of remobilization strategy, and "pre-emptive use". Methods: In our retrospective analysis (2009) (2010) (2011) (2012) , 86 patients' mobilization procedure was analyzed, 45 female, 41 male with median age of 57 years (range: 19-69 years). 53 myeloma multiplex; 19 non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and 14 Hodgkin lymphoma patients. 11 patients (13%) required plerixafor for the successful completion [P524] S119 of mobilization. Remobilization group (group 1) and a pre-emptive group (group 2) were created. Group 1 contained 5 patients, who had previously one or more unsuccessful mobilization attempts. Group 2 contained 6 patients, who had never been mobilized before in which 3 patients were defi ned as predicted poor mobilizers and 3 patients were diffi cult to mobilize due to poor stem cell mobilization kinetics. The target yield was > 4 x 10 6 CD34+ cells/kg body weight. All patients received plerixafor plus G-CSF with or without chemotherapy. Plerixafor was administered depending on the kinetics of CD34+ cells and white blood cell recovery. Results: In group 1 the median of circulating CD34+ cells after plerixafor administration was 36 cell/microl (range: 9-150) versus group 2 in which 45 cell/microl (range: 25-63) could be observed. The median of collected CD34+/kg cells was 7.11x10 6 /kg (range: 4.38 -13.2) in group 1, whereas in group 2 the median was 5.02x10 6 / kg (range: 3.08-6.34). Median apheresis number was 4 (range: [1] [2] [3] [4] in group 1,in group 2 the median was 3 (range: [2] [3] [4] . Two patients in group 1 required 2 remobilization. The average plerixafor dose in group1 was 2.5 vials, in group 2 it was 1.66 vials by which the required target cell number could be achieved. From 11 patients 9 underwent stem cell transplantation and were engrafted. Conclusions: All detailed patients achieved the required target cell number for ASCT. Plerixafor could be combined with G-CSF only or chemomobilization strategy. Our experience confi rmed the view that pre-emptive administration of plerixafor may rescue the mobilization process, and enable the patient to proceed to ASCT without delay. The kinetics of hematopoietic recovery after chemotherapy may allow for early (just in time) intervention with plerixafor and may help reduce the risk of the mobilization failure.

body_text.text: We evaluated in 2012 the Amicus Separator (Fenwal) as an alternate platform to collect mononuclear cells (MNC). The objective was to assess procedure performance and safety. Methods: A total of 17 Amicus (SW 4.3) autologous stem cell collections were compared with 17 Spectra procedures matched from the database (N=2427) for similar patient characteristics, mobilization regimen, blood counts and processed volumes. Data was also compared with previously performed procedures on Com.Tec and Optia. The Amicus Separator (software V.4.3) was set up with: 12:1 WB: ACD-A ratio, number of cycles (10 cycles ± 3), blood volume per cycle (1000ml if WBC > 35/μl or 1400ml if WBC < 35/μl), MNC off set (2.3 ml to 1.5 ml) and RBC off set (6.0 ml). The performance was evaluated based on 1) CD 34+ effi ciency; 2) CD34+ yield; 3) Procedure time; 4) Patient PLT depletion; 5) Overall cell content of the collected product; 6) Adverse events. Results: CD34+ collection effi ciency (N=16) was 44.4± 14.8% for Amicus vs 50.2 ± 20.5% for Spectra. CD34+ yield (N=17) was 6.3 ± 11.0 x 10E6 /kg for Amicus vs 4.4 ± 4.7 x 10E6 /kg for Spectra. Collection time (N=17) was 295 ± 42 min for Amicus and 248 ± 31 min for Spectra. Harvested platelets (N=16) were 4.8 ± 1.2 % for Amicus vs 26.5 ± 18.7 % for Spectra corresponding to a patient platelet loss of respectively 11.4 ± 11.0% (N=17) vs 40.8 ± 21.1% (N=15). The overall cell content for Amicus and Spectra is shown in graph 1. The key performance indicators for the four tested apheresis platforms are presented in table 1. Adverse events with Amicus were mild. No citrate related reactions were observed. Conclusion: CD34+ collection effi ciency with Amicus was satisfactory and comparable to Spectra with signifi cantly lower platelet depletion from the patient. Yield and purity of the collected product are predictable. Performance of the four tested separators is overall comparable with the exception of the lower platelet loss with Amicus. The full automated control of the cell separation and collection frees up operators from manual monitoring, while he still have the possibility to adjust parameters during the procedure.

Preemptive use of plerixafor in patients with lymphoproliferative diseases undergoing haematopoietic stem cell mobilization V. Telonis, T. Vassilakopoulos, E. Lalou, G. Boutsikas, Z. Galani, M. Moschogiannis, A. Dimitrakopoulou, C. Kalpadaki, A. Meletiou, K. Anargyrou, S. Sachanas, P. Flevari, G. Gainaru, A. Koutsi, L. Papageorgiou, A. Zannou, M. Dimou, N. Vyniou, P. Panayiotidis, M.-C. Kyrtsonis, P. Tsaftaridis, J. Meletis, M. Angelopoulou National and Kapodistrian University of Athens (Athens, GR) Plerixafor is a CXCR4 inhibitor that disrupts the adhesion of hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) to bone marrow stroma resulting in the mobilization of HSC to peripheral blood. It is indicated in combination with G-CSF in poor mobilizers. Using Plerixafor, patients in whom HSC collection has failed succeed in collecting suffi cient numbers of CD34+ HSC and may undergo subsequent autologous [P526] S120 stem cell transplantation. Aim: To evaluate the preemptive use of plerixafor in lymphoma and myeloma patients undergoing HSC collection. Methods: We retrospectively evaluated all patients from a single Hematology Unit in whom plerixafor was used preemptively: Patients were mobilized with chemotherapy or G-CSF and were not intended to receive plerixafor, unless absolute peripheral blood CD34 counts at the expected peak day were either below <20/μL or suboptimal for the desired HSC target. Results: Rescue plerixafor was used in 32 patients and 38 mobilization attempts; 6 patients underwent 2 mobilization procedures. Their median age at mobilization was 54 years, there were 18 females and 14 males, 12 had multiple myeloma, 1 Hodgkin and 19 non-Hodgkin lymphoma, 22 had received 1-2 prior chemotherapy regimens, whereas 16 patients ≥3 and 84% were chemosensitive. Mobilizing regimens included platinum-based chemotherapy in 6 (16%), ifosfamide-based in 6 (16%), cyclophosphamide in 13 (34%) and G-CSF in 13 (34%). Plerixafor was administered once, twice or thrice in 20, 11 and 7 cases respectively. One collection was performed in 16 patients, two in 14 and 3 in 8 patients. The median absolute CD34 counts after plerixafor (CD34-post) were signifi cantly higher compared to those before Plerixafor (CD34pre), i.e. 37.5/μL (4-208) vs 19.2/μL (2.6-67) , respectively, p<0.001. The median total number of CD34+cells/kg collected was 4.025 x 106/kg (0.49-16.77) and the median number of CD34+cells/kg per collection was 2.415 x 106/kg. Univariate prognostic factor analysis is shown in the table. Conclusion: Preemptive use of plerixafor according to circulating absolute CD34 counts at the expected days of peak results in suffi cient HSC collections, and might prove more cost-eff ective.

body_text.text: 'Platelet gel from cord blood' national project: preliminary data on internal validation at the Pavia cord blood bank I. Sbarsi (1) , P. Bergamaschi (1)

Cord blood (CB) represents an alternative stem cell source for transplantation in patients aff ected by haematological diseases. An accurate evaluation of all CB characteristics and maternal medical history ensures that only those units suitable for clinical use according to FACT-Netcord standards are banked. This leads to discard a huge amount of collected CB units. Recently the Milano CB Bank launched the idea to produce platelet gel (PG) from CB not eligible for unrelated transplantation and is coordinating a national project for applying CBPG to wounds repair in diabetic patients. At the Pavia CB Bank we modifi ed the protocol by Mazzucco at al. to verify its feasibility in producing CBPG in our setting. Only CB units with total nucleated cells <1x10 9 and platelet >200 x10 6 /ml were enrolled in this study. CB was collected, with mother's informed consent, in collection kit containing 22 ml CPDA (JMS) and was processed within 48 hours. After addition of 10 ml ACD and saline to a fi nal volume of 150 ml, CBPG was obtained with a three-step procedure: fi rst, a soft spin centrifugation (180 g x 10 min) to obtain platelet-rich plasma (PRP); second, an additional soft spin centrifugation (100g x 10min) to remove leukocytes as much as possible; third, an high-spin centrifugation (1000g x 10min) to pellet the platelets. Then platelet concentrate (PC) was resuspended in 8 ml of platelet poor plasma (PPP) and frozen at -80°C. A 6 mL plastic bag was used to ensure storage and transport conditions appropriate for clinical purposes (SIAD Healthcare). After thawing, CB-PCs were pooled according to ABO compatibility to reach 1.5-2 x10 9 platelets/ml and batroxobin (Plateltex-Act ®) was added according to the manufacturer instructions. 25 CB units with a mean platelet concentration of 255 x10 6 /ml were processed to obtain PCs with a mean platelet content of 835 x10 6 /ml and 35% of platelet recovery on average. Leukocyte contamination was always < 1 x 10 6 . Sterility testing performed at the end of processing resulted negative in all CB-PCs except of one. The addiction of batroxobin to pooled CB-PCs was able to obtain gelation demonstrating that this adapted protocol is feasible in producing CBPG in our hands. In future this strategy will rescue unsuitable CB to a new diff erent clinical use and reduce the discard rate in CB Banks. This will favorably impact on both donor's mothers' and collection site personnel's expectations: to be helpful for patients.

Zarzio plus chemotherapy as peripheral blood stem cell mobilization strategy in patients with haematological diseases candidated to autologous stem cell transplantation A. Ostuni, M.R. Morciano, A. Mele, M. Fina, D. Carlino, G. Greco, S. Sibilla, R. De Francesco, B. Rossini, C. Derisi, V. Pavone Hospital G Panico (Tricase, IT) Introduction: Biosimilar granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) has been recently approved for mobilization of peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC). Various recent reports describe a comparable effi cacy as original G-CSF with a signifi cant reduction of costs. In this study we assessed safety and effi cacy of Zarzio (Zarzio ® Sandoz Biopharmaceuticals) in order to mobilize PBSC in patients (pts) with hematological malignancies and to ensure an optimal engrafment capability. Methods: From June 2011 to December 2012, a cohort of 44 pts was studied. All pts received disease specifi c chemotherapy plus Zarzio at a dose of 5μg/kg body weight twice daily. Programmed CD34+ cells target dose was 4x10 6 /kg for pts with non-Hodgkin and Hodgkin Lymphomas, Leukemia and 6x10 6 /kg for Multiple Myeloma. Plerixafor was used in predicted poor mobilizer pts. Amicus Fenwal separator was used in all leukapheresis procedures. Results: Patients' demographic characteristics are listed in table 1. Median time of Zarzio administration was 8.2 days; 38 pts (86%) reached the target dose to perform autologous stem cell transplantation with an average number of apheresis of 1.45. Collection data are in table 2. Poor mobilization was documented in 13 pts (29%), mainly of them received more than 3 chemotherapy regimens previously. Six pts failed mobilization, two of them even after the administration of Plerixafor. Among pts who have mobilized, 21 (55.3%) were submitted to high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous (18) or allogenic (3) PBSC infusion. Median of CD34x10 6 /kg infuse and viability were 4.3 x10 6 /kg (0.8-6.2) and 75. 3% (51.4-88.2) , respectively. Engraftment occurred in all pts. The median time to absolute nucleated cells >500 and to platelets >20000 was 12 days (10-23) and 14 (10-33) after CD34+ infusion, respectively. Conclusion: Biosimilar G-CSF, such as Zarzio, may represent an eff ective strategy for PBSC mobilization and collection after chemotherapy in terms of CD34+ cell dose and timing of collection. A study of comparison will be necessary to establish advantages in terms of cost.

body_text.text: Comparison of 'plerixafor rescue' with standard use of plerixafor in autologous donors who fail mobilization following G-CSF with or without prior chemotherapy K. Wilson, D. Powell, S. Thompson, S. Phillips, W

cite_spans.text: Wilson, D. Powell, S. Thompson, S. Phillips, W

body_text.text: Background: Autologous haematopoietic progenitor cell transplantation (HPCT) is an established treatment for selected patients with lymphoma or multiple myeloma. However 15-30% of patients fail mobilisation making them ineligible for HPCT. Plerixafor is a selective reversible CXCR4 antagonist which, when used in combination with granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF), results in successful mobilisation in 60-85% of patients who previously failed mobilisation. Rationale: Plerixafor was approved for use in Wales for lymphoma and myeloma patients who failed mobilisation, precluding use in patients predicted to fail mobilisation. The ability to rescue a failed mobilisation attempt would minimise the under-utilisation of apheresis slots and prevent the need to re-book patients for harvest making the collection programme more effi cient and potentially reducing cost. Methods: To comply with use only in failed mobilisers, plerixafor rescue was limited to patients whose peripheral blood (PB) CD34 count after four consecutive days of G-CSF at a dose of 10 mcg/ kg (without prior chemotherapy) was insuffi cient to proceed to apheresis. These patients were given a fi fth dose of G-CSF followed by plerixafor 240 mcg/kg at 2200 h. On day 6 a further dose of G-CSF was given at 0800h followed by apheresis. Further plerixafor and G-CSF were given as required up to a maximum of 4 plerixafor doses. Patients failing mobilisation following G-CSF and chemotherapy were re-mobilised with the standard plerixafor protocol consisting of G-CSF 10 mcg/kg days 1-4, plerixafor 240 mcg/kg at 2200 h on d4 followed by G-CSF on d5 at 0800h followed by apheresis. Up to 4 doses of plerixafor were allowed. Results: Between May 2011 and October 2012, 120 collections were performed using G-CSF with (n = 70) or without (n = 50) prior chemotherapy. G-CSF alone was limited to myeloma patients attaining at least a very good partial response (VGPR). All other patients were mobilised with cyclophosphamide (myeloma patients without VGPR)or salvage chemotherapy (lymphoma patients) + G-CSF (chemo-G). Priming failure was higher with G-CSF (13/50 = 26%) than with chemo-G (4/70 = 6%) and with cyclophosphamide (25%) than salvage chemotherapy (4%). Nine of 11(82%) plerixafor rescue attempts were successful compared with 13/15 (87%) standard plerixafor for an overall plerixafor success rate of 22/26 (85%). Conclusion: Plerixafor rescue used after G-CSF mobilisation failure is as eff ective as re-mobilisation and prevents wastage of apheresis slots. van der Veeken, E.H.C.M. Römers, A. Kelder, F. Kessler, A. Dräger, J.J.W.M. Janssen, G.J. Schuurhuis VU University Medical Center (Amsterdam, NL) Introduction: In an allogeneic MUD transplantation, a transplant centre requires a minimum number of CD34 positive cells. If not reached the time to engraftment, the critical clinical care period for the patient and the duration of hospital stay may be aff ected. Sometimes the number of CD34+ cells determined by the collection centre is diff erent from that determined by the transplant centre. The most critical situation emerges when, according to the collection centre, the minimum number of CD34+ cells was harvested while according to the transplant centre the required minimum number has not been reached. These discrepancies were also seen in the grafts with large CD34+ amounts. We investigated whether these discrepancies are related to the time period between collection and transplantation or the white blood cell (WBC) concentration of the graft. Method: In a retrospective analysis in 132 MUD transplantations performed from September 2008 until October 2012, the total number of CD34+ in the graft was determined both by the collection centre and the transplant centre. From these data, the recovery of CD34+ cells was determined and the two factors of possible infl uence were assessed. Results: In the 132 MUD transplantations, the CD34 yield measured in the transplant centre was median of 97% (range 56 to 147%) of values in collection centre. The transplant centre found 24 cases that did not contain the requested minimal amount of CD34+ cells. A graft failure occurred in 5 of these 24 transplantations (21%) compared to only 9 of 108 other transplants (8%). In 9/24 cases only the collection centre reported enough CD34 yield, but these contained 2/5 graft failures. In transplants with a time period between collection and transplantation less than 40 hrs the median CD34 recovery was 93% (78%-129%); with a time period > 40 hrs 98% (56%-147)(no signifi cant: p=0.60). Regression analysis shows no correlation between the WBC concentration and the CD34 recovery; r 2 =0.012. When divided in 3 groups (WBC in millions per ml), ie <200, in between 200 and 300 and >300, CD34 recoveries were median 94% (62%-129%), 97% (63%-130%) and 97% (56%-147%). Conclusion: In roughly 10% of the transplants, graft failure was observed; this occurred in grafts with too low CD34 content according to both collection centre and transplant centre but also according to transplant centre alone. Discrepancies between collection and transplant centre CD34+ are not related to time period between collection and transplantation or WBC concentration.

body_text.text: Collection of peripheral blood stem cells in patients and donors using the Amicus ® Separator and the Spectra Optia®

A. Sputtek (1) , C. Schubert (1), S. Peine (1) , A. Rowe (2) (1)University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf (Hamburg, DE) ; (2) New York University School of Medicine (New York, US) Because technical support of the Cobe ® Spectra Apheresis System after 2014 is uncertain, we therefore compared the eff ectiveness of two alternative blood cell separators, i.e. the Spectra Optia ® Apheresis System and the Amicus ® Separator. After mobilization using G-CSF alone or G-CSF plus Plerixafor, 36 PBSC components were collected with each machine from patients and healthy donors, with 15 persons undergoing procedures with both machines. We tried to adjust the process time to 4 h (Amicus: 250 ±15 min, Optia 244 ± 15 min, mean ± standard deviation), irrespective of the processed blood volumes. As a consequence the volumes diff ered signifi cantly (P = 0.006, two-tailed Mann-Whitney-U-test): 10.9 ± 1.9 L for the Amicus and 9.8 ± 1.6 L for the Optia. But the volumes of the anticoagulant ACD-A used (942 ± 166 ml for the Amicus and 924 ± 138 ml for the Optia, respectively) did not diff er significantly. The numbers of collected CD34+ cells, CD34+ collection effi ciencies, and CD34+ collection rates amounted to 386 ± 413 x 10 6 , 64.6 ±14.6%, 1.55 ±1.65 x 10 6 /min (Amicus) and 378 ± 404 x 10 6 , 71.1 ± 12.0%, 1.56 ±1.69 /min (Optia), respectively. However, these diff erences were not signifi cant (P > 0.05). The components collected with the Amicus contained 21.3 ± 8.5 x 10 9 mononuclear cells compared with 18.4 ± 8.7 x 10 9 , for the Optia, however, this diff erence was not signifi cant as well. Whereas the Optia products showed a slightly higher contamination with granulocytes (11.0 ± 6,9 x 10 9 ) vs. 9.2 ± 4.8 for the Amicus, this diff erence was not signifi cant. Product hematocrits due to contaminating red cells were twice as high for the Amicus (0.029 ± 0.016 l/l) in comparison to the Optia (0.013 ± 0.019 l/l), and this was a signifi cant diff erence (P < 0.0001). On the other hand, the number of platelets contained in the Optia products was almost 4 times higher than in the case of the Amicus products (2.6 ± 1.5 x 10 11 vs. 0.7 ± 0.3 x 10 11 , P < 0.0001 ). We observed typical moderate citrate related reactions (perioral discomfort, paresthesia, nausea) in 4 out of the 72 runs, all of them could be stopped by either oral or intravenous Ca 2+ administration. In conclusion, both blood cell separators showed a good performance for peripheral blood stem cell collections in patients and donors and are suitable to replace the Cobe ® Spectra Apheresis System.

Modelling improvements in cell yield of banked umbilical cord blood and the impact on availability of donor units for transplantation into adults N. Kekre (1) , J. Philippe (2) , R. Mallick (1), S. Smith (2) , D. Allan (1) (1)University of Ottawa (Ottawa, CA); (2)Canadian Blood Services (Ottawa, CA) Background: Umbilical cord blood (UCB) is used increasingly as an alternative source of hematopoietic stem cells for allogeneic transplantation. Thresholds of pre-storage cell numbers associated with timely engraftment are well established yet availability of adequate donor units continues to be lacking for many patients and especially adults. We postulate that even modest improvements in the yield of cells following storage and thawing will allow more patients to fi nd suitable units with suffi cient cell numbers and proceed to transplant. Methods: We utilized 21 consecutive anonymous umbilical cord blood searches performed by Canadian Blood Services to simulate the impact of improved cell yield. Published criteria were used for selecting UCB units from the anonymized searches based on total nucleated cells (TNC) per kg recipient weight and in accordance with the degree of HLA matching. The number of donors available per patient was calculated based on hypothetical recipient weight of 50 kg, 70 kg and 90 kg. The analysis was repeated by increasing the fraction of cells surviving storage and thawing by 10%, 20% and 30%. Results: Increasing the percentage of cells that survive storage by 30% lowered the TNC threshold used to select UCB units and demonstrated an increase in UCB units available for patients weighing 50 (p=0.011), 70, (p=0.014) and 90 kg (p=0.003), controlling for diff erences in HLA compatibility using a mixed eff ects analysis. Moreover, if recipients were 90 kg, 12 out of 21 patients had access to at least one UCB unit that met standard criteria, and this increased to 19 out of 21 patients (p=0.035) when the fraction of cells surviving storage and thawing increased by 30%. Conclusion: We conclude that a modest increase in the yield of cells in banked UCB units can signifi cantly increase donor options for adult patients undergoing HSCT. Improved processing, cryopreservation and storage techniques could allow substantially more patients to undergo HSCT using UCB.

One step can make a diff erence in the optimization of stem cell collection S.M. Tan, S. Bai Renganathan, M.Z. Zakaria, T.C. Ong, Y.K. Guan, F. Kassim, A.S. Nordin, J. Tan, J.S. Rajasuriar, A.N. Kori, X. Sim, K.M. Chang Hospital Ampang (Ampang, MY) Introduction: Peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) harvesting and storage incur signifi cant cost and resources. For the last thirteen years since we started our autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) service, the cases have been increased tremendously. We implemented mobilizing patients based on peripheral blood CD34 count (PB-CD34) cutoff points at least 10/uL as one of our optimization of PBSC collection measures since June 2011. Method and results: We compared the outcome of PBSC collection in 18 months before (pre) and after (post) the implementation of mobilizing patients based on PB-CD34 cutoff points at least 10/uL. A total of 499 patients (215 pre and 284 post implementation) have been subjected for PBSC mobilization using G-CSF alone or in combination with chemotherapy mainly consists of high dose cyclophosphamide or etoposide since November 2009. Only 394 patients (78.96%) (182 pre and 212 post implementation) managed to undergo apheresis. Majority were lymphoma patients (Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) 189; 47.97% and Hodgkin's disease (HD) 92; 23.35%), followed by multiple myeloma (MM) 70; 17.77% and acute leukaemia (acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) 36; 9.14% and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) 7; 1.78%). There was no statistic difference in disease, age and gender distribution in between both groups. Among the 182 patients who underwent apheresis in pre implementation cohort, only 133 patients (73.07%) were successfully mobilized >2x10 6 /kg of CD34 as compared to 195 patients (91.98%) among the 212 patients in post implementation cohort. 96 cases were mobilized with PB-CD34 below 10/uL among pre implementation cohort as compared to 21 cases in post implementation cohort retrospectively. Furthermore, there were more patients underwent inappropriate PBSC collection (97.87% versus 40%) among the pre implementation cohort when mobilized with PB-CD34 below 10/uL. By using one step measure of deciding PBSC mobilization based on PB-CD34 cutoff points at least 10/uL, we have improved the successfulness of PBSC collection more than 18% and reduced the wastage of more than 57%. The cost effectiveness after implementation of this measure will be presented later.

body_text.text: Background: The Amicus Separator (Fenwal) can be used to collect mononuclear cells (MNC). The procedure is automated and doesn't require operator intervention for controlling the separation. This allows limiting the variation of the collection performance. Another benefi t is the low platelet contamination of the MNC product avoiding signifi cant platelet loss in patients. Amicus Separator is also characterized by high MNC collection effi cacy. Mont-Godinne BTC uses both Amicus (Fenwal) and Spectra (Terumo BCT). We report on the comparison of Amicus and Spectra in our institution during one year. Methods: We compared routine procedures performed in 2011: 68 MNC collections with Amicus (SW 3.2) and 36 MNC collections with Spectra (SW 7.2). Amicus settings are adjusted based on the patient's white blood cells (WBC) pre-count. For WBC <25K/μl, the whole blood (WB) collected per cycle is 1200 ml , the maximum fl ow rate 65 ml/min and the RBC off set 7.0 ml while for WBC >25K/μl, the WB per cycle is 800-1000 ml, the maximum fl ow rate 80 ml/min and the RBC off set 8.0 ml. MNC off set is 2.3 ml and MNC set point 0.6 in both cases. The evaluated parameters were WBC yield, CD 34+ yield, CD34+ collection effi cacy and platelet depletion. The CD34+ collection effi cacy is defi ned as CD34+ yield / ((pre + post /2) * WB processed). The adverse reactions due to citrate intolerance were recorded We also studied a subset of 13 patients collected on both Amicus and Spectra on two consecutive days Results: Total blood volume processed and whole blood fl ow rate were signifi cantly higher on SPECTRA. Platelet depletion was signifi cantly lower on AMICUS (22 ± 20% vs 38 ± 13%) . No signifi cant diff erences were observed for WBC yield (176 ± 72.108 vs 204 ± 116.108), CD34 yield (252 ± 212.106 vs 208 ± 140.106), CD34 collection effi cacy (63 ± 14% vs 59 ± 15%) or CD34 yield per minute of collection (1.04 ± 0.97.106/min vs 1,11 ± 0,82.106/min). The number of cases of citrate intolerance was 17 (25%) for Amicus and 7 (19%) for Spectra. 6 procedures (8.8%) required IV calcium for Amicus and 4 (11.1%) for Spectra. No procedure was stopped. Data from the subset of 13 patients collected on both machines will be presented during the fi nal communication. Conclusion: The CD34 + collection effi cacy with Amicus is equivalent to Spectra but platelet depletion in patients is signifi cantly lower. The Spectra procedure is manually controlled. The Amicus MNC procedure is automatically controlled, not requiring significant operator interventions.

Autologous peripheral blood stem cell collection and transplantation in patients with multiple myeloma previously treated with thalidomide and/or lenalidomide using a cyclophosphamide-based mobilization regimen R.M. Grubovic, A. Alavi, G.J. Schiller University of California Los Angeles (Los Angeles, US) Background: High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous transplantation of peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) plays an important role in the management of multiple myeloma. In order for successful engraftment to occur, adequate numbers of high quality PBSC must be harvested prior to transplantation.

body_text.text: Mobilization of PBSC in heavily pretreated patients is often associated with unsuccessful harvests. The aim of this study is to present our experience utilizing an intermediate-dose cyclophosphamidebased mobilization regimen in multiple myeloma patients previously treated with Thalidomide and/or its analog Lenalidomide. Material and Method: This is a retrospective study performed at the Department of Medicine/Hematological Malignancy/Stem Cell Transplant Unit at UCLA between 2006 and 2011. All patients underwent a single mobilization regimen that included, Cyclophosphamide 2.5gm/m 2 iv once, Granulocyte Colony-Stimulating Factor (G-CSF) 10mcg/kg/day sc until collection day 1, and Prednisone 2mg/kg po daily x 5 in all multiple myeloma patients. Minimum dose required to ensure successful and sustained engraftment was 2x10 6 /kg CD34+cells, whereas the optimal dose was 5x10 6 /kg CD34+cells. PBSC harvesting was performed with COBE Spectra processing 2-2.5 total blood volume/per apheresis session. Results: Autologous PBSC transplantation was performed in 103 multiple myeloma patients with high-dose Melphalan. 212 autologous PSBC apheresis procedures were done, with median number of apheresis per patient of 1.0 (range1-12). Median age was 55.7y (range 32. 6-75.1) . 70 patients (68.9%) required just one collection to achieve the requisite number of cells, 15 patients required 2 collections (14.5%), and 14 patients (17.4%) had more than two collection procedures. There was only one patient with fewer than 2x10 6 /kg CD34+cells (0.9%) collected and he underwent bone marrow harvesting. Median CD34+cells collected were 6.7 x10 6 /kg, range (1.4-33.5x10 6 /kg CD34+cells). Median CD34+cells infused were 5.8 x10 6 /kg, range . Most patients achieved neutrophil recovery in 10 days (range 1-18). Conclusion: Despite pre-transplant use of Thalidomide and/or Lenalidomide, combination of G-CSF, Cyclophosphamide and Prednisone happened to be an excellent mobilization strategy which permits adequate collection with the majority of patients requiring only one apheresis procedure with mobilization failure in fewer than 1%.

The eff ect of diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease on the number of CD34+ cells in the blood C. Pala (1) The aim of this study was to investigate the eff ect of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and diabetes mellitus (DM) on the number of stem cells in the peripheral blood. Sixty-two patients diagnosed with ESRD who had not received dialysis previously, 25 patients with a diagnosis of DM without nephropathy, and 21 healthy volunteers were included in the study. The group diagnosed with ESRD was divided into two groups. First group (DM-CRD) consisted of 28 patients with DM who had developed chronic renal disease (CRD). Second group (NON-DM-CRD) consisted of 34 patients without DM who had CRD by etiology. The routine complete blood count, renal function, and number of CD34+ cells were determined for all of those involved in the study. The microalbumin/creatinine levels were measured, and glomerular fi ltration rates were calculated in all patients. The number of CD34+ cells was found to be signifi cantly lower in the DM control group and DM-CRD group compared with the healthy group. No statistically signifi cant diff erence was found between the NON-DM-CRD and the healthy control group. There was a moderate negative correlation between the ratio of microalbumin/creatinine and the number of CD34+ cells. A signifi cant reduction in the number of CD34+ cells was shown in subjects with DM and ESRD caused by diabetic nephropathy.

Outcome of stem cell mobilization following G-CSF versus G-CSF plus chemotherapy in adult patients with haematological malignancies W. Ingram (1), D. Powell (1) , S. Thompson (1) , D. Davies (1) , H. Bass (1) , J. Thomas (2) , S. Al-Ismail (2) , H. Sati (2) , S. Phillips (1), K. Wilson (1) (1)University Hospital of Wales (Cardiff , GB); (2)Singleton Hospital (Swansea, GB) The ability to mobilise adequate number of CD34+ stem cells is a pre-requisite for autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT). Selection of the optimal priming regimen is vital to maximise the CD34+ cell yield. Furthermore, adherence to priming protocols minimises adverse events such as prescribing errors and enhances effi ciency of the service through the use of predicted dates of mobilisation. The stem cell collection (SCC) facility at the University Hospital of Wales (UHW) provides aphaeresis services for the South Wales Blood and Marrow Transplant (SWBMT) Programme. A prospective data collection exercise of 124 adult referrals who underwent SCC using pre-defi ned priming protocols from May 2011 to October 2012 inclusive was conducted. The underlying diagnoses were Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL) n=48, Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL) n=21, Multiple Myeloma (MM) n=53 and Plasmacytoma (PC) n=2. A summary of outcomes is shown in the attached table. Priming failure was defi ned as a predicted CD34+ cell dose of < 0.8 x 10 6 /kg. The dose of cyclophosphamide (cyclo) was at the discretion of the referring clinician (1.5g/m 2 n=3, 3g/m 2 n=15 and 4g/m 2 n=2). Other chemotherapy regimens encompassed a variety of salvage protocols commonly used for HL and NHL, with only miniBEAM resulting in priming failure. The minimum CD34+ cell dose acceptable for ASCT was 2 x 10 6 /kg. With regard to MM, a CD34+ cell dose suffi cient for two transplants was achieved in 46% v 64% of patients receiving G-CSF alone v G-CSF + cyclo. In summary, with the exception of mini-BEAM, G-CSF + chemotherapy successfully mobilised stem cells in a high proportion of lymphoma patients (84%) with a low rate of infectious complications. Although priming failures in MM were lower following G-CSF + cyclo than with G-CSF alone, the high rate of infections resulted in an overall lower rate of successful SCC (61% v 70%). Whether 1.5g/m 2 cyclo will result in lower rates of infection and improved outcomes is the subject of further evaluation.

Infl uence of plerixafor on viability of peripheral blood stem cells collected by apheresis M. Postorino (1) F. Marchesi (2) , D. Renzi (2) , G. Adorno (1) , M. Cantonetti (1) (1)Policlinico Tor Vergata (Rome, IT); IT) Background: Plerixafor is a CXCR-4 receptor antagonist capable to mobilize stem cells (SCs) in peripheral blood. Diff erent studies showed that circulating CD34+ cells can be increased by several folds with the use of Plerixafor associated to G-CSF and that this mobilization regimen can be a valid option for myeloma or lymphoma patients defi ned "poor mobilizer". It is now not clear if the combination of Plerixafor to G-CSF has a role in viability of stem cells collected from peripheral blood. We report analysis of data relative to viability of CD34+ cells collected after mobilization with Plerixafor and G-CSF in two diff erent patients. Methods: Two patients (one Multiple Myeloma and one Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma) both underwent to a second harvest of CD34+ cells after mobilization with Plerixafor plus G-CSF as a consequence of low rate of viability observed at the moment of cryopreservation of the fi rst harvest collected after mobilization with chemotherapy plus G-CSF. Patient #1 underwent a fi rst attempt of mobilization with high-dose Cyclophosphamide, resulting in a CD34+ cells/Kg harvest of 4,2 x 10 6 with a viability of only 22,5%. Patient #2 underwent two attempts of mobilization with highdose Cyclophosphamide and high-dose Cytarabine, resulting in two subsequent CD34+ cells/Kg harvests of 7,3 x 10 6 and 4,5 x 10 6 with a viability of only 5% and 45% respectively. In all cases CFU-GM assays confi rm the low percentage of viable cells. Results: In patient 1, after mobilization with Plerixafor 0,24 mg/Kg and G-CSF 10 μg/Kg/day, we obtain a number of CD34+ cells/Kg of 6 x 10 6 with a higher level of viability (93 and 89% in two different units),CFU-GM 41,5 and 55,5 respectively. In patient 2, after mobilization with Plerixafor 0,24 mg/Kg and G-CSF 10 μg/Kg/day, we obtain a number of CD34+ cells/Kg of (4,8 x 10 6 ) with a higher level of viability (99 and 83% in two diff erent units),CFU-GM 46 and 34,25 respectively. Conclusions: Our data seem to suggest that combination of Plerixafor to G-CSF determine an increase of CD34+ cells viability rate observed before cryopreservation in patients in which we obtained a low viability rate of CD34+ cells collected after mobilization with chemotherapy and G-CSF. Further studies are necessary to defi ne the cause of reduced viability of SCs before cryopreservation and to confi rm our observation about the mobilization of viable SCs with Plerixafor in these particular conditions.

When can we safely talk about healing in chronic myeloid leukaemia patients after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplant? A.P. Iori, D. Diverio, S. Perrone, A. Ferretti, E. Scalzulli, W. Barberi, F. Natalino, M.G. Loglisci, A. Di Lascio, M. Breccia, G.F. Torelli, R. Foà Sapienza University (Rome, IT) Objectives: Studies on long-term results in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) patients who underwent an allogeneic hemato poietic stem cell transplant (HCT) have shown very rare relapses even after 10 years. However, long-term molecular assessment of the disease has never been closely evaluated. Aim of this study was to verify whether patients who survive for many years after an HCT, apparently free of leukemia, may have residual leukemia cells by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (RQ-PCR) analysis. Patients & Methods: Since January 2010, we performed a single center, prospective evaluation of the persistence of the Bcr/Abl transcript, by qRT-PCR, in 61 patients with CML who underwent a myeloablative HCT from an identical sibling between 1984 and 2001, and surviving in continuous complete hematological remission (CCR) for at least 10 years after transplant. Of these 61 patients, 8 refused to participate in the study and 7 were not traceable. The qRT-PCR analysis was therefore performed on 46 patients. Results: Of the 46 patients analyzed, with a median follow-up from transplant of 17 years (range 12-30) and in CCR for over 10 years, qRT-PCR resulted positive in 6 (13%). A patient with 62 copiesIS, at 23 years after HCT, presented a previously undetected hematological relapse. A patient with 33 copiesIS showed a cytogenetic relapse. Four patients with a median number of copiesIS of 0.3 (range 0.2-0.7), negative cytogenetics for the Ph chromosome and normal blood cell counts were monitored by qRT-PCR every 3 months: molecular evidence of disease persisted in 2 cases, evolved into an hematological relapse in 1 patient and disappeared in the other. Conclusions: Our study shows that residual leukemia stem cells identifi able by qRT-PCR may persist in CML patients long after HCT. It is therefore necessary to indefi nitely monitor allografted CML patients. However, the prognostic signifi cance of residual leukemic cells at low molecular levels and the defi nition of "low molecular level" after an allo-SCT remains undefi ned: we observed disappearance of the rearrangement in some patients and the persistence or the evolution into an overt hematological relapse phase in others. The uncertain clinical signifi cance of these molecular fi ndings raises ethical and clinical concerns regarding disclosing adequate information to the patients and in terms of therapeutic decisions. Prospective studies on long-term molecular assessments are required to monitor late relapse patterns and to answer the above-mentioned questions.

body_text.text: Long-term outcome of allogeneic stem cell transplantation for chronic myeloid leukaemia: a 30-year single centre experience S. Perrone (1) (1), A.P. Iori (1) (1)Sapienza University (Rome, IT); (2)"Tor Vergata" (Rome, IT) Purpose: For decades allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) has been considered the curative approach for patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML. In the era of tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs), HCT represents a second line treatment, due to the high risk of transplant-related mortality (TRM). Over the years, advances have been made in the care of patients undergoing transplantation. We conducted a study to determine whether these advances have improved the outcome of transplanted CML patients over a prolonged follow-up period. Patients and Methods: We retrospectively analysed the overall survival (OS), TRM and haematological relapse among 163 consecutive patients with CML in chronic phase or accelerated phase who received their fi rst HCT at our centre between 1984 and 1990 (group A, 62 patients), between 1991 and 2000 (group B, 75 patients) and between 2001 and 2011 (group C, 26 patients) . Results: At a median follow-up of 7 years (range 1-28years), the 10 year OS for the entire case series was 37%, 60% and 92% for groups A, B and C, respectively (p=0.0005) (Fig. 1 ). The 10 year cumulative incidence of TRM was 30%, 28% and 3% for each group, respectively (p=0.04). Patients in group A, B and C showed a cumulative incidence of haematological relapse of 72%, 27% and 2.7% respectively (p <0.001). Conclusions: We observed a substantial reduction in the hazard of death related to HCT, as well as a reduction in haematological relapse and an increased OS over the years. The reduction in TRM is probably due to advances in the care of patients undergoing transplantation; moreover, the more recent strategy of a close monitoring of minimal residual disease, with a prompt use of TKI or donor lymphocyte infusion strategies have reduced the risk of haematological relapse. These improved transplant policies have translated into a signifi cantly better OS. Nowadays, allogeneic transplantation is therefore a safer therapeutic procedure for CML patients that should be timely employed in TKI resistant patients.
