body_text.text: Successful stem cell transplantation in homozygous α-thalassemia 1: the fi rst case in Asia B.C. Pongtanakul, K. Sanpakit, V. Chongkolwatana Faculty of Medicine, Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University (Bangkok, TH) Homozygouse α-thalassemia 1 is the most severe thalassemia disease. This group of patients presents with hydrops fetalis and always dies before or shortly after birth. We reported successful stem cell transplantation in homozygouse α-thalassemia 1. A Thai girl was born at 32 weeks of gestational age (birth weight 1,300 gm) with hydrops fetalis by cesarean section. Her mother was 33 years old came to our hospital because of toxemia of pregnancy and prenatal ultrasonography showed hydrops fetalis with massive ascites. Her hemoglobin at birth was 6.8 g/dl. She was intubated, abdominal, pleural paracentesis and total blood exchange transfusion immediately after birth. Her hemoglobin typing before total blood exchange transfusion was 100% of hemoglobin Bart's and DNA analysis showed homozygouse α-thalassemia 1 (South East Asian deletion). After she was stable from preterm complications, she was started on hypertransfusion every 3-4 weeks and kept pre-transfusion hemoglobin at 9-10 g/dl since the age of 3 months. She has 6/6 HLA matched with her older sister. She was underwent stem cell transplantation at the age of 1 year. The conditioning regimen consisted of busulfan 1.2 mg/kg/dose every 6 hours intravenously for 4 days and cyclophosphamide 50 mg/ kg/day for 4 days. GVHD prophylaxis was cyclosporine and short course metrotrexate. The stem cell source was bone marrow and total CD 34 counts was 9.41 x 10 6 cells/kg. Her transplantation complications were febrile neutropenia and mucositis. She had WBC engraftment at day+17 and DNA showed full donor chimerism at day+25. On day+112, DNA showed mixed chimerism with 41% of recipient's DNA but hemoglobin was still stable. Cyclosporine was stopped and she received donor lymphocyte transfusion (DLI) at the dose 1x10 7 cells/kg of CD3 from her sister every 2 weeks. After 4 times of DLI, she could achieve full donor chimerism. Now, she is 4 years old with post transplantation for 3 years and her DNA is still full donor chimerism. Her hemoglobin is 13 g/dl, normal hemoglobin typing. Her developmental milestones are up to her age. Conclusion: Homozygouse α-thalassemia 1 can be cured with stem cell transplantation. Preterm delivery with immediate total blood exchange transfusion, hypertransfusion and proceed to stem cell transplantation is possible treatment strategy to cure from this fatal disease. From our knowledge, this is the fi rst successful stem cell transplantation in homozygouse α-thalassemia 1 in Asia. Pulmonary haemorrhage (PH) is a well recognised complication of haematopoietic stem cell transplantation for Hurler's Syndrome (MPS 1H), previously suspected to be due to glycosaminoglycans (GAGS) accumulation in pulmonary tissues. However, introduction of pre-transplant enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) has not prevented PH despite improving upper airway obstruction. We report a male patient who underwent 5/6 matched cord blood transplantation (CBT) for MPS 1H at 18m after conditioning with fl udarabine, busulfan and ATG. He had required neonatal oxygen therapy and had suff ered recurrent chest infections during his fi rst year, including metapneumovirus and adenovirus infections both requiring ventilation. These left him with a permanently consolidated right upper lobe and need for long-term oxygen therapy. He was commenced on ERT at diagnosis of MPS-1H at 13 months and proceeded to transplant when off supplemental oxygen. On day 12 post-CBT he developed fever, stridor and respiratory distress requiring ventilation and then had an episode of cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity which responded rapidly to resuscitation. Platelets during this period were in the range 31-63 x 10(9)/L and no blood was seen in endotracheal aspirates. Echocardiogram showed a fractional shortening of 31%, and a dilated left atrium with moderate mitral regurgitation. He was treated for hypertension with nifedipine and received inotropic support which was gradually weaned to stoppage. He subsequently engrafted satisfactorily without GVHD, normalised his respiratory rate and oxygen saturations, was feeding well, and was due for discharge by day 49 post-transplant. He then developed respiratory distress without underlying infection, and rapidly deteriorated to unresuscitatable cardiorespiratory arrest with fresh blood issuing from his nose and mouth. His platelet count at that time was 17 x 10(9)/L. Findings at post-mortem included diff use pulmonary haemorrhage, presence of iron laden macrophages (suggestive of previous PH), GAGS infi ltration of the mitral valve and marked pulmonary venous hypertensive (PVH) changes. Previous reports have suggested that platelet counts of 40+ are not protective against PH in these patients. The risk of PH may also be exacerbated by allogeneic responses, particularly following CBT. This patient's problems suggest that PH may have cardiogenic origin, with mitral regurgitation producing secondary PVH, making a case for more proactive cardiac drug therapy even without overt cardiac failure.

body_text.text: Stem cell transplants in chronic granulomatous disease: single centre report V. Grassi, F. Bolda, R. Baff elli, A. Beghin, C. D'Ippolito, A. Soresina, A. Lanfranchi, F. Porta Children's Hospital (Brescia, IT) Bone marrow transplantation (BMT) is the only curative treatment for chronic granulomatous disease CGD). We grafted 5 children aff ected by CGD, 4 from MUD and 1 from a matched family donor. Pt 1 at the age of 3 yrs received full conditioning and MUD BMT. At day + 15 engraftment was present, but the child became lethargic. A CT scan demonstrated a cerebral mass compatible with an aspergillus infection. Despite antifungal therapy the child died on day +25 post-BMT. Pt 2 , aged 6 yrs and 3 aged 18 months, two brothers, were diagnosed CGD. Pt 2 received matched familial BMT after conditioning with Bu Mel ATG . He engrafted on day +15, after discharge, being a full donor chimera, he reactivated a viral infection that led on day +60 to GVHD and PPT and subsequently died of cerebral bleed. Pt 3 received familial phenoidentical BMT. He engrafted on day +12. Donor chimerism declined from 100% to 39% within two mos. Therefore BMT was boosted with CD34+ cells reaching 60%. Pt 4 received PBSC form a MUD and engrafted nicely on day +15 and is a full chimera. Pt 5 aged 12 yrs with chronic intestinal disease received a MUD PBSC after a RIC BU conditioning . He engrafted nicely at day + 15. Six<month later he died of heart failure due to a pregress cardiac insuffi ciency. In our experience BMT in CGD remains the only curative therapy in severly aff ected pts (i.e. MICI), RIC BU conditioning plus PBSC at present is the golden standard that decreases toxicity risks and shortens aplasia. Hromadnikova (1) , P. Pirkova (1) , L. Sedlackova (1) , A. Fiserova (2) (1) Charles University (Prague, CZ); (2) Institute of Microbiology, Academy of Sciences (Prague, CZ) NK cells represent a potential tool for adoptive immunotherapy against solid tumors and leukaemia. Membrane-bound Hsp70 acts as a tumor-specifi c marker enhancing NK cell activity (1, 2) . We have demonstrated that human leukaemia cell lines were positive for cell surface Hsp70 expression (5, 6) . Incubation of peripheral blood lymphocytes with Hsp70 derived 14-mer peptide (TKD) plus a low dose IL-2 initiates the cytolytic and migratory capacity of NK cells toward Hsp70 membrane positive tumor cells (3, 4) . This study is a part of comprehensive study focused on the inducement of GvL eff ects through NK cells against leukaemia. Using FACS, the eff ect of in vitro stimulation with IL-2 or IL-15 alone or in combination with TKD on cell surface expression of NK activatory receptors (CD16, NKG2D, NKG2C, NKp46, NKp44, NKp30, KIR2DL4, DNAM-1 and LAMP1) and NK inhibitory receptors (NKG2A, KIR2DL2/L3, LIR1/ILT-2 and NKR-P1A) in healthy individuals was studied. Results were expressed as the percentage of receptor expressing cells and the amount of receptor expressed by CD3-CD56+ cellular population. CD94, NKG2D, NKp44, NKp30, KIR2DL4, DNAM-1, LAMP1, NKG2A and NKR-P1A were upregulated after the stimulation with IL-2 or IL-15 alone or in combination with TKD. KIR2DL2/L3 was upregulated only by IL-15 and IL-15/TKD. Concurrently, an increase in a number of NK cells positive for CD94, NKp44, NKp30, KIR2DL4 and LAMP1 was observed. IL-15 and IL-15/TKD caused also cell number rise positive for KIR2DL2/L3 and NKR-P1A. Cell number positive for NKG2C and NKG2A was increased only by IL-2 and IL-2/TKD. The diverse eff ect of IL-2 or IL-15 w or w/o TKD on cell surface expression was observed in CD16, NKp46 and LIR1/ILT-2. Although NK cytotoxicity fi nally depends on the type and the expression of ligands on the target cells interacting with NK activatory and inhibitory receptors, the study showed clearly how NK cells were infl uenced under in vitro conditions in the presence of other immunocompetent cells by low-dose interleukins themselves or in combination with TKD peptide. CD8 T-cell responses against several WT1-derived peptides have been characterized and are supposed to contribute to disease control after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). Also the identifi cation of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class II-restricted CD4 T-cell epitopes from WT1 is a challenging task of T cell-based cancer immunotherapy to improve the eff ectiveness of WT1 peptide vaccination. Here we demonstrate HLA-DR-restricted CD4 T-cell responses in leukemia patients after allo-HSCT to a highly immunogenic 9-mer WT1 peptide that was primarily reported as an HLA-A*02 restricted epitope. CD4 T-cell depletion completely abolished IFNγ induction in response to WT1 126-134, and antibody-mediated blockade mapped peptide presentation to HLA-DR (IFN-γ ELISPOT Assay, fi g.1). Beyond cytokine production, a fraction of WT1 126-134 specifi c CD4 T-cells was CD107a positive after WT1 126-134 peptide stimulation, indicative of their cytotoxic potential. By fl ow cytometry analysis it was demonstrated that WT1 126-134 specifi c CD4 T-cells were mainly functional cytotoxic CD4 T-cells, and subpopulations of them were eff ector memory cells. Longitudinal analysis showed that WT1 126-134 specifi c CD4 T-cells persisted for months or even longer after allo-HSCT and expressed a monoclonal or oligoclonal T-cell receptor V-β repertoire. Such expanded WT1 126-134 reactive CD4 T-cells were absent in the donor of the stem cell graft, suggesting that antigen-specifi c T-cells had expanded in the recipient in response to tumor cells.

body_text.text: In conclusion, we demonstrate for the fi rst time that a 9-mer WT1-derived peptide can induce HLA DR-restricted cytotoxic CD4 T-cell responses. The simultaneous stimulation of CD4 and CD8 T-cells is presumably essential for a strong and persistent immune response. In tumor specifi c T-cell responses against low affi nity antigens like WT-1, the capability of one single peptide antigen to bind to HLA-class I and class II may increase the opportunity for an effi cient tumor specifi c T-cell response which may contribute to disease control after allogeneic HSCT. The common structural basis of HLA class I and class II molecules binding to primary and secondary peptide anchor motifs by covering the central 9-10 amino acids, might be a fi rst explanation for the investigated phenomenon.

Inhibition of B-cell proliferation and antibody production by mesenchymal stromal cells is mediated by T-lymphocytes M.M. Rosado, M.E. Bernardo, M. Scarsella, A. Conforti, E. Giorda, S. Biagini, S. Cascioli, F. Rossi, M. Vivarelli, I. Guzzo, L. Dello Strologo, F. Emma, F. Locatelli, R. Carsetti Ospedale Pediatrico Bambino Gesu (Rome, IT) Objectives: Bone marrow (BM)-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) represent a promising tool for immunoregulatory and regenerative cell-therapy; however, their specifi c role in modulating B cell function is controversial and still incompletely understood. Here, we studied the role of BM-derived MSCs in modulating Blymphocytes stimulated with a polyclonal activator (CpG) in healthy donors (HDs) and in two pathologic conditions in which B cells induce/maintain infl ammation and tissue damage, i.e. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and patients receiving kidney transplantation. Methods: We established an in vitro culture system to analyse the eff ects of MSCs on B-cell proliferation, plasma cells diff erentiation and antibody secretion after stimulation with CpG for 7 days. We compared B cell function in the presence and absence of MSCs in diff erent experimental conditions: total peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs), sorted B cells, PBMCs without T cells, sorted B cells mixed to sorted T cells. B-cell proliferation and plasma cell diff erentiation were measured by FACS analysis, whereas antibody secretion was quantifi ed by ELISA in culture supernatants. Results: We found that, both in HDs and in patients, in vitro B-cell proliferation, plasma-cell diff erentiation and antibody production are inhibited in the presence of MSCs co-cultured with PBMCs+CpG, but not when sorted B cells are cultured with MSCs+CpG. Inhibition is restored in CpG+MSC co-cultures when sorted T cells are added to sorted B cells, suggesting that this eff ect is mediated by T cells, with both CD4+ and CD8+ subsets playing a role. Removal of Treg cells from culture did not alter MSC-dependent inhibition of B-cell proliferation and antibody production. IL-6 and IFN-γ are likely involved in T-cell dependent inhibition of B-cell function by MSCs since the level of these cytokines was increased in the supernatant. Conclusion: In our culture system BM-derived MSCs inhibit B cell function with a T-cell dependent mechanism. This fi nding has to be taken into account in the design of innovative MSC-based strategies in SLE and kidney transplanted patients, in whom T-cell function is often impaired by the immunesuppressive therapy. Veys (2) (1)Institute of Child Health (London, GB); (2)Great Ormond Street Hospital (London, GB) Objective: In contrast to bone marrow (BM) or peripheral blood (PB), early T cell reconstitution after cord blood (CB) transplant is CD4 biased and associated with a relatively lower incidence of GVHD. In view of emerging evidence that foetal and adult T cells arise from ontogenically diff erent populations of haemopoietic stem cells, we have investigated whether these diff erences refl ect diff erential gene expression in CB and PB T cells. Methods: We compared the gene expression profi le on fl ow cytometrically sorted naïve CD4+CD45RA+CCR7+ T cells derived from normal donor CB and PB using Aff ymetrix Human Gene 1.0 ST arrays. Diff erentially expressed probe sets were identifi ed using Bioconductor package "limma". The threshold for identifying signifi cant genes was set at a false discovery rate of 5% and foldchange of ≥ 2. Pathway analysis was performed using Ingenuity and Gene Set enrichment analysis software. Results: In 2 separate gene expression profiling experiments comparing CB and PB naïve CD4 T cells (n=5 total), Principal Component Analysis showed CB and PB T cells segregated separately with 243/232 differentially expressed genes. 69 genes were differentially expressed in both experiments, of which 90% were up-regulated and 10% down-regulated in the CB CD4 T cells. Of these overlapping genes, 11 (i.e. TNF, JUN, EGR1, SOX4, BCL11A, TNFAIP3, TOX, CD69, IKZF2, GZMA, PAK1) were T lineage specific and 4 (i.e. GZMA, AUTS2, IGF2BP3, RGS1) have previously been identified as characteristic of foetal CD4+ T cells. Of these 69 genes, 8 (i.e. TNF, JUN, NFKBIA, EGR1, SGK1, KLF6, PAK1, HIST1H2BM) were involved in cell cycle progression. Pathway analysis showed that TNFR1 /TNFR2 signalling were the most upregulated pathways in CB CD4 T cells and within these pathways genes causing proliferation rather than apoptosis were up-regulated. Conclusion: Our data demonstrate that CB CD4 T cells are genetically distinct from their counterparts in PB and this may explain their preferential expansion and tolerogenic propensity. In particular, the TNFR pathways may play a critical role in this. Further studies are underway to determine if gene expression in T cells after CB transplantation recapitulates ontogeny, switching from a foetal profi le early after transplant when T cells are derived from those transferred with the graft to an adult profi le when stem cell derived T cells emerge at later time-points.

body_text.text: Vγ9Vδ2 T-cells recognize and kill chemotherapy-resistant acute myeloid leukaemia cells via movement of lytic granules controlled by CD226 participated ERK1/2 phosphorylation K. Wu, Y. He, H. Fu, Y. Hu, L. Sheng, H. Huang School of Medicine, Zhejiang University (Hang Zhou, CN) Background: Julie Gertner-Dardenne et al. recently reported Vγ9Vδ2 (gd) T cells recognized and killed acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells. The questions therefore arise as to what is the eff ect of gd T cell on chemotherapy-resistant AML cells, whether the resistance aff ect gd T cell cytotoxicity. We focused on this intresting point and accessed the possible eff ect and mechanisms. Methods: gd T cells were expanded in the presence of 2uM zoledronate and IL-2.6 AML cell lines HL-60,NB4,K562 and their chemotherapeutics-resistant cell lines HL-60/ADR,K562/AO2, NB4/R1 as well as primary cells from 15 refractory/resistant AML patients were used as target cells. Cytotoxicity was measured by fl ow cytometry using CFSE and 7-AAD.The extracellular signal-regulatory kinase1/2 (ERK1/2) activation was analysed by western blot using the method of mixing gd T cells with an equal number of paraformaldehyde-fi xed target cells.CD107a expression was detected after 4h coincubition of gd T cells and target cells. The surface molecules were detected by fl ow cytometry.Specifi c ERK1/2 inhibitor PD098059 or blocking mAbs were incubated with gd T cells 1 hour before further experiments. Results: gd T cell effi ciently kill chemotherapy-resistant AML primary cells at diff erent eff ect:target(E:T) ratios (Figure1A). The resistance did not decrease T cell cytotoxicity compared with matermal cell lines (Figure1B). gd T cell binding to tumor cells for 5 min was suffi cient to maximally activate ERK1/2, demonstrated by its tyrosine phosphorylation. ERK1/2 activation was achieved in gd T cells after contact with gd T -sensitive K562 and K562/ AO2 cells,but not gd T -resistant HL-60 (Figure1C). PD098059, block degranulation of gd T cells, which occur upon target ligation (Figure1D). PD098059 also inhibited the cytotoxicity of gd T cells. To further clarify the mechanism,we assessed the expression of ligands of CD226, which has been found to play an important role in gd T cell killing AML cells, on diff erent AML subsets above, and found no signifi cant decrease of expression in resistant AML cells(Figure1E). Blocking CD226 inhibited ERK1/2 activation of gd T cells after contact with gd T -sensitive K562 and K562/AO2 cell (Figure1F), and inhibited gd T cell -mediated lysis (Figure1G). Conclusion: These results showed gd T cells effi ciently kill chemotherapy-resistant AML cells, and documented a a pivotal role of CD226 induced ERK1/2 in gd T eff ector function, possibly by its control of movement of lytic granules.

IL2 plays dual role in immune responses, contributing to both the generation of eff ector T cells and the maintenance of regulatory T cells (Tregs). Recently, low dose IL2 therapy has been advanced as a potential immune modulator able to "tweak" the immune response to aid transplant tolerance and to suppress GvHD (N Engl J Med. 2011; 2055-66) Objectives: We aimed to investigate the impact of priming lymphocytes with low dose IL2 on their proliferative responses to allo-stimulation in vitro.

body_text.text: Lenalidomide (len) is an immunmodulatory drug used for multiple myeloma and other haematological diseases. We and other have pioneered the use of len after allogeneic stem cell (allo SCT) transplantation. The drug is known to up regulate pro infl ammatory cytokines like TNF α and IFN α which might contribute to the incidence of GvHD in the context of allo SCT. In our dose fi nding study we found 18% of infections. We therefore analysed the immunological data for our patients with a focus on the T cell development in patients with a clinical signifi cant infection and those without. Interestingly both groups showed a decrease in their total number of CD3+ T-cells. This eff ect was more prominent in the group with infections. Further the number of CD4+ T helper cells decreased also in both groups but those patients with infections dropped to a level below 200/μl. In contrast CD8+ T-cells were not aff ected by len treatment. To understand this clinical data we treated T-cells in vivo with len and observed a diff erential response of the CD4 and CD8 compartment towards the drug. While CD4 cells showed a growth arrest, CD8 cells were nearly unaff ected. This observation can be explained by a diff erential expression of p15, a cell cycle inhibitor of the ikn4 locus, in CD4 and CD8 cells after len treatment. We suggest that this diff erential response is accountable for the incidence of GvHD triggered by CD8+ cells and a higher risk for infection due to inbibited CD4+ cells. Therefore we conclude that len treatment beside its eff ects on cytokine expression infl uences the cell cycle regulation in T cells which should be further investigated to understand its way of action on immune cells.

body_text.text: Graft versus host disease is one of the major complications in haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). In order to modulate this disease, regulatory T cells (Treg) have been proposed as a cellular therapy. Treg cells have been described as suppressor of cells that are responsible for GvHD, such as T cells, but on the other hand they also suppress Natural killer (NK) cells, key players of the Graft versus Leukaemia (GvL). It has been showed that Treg cell may suppress NK cells in certain conditions, but no information is available on the eff ects of NK cell diff erentiation. Due to the critical role of NK cells in HSCT, we addressed this question. Because of the rising use of umbilical cord blood (CB) as a source of stem cells for HSCT, this study examined CB NK cell diff erentiation through an in vitro 5-week culture. CD34+ stem cells were cultured in the presence or not of resting or TCR-stimulated allogeneic CB Treg cells. To determine Treg cells eff ect on diff erent stages of diff erentiation, Treg cells were added at a ratio of 1 to 4 (Treg to NK cells) at 2, 9, 16, 23 and 30 days of culture. When TCR-stimulated, Treg cells were pre-incubated for 48 hours with plate bound CD3, soluble CD28 and Interleukin-2 and then added to the culture. Interestingly, a 90% reduction in NK cell count was detected when TCR-stimulated Treg cells were added at day 9. In contrast, the remaining had a normal phenotype and was fully functional. Surprisingly, high levels of secretion of IL-10 were observed in this particular condition. No eff ect was observed when resting Treg cells were added to the culture at any time on NK cell count, viability, phenotype and function. These results may strongly suggest an effect on CB NK cell differentiation in vitro by IL-10 CB Treg cells. This study may provide more information to determine if NK cell differentiation and NK cell mediated GvL is impaired by a possible CB Treg cell therapy.

Gómez Hoapital universitario Reina Sofía (Cordoba, ES) Objectives: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation is a potentially curative modality for hematologic diseases. Donor T cells contained in the graft exert in receptors benefi cial anti-tumor and anti-infection eff ects, but also the detrimental graft versus host disease (GVHD) by recognizing HLA disparities recipient's tissues (skin, liver, gastrointestinal). Analysis and isolation of subpopulations naive-memory T cells involved in GVHD and anti-infective protection is the key to the future development of graft engineering. In this study we sought to determine the correlation of circulating naïve/memory total and CMV-specifi c CD8lymphocytes with clinical variables mainly the incidence of GVHD and CMV-disease. Materials and Methods: We analyzed peripheral blood samples from 19 HLA-I*0201patients (paediatrics n = 7) and adult (n = 12) who underwent HSCT from November 2005 to December 2011. We studied maturation profi le (naive -memory) with CD27, CD45RO, CD62L MnAbs of total CD8 lymphocytes and specifi c anti-CMV characterized with anti-HLA tetramers pp65. Results: The proportion of naive-memory CD8 lymphocytes post-HSCT is greatly skewed according to donors' age, with a statistically signifi cant predominance of population naive CD27 + (p = 0.010) if the donor was younger than 40 years and CD45RO-(p = 0.026) if the donor was older than 40 yrs. Patients who underwent conventional conditioning regimen harboured also statistically signifi cant higher frequency of naïve CD27 + populations than those receiving reduced-intensity conditioning regimen (p=0.034). Although patients who develop acute GVHD contained a larger number of naive CD8+ lymphocytes, these diff erences did not reach statistical signifi cance. We also showed a signifi cantly higher number of population specifi c CD8 anti-CMV (p= 0.033) in patients who developed CMV infection and underwent valganciclovir treatment. Conclusions: Circulating CD8 populations post alo-TPH are signifi cantly infl uenced by donor age and type of conditioning and CD8 + anti-CMV TPH are more frequently detected especially post-post-infection.

body_text.text: Impaired function and proliferation of NK cells from patient granulocyte colony-stimulating factor mobilized leukapheresis Y. Xiong, Y. Wang, J. Stoltz, D. Bensoussan, V. Decot CHU de Nancy (Vandoeuvre les Nancy, FR)

Objective: Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)mobilized peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) collections are increasingly emerging as the graft of choice in many centers for autologous transplantation, and with increasing frequency in allogeneic transplantation. In an allogeneic setting, natural killer (NK) cells have a critical role in graft versus host disease and graft versus leukemia eff ects. However, the impact of G-CSF on NK cells response remains unclear. In this study, we compared NK cell phenotype and functions isolated from PBSC collections from both healthy donors and patients mobilized with G-CSF. Materials and Methods: After informed consent, NK cells were isolated from 150 mL fresh blood sample from healthy donors, 3 mL of fresh PBSC transplant from allogeneic healthy donors and 3 mL of fresh autologous PBSC transplant from patients, enriched using a CD3/CD19 depletion method and expanded for 14 days in the presence of 50 ng/mL interleukin (IL)-15. Expression of NKG2D, KIR2DL1, KIR2DL2, KIR2DL5, and CD137 was monitored by fl ow cytometry during expansion and cytokine secretion was followed using Cytometric bead array. NK cell cytotoxicity was evaluated at the end of the culture. Results: Highly T-and B-cell depleted NK cells were obtained. The percentage of CD16+/CD56+ NK cells was signifi cantly diminished in G-CSF mobilized PBSC from patients after expansion and proliferated less than NK cells from normal peripheral blood or G-CSF mobilized PBSC from normal donors. The fi ve receptors studied were up regulated after 14 days of culture, and the expression of NKG2D, KIR2DL1 and CD137 was signifi cantly diff erent between the three origins of NK cells. NK cells sorted from G-CSF mobilized PBSC from patients also exhibited a diminished ability to kill tumor targets. Conclusion: The findings presented here show that G-CSF administration to patients decreases NK cell population, proliferation and function. Overcoming this impairement in lymphoid capacity may be important to facilitate post-transplant immunotherapy.

body_text.text: Natural killer (NK) cell/cancer cell conjugation leads to reciprocal cellular damage. Nature and specifi city of this phenomenon in post-activated NK cells are unclear. Using standard immunological methods, we assessed the eff ects of human and mouse cancer cells on post-activated human and mouse NK cells. Human, allogeneic, malignant cells triggered human NK cell alteration (NKCA) including FcγRIII (CD16) down-regulation, NK cell loss and apoptosis. In contrast,allogeneic PBMC, depleted of NK cells, failed to induce significant NKCA. Mouse allogeneic leukemia cells induced mouse NK cell loss and apoptosis while syngeneic, allogenic mouse splenocytes, depleted of NK cells, and xenogenic cancer cells did not, suggesting that NKCA preferentially involved allogeneic, malignant cells. After 10 days PBMC culture, in the absence of cancer cells, post-activated and unstimulated NK cells showed some CD16 antigen down-regulation while became resistant to cancer cell dependent NKCA and maintaining cytotoxic function. Actinomycin D restored NKCA in long term NK cells (LTNKC) suggesting that the resistance to NKCA utilized RNA transcription. TAPI-0, a functional analogue of the tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMP) 3, reversed cancer cell dependent NKCA underlying a role for a restricted group of metalloproteinases (MMPs) in the generation of this phenomenon. LTNKC resistance to NKCA was associated with increased levels of TIMP3 gene expression and sustained contents of soluble TIMP3 in the supernatants of LTNKC cultures. This study provides evidence that TIMP3 plays a role in the protection of LTNKC from cancer cell dependent NKCA.

body_text.text: A novel multiple imputation method for uncovering HLA disease associations using unrelated donor registry databases L. Gragert (1), S. DiPrima (1) , M. Albrecht (1) , M. Zhang (2) , X. Zhong (2) , P. Hari (2) Aim: Finding HLA associations for disease in retrospective studies is challenging primarily due to poor statistical power due to unavailability of large well-defi ned case and control datasets. Fortunately, the National Marrow Donor Program (USA) registry has accumulated large numbers of disease cases from patient searches for allogeneic stem cell transplants along with HLAtyped controls from donor recruitment. We aimed to use this data to uncover HLA associations for transplantable diseases. Methods: We developed sets of HLA-typed case/control datasets from the NMDP registry for several US populations. Because most HLA typing has allelic ambiguity, we utilized a multiple imputation framework which assigns allele-level HLA-A~C~B~DRB1~DQB1 haplotype pairs based on a probability distribution calculated from ambiguous subject HLA typing and reference population HLA haplotype frequencies. Replicate studies each with potentially-varying HLA haplotype assignments were performed to ensure that the HLA typing ambiguity was incorporated in the statistical model. We ran multivariate logistic regression using a generalized linear model controlling for the covariates of age, geographic location, and gender to calculate odds ratios, P-values, and 95% confi dence intervals for HLA allele and haplotype variants. Results: In a study of 2,887 European-American Multiple Myeloma (MM) patients compared to 500,000 controls, we found signifi cant HLA associations. B*07:02 was predisposing for MM with an odds ratio (OR)of 1.27 and a P-value of 0.0001. Meanwhile B*44:02 was protective (OR=0.858. P-value=0.0491). Other associations were observed for A*66, B*27, C*16:01. In some cases grouping alleles into allele families resulted in more statistically-signifi cant associations, while in other cases confounding between alleles within a family made grouping undesirable. Combinations of multiple risk variants within haplotype and genotypes had an additive or dose-dependent eff ect. Conclusion: The combination of large registries and the application of this multiple imputation statistical framework provides a unique opportunity to study HLA associations for transplantable disease at a higher resolution than ever. We are expanding this framework to examine amino acid polymorphisms and sequence feature variant types (SFVTs) within HLA molecules. International collaboration with additional registries and experts in disease is needed to fully exploit the potential of this method and secure grant funding.

Natural chimera identifi ed during routine histocompatibility testing for haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: a case study Z. Grubic, J. Kelecic, K. Stingl, R. Zunec Clinical Hospital Centre Zagreb (Zagreb, HR) Chimerism, a state described as a presence of two genetically distinct cell lines in an organism, routinely occurs in patients who were subjected to medical procedures such as transplantation or transfusion. However, this state can also appear naturally, as a consequence of feto-maternal transfer of cells through placenta during pregnancy. In this report, we describe a case of natural chimerism identifi ed during a routine histocompatibility testing. S164 A six months old boy was diagnosed with a Severe Combined Immunodefi ciency Syndrome (SCID). In preparation for Hematopoietic Stell Cell Transplantation (HSCT), the patient and his parents underwent HLA testing. Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood cells and HLA-A, -B, -DRB1 typing was performed by Luminex technology. Typing results of the patient's HLA-B locus were not interpretable. All samples were re-typed for HLA-B by PCR-SSP. Patient's sample could not be interpreted using commercial software due to several weak positive reactions. The typing was repeated on a sample of patient's bone marrow and the results were again non-interpretable. The analysis was extended to HLA-C locus, however, the patient's alleles were again not possible to determine due to several weak reactions, either for blood or bone marrow. Five out of 16 microsatellites (HUMTH01, HUMSE33, D1S1656, D18S535, D15S659) were informative and demonstrated three alleles in patient's sample (two maternal and one paternal) out of which paternal allele appeared with a distinctly lower intensity. The retrospective manual interpretation of results obtained for HLA-B and -C loci revealed that weak positive reactions were indeed due to the paternal HLA-B and -C alleles and that the patient had both maternal and one paternal allele. Finally, the DNA from patient's buccal cells was isolated and HLA-B and -C loci were re-typed by PCR-SSP. The analysis revealed that the patient inherited one paternal and one maternal allele. This fi nding was confi rmed by analysis of informative microsatellites, which demonstrated only one maternal and one paternal allele in patient's buccal cells. The initial failure to recognize the chimeric state of the patient was due to the mother's homozygosity at the HLA-A and -DRB1 loci. In summary, combination of several diff erent typing methods including the manual interpretation of results was necessary to obtain the HLA typing results of the patient and subsequent successful search for an unrelated donor.

body_text.text: Immunogenetics is often erroneously considered a static science. This is not the case, since every year tens of new alleles are discovered and a plenty of new insights stems in antibody-mediated and cell-mediated immune response to allografts. Most physicians involved in transplantation sciences are not fully aware of these developments because these novelties are too often targeted at a highly specialized audience. At the same time even immunogenetists have troubles at staying updated in their fi elds of interest because of the proliferation of published journals and the clear multidisciplinarity of transplantation immunology. Modern web tools (such as RSS feed aggregators) facilitate continuing immunogenetics education sparing precious time to busy scientists. Anyway there is currently a lack of Web 2.0 platforms for sharing immunogenetics knowledge. The not-for-profi t "Immunogenetics and Transplantation blog" (http://immunogenetics.blogspot.com) was developed with Web 2.0 in mind to allow interaction with visitors. The blog, launched on November 1, 2011, was arranged on the well-known Blogger platform, allowing consultation onthe-go thanks to its simplifi ed mobile interface. In the fi rst year of life the blog posted > 70 paper abstracts and received > 25,000 visits, which is a good results for a highly specialistic fi eld. Among blog features, visitors can enjoy : 1) ability to search and comment each post; 2) polls on current topics of interests; 3) easy e-mailing, sharing and cross-linking to social networks for each single post; 4) shareable Google calendar with deadlines and dates for most important world congresses on immunogenetics and transplantation ; 5) useful links; 6) interactive chatbot; 7) single-click, inline translation to 10 diff erent languages; 8) ability to join free text or video chats; and 9) a mobile app for Windows Phone and

body_text.text: HLA (human leukocyte antigen) genotypically identical siblings are preferred as donors in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) because the inheritance of identical HLA haplotypes by descent includes identity for all gene variations within the two parenteral haplotypes. Matching for HLA in unrelated HSCT does not mean that non-HLA genes in HLA region also matched. Present of frequent haplotypes in patient positively aff ects the probability and speed of identifying unrelated donor. Patients carrying at least one of the 10 most frequent Caucasoid HLA haplotypes have the highest chances of the quick identifi cation of matched donor. Those patients have a decreased probability of acute graftversus-host disease without increased risk of relapse compared to patients without frequent haplotypes. Frequencies of HLA allele and their associations vary from one geographic region to another.
body_text.section: HLA-A*/B*/C*/DRB1*/DQB1* haplotypes assigned by family segregation analysis in Russian patients awaiting allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation E. Khamaganova, T. Chugreeva, Y. Mamukova, E. Parovichnikova Research Centre for Hematology (Moscow, RU)

body_text.text: Objective: To estimate the distribution of HLA-A*/B*/C*/DRB1*/ DQB1*haplotype frequencies in Russian patients in need of HSCT. Methods: 201 patients (Caucasoids) with diff erent hematological disorders awaiting allogeneic HSCT (related or unrelated), whose HLA-haplotypes were identifi ed by family segregation analysis with certainty, were included in the study. HLA-A*/B*/C*/DRB1*/ DQB1* genotyping was done using PCR-SSP Kits (Invitrogen, WI, USA). Results: 21 out of defi ned HLA haplotypes occurred in our patients three and more times. Our patients carried all of the 10 most frequent Caucasoid haplotypes, but their distribution had some peculiarities. The most frequent haplotype was A*03-B*07-C*07-DRB1*15-DQB1*06, which was identifi ed in 17 patients (8.5%). 13 patients (6.5%) carried A*01-B*08-C*07-DRB1*03-DQB1*02. A*02-B*13-C*06-DRB1*07-DQB1*02 was the third according to frequency (5%), it was revealed 10 times in 9 patients. 3 haplotypes of the 10 most frequent Caucasoid haplotypes occurred less than three times: twice A*02-B*40-C*03-DRB1*13-DQB1*06 (1%) and A*30-B*13-C*06-DRB1*07-DQB1*02 (1%), and once A*29-B*44-C*16-DRB1*07-DQB1*02 (0.05%). Only 23.9% of the patients had at least one of the 10 most frequent haplotypes, 2% of the patients had two such haplotypes. Conclusion: The investigated patients had peculiarities in distribution of HLA haplotype frequencies. Possible solution of the problem to fi nd HLA compatible donor at least for the part of our patients is to increase donor pool size in diff erent regions of Russian Federation.

Iniotaki General Hospital of Athens ''G.Gennimatas'' (Athens, GR) Aim:To evalute Sequence Based Typing(SBT) as a method for HLA four digit high resolution typing and allele identifi cation in patients for hematopoietic stem cells transplantation and their potential unrelated donors. Methods: 559 HLA-A,-B,-C and DRB1 loci were tested and analyzed by SBT using commercial SBT kits,an automatic AB 3500XL Analyser and the kits software. Exons 2,3 and 4 were analyzed for class I and exon 2 for class II loci. For allelic ambiguities defi nition we used Heterozyguous Ambiguity Resolution Sequencing Primers (HARPs). All loci were typed in parallel with HR SSO/SSP. Results: Unambiguous four digit allelic results were observed for 223/559(39,9%) loci by SBT. Using HARPs we were able to improve the resolution for 160(28,6%) more loci, achiving a total of 383(68,5%) unambiguous results. For the rest 176(31,5%) loci further testing needed to rule out the ambiguities from 18,3% HLA-A, 36,1% HLA-B,70,3 % HLA-C and 21,7% HLA-DRB1 loci. Analysing the results from SSO/SSP typing we resolved ambiguities in 136/176 loci while 40 remained unresolved and assigned using NMDP guidelines and population frequence tables. Conclusions:Implementation of SBT increases alleles resolution but we still need SSO/SSP to rule out ambiguities. In order to increase allele resolution using SBT it is necessary to extend the analysis to other exons and proceed to new HARPs. Objectives: We and others have reported abnormalities in the regulatory T lymphocytes (Treg) of hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) recipients with chronic graft-versus-host-disease (GvHD). Because of the clinical similarities between chronic GvHD and scleroderma (SSc), we analyzed the Treg lymphocytes of pediatric SSc patients (jSSc) and identifi ed decreases in both resting and activated Treg lymphocytes. In addition, we identifi ed an increased frequency of CD45RA expressing eff ector memory (EMRA) CD4 T lymphocytes that uniformly express CCR7 and CD28, which are not uniformly expressed by the increased EMRA T lymphocytes present in elderly individuals. We, therefore, cross-sectionally analyzed allogeneic pediatric HSCT recipients more than 1 year following HSCT for the presence of CCR7 expressing EMRA CD4 T lymphocytes as possible eff ector T lymphocytes in chronic GvHD. Methods: HSCT recipients were classifi ed as 1: no history of acute or chronic GvHD; 2: history of only acute GvHD; 3: active chronic GvHD; and 4: history of resolved chronic GvHD. Peripheral blood leukocytes of the normal individuals and the HSCT recipients were analyzed by FACS analysis for the frequency of EMRA CD4 T lymphocytes and their expression of CCR7 in addition to quantifying the frequency of resting and activated Treg lymphocytes using the Miyara classifi cation and 6 color FACS analysis. Results: Elevated frequencies of EMRA CD4 T lymphocytes were present in all HSCT groups except HSCT recipients with only a history of acute GvHD (Group 2). Increased expression of CCR7 by the EMRA T lymphocytes was present in all HSCT recipients except those with a history of only acute GvHD. HSCT recipients without a history of GvHD or resolved chronic GvHD (Groups 1 and 4) had relatively normal numbers of resting Treg (rTreg) lymphocytes while HSCT recipients with active chronic GvHD or a history of only acute GvHD had reduced frequencies of rTreg lymphocytes. Conclusion: CCR7 expressing EMRA CD4 T lymphocytes may be an eff ector T lymphocyte population in the pathogenesis of human chronic GvHD in the content of abnormalities of rTreg lymphocytes. The presence of adequate numbers of rTreg lymphocytes can result in an absence of chronic GvHD or its clinical resolution in spite of the presence of increased numbers of CCR7 expressing EMRA T lymphocytes. Thus, active chronic GvHD may be due to the action of CCR7 expressing EMRA CD4 T lymphocytes in the context of immune dysregulation.

The combination of RAD001 and mycophenolat mofetil for pre-and post-transplant immunosuppression following non-myeloablative haematopoietic stem cell transplantation in canine littermates C. Mueller, S. Lange, J. Werner, R. Wacke, D. Killian, A. Knueppel, G. Knuebel, H. Vogel, C. Roolf, C. Junghanss University of Rostock (Rostock, DE) Background: A common immunosuppression (IS) following allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the combination of Cyclosporin A (CsA) and Mycophenolat Mofetil (MMF). The mTOR-inhibitor Everolimus (RAD001) is used in solid organ transplantation and has been tested for prevention of graft-versus-host disease. Here we investigated a combination of RAD001/MMF as pre-and post-transplant IS following nonmyeloablative HSCT. Methods: On day (d) 0 all dogs (n=8) received HSCT from its MHCidentical siblings. The non-myeloablative conditioning consisted of 200 cGy total body irradiation on d -1. RAD001 was given with 1,5 mg BID from d -1 to +49 and tapered until d +56. MMF (20 mg/ kg bw BID) was administered from d 0 to +28 and tapered until d +42. Pharmacokinetic data were measured on d +5 and +21.

Data were compared to a historical CsA/MMF group (CON). Results: All dogs engrafted. The maximal donor chimerism was median 84% (33-96%) for G on median d +18 and 58% (3-85%) for PBMCs on median d +25. Median platelet nadir of the RAD001 group was 0 * 10 9 /L versus nadir CON: 35 * 10 9 /L (p=0,001). The duration of thrombocytopenia was increased up to median 36 (29-36) days compared to CON median 4 (0-13) days (p=0.001). Median leukocyte nadir was 1 * 10 6 /L versus CON (2.4 * 10 6 /L, p<0.05). The toxicities for RAD001/MMF compared to the CON were signifi cantly increased for all qualities (overall p<0.05). Conclusion: RAD001 and MMF is feasible as pre-and posttransplant IS in a HSCT model but associated with signifi cant toxicities including a prolonged platelet recovery time as well as increased infections. Serum albumin level predicts survival of acute gastrointestinal graft-versus-host disease after allogeneic stem cell transplantation with myeloablative conditioning F. Ayuk, T. Zabelina, L. Bussmann, R. Veit, C. Wolschke, H. Lellek, U. Bacher, A.R. Zander, N. Kröger University Medical Center Hamburg (Hamburg, DE) Introduction: Acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD) is a major cause of mortality after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT). Till date there are no validated biomarkers predicting the outcome of patients (pts) who develop aGVHD. A decrease in serum albumin ≥ 5g/dL from pre-transplant baseline to development of aGVHD has been reported to predict outcome of aGVHD after non-myeloablative conditioning. Methods: We retrospectively analysed 495 consecutive adult patients who underwent allo-SCT at our center between 2005 and 2009. All pts received myeloablative conditioning which was full intensity in 123 (39.9%) and reduced intensity in 185 (60.1%) pts. AGVHD was recorded as from day 5 till 100 after transplant. GVHD was graded according to Przepiorka et al. and treated with 2mg/kg methylprednisolone. The impact of the initial grade of aGVHD, serum albumin and other relevant pre-transplant donor and patient characteristic on overall survival (OS) was estimated by Kaplan-Meier method. Cox regression models were used to estimate hazard ratios. Results: In all, 308 pts (62%) developed aGVHD grades I-IV which was initial grade I in 118 (38,3%), II in 127 (41,2%) III in 48 (15,6%) [P631] S168 an IV in 15 (4,9%) pts. 1 year OS was 82%, 65% and 60% % for grades I, II and III respectively und 60% for II-IV combined. Only 1/15 pts with aGVHD IV was alive after 3 months. Pre-transplant albumin level did not signifi cantly impact 1/5 yr. survival (65/48% vs. 71/54%, p = 0.3). for patients with albumin ≤ 34 (low) and > 34 (high) respectively. Neither did decrease ≥ 5g/dL from pre-transplant baseline to development of aGVHD (56/49%% vs. 70/52%, p = 0.42). However serum albumin level at time of diagnosis of aGVHD predicted outcome: 1/5 yr OS was 60/40% for pts with low vs. 75/63% for pts with high albumin, p = 0.001. In patients with gastrointestinal (GI) aGVHD II-IV (n = 50) 1 yr OS was 32% for low vs. 68% for high albumin, p = 0.01. On the other hand, survival of patients with only skin aGVHD II-IV (n = 68) was 72% for both low and high albumin. Results of cox regression multivariate analysis are summarized in table 1. Conclusion: Our results indicate that serum albumin is a relevant prognostic biomarker in adult patients who develop GI-aGVHD after myeloablative conditioning.

body_text.text: Tissue-specifi c homing of NK cell subpopulations impacts GVHD prevention

Clinical studies exploiting the impact of natural killer (NK) cells in allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) have provided promising results. It is known that NK cells are a heterogeneous population and can be divided into functionally distinct NK cell subpopulations. Murine NK cells can be separated along their expression of CD27 and CD11b and CD117 (c-kit). However, the functional relevance of distinct NK cell subsets in graft-versushost-disease (GVHD) has not been investigated in detail so far. Here we report on diff erent genomic, phenotypic, functional and migratory properties of four distinct NK cell subsets. Our data clearly demonstrate that CD27+ NK cells revealed the highest IFN-g production upon coculture with tumor cells and/or IL-2, whereas the CD11b+ NK cells express multiple genes of cytotoxic pathways and develop the highest cytotoxic capacity towards tumor cells. Furthermore, the CD11b+ NK cell subset signifi cantly reduced T cell proliferation induced by allogeneic dendritic cells in mixed lymphocytes reactions. Next, we analyzed the migratory capacity and tissue-specifi c homing of the diff erent NK cell subsets by in vivo bioluminescence imaging (BLI) of adoptively transferred FACS-sorted Luc+CD45.1+ NK subpopulations in autologous and allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Of interest, FACS analysis and in vivo imaging revealed that CD11b+ NK cells preferentially migrated to peripheral GVHD target organs.

body_text.text: Finally, this study addressed for the fi rst time the role of distinct NK cell subpopulations in the development of GVHD in a fully MHC mismatched HSCT mouse model. Importantly, we identifi ed the CD11b+ NK cell population as the NK cell subset that signifi cantly diminished GVHD. BLI of Luc+CD11b+ NK cells revealed that this subset migrates to the colonic tissue to prevent development of GVHD colitis as shown by colonoscopy. In summary, our comparative study outlines that only CD11b+ NK cells, migrating to the peripheral GVHD target organs and providing the most effi cient cytolytic capacity directed against allogeneic dendritic cells, protect against GVHD. These new insights are highly relevant for the selection of optimal NK cell subsets in the fi eld of cellular immunotherapy.

body_text.text: Cytokine gene polymorphisms and severe acute graftversus-host disease (grade ≥II) after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation from HLA identical siblings

Graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) is one of the most important complications after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and infl uences morbidity and mortality. Polymorphisms at genes coding for several proinfl ammatory cytokines and for their related receptors or receptor inhibitors are involved in this complication. To assess the role of cytokine gene polymorphisms on acute GvHD (aGVHD), we analysed 189 pairs of donor and recipients transplanted from HLA identical sibling for malignant hematological diseases between 2000 and 2007. The median recipients age at transplantation was 43.4 years . Two third of the patients received bone marrow before myelo-ablative conditioning regimen, the median delay between diagnosis and transplantation was 9 months (1-76). Five diff erent polymorphisms from 3 cytokine genes were analyzed: IL-10 -592C/A, -819C/T and -1082G/A, IL-1β -511A/G and TGFβ1 -509C/T. All the pairs were studied for each gene polymorphism using the Taqman technology as previously described (Malkki 2007) . Univariate analysis found a signifi cant negative impact of donor genotypes carrying IL1β A allele (p=0,02) or IL10-592 A allele (p=0,03) on aGvHD. We did not fi nd any eff ect associated with IL10-819 and -1082 polymorphisms, but as previously described (Lin 2003) , the presence of IL10 A-T-A haplotype in the donor, signifi cantly increased the risk of aGVHD (p=0.043). We performed a multivariate analysis on aGVHD incidence taking into account TGFβ1-509, IL-10-592 and IL1β polymorphisms, together with other known risk factors. A higher incidence of aGVHD was found in pairs where donor has an IL1β A allele (HR 4,16 -p=0,0031) and increased when the

S169 donor is A/A (HR>15 -p=0,0091). For IL10-592, the impact of the A allele was found diff erent when carried by the donor (higher risk of aGVHD, HR=3,52 p=0,00083) or the recipient (lower risk of aGVHD, HR=0,48 p=0,024), but this eff ect seems only signifi cant in pairs where donor did not carry any A allele (rec AC x don CC -HR 0.2 -p=0.05). Donor with TGFβ1-509 T allele was found to have a signifi cant lower risk of aGVHD (HR 0,42 -p=0,02). (table 1) . The role of the cytokine cascade in the physiopathology of GVHD is well established. Our study documents the possible role of IL-1β, TGFβ1 and IL10 gene polymorphisms in this setting. A proven association of cytokine gene polymorphisms with acute GVHD would enable the clinician to modify the therapeutic strategy and enhance the outcomes. Background: Genetic aberration of TNFRSF14 occurs in half of patients (pts) with follicular lymphoma (FL). TNFRSF14 is a ligand for BTLA, a receptor which inhibits T cell responses. Activated B cells effi ciently present antigens, and BTLA signaling is important in control of donor T cell alloresponses that mediate acute graftversus-host-disease (aGvHD) after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT). We therefore hypothesized that TNFRSF14 aberrations in FL may reduce BTLA-mediated inhibition of alloreactive donor T cells after AHSCT resulting in increased frequency or severity of aGvHD. Objective: To investigate the impact of TNFRSF14 aberrations on outcome of FL pts undergoing AHSCT. Methods: 21 FL pts undergoing T-cell replete reduced-intensity conditioned AHSCT were included in the study. Tumour DNA from pre-ASCT lymph node biopsies was screened for TNFRSF14 mutations and deletions by Sanger sequencing and multiplex ligation-probe amplifi cation respectively. Cumulative incidence (CI) of aGvHD and treatment-related mortality (TRM) were calculated with FL progression as a competing risk. Results: TNFRSF14 aberrations were identifi ed in 10/21 pts (48%). 5 pts had mutations (of which 4 had deletions of the second allele) and 5 pts had deletions without mutations. Disease and donor characteristics were similar in pts with and without aberrations. There was no signifi cant diff erence in the CI of aGvHD in pts with or without TNFRSF14 aberrations. However all 4 pts that died from aGVHD had TNFRSF14 aberrations (3 pts had mutations, 2 with additional deletions of the other allele). There was a signifi cantly higher CI of death from aGvHD and a trend to lower overall survival in pts with TNFRSF14 aberrations compared to those without TNFRSF14 aberrations (38% vs. 0% (p=0.03, Fig. 1 ) and 40% vs. 74% (p=0.06, Fig. 2 ) respectively). Conclusions: This study is the fi rst to describe the potential impact of TNFRSF14 aberrations in FL on outcome after AHSCT. Even in this small cohort of pts, the presence of TNFRSF14 aberrations, particularly biallelic loss, was associated with increased death from aGvHD. These fi ndings require confi rmation in a larger cohort and in vitro studies to determine the functional impact of TNFRSF14 aberrations on allogeneic T cell responses. However, our results suggest FL patients with TNFRSF14 aberrations may benefi t from more aggressive immunosuppression to reduce the incidence of fatal aGvHD after AHSCT. (1)

Introduction: Despite many improvements in the fi eld of HSCT, acute graft versus host disease (aGVHD) remains a life-threatening complication and reduces the effi cacy of HSCT substantially. Especially the outcome of patients with severe steroid-resistant aGVHD remains very poor. Therefore, new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of aGVHD are needed. Objective: The feasibility of the generation of Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (MSC) expanded with human plasma and platelet lysate (hPPL) was tested as well as the feasibility and safety of S170 the application of hPPL-MSC in patients with steroid-refractory aGVHD. As mechanisms in humans are poorly understood, phenotypical and functional changes in immunological cell types and cytokine levels were investigated before, during and after infusion of MSC. Methods: 50 patients with steroid-refractory aGVHD grade II to IV were included in an open-label, non-randomized prospective phase I/II study and received up to four MSC infusions. Clinical parameters as well as a comprehensive phenotypical and functional analysis was performed. Results: Between January 2009 and July 2012, 50 patients were included, 2 patients dropped out due to fast relapse of their primary malignancy. 48 patients were thus available for analysis of whom 7 children. Median overall grade was III, organs involved were skin (52%), gastrointestinal tract (88%) and liver (35%). No severe side effects were observed. Complete overall response was observed in 24 patients (50%) after a median of 53 days (range 3-116 days). The overall survival was significantly better in responders when compared to non-responders (p <0.001). Immunological monitoring suggests that anti-viral and anti-leukemia reactive T-cells are well preserved in all patients who responded to MSC treatment. In addition, we identified biomarkers which associate even 2 weeks after MSC infusion with a complete resolution of GVHD, which occurred usually after months and studied the microenvironment of the gut in selected patients. Conclusion: Generation and infusion of hPPL-MSCs in steroidresistant aGVHD grade II-IV is feasible, safe and appears to be eff ective. Infusion of MSC did not impair anti-virus and antileukemia reactive T-cells. Identifi ed biomarkers predict very early a usually late clinical resolution of GVHD, cellular biomarkers are found to be located within the gut and are thus most likely both, relevant for the biology of the disease and useful to early guide clinical decisions.

body_text.text: Acute graft-versus-host disease (aGvHD) remains a major complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), thus early investigator-independent diagnosis is important for early intervention. Using capillary electrophoresis coupled on-line to mass spectrometry (CE-MS) to monitor urine of patients after allogeneic HSCT a proteomic pattern consisting of 17 differentially excreted peptides was generated. Ten peptides have been identifi ed to date as various collagen fragments (indicating disturbances in metabolism of collagen or early organ damage), fragments of fi bronectin and albumin. In addition, fragments of β-2-microglobulin (β2M) and CD99, an activation marker of T-cells, are excreted in patients with aGvHD depending on severity. These peptides correspond to proteins which are present in human plasma and can be detected by antibodies allowing direct comparison with proteins described by others as plasma biomarker at the time of diagnosis of acute GvHD. 69 patients transplanted at Hannover Medical School were included in this fi rst analysis. The majority were transplanted for acute leukaemia (n=48) from matched, unrelated donors (n=39), HLA-identical siblings (n=18) or mismatched donors (n=12). Reduced intensity conditioning was used for 20 patients and 63 received T-cell depleting antibodies prior to HSCT. Samples were collected prospectively from patients at onset of aGvHD (n=20), patients at similar time-points early after HSCT without aGvHD (n=14), patients at diagnosis of chronic GvHD (cGvHD; n=13) and patients without GvHD (>day +100; n=33) and analyzed with CE-MS, ELISA and Bio-Plex. The previously published biomarker sIL-2Rα, IL-8, sTNFR1, ST2/IL-1R4, HGF, REG3α and Elafi n (Levine et al., 2012) as well as CD99 and β2M (CE-MS-analysis) were analyzed in all plasma samples. Elafi n and HGF were not useful to distinguish patients with aGvHD or cGvHD from those without. None of the known plasma biomarker were able to distinguish acute from chronic GvHD, as they are rather marker for infl ammatory processes. But our results confi rm that β2M and CD99 are fi rst of all detectable in urine and plasma of patients with aGvHD and secondly diff erentially excreted according to severity of disease. In addition, both marker are capable of distinguishing patients with aGvHD from those with cGvHD with high sensitivity and specifi city. Reproducibility of the preliminary results and the predictive power of those biomarker will be tested in a blinded, prospective validation set.

body_text.text: Dendritic cells (DC) are centrally involved in the development of acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) following allogeneic hemopoietic cell transplantation (alloHCT) and previous work has shown that DC expression of the activation marker CMRF-44 correlated with subsequent acute GVHD. The traffi cking of immature DC from blood to GVHD target organs is likely to be regulated by chemokine receptors expressed on activated DC and published data suggests that CCR5 is important in alloHCT. We found diff erences in chemokine receptor expression on DC subsets in normal individuals and showed that, although the major CD16+ myeloid blood DC subpopulation did not express CCR5, it was induced on CD16+ DC after culture in allogeneic MLR supernatant, an eff ect mediated largely by interferon-γ. In 42 patients monitored to day 100 post alloHCT, CCR5 was expressed on a signifi cant proportion of CD16+ DC (p = 0.0001, compared to normal cells). The maximum percentage of CCR5+ CD16+ DC in patients at any time post-transplant correlated with acute GVHD: mean 27.5% (0-50%) in GVHD grades II-IV, mean 11.6% (0-44; p=0.0006) in grades 0-I. The maximum percentage CCR5 positive prior to developing grades II-IV GVHD (mean 22.7%, 0-50%) was higher than in grades 0-I GVHD (mean 11.4%, 0-38%) (p=0.0285). CCR5 levels >20.5% on CD16+ myeloid DC predicted grades II-IV GVHD with a sensitivity of 66.7% and specifi city of 86.7%. These observations may refl ect DC activation and altered DC homing during the alloimmune response to alloHCT, and could allow early therapeutic intervention prior to the clinical diagnosis of GVHD. Acute graft-versus-host disease (aGvHD) of the skin following hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is diffi cult to clinically diff erentiate from other underlying causes. Elafi n has been reported to be specifi c for skin-aGvHD, but no longitudinal follow-up is available as to whether elafi n can predict response to steroids. We aimed to determine in a retrospective longitudinal study the role of elafi n in monitoring skin aGVHD. All children transplanted in our unit between 2004-2012 who developed severe (≥ grade 2) aGvHD with skin involvement (n=33) were evaluated. Skin biopsies (n=31) from 25 aGvHD patients were available and compared to 23 biopsies from patients without aGvHD (n=13) or non-HSCT recipients. Biopsies were stained for elafi n, a biomarker reported to be specifi c for skin-aGvHD. The intensity of Elafi n expression on skin biopsies was scored and the mean score was signifi cantly higher in skin-aGVHD biopsies than in controls (4.3 versus 1.8; p<0.0001). In addition, Elafi n scores in biopsies after HSCT distinguished aGvHD from other causes (sensitivity 88.5%, specifi city 92.3%) Biopsies especially in children are not always feasible and ELISA for biomarkers are commercially available giving results within 4 hours. Elafi n and three other previously reported biomarkers, sIL2Ra, HGF and TNFR1, were longitudinally measured in sera from pre-HSCT until at least day 50 after aGvHD. Sera of 27 patients were available. At the start of aGvHD, Elafi n, sIL-2Ra and sTNFR1 concentrations in serum were signifi cantly elevated, compared with samples before onset of skin-aGvHD (p=0.007, <0.0001 and 0.0002). In addition, these concentrations were signifi cantly higher than serum levels in patients without aGvHD (n=12). Only elafi n concentrations correlated at the day of biopsy with the pathology report showing increased levels in aff ected patients (p=0.0021). HGF concentrations were signifi cantly lower in patients refractory to steroids prior to and at onset of aGvHD. Based on these data, sIl-2Ra and sTNFR1 are not specifi c for skin GvHD and may be related to other organs involved in aGvHD. In contrast, serum elafi n is a suitable alternative for diagnostic biopsies for skin-aGvHD. However response to steroids cannot be predicted on the basis of Elafi n concentrations. Early intervention with second line salvage therapy should be considered in patients with low HGF concentrations. Assessing response to treatment of gastrointestinal acute graftversus-host disease (aGvHD) may be hampered by persistent diarrhea resulting from damage to the gut in the absence of ongoing aGvHD. Histological examination of gut biopsies confi rm the diagnosis but are invasive. Biomarkers may be an alternative diagnostic tool. We aimed to study biopsies and biomarkers to evaluate the response to treatment with mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC) in children. In this study, 22 patients received MSC for severe steroid refractory aGvHD of the gut (confi rmed by a biopsy in 20 patients). In 82% (n=18) diarrhea persisted after the fi rst MSC and a second (and in 3 cases a third) MSC infusion was considered. A second gut biopsy was taken from 12 patients before subsequent MSC infusion and in 8 of these biopsies no signs of active aGvHD were seen. Three patients with a positive biopsy responded to subsequent MSC infusion. Eleven patients showed a complete (CR), 6 a partial response (PR) and 5 no response at 28 days after starting MSC therapy (1-3 infusions) . In addition, previously reported biomarkers were assessed. Patient samples were longitudinally measured starting before SCT until 50 days after the last MSC infusion. At the start of aGvHD, serum concentrations of sIL-2Rα, sTNFR1, REG3α and soluble cytokeratin 18 fragment (sCK18F) were signifi cantly elevated compared with samples before onset. Response to MSC at day 28 was predicted by sIL-2Rα concentrations on day 7 post MSC. Patients with CR/PR (n=17) had lower sIL-2Rα concentrations compared to non-responders (n=5) (p=0.015). sCK18F at start of aGvHD and at initiation of MSC therapy discriminate between CR and PR/NR (p=0.01). Serum levels of sCK18F were signifi cantly raised at the day of a positive gut biopsy ( Figure 1 ). Individual results of these tests showed a wide variation in values. Conclusion: This is the fi rst report to assess the usefulness of biopsy versus biomarkers in children with aGvHD treated with MSC. Biopsy evaluation after MSC infusion eff ectively distinguishes children requiring additional MSC infusions. We confi rm that biomarkers are elevated at the onset of GvHD and although predictive of those children who responded to MSC therapy, failed to distinguish between persistent aGvHD and post infl ammatory malabsorption ( Figure 2 ). Sequential biopsies remain essential and should be included in clinical trials of experimental cellular therapy. Further study of biomarkers is warranted.

body_text.text: Inolimomab for children with steroid-refractory acute graftversus-host disease: a national multicentre phase II retrospective analysis M. Ouachee-Chardin (1), B. Neven (2) , L. Deville (2) , I. Hirsch (2) (4), G. Plat (5) , V. Gandemer (6) , P. Lehert (7), A. Fischer (2) (

One hundred twenty-three children were evaluated retrospectively for the treatment of steroid-refractory acute graftversus-host disease (aGVHD) with Inolimomab, a murine anti-IL2R. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantations(HSCT) were performed between 1995 and 2012. Diseases were non malignant inherited diseases (63%) and hematological malignancies (37%). Median age was 4,3 years. Donors were Matched-related (27%), Matchedunrelated (32%), Mismatched-unrelated (13%), Haplo-identical (21%) and Cord Blood (7%). The graft source was BM (80%),PBSC (12%) and CB (8%). 37% patients had a myeloablative conditioning. The median time to aGVHD was 13 days after HSCT. The baseline grade of aGVHD was I in 19%, II 46%, III 25% and IV 10%. The median delay between aGVHD and Inolimomab was 16 days. The median dose was 0.4mg/kg and the median treatment duration of 27 days. We observe 55% complete responses and 14% partial responses for a total response rate of 69% and with no side eff ects. Among the responders, 26% relapse. Incidence of infection during treatment was 19%. A logistic model on complete response provide evidence of the high predictive negative eff ect of the GVHD baseline grade [Odds Ratio(OR): 5.24]. No particular target organ was a signifi cant predictive factor for treatment response or survival. However, multi-organ involvement predicted worse survival with 34%, 45% and 52% of death for patients with one, two, and three or more organs involved, respectively (p=0.234). The observed overall survival probability was 59%, with a median survival time of 463 days. Survival was also signifi cantly improved for responders (Relative Risk: 0.413; p=0.002). As shown by multivariate Cox model, the survival was signifi cantly lower for patients with non malignant inherited diseases [Hazard Ratio (HR) =2.88, p<.001] compared with hematological malignancies, and female patients were associated with higher mortality (HR=1.72, p=.049). For both response and survival, the success rates were signifi cantly increasing with year of transplantation. Chronic GVHD (cGVHD) occurred in 56% patients, extensive in 42%. cGVHD incidence was 78%, 72%, 42% for Non Responders, Partial Responders and Complete Responders (Anova, p=.017). Patients with hematological malignancies were observed with signifi cantly less cGHVD (OR=.29, p=.012). Fifty-one patients died, 17(33%) before day 100 and 34(67%) after day 100, mostly of infections (55%) and GVHD (51%). In conclusion, Inolimomab is well tolerated and eff ective for steroid-refractory aGVHD in pediatrics.

body_text.text: Because of its potent immunomodulatory eff ect together with presumably high safety profi le, apoptotic cells infusion (ApoCell) was tested in addition to cyclosporine and methotrexate, as prophylaxis of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in HLA-matched myeloablative allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (alloBMT) from a related donor. We conducted a phase I//IIa clinical trial where we treated 13 patients (median age, 37 years; range, 20-59 years) with advanced hematologic malignancies (7 patients with ALL, 5 patients with AML (4 patients with MDS that transformed to AML and one patient with AML de novo), and 1 patient with CML that received conventional myeloablation with 35, or 70, or 140, or 210x106 cell/kg of donor ApoCell, on day -1 of transplantation. Ten serious adverse eff ects were reported with all being not related (seven) or unlikely to be related (3) to ApoCell infusion. Out of hundreds adverse eff ects, only three were reported as possibly related to ApoCell infusion (with no defi nite or probable adverse eff ects). The non-relapse mortality at day 100 and 180 after transplantation was the same, 7.7%. The overall survival at 100 and 180 days after transplantation was 92% and 85%, respectively. The incidences of acute grades II through IV GVHD for all 13 patients and for the two higher doses were 23% and 0% (six patients), respectively. Biomarker ratio levels including tumor necrosis factor receptor I (TNFR1), hepatocyte growth factor (HGF), interleukin 2 receptor α (IL-2Ra), and interleukin 7 (IL-7), supported the clinical data. These results suggest that single-infusion high-dose donor early apoptotic cells in HLA-matched myeloablative alloBMT is a safe and potentially eff ective single-agent prophylaxis of acute GVHD occurring after myeloablative alloBMT. Introduction: In allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), the anti-CD52 antibody Alemtuzumab is frequently used for T-cell depletion (TCD) to prevent graft versus host disease (GVHD). We demonstrated long term persistence of functionally impaired glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchor negative eff ector T-cells in patients receiving high dose (100mg) Alemtuzumab in combination with a dose reduced conditioning regimen (Fludarabin/Melphalan). Despite TCD, half of our patients developed acute GVHD. Since regulatory T cells (Treg) play a major role in GVHD, we asked whether GPI-anchor negative Treg are present in our patients. Methods: We analyzed peripheral blood samples of 12 patients with acute GVHD (aGVHD), 7 with chronic GVHD (cGVHD), and 10 patients without GVHD after Alemtuzumab-mediated TCD. Treg were identifi ed as CD3+CD4+CD25+ cells either FoxP3+ or CD127-and investigated according to their CD52-expression. FLAER staining confi rmed that the lack of CD52 was due to missing GPI-anchors. We analyzed the activation-markers GARP, HLA-DR and CD45RA and studied Treg populations in the time course of patients who recovered from aGVHD and those with ongoing late aGVHD. In individual patients, we isolated GPI-anchor positive and negative Treg by FACS-Sort, expanded them and performed Treg suppression assays. Results: GPI-anchor negative Treg were observed in all patients. The percentage of GPI-anchor negative Treg was signifi cantly elevated in patients with aGVHD: median 80.35% (range 56,2-96,8%) in comparison to 17,4% (range 0-57,8%) in patients with cGVHD or without GVHD. Activated Treg were exclusively detected among GPI-anchor positive Treg. Patients resolving from aGVHD restored GPI-anchor positive and activated Treg. The percentage of GPIanchor negative Treg populations remained high in patients with ongoing aGVHD and we found no activated Treg even under long term immunosuppression. First experiments with sorted Treg suggest that GPI-anchor negative Treg were unable to suppress T-cell proliferation. Summary: We demonstrated for the fi rst time the reconstitution of GPI-anchor negative Treg in patients following Alemtuzumabmediated TCD. These Treg were functionally altered and less likely to exhibit an activated phenotype. Ongoing aGVHD was associated with high percentages of GPI-anchor negative Treg suggesting that their functional alteration might play a role in aGVHD pathophysiology.

Background: Steroids are used as front-line therapy of aGVHD, with an increased risk of infectious complications. To reduce the incidence of infections in the setting of haploidentical T-replete (TR-H) bone marrow transplantation patients developing aGVHD, we decide to perfom ECP as fi rst line therapy to treat aGVHD. Patients and methods: Since 2009, 43 received TR-H with NMA/ RIC regimens. Patient characteristics are listed in table 1. Conditioning regimens consisted of Cy, fl udarabine, and low dose TBI in 40 patients, and thiotepa, fl udarabine, Cy and low dose TBI for 6 patients. GVHD prophylaxis consisted of Cy 50 mg/kg day +3 and +4, tacrolimus and MMF, from d+5. ECP was performed using the off -line technique and started as soon as possible after aGVHD diagnosis. The ECP schedule consisted of 4 rounds of two procedures per week, 3 rounds of two procedures every other week, and fi nally 2 procedures every month until clinical improvement. Decision to discontinue ECP was made on a case-by-case basis, taking into account clinical response (including IST changes), logistical reasons, and the decision of the treating physician. Results: Grade 1-4 aGVHD was diagnosed in 13 patients (30%) and grade 2-4 aGVHD in 10 (23%). The median time to aGVHD was 52 days (d) (range 38-81). All patients had grade 2 skin aGVHD and only 1 grade 4 liver aGVHD. Three patients received steroids because of logistical problems. 7 out of 10 patients was treated by ECP alone. In 3 patients steroids therapy was administered waiting for ECP and stopped in a week. ECP was started after a median time of 3 d (range 1-30) from aGVHD diagnosis. The median number of ECP was 15 (range 9-44) and the median duration was 99 d (range 40-368). All but one patient achieved complete response, and 1 partial remission. One patient achieved partial remission. The median time to response was 14 d (range . Tolerance to ECP was good and no patients developed severe toxicities. Infectious complications after ECP were rare and no lifethreatening. Chronic GVHD was diagnosed in 2 patients (18%). 4 patients died: 1 from heart failure secondary to hemocromatosis, 2 from disease progression and 1 from aGVHD toxicity after donor lymphocyte infusions for treat relapsed disease. Conclusions: This study suggests that fi rst line ECP is eff ective and well tolerated in patients developing aGVHD after TR-H. However, these results are preliminary and have to be confi rmed in a more consistent cohort of patients.

body_text.text: Introduction: Glutathione S-transferase T1 (GSTT1) and GSTM1 are drug-metabolizing enzymes and are highly expressed in liver and kidney. GSTT1 is absent in 20% of the Caucasian population, while GSTM1 in 50%. In liver and renal transplantation, we have reported that GSTT1-negative patients who received a GSTT1positive graft have a higher risk to develop chronic rejection. In addition, UDP glucuronosyltransferase 2 family, polypeptide B17 (UGT2B17) catalyzes the transfer of glucuronic acid. This protein is highly expressed in liver and prostatic tissues and is absent in 12% of the Caucasian population; UGT2B17-mismatch is a risk factor for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Objective: The aim of this study was to analyze the infl uence of these mHAs in the development of acute or chronic hepatic (h) GVHD. One hundred forty-four patients with hematologic malignancies undergoing HSCT, between 2003 and 2011 in Hospital Virgen del Rocío (Seville, Spain), were included in the study. Methods: We performed the mHAs genotyping by Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) of recipient DNA and their corresponding donors. Three combination groups are detailed in Table 1 . We consider mismatch the null-donor and positive-recipient combination and matched the other three possible combinations. Conclusions: In conclusion, we identify GSTT1 disparity as a risk factor to develop acute and chronic hepatic GVHD and to infl uence survival after HSCT.
