body_text.text: Introduction: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) remains the only cure for most haematological neoplasms, however the mortality rate is high (40 to 60%) and recovery is mainly limited by complications such as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). High resolution HLA matching has improved survival in HSCT over recent years, however acute GVHD (aGVHD) still remains a serious complication. Specifi c novel diagnostic markers that would predict for the occurrence and severity of aGVHD could reduce the incidence and mortality of this disease. There is substantial evidence to indicate that the inappropriate production of cytokines and chemokines contribute to the pathogenesis of aGVHD. The aim of study was to investigate the expression of selected candidate genes in order to identify novel early diagnostic markers for GVHD which may in the future reduce the rate of mortality of this disease. Methods: In order to investigate gene expression in aGVHD we used RNA from a human skin explant assay which has been shown to predict GVHD in patient cohorts and in addition RNA from clinical aGVHD skin samples taken at the onset of aGVHD and normal skin samples. For our initial screening process we used three custom taqman low density arrays and then further validated these results. Results: Our study identifi ed four genes whose expression was signifi cantly up regulated in aGVHD skin, they were, CXC chemokine type 9 (CXCL9), transporter associated with antigen processing 1 (TAP1), leucocyte immunoglobulin like receptor type 5 (LILRA5) and ubiquitin D (UBD) (p=0.0007, 0.0174, 0.0402 and 0.0441 respectively). In addition we identifi ed three genes, complement C1Q and tumour necrosis factor-related protein 7 (C1QTNF7), interleukin 1 receptor type 2 (IL1R2) and leucocyte specifi c transcript 1 (LST1), whose expression was signifi cantly down regulated in aGVHD skin (p=0.0002, 0.0028 and 0.0138 respectively). Six of these genes CXCL9, TAP1, LILRA5, UBD, IL1R2 and LST1 are induced by IFN γ whereas C1QTNF7 is an adipokine, members of the adipokine family have been associated with the innate immune response. Conclusion: These seven genes or their protein products could potentially be used as diagnostic markers for GVHD or in predicting its severity and are currently being evaluated in independent cohorts.

body_text.text: Introduction: Clinical advantage of human fetal membranes cells (hFMCs) has been documented in more than 100 years ago in burns. In recent years hFMCs raised signifi cant attention as source of stromal cells and may also be of potential benefi t in regenerative medicine. We have previously shown that hFMCs suppress human lymphocyte proliferation in vitro in mixed lymphocyte culture (MLC) and may reverse graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in vivo. Further studies have shown that suppressive function of hFMCs is dependent on cell-to-cell contact. In the present report we evaluate the suppressive function of hFMCs in xenogeneic setting to explore the underlying immunosuppressive mechanisms. Methods: Isolated hFMCs from passage 3 or 4 were used in series of ex vivo MLC and in vivo (mouse model GVHD) animal experiments. C57BL/6 and BALB/c mice, as two allogeneic strains, were used for MLC experiments as well as donor and recipient in an experimental GVHD setting. Results: Our fi ndings show that despite species diff erences, hFMCs suppress proliferation and activation of mouse lymphocytes. The immunosuppressive eff ect is not strain limited and lymphocytes from both strains were suppressed. Balb/c lymphocyte proliferation, against allogeneic (B6 lymphocyte), mitogen (Con A) and xenogeneic (human PBL) stimulation, were decreased by 75% to 80% following addition of 25% of hFMC to the culture. Similar fi nding were observed when C57BL/6 splenocyte were used as responder cells. The immunosuppressive function of hFMCs was not due to T reg cell induction or through trans-well culture setting, meaning that cell to cell contact was needed. Subsequently we applied hFMCs at diff erent time points following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation in a well-established mouse model of GVHD. The preliminary results are promising and infusion of hFMCs 3 days after allogeneic BMT increased survival of the animals. However, the hFMCs cell dose and injection time need to be optimized. Conclusion: FMCs may be a valuable source of stromal cells for GVHD. The isolated FMCs are strong immunesuppressive cells not only in allogeneic setting but also in xenogeneic systems. Further improvements regarding isolation, culture and application are needed. Introduction: Although multiple biomarkers of acute intestinal GVHD (GI-GVHD) have been identifi ed, the translation of these from the bench to the bedside remains complex. The aim of this study was to evaluate fecal calprotectin (FC) as a single biomarker for the diagnosis and follow up of GI-GVHD in adult patients with haematological malignancies who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) at our center. Patients and Methods: From January 2012, 22 consecutive SCT patients had been monitored for FC (normal range: 0-50 mg/kg) with at least 2 samples/patient (range 2-13). Fecal samples were collected at 2 week intervals until day 90 from SCT or at the onset of symptoms of GI-GVHD, even after day 90. Table 1 summarizes patients' characteristics. The diagnosis of GI-GVHD was based on standard clinical criteria, together with other microbiological and histopathological tests.

body_text.text: Results: Seven of 22 tested patients (32%) were diagnosed with GI-GVHD. In this group FC median value was 467mg/kg (range 29-5000) at the onset of symptoms; only one of these 7 patients presented FC levels in the normal ranges at the diagnosis and during follow-up (<50mg/kg). In one of the 22 patients included in the study the clinical diagnosis of GI-GVHD was not supported by the endoscopic and histological fi ndings and in this patient, the FC median value was 60mg/kg (range 6,25-120). FC median value in all other 14/22 patients (64%) without GI-GVHD was 44mg/kg (range 6-163). For a cut-off point value of 200mg/kg, sensitivity for the test was 86%, specifi city 100%, positive predictive value 100% and negative predictive value 94%. We couldn't observe a correlation between FC levels at the onset of GVHD and severity of clinical symptoms. In fact FC median value was 728mg/kg (range: 258-5000) in patients in stage 1 GVHD compared with 467mg/kg (range: 29-3121) in patients in stage 2-4. We observed that patients achieving stable FC values under 200mg/ kg at the follow-up (in 4 of the 6 patients with abnormal FC fi ndings at the onset of GVHD -true positive) had a more favourable outcome and prognosis. Conclusion: Our data confirm that FC is specific, inexpensive, non-invasive test and easy to perform. This biomarker can improve the diagnosis of acute GI-GVHD with an optimal cutoff level of 200mg/kg. This test seems to be promising also for the evaluation of the activity of GI-GVHD during follow-up and it could be used as a potential decisional tool for anti GVHD therapy modulation.

Objective: Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) are multipotential cells which are capable of diff erentiating into a variety of cell types. Due to their immunomodulatory properties, MSCs have been used as cell-based therapy to reduce grafts-versus-host disease (GVHD) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). As reactivation of cytomegalovirus (CMV) constitutes a frequent problem after HSCT, we studied whether MSCs may also have an infl uence on CMV-specifi c T cell responses. Methods: For mixed lymphocyte reaction (MLR), CD8 negative peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from donor A were co-incubated with CD8 positive cells from donor B (APC:T cell ratio=8:1) for 6 days. MACS®-purifi ed CD8 positive T cells from buff y coats of HLA-A2/CMV seropositive healthy volunteers were stimulated with a HLA-A*0201-restricted CMVpp65 (NLVPMVATV) peptide in a mixed lymphocyte-peptide culture (MLPC). Bonemarrow derived MSCs from human platelet lysate (PL) or fetal calf serum (FCS) based medium were co-cultured with the MLR and MLPC. Flow cytometry and enzyme-linked immunospot (ELISPOT) assays were used to study the immunomodulatory eff ect of MSCs on CMV-specifi c CD8 positive T cells. Results: Both PL-and FCS-cultured MSCs inhibited the proliferation of CD8 positive T cells after stimulation with CMV pp65 peptide, and reduced the number of CMV-specifi c T cells stained with pp65-specifi c MHC-tetramer by more than 60%. Similarly, MSCs suppressed the frequency of activated CD8 positive T cells expressing CD137 and the secretion of cytokines like IFN-γ and granzyme B. In addition we confi rmed the modulatory eff ect of MSCs in MLR, as we observed inhibition of T cell proliferation. Conclusion: MSCs have strong immunosuppressive eff ects on alloreactive T cells and infusion of MSCs could be a promising immunotherapy for GVHD. However, MSCs can also inhibit CMV specifi c CD8 positive T cells. Therefore attention must be paid to early detection and pre-emptive treatment of CMV reactivation when patients are undergoing therapy with MSC. Acute GvHD (aGvHD) of the GI-tract is a severe complication after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT). Since an early treatment of aGvHD is essential a rapid diff erentiation between aGvHD and infections is necessary. For the fi rst time this study describes systematically magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) fi ndings in intestinal aGvHD. Methods: Prior to conditioning 46 consecutive patients planned for allogeneic SCT underwent as baseline investigation abdominal MRI on a whole-body 3T MR-scanner. The sequence protocol included axial and coronal T2 weighted sequences, an axial diffusion weighted sequence and a dynamic T1 weighted, contrast enhanced sequence. All patients with severe GI-tract symptoms or with signs of skin aGvHD received a second MRI immediately after onset of symptoms. In addition, all patients with severe GI tract symptoms received endoscopic examination of the upper GI-tract and colon. MRI fi ndings of patients with histologically proven intestinal aGvHD (GvHD group) were compared with the results from patients with isolated aGvHD of the skin or non-GvHD related GI-tract symptoms (control group). Results: 8 patients (GvHD group) suff ered from histologically proven intestinal aGvHD. In the control group 3 patients had isolated skin aGvHD, 1 patient had CMV colitis and 4 patients experienced diarrhea without specifi c diagnosis. In all GvHD group patients a unique MRI pattern was detected: Gut involvement presented as long-segment (>20cm) bowel wall thickening with submucosal edema. Mucosal wall was signifi cantly thickened in patients with intestinal aGvHD in comparison with control group patients as well as with baseline data (mean large bowel wall thickness: baseline 0.35mm, GvHD group 0.9mm, control group 0.36mm; mean small bowel wall thickness: baseline 0.38mm, GvHD group 0.79mm, control group 0.34mm). A mucosal diff usion restriction was seen in all GvHD group patients. The perfusion of the bowel spared the submucosa while demonstrating strong mucosal perfusion: In the T1 sequence 2 minutes after gadolinium injection a 2-fold enhancement was detectable in the bowel wall of the control group. In contrast, the mean enhancement was 2.8-fold in small bowel wall segments aff ected by aGvHD. Conclusions: In intestinal aGvHD a specifi c MR-appearance with long-segment aff ection of the bowel concomitant with marked bowel wall edema, restricted mucosal diff usion, mucosal hyperemia and ascites was detected. This unique MRI pattern might allow an early non-invasive diagnosis of intestinal aGvHD. The placenta protects the developing fetus from the mother's immune system. Fetal membranes have been used for almost a century to treat severe burn injuries, indicating that these tissues can promote wound healing. We have previously found that fetal membrane cells (FMCs) isolated from term placenta prevent alloreactivity in vitro. FMCs share many features with bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs), which we previously introduced to treat severe acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Here, we tested FMCs for treatment of steroid-refractory acute GVHD. After two passages in culture, approximately 10 9 FMCs were obtained from one single placenta, although not all cells from passage 0 and passage 1 were used for expansion. The FMCs were positive for CD29, CD44, CD73, CD90, CD105, CD49d, ICAM-1, PD-L1 and PD-L2, but were negative for hematopoietic, endothelial, and epithelial markers. Microsatellite polymorphism analysis showed that FMCs were of maternal origin. All FMCs used showed normal karyotype. Nine patients who had undergone hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and who had developed steroid-refractory grade III-IV acute GVHD were given 0.9-2.8 x 106 FMCs/kg at 15 infusions. Median age was 57 years. There was no toxicity from infusion of FMCs. Two of eight evaluable patients had a complete response and four had a partial response, giving an overall response rate of 75%. Two patients showed no response at all. Three patients are alive from 6 to 21 months after HSCT. One patient is well and two have chronic GVHD.

body_text.text: To conclude, we have developed a protocol for generation of large quantities of stromal cells with immunosuppressive capacities that are accessible without any invasive procedures. FMCs may be successfully used for immune modulation and tissue repair. It is now widely assumed that MSCs secrete a number of immunemodulatory factors, which impair infl ammation and thus help to suppress GvHD. Exosomes are secreted cell organelles, which exert immune-modulatory properties. These small membrane vesicles are released by a huge variety of diff erent cell species, including MSC. Methods: Here, we purifi ed exosomes from bone-marrow derived MSC of four diff erent unrelated stem cell donors and compared their immune modulatory properties in vitro. Next, we administered immunosuppressive MSC-derived exosomes in escalating doses into a 22-years female patient suff ering from a severe therapy-refractory cutaneous and intestinal GvHD grade IV. We monitored the clinical eff ects on an in-hospital basis and correlated this with the levels of infl ammatory cytokines measured in the patient's plasma. Results: We show that even though all propagated MSC lines released exosomes, exosome-enriched fractions diff ered in their potential to modulate immune responses in vitro. Administration of the exosome-enriched fraction with the strongest immune suppressive in vitro eff ect into the GvHD patient was well tolerated and appeared to be safe. During the course of the exosome therapy a clear reduction of the pro-infl ammatory cytokines IL-6, IL-8 and IL-17 was observed in the patient's plasma. In line with the reduced anti-infl ammatory cytokine reaction, the clinical GvHD symptoms improved signifi cantly. The cutaneous and mucosal GvHD showed a remarkable response within two weeks which was stable even after 16 weeks following the MSC-exosome therapy ( Figure 1 ). The diarrhea volume, too, was objectively reduced after exosome therapy (before: average (avg.) 3,1 l/die, after: 1,3 S177 l/die, Figure 2 ). Due the clinical response achieved the dosage of the immunosuppressive agents -particularly of steroids -could be reduced signifi cantly (before: avg. 125 mg/d; after: 30 mg/d).

body_text.text: Conclusion: To our knowledge this is the fi rst attempt to deliver MSC-derived exosomes in therapy-refractory GvHD. The application was well tolerated and led to a signifi cant and sustainable decrease of GvHD symptoms. Further research is warranted, but it appears to be a promising new treatment option in the otherwise dismal situation of refractory GvHD.

body_text.text: The The use of third party Treg from cord blood has been reported in HSCT. This present study investigated the effi cacy of third party Treg from peripheral blood in preventing GvH tissue damage. Methods: Mixed lymphocyte reaction and an in vitro human GvHD skin explant model were used to assess the ability of third party Treg to modulate alloreactivity of CD8+ T cells and prevent cutaneous GvH tissue damage in comparison to the eff ect of Treg from donor origin i.e autologous to CD8+ T cells. Treg of third party or donor origin were identically processed using published isolation and expansion protocols. Results: Activation, proliferation and expression of skin homing markers on allo-stimulated CD8+ T cells were signifi cantly reduced in the presence of third party Treg. Activation of CD8+ T cells was measured by CD69 and CD25 expression and this was suppressed to the same extent by both allogeneic and autologous Treg. Expression of skin homing marker CLA was also reduced in the presence of autologous and allogeneic Treg with no significant diff erence between the two. CD8+ T cell proliferation was measured by 3H thymidine incorporation, both autologous and allogeneic Treg signifi cantly reduced allo-stimulated CD8 T cell proliferation. There was a trend to suggest autologous Treg prevented proliferation to a greater extent than allogeneic Treg however this was not statistically signifi cant. Secreted levels of IFNγ, measured by CBA fl ex in MLR supernatants, were signifi cantly reduced by both autologous and allogeneic Treg. Skin sections of recipient origin incubated with recipient PBMC primed donor PBMC in the absence of any Treg showed grade III tissue damage whereas in the presence of either donor or third party Treg the damage was limited to grade I, the same as medium control. Conclusions: Our data suggests that third party Treg are able to suppress cutaneous GvH reactions to the same extent as donor Treg by preventing eff ector T cell proliferation and migration into the skin. Saccardi (1) Background: Cord Blood (CB) has been increasingly used in the last 10 years as an alternative source of haematopoietic stem cells for transplant. The incidence and severity of GVHD in HLApartially mismatched transplants has been reported to be lower than for adult donors. We report here the occurrence of skin GVHD showing atypical features at both clinical and histological level in adult recipients of unrelated CB transplants (CBT). Methods: Forty patients underwent CBT in our Institution from 12/2006 to 10/2012. Median age at HSCT was 43 yrs (range 16-66), M/F distribution was 21/19; HLA antigens matching was 4/6 (32) and 5/6 (8). A single Unit was used in 31 pts, a double in 9, with a median of of 3 TNCx10E7/Kg infused (range 1.7-6). Myeloablative/ non-myeloablative conditioning regimen ratio was 28/12. GVHD was classifi ed according to NIH guidelines. Skin biopsies were collected in case of any rush of undetermined signifi cance, fi xed in formalin, processed and stained with haematoxylin/eosin. Results: Twenty-one patients developed a GVHD at a median of 73 days after CBT (9-333). GVHD forms at onset of fi rst occurrence were acute (12), acute late onset (4), overlap (3) and chronic (2) . A second occurrence of GVHD was shown in 6 patients and a third in one, respectively, with a total of 33 GVHD episodes. In 10 episodes (30.3%) an atypical rush with erythematous-squamous patches suggestive of an eczema-like or atopic dermatitis was shown. Such an abnormal feature occurred in acute late onset (6) , chronic (2), acute (1) and overlapping (1) GVHD forms, respectively. Four out these 21 patients (2 typical and 2 atypical) died for GVHD-related reasons. In all these cases, histopathology revealed epidermal hyperplasia, spongiosis and a dermal mixed infl ammatory infi ltrate with lymphocytes and eosinophils, in some cases associated with folliculitis. There was no evidence of the typical apoptotic or fi brotic tissue damage commonly associated to GVHD, therefore confi rming the clinical evidence. Conclusions: Improving diagnosis and treatment of GHVD in CB recipients is crucial for the outcome of this increasingly used procedure. We report unusual eczema-like eruptions in CB recipients.
Although the signifi cance of such observation is still unclear, we suggest that they represent atypical, eczema-like GVHD rashes.
Prospective clinical and immunological studies are needed for a better understanding of these unusual features, which may lead to GVHD underdiagnosis.

Introduction: In reduced intensity cord blood transplantation (CBT) post transplant immune disorders, including early immune reactions (PIR) and acute GVHD, are potential complications following CBT in adult patients. Such reactions might increase the risk of organ dysfunction, leading to high rates of transplantationrelated mortality, particularly in patients who do not respond to primary therapy, which usually consists of steroids. Infl iximab, a chimeric monoclonal antibody against tumor necrosis factor α, has shown activity against steroid refractory acute GVHD. Patients and Methods: We retrospectively reviewed 275 patients who underwent single-unit reduced intensity cord blood transplantation consecutively from November 2007 to June 2011 at Toranomon Hospital. Patients who were in poor performance status (ECOG PS >3), had active bacterial or fungal infections at the time of conditioning were excluded. The most frequently used conditioning regimens were fl udarabine, alkylating agent (melphalan or busulfan) with total body irradination (TBI), tacrolimus plus mycophenolate mofetil for GVHD prophylaxis. Patients in whom acute GVHD developed received methylpredonisolone 1-2 mg/kg per day. If no partial or complete resolution of symptoms occurred, they were considered steroid-refractory and proceeded to infl iximab treatment. The dose of infl iximab was 5 mg/kg/day once weekly for at least 1 course. Results: 54 patients among this group developed steroid refractory acute GVHD. Of these, 21 who received infl iximab were analyzed. GVHD prophylaxis was with only tacrolimus(n=15) and mycophenolate mofetil+tacrolimus(n=6). All of them developed grade III to IV GVHD. Median follow-up time of survivors was 548 days (range, 222-1152). The overall response rate was 62% (n=13), and 9 patients (43%) experienced complete response (CR). 5 patients (24%) did not respond and 3 (14%) had progressive GVHD. Overall survival (OS) was estimated as 31% at 2years post-treatment. Four patients who responded subsequently died, one of exacerbation of GVHD, three of infections. All the 8 unresponsive patients died of GVHD. Five patients (21%) had non-Candida invasive fungal infections. Sixteen patients(79%) had bacterial infections. Conclusion: Infl iximab was well tolerated and active for the treatment of steroid-resistant acute GVHD even following re-duced intensity cord blood transplantation. However, it is associated with a high rate of infections.

body_text.text: Though adoptive therapy with viral specifi c T-cells has proven safe and eff ective for both prevention and treatment of post-transplant viral reactivation, improved strategies are still needed to increase the general applicability of this approach. We tested a simplifi ed rapid strategy of the generation of a single product of CD4+ and CD8+ cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTL) lines recognizing cytomegalovirus (CMV), Epstein-Barr-(EBV), Adeno-(Ad) and BK-virus. Dendritic cells derived from elutriated monocytes were pulsed with overlapping 15mer pepmixes spanning CMV-pp65 and IE-1; EBV-LMP2, BZLF1 and EBNA1; Adv-Penton, Hexon; BKV-LT, ST and VP1 alone or in combination (Mix) and subsequently were co-cultured with autologous lymphocytes obtained from the initial elutriation in presence of IL-7, IL-15, and low dose IL-2. For detection of antigen specifi c CTLs, cells were stimulated with test pepmix or control superantigen in the presence of Brefeldin A, anti-CD28 and CD49d, washed, stained for T-cell subset markers and then permeabilized and intracellular-stained for IFNγ, TNFα, IL-2, CD107a. Quadrivirus-specifi c IFN-γ-producing CD4+ and CD8+ CTLs were successfully induced in all 12 donors (CD4+ 5.8±6.8%, CD8+ 7.3±7.9%). Induction of reactivity in cultures containing individual pepmixes was comparable with results from the cultures containing combination of all studied peptide libraries, supporting the feasibility of developing of a quadrivirus-specifi c product in a single mixed culture. Two rounds of expansion resulted in signifi cant increase in frequency of CD8+ antigen-specifi c cells, while there was no change in reactivity of CD4+ cells. The predominant specifi city was against CMV in CMV-seropositive donors (n=6; CD3+:8.7±8%, CD4+:3.6±5.9%, CD8+:5.1±3.6%). Signifi cant CMV-reactivity of CTLs was also induced in CMV-seronegative donors (n=6; CD3+:1.6±1%, CD4+:1.2±0.7%, CD8+:0.4±0.3%). The expanded T cells retained predominantly naïve or central memory phenotype and only a small subset demonstrated undesirable markers of terminal diff erentiation or senescence. Furthermore, the anti-viral cells were polyfunctional, as evidenced by simultaneous production with IFNg of TNF-α and (to a lesser degree) IL-2. In conclusion, we demonstrate a simple, rapid (9 days) GMPcompatible methodology to generate a single preparation of polyclonal CTLs specifi c for four viruses that are frequent causes of post-transplant mortality or morbidity. Objective: Mobilization of hematopoietic stem cell (HSCs) can be achieved either by the combination of chemotherapy plus growth factors or by the growth factors alone. However there is no consensus concerning the dose of growth factor alone that should be administered, with ranges varying from 5 μg to 16 μg / kg body weight. In this context, we report our experience in mobilization of HSCs, using growth factor alone at the dose of 15 μg /kg in MM, Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) and non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). Patients and methods: A total of 122 ASCT were performed in our center, from May 2009 to July 31st 2012. This concerned 88 patients with MM, 30 with HL and 4 others with NHL. Mobilization started with G-CSF alone (fi lgrastim) at the dose of 15μg/kg/daily subcutaneously for 5 days. Apheresis was performed at day-2 and day-1 using a device type Spectra Optia CMN, and the CD34+ count was assessed by fl ow cytometry. Failure of mobilization was defi ned as a level of CD34+ lower than 2.106/kg, after two leukapheresis. In our study, patients were divided into three groups: optimal (>5.0 × 106 CD34+cells/kg), suboptimal (2.0-5.0 × 106 CD34+cells/kg) and poor (<2.0 × 106 CD34+ cells/kg) mobilization groups. Results: The average number of apheresis was 1 and that of CD34+ was 3.48x106/kg in MM and 3.60x106/kg in HL and NHL. Failure of mobilization represented 6 cases (5%) of the 122 ASCT done.The most adverse events were, bone pain and headache were reported for 49% and 25% patients, respectively, fever in 25% and asthenia in 18%.Conclusion:Our study show an overall success rate of 96% over a total of 163 leukapheresis done. body_text.text: Objectives: Determination of the number of viable CD34+ cells is important for clinical decision-making in stem cell transplantation. Flow Cytometry (FCM) is standardly used for enumeration of hematopoietic stem cell levels in bone marrow, cord blood, peripheral blood, and apheresis products. As the dead cells and debris can disturb the correct interpretation of the FCM results, the apoptotic cells should also be excluded from the viable cell determination. A cell membrane permeability marker, 7-Aminoactinomycine D (7-AAD), is currently used as a standard DNA intercalating dye to determine the amount of dead and early apoptotic stem cells by FCM. However, these cells are more diffi cult to identify due to the low intensity of 7-AAD in them. Furthermore, 7-AAD can nonspecifi cally bind to cells and increase as such the number of non-viable cells. DRAQ7 (Biostatus, Shepshed, UK) is a novel more intense staining viability probe fl uorescing in the farred that does not enter intact cells but when the membrane integrity is compromised, it enters and binds readily to nuclear DNA to report cell death, reducing the potential for false-positives. Methods: DRAQ7 and 7-AAD were both tested in the ISHAGE protocol with and without Syto16 (an inert probe which does not interfere with cell viability) to provide detailed characterization and tracking of cell death. Fresh and cryopreserved Hematopoietic Progenitor Cells (HPC) from Apheresis (HPC-A) were analysed on a Beckman Coulter Navios fl ow cytometer using CD34 and CD45 monoclonal antibodies. The number and the pattern of viable, apoptotic and dead stem cells staining defi ned by both dyes were compared. Results: Our results show a better staining of apoptotic stem cells by DRAQ7. Furthermore, we found signifi cant more (2.2 fold higher, P<0.05, n=6) dead Syto16low/-/7-AAD+ stem cells with a median frequency of 28% (range 2-37%) than dead Syto16low/-/DRAQ7+ stem cells with a median frequency of 13% (range 1-15%). Conclusion: The preliminary data demonstrate that 7-AAD causes more apoptosis compared with DRAQ7 in the same stem cell samples. These results suggest that DRAQ7 is a more suitable viability dye to determine the correct amount of existing dead and apoptotic stem cells and therefore should be incorporated in FCM research and clinical protocols, especially in the CD34+ stem cell enumeration assay.

body_text.text: The cord blood unit (CBU) is an important source of stem cells to reconstitute the hematopoietic system after transplantation in patients with onco-hematologic diseases. The limited number of progenitor stem cells present in CBU compared to other sources of stem cells requires a strict control of all procedures necessary for its therapeutic use from collection to transplantation. During the process of cryopreservation cells structures are subjected to thermal shock, which could alter the functional capacity of the cells. Before CBU's release to Transplant Centers for transplantation, it is mandatory to perform quality controls (QC) on CBU's satellite samples. Calabria Cord Blood Bank (CCBB) performed a validation study to assess and confi rm the reliability of CQ results of satellite samples compared with CQ results of related CBU. We used n. 10 CBU not eligible to be banked and released for transplantation. CBU and related satellite samples have been stored in liquid nitrogen, then were thawed and washed. Resnick Hadassah University Medical Center (Jerusalem, IL) Background: Bone marrow (BM) derived human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSC) have a growing number of indications for clinical use. BM donation is problematic for a non-conventional treatment, and as such the possibility to use a side product of BM harvesting -used bone marrow fi lters was re-evaluated. According to current knowledge, there is a single publication which characterized BM fi lters as a poor source of hMSC for clinical use [Sundin et al., 2008] . Materials and methods:Six fi lters for MSC expansion were used. Filters from BM harvesting sets were collected from operating room in sterile normal saline. Cells from fi lters were counted, re-suspended in specifi c medium for MSC (DMEM Low Glucose with 15% Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS), 1% Penicillin-Streptomycin-Nystatin and 1% Glutamine), then seeded in 75 cm2 fl ask (8*10 6 cells per fl ask in total volume of 20ml). The medium was changed twice weekly until confl uency. Cultures were washed with phosphate buff ered saline and then trypsinized, washed again and resuspended for a fi rst passage in 182 cm2 fl asks (1.5*10 6 cells per fl ask in a total volume of 35 ml). Results: From each fi lter 80*10 6 to 150*10 6 MSC were received in total after one passage. During simultaneous MSC expansion from the same BM samples (n=2), fi lters showed similar or superior kinetics growing velocity ( Figure) . Immunophenotype from both fi lters and bone marrow derived hMSC was similar (CD90+CD73+HLA-ABC+CD105+ and CD45-CD3-HLA-DR-). There were no cases of microbial contamination. Filter derived products were used for the treatment of 5 patients with acute graft versus host disease. Conclusion: hMSC can be successfully extracted and expanded from BM fi lters trapped material which are normally discarded. (3):238-42.

body_text.text: Separation of lymphocyte populations from peripheral blood progenitor cell products using a novel microchip based acoustophoretic platform A. Jamal (1) Objective: Processing of peripheral blood progenitor cells (PBPC) for clinical transplantation or research applications aims to effectively select or deplete specific cell populations. Usually, fluorescence-or magnetically-based sorting techniques are used for PBPC processing. Here, we investigated the performance of a novel microchip-based ´acoustophoresis´ technique, utilizing ultrasound for the separation of lymphocyte subsets from PBPC. By applying an acoustic standing wave field on to a continuously flowing cell suspension in a micro channel, cells can be separated depending on their physical properties, such as size and density. Methods: PBPC samples were obtained from patients (n= 16) and healthy donors (n=6). Following density gradient centrifugation, cells were labelled with either anti-CD4 or anti-CD8 microbeads (Dynal) and sorted on an acoustophoresis-microchip. In parallel, control magnetic sorting was performed. PBPC samples, target and waste fractions were analysed for separation effi ciency, recovery, T-cell function and progenitor cell content. Results: The mean separation efficiency of CD4+ lymphocytes to the target fraction was 87 ± 7% with acoustophoresis compared to 95 ± 8% for control magnetic sorting (n=19). Viability of sorted cells was 95 ± 4% (acoustic) and 97 ± 3% (magnetic). Following further technical improvement of the chip, purities obtained with acoustic sorting of CD8+ lymphocytes were 96 ± 3% compared to 93 ± 4% for magnetic sorting (n=3). The median recovery of acoustically selected lymphocytes was the 57%. Leukocyte subpopulation analysis performed after CD4 selection showed a relative increase of CD8, CD19, CD34, CD56, CD14 cells in the nontarget fractions. These changes were due to the removal of CD4 cells and found to be within the expected range. Functional testing of sorted CD4+ cells showed unimpaired mitogen-induced proliferation capacity as well as cytokine production. Results from hematopoietic progenitor cell assays indicated a preserved colony-forming ability post-sorting of non-target cells.

Conclusion: The acoustophoresis technique can be utilized to effi ciently sort bead-labelled lymphocyte populations from PBPC samples with high purity and recovery without impairing lymphocyte function. Acoustophoresis is, thus, an interesting technology for PBPC processing, which has furthermore the potential to off er a single platform technique for multi-parameter cell separation. Haematopoietic Stem Cells Transplantation (HSCT). The graft is usually thawed bedside and shortly reinfused without any manipulation. Infusion-related toxicity is usually mild, although severe reactions have been reported. Washing the product after thawing would allow an easier management of the infusion and of the logistics, due to the prolonged stabilization of the graft. We report here the validation of a fully automated washing method through an international, prospective, multicenter trial. Methods: Forty-three patients undergoing autologous HSCT according to local protocol were enrolled in 4 European Centers (Florence, Murcia, Marseille and Basel), following a pre-clinical study aimed to validate the procedure. PBSC were thawed and washed before infusion with the SmartWash™ program on Sepax2® (Biosafe, Switzerland). Standard lab parameters were collected before and after washing. Clinical outcome was prospectively assessed by infusion-related adverse events scoring and engraftment parameter. Results: All the washing procedures were completed without any laboratory problems in the participating centers. The additional active manpower, as compared to the unmanipulated infusion, was around 12 mins/bag. After washing, the mean (SD) recovery of viable CD34+ cells was 73.9% (21,8) with reference to the frozen product. In no cases any loss of viable CD34+ cells was reported during the washing procedure. Inter-laboratory variability showed no statistical difference in CD34+ recovery even though cellular composition of the apheresis was heterogeneous.The infusion-related toxicity was negligible (1 grade 1 out of 43 patients, according to CTC-NCI scoring system) and all patients achieved a sustained engraftment: median day of recovery of neutrophils >500x10 9 /L and platelets >20x10 12 /L was: 9 (12-18) and 12 (7-30), respectively. No significant differences in engraftment kinetic were shown across the participating centers.

Conclusions: The SmartWash protocol on Sepax® 2 is an effi cient and safe automated method to wash thawed PBSC grafts in a closed, clinical-grade system. The washed product is stable and clinically feasible for several hours after thawing. Benefi ts for clinical staff s include a lower frequency of infusion-associated adverse events as well as a reduced burden as compared to management of thawed products at the bedside.

Introduction: In 2008, biosimilar G-CSF XM02 (Ratiograstim®, Tevagrastim®, Biograstim®) has been fully approved for all indications of the reference fi lgrastim (Neupogen®) on the basis of extrapolation. This extrapolation raised questions in the EBMT on the effi cacy and safety of biosimilar G-CSF for stem cell mobilization. In a recent review by Shaw EB et al. (Haematologica 2011; 96:942-7) , the World Marrow Donor Association (WMDA) recommends biosimilars not be used for mobilization unless the donor is followed on a study. Only after collection of comprehensive data G-CSF biosimilars could be considered routinely. Here, we performed a meta-analysis on the subject. Methods: The databases PUBMED and Google Scholar were consulted for full papers, the EBMT 2012 Abstract Book for abstracts regarding the mobilization of stem cells with biosimilars. Results: Our own group (Onkologie 2011; 34(S6):280 (P926); full BMT paper in press) used biosimilar G-CSF XM02 vs. reference G-CSF (Neupogen®) to mobilize stem cells in 22 healthy donors.

Conclusion: Mobilization of stem cells in the allogeneic as well as the autologous setting has been performed in 11 healthy donors as well as in 450 patients with myeloma and lymphoma. body_text.text: Multiple myeloma patients mobilizing poorly with G-CSF achieve a signifi cantly higher haematopoietic stem cell harvest with additional administration of plerixafor Introduction: About 10% of multiple myeloma (MM) patients are considered to be "poor mobilizers" with a CD34+ cell count ≤ 20/ μl in the peripheral blood after chemotherapy and stimulation with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF). Addition of the CXCR-4 inhibitor plerixafor (Mozobil®) might increase the efficiency of CD34+ stem cell harvest with even fewer leukapheresis procedures needed. Here we retrospectively analyzed data from multiple myeloma (MM) patients at our institution to evaluate the eff ect of plerixafor in this setting. Methods: Twenty-two MM patients were mobilized with or without chemomobilization and G-CSF. Patients received plerixafor after fi rst or second mobilization due to low CD34+ cell count in peripheral blood (PB) or poor yield of collection. A median amount of 6.60 (3.33-11.54) μg/kg BW G-CSF and 0.25 (0.16-0.41) mg/kg BW plerixafor was applied. One to four leukapheresis procedures were performed. Results: Patients were categorized into two groups according to their CD34+ stem cell count in PB : group A ≤ 20/μl and group B >20/μl. Group A harvested 3.84 (0.29-9.43)×10E6/kg BW CD34+ cells, group B 8.18 (5.5-14.34 -4) . A minimum cell yield ≥ 2x10E6 CD34+cells/kg BW was harvested in 11/12 patients in group A and 10/10 patients in group B. Conclusion: Mobilization of hematopoietic stem cells with additional plerixafor was well tolerated. The median hematopoietic stem cell harvest in group A (≤ 20 CD34+ cells/μl PB) was signifi cantly higher after additional mobilization with plerixafor. Our results provide safety and effi cacy data for the use of plerixafor in patients who are considered to be poor mobilizers. As several previous studies demonstrated that in poor mobilizers a suffi cient stem cell number cannot be harvested, the use of plerixafor should be upfront considered in this subgroup of patients. Even in patients with a CD34+ cell count > 20/μl in PB (group B), addition of plerixafor signifi cantly increased the consecutive stem cell harvest. Fewer leukapheresis procedures were needed with plerixafor to reach the requested amount of stem cells. HLA-haploidentical stem cell transplantation (HSCT) may be complicated by high rates of graft failure and severe GVHD due to strong bidirectional alloreactivity. High-dose Cy, when administered in a narrow window after HSCT has been shown to attenuate GVHD and facilitate engraftment by eliminating alloreactive T cells while sparing quiescent hematopoietic stem cells, far more resistant to cytotoxic chemotherapy. Aim of the study: to evaluate safety and effi cacy of post-transplant Cy after T cell-replete marrow HLA-haploidentical HSCT for advanced hematological malignancies. Methods: between April 2010 and August 2012, 25 patients with hematologic malignancies (n=21 AML/MDS; n=2 LMC; n=2 lymphomas) have been enrolled, the majority (60%) of whom were in advanced phase of disease (n=13 relapse/refractory; n=2 accelerated phase/blast crisis) at the time of transplant. Seven patients had received a previous allogeneic HSCT. Thirteen patients received a tandem approach consisting of de-bulking high dose chemotherapy followed by the conditioning regimen and HLA-haploidentical marrow infusion. Patients received either a reduced-intensity conditioning including fl udarabine-Cy and single dose 200 cGy TBI (9 patients), or a myeloablative regimen consisting of thiotepa-fl udarabine and i.v. busulphan (15 patients) or thiotepa-fl udarabine-melphalan (1 patient), followed by T-cell replete bone marrow. Postgrafting immunosuppression consisted of Cy 50 mg/Kg/day on days +3 and +4, mycophenolate mofetil and tacrolimus. All patients received G-CSF after transplantation Results: neutrophil engraftment occurred in 23 of 24 evaluable patients at a median of 18 days (range 14-24 days). The incidences of grades II-IV and grades III-IV acute GVHD were 26% and 4% respectively. Bacteremia occurred in 8 patients, 13 patients developed viral infections (n=12 CMV reactivation, n=1 EBV reactivation). After a median follow-up of 264 days (range 124-936 days), 14 patients (56%) are alive, 9 of whom are in complete remission.

Overall survival and event-free survival at 1 year were 43% and 40% respectively. The 1-year cumulative incidence of transplantrelated mortality was 31% . Conclusion: our recent experience confi rms the feasibility of HLAhaploidentical HSCT with high-dose post-transplant Cy in heavily pretreated patients with acceptable early morbidity and mortality. Longer follow-up on a larger series of patients is need to evaluate long-term clinical outcomes.

Mohty (1), K. Hübel (2) , N. Kröger (3), M. Aljurf (4) , J. Apperley (5) , G. Basak (6) , A. Bazarbachi (7), K. Douglas (8), I. Gabriel (5), L. Garderet (1) , C. Geraldes (9), O. Jaksic (10) Background: Autologous haematopoietic stem cell transplantation with peripheral blood stem cells (PBSCs) is nowadays a standard therapy in multiple myeloma (MM) and lymphoma patients. However, current mobilisation strategies vary between centres and a signifi cant no. of patients is unable to mobilise suffi cient PBSC yields. Methods: Based on currently available literature and clinical practice, a group of 28 experts from the European Group for Blood and Marrow Transplantation (EBMT) attempted to achieve a consensus on the best approaches to mobilise PBSCs in MM and lymphoma patients and on potential optimisation options for poor mobilisers.

Results: For MM patients, steady state mobilisation (cytokines only) or chemotherapy-based regimens according to national guidelines are recommended. For lymphoma patients, diseasespecifi c chemotherapy approaches are suggested to avoid the burden of additional chemotherapy cycles. For selected lymphoma patients who are in complete remission and/or are ineligible for chemo-mobilisation, steady state mobilisation may also be an option. To optimise steady state or chemo-mobilisation protocols and increase graft yields, the addition of new mobilisation agents such as plerixafor are suggested. Over the past years several factors have been described in the literature to be predictive of poor PBSC collection, including older age, more advanced disease stage, higher no. of prior treatment lines, prior treatment with fl udarabine or melphalan, and prior irradiation. However, the most robust predictor for poor PBSC collection is presumably the CD34+ cell count in PB before apheresis. For patients with <10 CD34+ cells/microlitre in PB prior to apheresis, preemptive plerixafor use is suggested to reach a target apheresis count of 2.0 Mio CD34+ cells/kg. For patients with 10-20 CD34+ cells/microlitre in PB prior to apheresis, a dynamic approach is recommended taking into account patients' disease characteristics and treatment history. Readily available and robust techniques to determine CD34+ cell counts are needed. Conclusions: PBSC mobilisation can presumably be optimised by choosing an appropriate strategy adapted to each patient, based on disease and treatment features. A low CD34+ cell count in PB prior to apheresis is a candidate predictor for poor PBSC collection. Thus, CD34+ cell count determination might estimate the patient's risk for poor PBSC collection and allows a proactive intervention to rescue mobilisation failure.

Successful autologous stem cell transplantation is reliant on the ability to harvest suffi cient stem cell dose either via the use of G-CSF ± standard chemotherapy mobilisation. Although the exact mechanism of G-CSF's mobilising eff ect is debated, down-regulation of the chemokine CXCL12 may be involved. For most patients a satisfactory cell dose can be harvested: however, about 15% of patients mobilise PBSC poorly which has signifi cant implications for their long term management. Recent published data examining a small group of autograft patients suggested that elevated serum glucose concentrations impair stem cell mobilisation via a defect in activation of the sympathetic nervous system which causes a blockade of G-CSF induced down-regulation of CXCL12(1). This was indicated by a low CD34 count at time of harvest and delayed engraftment post transplant. We extended this investigation by examining autograft patients referred for peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) harvest in the West of Scotland between 2009 and 2012. Clinical data were available on 256 patients. 5% (n=13) patients were confi rmed as diabetic.

However, the small number of diabetic patients may indicate a diffi culty in identifying a diff erence in this data set. Other potential confounding factors include the age and sex of patients which were at variance between the two groups [median age 61yrs vs 56yrs, p=0.0045 and male sex n=12 (93.3%) and n=130 (52.2%)] in the diabetic and non-diabetic cohort respectively. Dykes (1) Background: Rigorous depletion of TcRα/β+ cells whilst preserving valuable TcRα/β+ cells in the stem cell graft is an attractive alternative to CD3+ T-cell depletion for prevention of GvHD in HLA-mismatched transplantation. Study design and methods: PBPC were harvested from 8 HLAhaploidentical donors. The cells were sequentially labelled with TcRα/β-Biotin reagent and CliniMACS anti-Biotin reagent and processed with the CliniMACS device using the D3.1 program (n=8) with the DTS (Depletion Tubing Set). TcRα/β -cell depleted grafts were produced with a target cell dose of ≥ 5 × 106 CD34+ and ≤ 1 × 105 TcRα/β + cells per kilogram of recipient body weight. In fl ow cytometric analysis viable TcRα/β+ cells were defi ned by their cell scatter properties of lymphocytes, positivity for CD45 (bright), CD3 and TcRα/β and negativity for propidium iodine staining, as well as lack of CD13-, CD19-, CD14-and TcRα/β-expression. Bright fl uorescent dyes were selected for TcRα/β (PE) and CD3 (APC) staining. The fl ow cytometric dot plot of a "spiked" sample (10:1 mixture of depleted target fraction: non-target TcRα/β+ cells) was used to adequately set the gate for TcRα/β+ cell detection. A minimum of 106 events were acquired for analysis. Results: The median log10 TcRα/β-cell depletion rate was 4.6 (range 3.0-5.0), corresponding to a median of 0.0017 % (range 0.00041-0.036%) TcRα/β+ cells in the target fractions. The median recovery of CD34+ cells was 94% (range 85-99%) and the median recovery of TcRα/β+ cells was 79% (range 72-95% Introduction: Immunomagnetic depletion of TCR α/β (TCRab) positive cells from the hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) graft is a new method of graft processing, which removes potential eff ectors of graft-versus-host disease, sparing presumably important populations, such as NK cells and γ/δ T-cells. This method was adopted as a basic graft processing platform for haploidentical (haplo) and matched unrelated donors (MUD) in our center since May 2012. We report herein the technical results of the procedure. Methods: Overall 34 procedures were performed between May and November 2012. Grafts were GCSF-mobilized PBSCs derived from MUD (n=23) and haplo (n=11) donors. Initial characteristics of the graft were similar with median total nucleated cell (TNC) count = 57x109, CD34 = 416x106, TCRab = 13,9x109, CD19 = 3,5x109. The only diff erence was in the time period from apheresis to processing start, which was a median of 48 and 22 hours for MUD and haplo, respectively. The procedure of TCRab and CD19 depletion was performed with appropriate reagents and Clini-MACS Plus instrument, Miltenyi Biotec, according to manufacturer's instructions. Magnetic reagent volumes were adjusted to TNC and labeled cell count. Product analysis was performed on FACS CANTO II cytometer, BD according to Miltenyi Biotec protocol. Results: Median recovery of CD34 cells was 93% and 90% for MUD and haplo. Median log depletion of TCRab cells was 3,9(2,9-4,7) and 3,9(3,3-5) (fi g 1.). Median log depletion of CD19 cells was 2,9(1,8-3,9 ) and 3,1 (2, 7) , respectively. The only factor that signifi cantly correlated with depletion eff ectiveness was the ratio of magnetic reagent TNC capacity to the real TNC count (fi g. 2). Conclusions: TCR α/β and CD19 depletion with CliniMACS technology is a robust and eff ective method of graft processing for HSC transplantation. The method secures target graft quality independent of the graft source, transportation and processing delay up to 48 hours. An excess of the immunomagnetic reagent correlates with greater depletion of the labeled cells.

Development of a cryopreservation process for donor lymphocytes using a closed bag system R. Peter, D. Gasch, I. Nachtigall, E. Schafnitzel, K. Götze, H. Menzel, C. Peschel, A. Krackhardt Technical University Munich (Munich, DE) Infusion of donor lymphocytes off ers a salvage option for selected patients after allogeneic stem cell transplantation. We have previously developed a simple method for cryopreservation of peripheral blood stem cells within a functionally closed system that fulfi ls GMP guidelines and allows for processing without a cleanroom facility. The actual objective comprises the modifi cation of our system for processing, portioning and cryopreservation of donor lymphocytes. At our clinic, patients usually receive subsequently 1x10 6 , 5x10 6 , 10x10 6 and 50x10 6 donor lymphocytes per kg bodyweight (BW). The fi rst donation is removed directly from the apheresis product. For subsequent donations, the cell number is fi rst adjusted within a transfer bag to 50x10 6 /kg BW in a volume of 95ml and transferred to a cryobag of the fi rst Cell Cryo Freeze Prep Set (CCFPS). After disconnection, the transfer bag is connected to a plasma collection bag containing 150ml of donor plasma. 40 ml of the undiluted cell suspension are transferred to the plasma collection bag resulting in a dilution of 1:5 after fi nal preparation. Therefore, the plasma collection bag was connected to a second CCFPS followed by addition of DMSO (5ml per bag) and distribution to two cryobags. Similarly, DMSO was added to the cryobag of the fi rst CCFPS and all cryobags were crypreserved followed by long-term storage below -140°C. Numbers of CD3/CD45 cells were analyzed after each preparation step by fl ow cytometry. A total of 6 processes have been completed. The mean content of the donations were 2.4 CD3/CD45 cells/kg BW for the fi rst donation, and 13.5, 13.7 and 52.5 for the following donations. The standard deviation was 0.57, 4.85, 3.83 and 5.82, respectively. The cell number applied to the patient will be adjusted according to the exact number of lymphocytes measured after preparation and the medical need. Vitality of nucleated cells after cryopreservation was >90% (trypan blue staining). Sterility was analyzed for both CCFPS preparations revealing no contamination in all processes performed. These data demonstrate that cryopreservation of donor lymphocytes in a closed bag system is feasible and off ers superior advantages: The process is simple, safe and cost-saving and the dosage of CD3+/CD45+ cells to be infused to the patient can be individually adjusted by the clinician according to the eff ectively measured number of cells within the cryobag after preparation and the specifi c condition of the patient. .2 ): patient's death (47%), microbial contamination (22%), structural damage to the bags (16%); insuffi cient amount of CD34+ content (5%) and mistakes/damages in the labels (1,5%). Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) mobilisation in peripheral blood (PB) is prerequisite for successful collection in apheresis procedure S190 and subsequent autologous HSC transplantation. The number of CD34+ cells in PB prior to apheresis is one of the most important predictors of successful HSC collection. In case of low CD34+ numbers apheresis can be prolonged with more blood volumes (BV) processed to improve yield due to additional recruitment of CD34+ cells from bone marrow (BM). Also, administration of CXCR-4 antagonist plerixafor in poor mobilisers leads to increase in PB CD34+ numbers due to shift from BM to PB. Thus, we performed primary hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (HSCT) from mismatched mother to thalassemic patient without an HLA-identical donor. 42 patients with thalassemia major were conditioned with 60 mg/kg hydroxyurea and 3 mg/kg azathioprine from day -59 to -11, 30 mg/ m2 fl udarabine from day -17 to -11, 14 mg/kg busulfan starting on day -10 were administered orally 3 times daily over 4 days in the fi rst 17 patients, and corresponding dose of busulfan give intravenous in the following 25 patients, and 200 mg/kg cyclophosphamide,10 mg/kg Thiotepa, and 10 mg/kg ATG (Fresenius) daily from day -5 to -2. 34 patients received CD34+ mobilized peripheral and bone marrow progenitor cells; 8 patients received marrow graft selected PBSC CD34+ and BM CD3/CD19 depleted. T-cell dose was adjusted to 2x105/kg by fresh marrow cell add back at the time of transplant. Both groups received cyclosporine for graft versus host disease prophylaxis for two months post transplant. 3 patients died , 12 patients reject their grafts, and 27 showed full chimerism with functioning grafts at a median follow-up of 56 months. The overall survival, thalassemia free survival and mortality is 90%; 59% and 11%. To analyze immunohematologic reconstitution, particularly NK cells, we evaluated 13 thalassemia patients after 20 and 60 days and 1 year post transplantation with T cell-depleted HLA-haploidentical stem cells. NKs were the fi rst lymphocytes to repopulate the peripheral blood. A signifi cant increase in CD4+ and CD8+ markers paralleled an increase in CD3-CD16+ NKs, especially with full engraftment. In order to increase the T-cell depletion of PBSC while maintaining the anti-infectious and the engraftment facilitating eff ects of the depleted grafts, we have introduced the depletion of αβ T Lymphocytes using the CliniMacs System. In addition to the Cd3 depletion, αβ-depleted grafts contain large number of γδ T lymphocytes studies were then conducted to determine if γδ T cells were capable of preventing graft rejection in the context of haploidentical transplant. Using this new strategies in 3 haploidentical transplant in thalassemia patients we observed more rapid immunological reconstitution after 60 days post transplant, with an increase of T cells (CD4+ and CD8+), B cells (CD19+) and NK cells (especially CD3-CD16+, with cytotoxic potential) in the peripheral blood of these patients.

It is well established that recombinant human granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) accelerates neutrophil recovery following autologous peripheral stem cell transplantation (APSCT). However, the optimal timing for initiation of G-CSF therapy following APSCT is still not clear. A number of studies have been conducted to determine this timing. Most of these studies investigated whether delayed use (day +3 to day +8) of G-CSF therapy was as safe and effi cient as with early use (day 0 to day +1) of G-CSF therapy after transplantation. We conducted a prospective randomized study comparing the eff ect of daily administration to every other day administration of G-CSF (300 μgr of fi lgrastim) on neutrophil engraftment following APSCT for non-myeloid hematologic malignancies in adult patients. Duration of G-CSF administration, incidence of blood stream infections, duration of febrile neutropenia, duration of non-prophylactic antibiotic therapy, transfusion requirements, duration of hospitalization and G-CSF costs were also studied. Forty seven patients with diagnosis of lymphoma and multiple myeloma undergoing high-dose therapy and APSCT were randomized to receive post-transplant daily or every other day G-CSF therapy both beginning on day +1. Both groups were comparable with regard to age, sex, diagnosis and antecedent therapy as well as the number of stem cell infused. There was no signifi cant diff erence in time to neutrophil engraftment between the two groups (p=0,31). The duration of G-CSF administration was signifi cantly less in the intermittent group (p<0,001). There were no detectable diff erences seen in the number of febrile days, duration of non-prophylactic antibiotics, the incidence of blood stream infections, transfusion requirements and the duration of hospitalization. There was a trend towards a faster platelet recovery in the intermittent G-CSF treated patients, although the diff erence was not statistically signifi cant compared to daily G-CSF treated group (p=0.059).The number of doses of G-CSF used per transplant is signifi cantly reduced with intermittent employment, resulting in a signifi cant reduction in drug costs.

body_text.text: A comparison of post-thaw cord blood unit (CBU) quality as a function of time with and without the use of 10% dextran and 25% albumin as reconstitution media R. Nath (1) Background: Best measure of the quality of a CBU is its timely engraftment post stem cell transplant (SCT). Total nucleated cell count (TNC), CD34 count and determination of viability using tryphan blue and 7 AAD are surrogates for CBU quality. This study examines the eff ect of time on these quality control variables of CBU frozen in 10% DMSO post thaw with and without reconstitution with 10% dextran and 25% albumin. The results are important to determine the optimal time limit of CBU infusion post thaw for patients undergoing CBSCT. Methods: 15 CBUs frozen in 10% DMSO were thawed at 37°C water bath. 5 CBUs were reconstituted by adding media consisting of 10% dextran and 25% albumin to equal one half of the total syringed volume + 5ml. The other 10 CBU were thawed without the addition of reconstitution media. Trypan Blue viability and 7-AAD viability (by fl ow cytometry), and CD34 viability (by fl ow cytometry) were assessed for each of the CBU immediately post thaw, 30 minutes 1, 1.5, 2 ,4 and 6 hours post thaw. Results: The drop in the total viability of the cells as measured by Trypan Blue (TB) as well as the viability of the CD34+ cells was faster if the reconstitution media was not used. In the presence of the reconstitution media, the viability of the CD34+ cells stayed stable till 1.5 hours (see graph A) whereas there was a sharp decline after 30mins without reconstitution medium (see graph B). Conclusion: As the viability of the CD34+ cells is important, and we need to look at the plateau of the CD34+ viability curve to select a point before which the cells should be infused and the reconstitution media gives a longer and more workable time (1.5 hours) compared to cells that are not in reconstitution media (30 mins). The eff ects of alemtuzumab on peripheral blood nucleated cells (PBPC) grafts need better defi nition. As haematopoietic cells express CD52 antigen, the optima cell number, antibody concentrations or eff ect of complement in the graft are not known. Methods: PBPC from normal 5 allogeneic stem cell donors harvested by apheresis and incubated with incremental concentrations of alemtuzumab (10-2 to 10-5 mg/mL for 30 min at 20ºC or at fi xed dose of 10-3 mg alemtuzumab was added to 0.1, 0.5 and 1x107 cells/mL in the presence of fresh or heat inactivated AB serum as source of complement were studied. Supernatants were

[P684] S192 removed and stored at -70 ºC and concentrations tested with ELISA assay. Pelleted cells were enumerated before and after exposure to alemtuzumab and analysed using 4 colour fl owcytometry in a Facs Calibur instrument. The mean-fl uorescent intensity and cell numbers were recorded. Selected CD34+ lineage negative cells we incubated at 10-5 to 10-2 mg/mL alemtuzumab for 30 min at room temperature and cultured in methylcellulose in CF-GM assay with IL-3 and G-CSF 10 mg t 37ºC. The colony numbers were compared to control cultures. Results: Incremental concentrations of alemtuzumab led to signifi cant (2 log) reduction in the CD3, CD4, CD8 populations which plateaued at 10-3 mg/mL without further drop at 10-2 mg/mL. However CD20+, myeloid (CD33, CD13) and monocytic (CD14) cells were reduced by 1 log at the highest concentration. Fresh AB serum led to a signifi cantly higher reduction in the CD4 and CD8 cells. Highest CD4 (4 log) and CD8 (3 log) death was obtained at 1 x107 cells/mL. Analysis of supernatants for soluble alemtuzumab showed a signifi cant reduction in the antibody concentration when the cell number was increase from 0.1 to 1 x10 7 /mL implying utilisation of the antibody by target cells. At the highest cell concentration the antibody was below the level of detection of the assay. Incremental concentrations of alemtuzumab did not aff ect the number of CFU-GM implying lack of cytotoxicity on early progenitor cells.

Conclusions: Alemtuzumab depletes all cells expressing the CD52 antigen and has the highest activity on CD3 and particularly on CD4 cells. Addition of complement and incubation at higher cell number resulted in signifi cantly higher cell depletion. Thus cell numbers and plasma depletion must be done with caution to prevent loss of complement activity when manipulating grafts that were incubated ex vivo with alemtuzumab.

Increasing demand for stem cell collection for therapeutic use, including tandem transplants and donor lymphocyte infusions, has caused pressure on the storage space available for haematopoietic progenitor cell (HPC) products. Additionally HPC collections using the Optia apheresis machine produce larger volume harvests than those using the Spectra. As Spectra machines are being superseded by Optias, this may pose storage challenges for other centres. In a retrospective study of 50 consecutive Optia and Spectra harvests, collection volumes were 228.3mls ±11.57 and 199.8mls ±4.7 respectively. To minimise the volumes stored and also to reduce patient exposure to the cryoprotectant dimethylsulphoxide (DMSO), the ratio of cell concentration to cryoprotectant mix has been optimised in our centre. HPC products are cryopreserved using a fi nal concentration of 6% DMSO, where the freeze mix comprises 12% of the total product volume and is made from equal quantities of DMSO and saline. In comparison, most centres use a 10% fi nal DMSO concentration achieved by the addition of a 50:50 mix of 20% cryoprotectant to the HPC product. This would have resulted in a 38% increase in cryopreserved volume in the cohort studied, compared with our method which has the additional benefi t of fewer bags stored and reduced DMSO exposure for the patient. Pre and post thaw fl ow cytometric viability studies conducted inhouse have validated our approach at consistently > 93% viable CD34 cell recovery. Furthermore, there is no adverse impact on patient engraftment. Red cell contamination of the HPC product is apheresis dependent. Our aim is to collect low haematocrit (HCT) products (4%) resulting in fewer lysed red cells in the cryopreserved product.

body_text.text: With high HCT donations steps are taken to minimise exposure to lysed red cells and the resultant free haemoglobin. Harvests are cryopreserved in portions to ensure products containing no more than 0.25mls/kg of red cells are given to patients in any one infusion episode. Infusion sessions may be either several hours or a day apart to allow for hydration and avoid overloading with lysed RBCs. A signifi cant reduction has been noted in infusion related complications including increased blood pressure, severe headaches, renal pain and occasionally seizures or collapse necessitating admission to intensive care. This has been apparent particularly in small children.

Cernelc (1) Aim of the study: In this retrospective study we have looked into the transplant outcomes(overall survival,disease free survival,GvHD and immune reconstitution) of T-cell depletion with Alemtuzumab in the stem cell bag of HLA fully matched unrelated donor allografts. Patients and methods: 14 patients received a myeloablative conditioning with TBI/cyclophosphamide (n=10) or busulphan/ cyclophosphamide (n=4). 12 patients had AML in CR and 2 CML (1 chronic phase 1 accelerated phase). All the patients received PBSC grafts and ciclosporin as GvHD prophylaxis along with 15mg of Alemtuzumab in the bag.The median age of the patients were 32.9 (median 17-49). The median follow up was 39 months (range 5-142mo). Results: The 3 year overall survival was 52%. All patients engrafted with a median neutrophil engraftment of 12 days (11-16) and a median Platelet engraftment (PLT>20 unsupported) of 16 days (range 13-21). 42% of patients developed Grade I-II GvHD but none severe grade III-IV. The non relapse mortality was 18% in the first year (all infection related) and the overall relapse rate was 29% (4/14). Immune reconstitution of a CD4 count >200 was observed at a median time of 5 months (range 1-17 months). Conclusion: The strategy of T-cell depletion with Alemtuzumab ex vivo is a simple and eff ective way in reducing transplant related mortality and Graft versus host disease while it maintains a potent graft versus malignancy eff ect and provides a rapid immune reconstitution. Prospective studies with higher number of patients are needed to confi rm these results and defi ne the appropriate dosing of alemtuzumab in the stem cell bag. Conclusions: In our experience the use of BTZ at induction regimen before ASCT at MM's patients shows that it doesn't aff ect the achieve of HSC, and is better than treatments used before the BTZ era. Patients treated with BTZ didn't need more aphaeresis process to achieve the same amount of CD34+ HSC, and wasn't more likely to fail mobilization, than patients treated with other regimens. We have also seen that BTZ not infl uence the risk of being poor mobilizers as alkylating chemotherapy has previously demonstrated. The use of BTZ in induction regimen keeps us to make an ASCT in the most of the patients with MM.

Introduction: End of 2011, stem cell collection facilities were informed by the Terumo BCT Company about the end of life campaign for the Cobe Spectra device. These plans caused a lot of trouble, because the Spectra device is accepted as the gold standard for stem cell collections all over the world. As many others we had to decide, which device we will use in the future for allogeneic and autologous stem cell, lymphocyte and granulocyte collections. Material and Methods: As in many other European countries it is regulated by German authorities how to validate a new technical device and procedure before starting its use in routine production of a stem cell transplant. Because we need a license for our stem cell products, we geared our comparison investigation to German guidelines, which are published by Paul-Ehrlich-Institut. So we performed twelve collection procedures for allogeneic and autologous stem cell products respectively. We compared following results: stem cell count in product, collection effi ciency, contaminating cells, platelet loss in donors or patients, practicability and limitations of the procedure. Results: Amicus and Optia devices both collect autologous and allogeneic stem cell products. Nevertheless there are some diff erences, which we show in table. Conclusion: We found Pro's and Con's for both devices. Amicus collects a smaller volume and fewer platelets. So it is much more suitable for autologous stem cell collections, if products will be cryopreserved and patients are suff ering from thrombopenia. Amicus cannot collect granulocytes and stem cell products contain higher amounts of CD3-positive cells, which can play an important role in mismatched allogeneic transplantations. Optia collects varying and unpredictable volumes. That can cause problems, if cryopreservation is planned. Platelet loss in patients or donors is much higher than in Amicus collection procedures. Optia has a granulocyte collection protocol. Stem cell products contain fewer CD3-positive cells, which can be an advantage in mismatched transplantations. The decision, which device replaces Spectra best, should focus on the product type.

We conclude that long-term outcome of io infusion of bone marrow stem cells is safe and that the results are similar to those from the current clinical practice of iv infusion. Background: Plerixafor is a new CXCR4 antagonist that induces the mobilization of CD34(+) hematopoietic stem cells from bone marrow to circulation. Limited experimental data suggest that plerixafor+ Granulocyte-Colony Stimulator Factor (G-CSF) mobilized apheresis products (HPC-A) are functionally diff erent from G-mobilized HPC-A. Aim of the study: To evaluate the eff ects of plerixafor injection on graft composition in terms of lymphocytes subsets, monocytes and on gene expression profi le of molecules involved in immune network, cellular adhesion, engraftment. Methods: Fourteen patients aff ected by multiple myeloma were included in the study. All patients received G-CSF alone or after high dose cyclophosphamide to mobilize stem cells. Six patients received plerixafor pre-emptively owing to poor mobilization or poor collection yields. The rest of the patients constituted the control group. Graft composition was evaluated by fl ow cytometric analyses in terms of CD34+, CD3+, CD4+, CD8+, CD19+, CD56+, CD14+ cells. Gene expression profi les were evaluated on peripheral blood samples after G-CSF administration and, when plerixafor was injected, daily after every dose.

Results: The amount of T suppressor cells (CD3+/CD8+), NK cells (CD3-/ CD16/56+), B cells (CD19+) in the graft was all signifi cantly higher in the plerixafor group. On the contrary, T helper cells (CD3+/CD4+) was more representative in the other group. Monocytes were higher in plerixafor group and the amount increased with subsequent dose of the drug. Gene expression profi le documented CD83 and TNF levels signifi cantly higher in the peripheral blood after plerixafor administration. Conclusion: Plerixafor determines modifi cation of apheresis product respect G-CSF in terms of cellular types. Futher studies are needed in larger group patients to confi rm these data and to analyze their impact on immune reconstitution, longterm engraftment, patient outcomes after autologous stem cell transplantation.

Intramyocardial stem cell transplantation is expected to improve ventricular remodelling and survival. In our study, autologous CD34+ haematopoietic progenitors intended for the myocardial regeneration were collected after mobilization with G-CSF, then the CD34+ fraction was enriched and collection effi ciency was evaluated. Methods: Samples from 40 adult patients were used to prepare CD34+ haematopoietic progenitor stem cell enriched and concentrated products intended for autologous transplantation. The fi nal volume of therapeutic transplant was 8 mL. The median age of patients was 54 years. Immunomagnetic separation by targeting CD34 antigen using CliniMACS (Miltenyi Biotech) was used to enrich CD34+ cells. For the quality analysis, samples were taken from each apheresis product pre-and post-immunomagnetic selection. After staining cells with anti-CD45, anti-CD34 and 7-AAD, fl uorescent beads were added for evaluation of viable CD34+ count by fl ow cytometry and the CD34+ cell separation effi ciency was calculated.

Results: The average of CD34+ cells recovery after immunomagnetic separation was 63%±22, cell purities (%CD34+/%CD45+) increased from 0.7%±0.3 to 62%±35 after enrichment. A fi nal average dose was 109 x 10E6 cells/product. The average viability of CD34+ cells in our cell products prepared for implantation was as high as 97%. S196 Conclusion: Our protocol for the enrichment of autologous CD34+ cell products for intramyocardial application in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy by means of CD34+ immunomagnetic isolation is suitable for further clinical application based on high enrichment of the target CD34+ cell population. Further studies for the analysis of stem cell subpopulation in these autologous grafts are on the way.
