Stem cell transplantation, is the only curative treatment option for the malign and benign hematological diseases. Mobilized peripheral blood after granulocyte colony stimulating factor, is the mostly preff ered stem cell source. Determination and collection of CD34(+) hematopoietic stem cells(HSC) by fl ow cytometry is the routine method used in transplantation units. Aldehyde dehydrogenase, a functional marker, which is widely exspressed in the early hematopoietic progenitors can also be used for identifi cation of HSC. We aimed to asess the expression of ALDH, CD90 and CD38 markers in addition to CD34 in the mobilized peripheral blood samples and apheresis products to identify HSC. We also planned to determine the correlation between neutrophil, platelet engraftment and CD34(+)ALDHbr cell numbers infused. We included 19 autologus stem cell transplantation patients with diff erent diagnosis and 6 healthy donors for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. CD34ALDHbr cell percentage in the apheresis products of autologus and allogeneic transplantation patients were 0.78% and 0.49% respectively. CD34(+) and ALDHbr cell numbers were correlated in the peripheral blood and apheresis products (r=0.651, p<0.001, r=0.710, p<0.001). There was no difference in the peripheral blood and apheresis products, between the autologus transplantation group and healthy donors, according to ALDH, CD34 expression. Neutrophil and platelet engraftment was not correlated with CD34(+)ALDHbr cell numbers. In conclusion, as we could not show a relationship betweeen ALD-Hbr cell number and engraftment, it seems useless to determine ALDHbr cells in apheresis products.

Characteristics of patients with autograft containing less than 2x10 The main condition for successful autologous stem cell transplantation (AutoSCT) is the number of CD34+ cells in the autograft. The aim of the study was to fi nd out the clinical features of patients which autotransplant contained less than 2x10 6 CD34+ cells/kg. There were 14 patients with autograft failure. The median age of these patients was 47.5 years (19-62). Their diagnoses were myeloma (6 patients), nonHodgkin lymphoma (3 patients), acute myeloid leukemia (3 patients), and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (2 patients). Before stem cell collection the patients were treated with 1 to 4 regimens of chemotherapy. 3 regimens were used for stem cells priming: G-CSF only (5 patients), cyclophosphomide (Cph) 1-3 g/m 2 only (8 patients), and combination of high dose chemotherapy plus G-CSF (1 patient). The median of mono nuclear cells in the autograft was 1.9x10 8 kg (1.0-5.8 ) and the median of CD34+ cells was 0.51x10 6 kg (0.03-0.72). There were 36 patients with more than 2 10 6 CD34+ cells kg in the control group. There was no signifi cant diff erence in the age, number of previous lines of chemotherapy, total dose of antracyclines and number of aphaeresis which were done with Cobe Spectra between study and control groups. At the same time there was association between graft failure and dose of Cph less than 2.5 g m 2 . As there was no any possibility to repeat stem cell collection 8/14 patients were transplanted after conditioning with BEAM and Melphalan 200 mg m m 2 . The engraftment was reached in all patients with restoration of granulocyte count ≥ 0.5 10 9 l on the 12-30 days and platelets ≥50 10 9 l on the 12-100 days. Nevertheless there was much more number of infectious episodes (>54%) and number of platelets transfusions (>75%) in the study group compared with the control group.

The conclusion is that it is necessary to use the combination of G-CSF plus plerixafor in the cases with the dose of Cph for priming is less than 2.5 g m 2 . Objectives: rapid identification of eligible cord blood units (CBU) for banking is an important issue in hemopoietic stem cell (HSC) procurement. Distinct targets of CD34+ cells in CBU may identify grafts for small and adolescent/adult unrelated patients or potentially available for directed donor allogeneic/autologous storage.

Methods: Considering thresholds of CD34+ cell content of 3 and 2x10e6 (1x10e5/kg in recipients >30kg or >20kg, respectively) and a threshold content of 1x10e6 CD34+ cells which may be stored as mimimum dose in directed donor allogeneic/autologous setting, we analyzed a consecutive series of 1309 CBU. CBU were collected for autologous banking without any volume-based pre-selection criteria. Predictors of distinct content of CD34+ cells have been assessed by ROC curve analysis. Results: Median TNC and CD34+ cells of the entire series were 6.97x10e8 (range 0.36-34.9) and 1.47x10e6 (0-20.56) . Volumes ranged from 21 to 163 ml, with a median of 73.8. For the lowest CD34 target of 1x10e6, the best predictor at ROC analysis was TNC with a threshold of 6.63x10e8; volume resulted less predictive with a value of 68.1 ml (AUC of 0.900 and 0.856 respectively; Fig.1 ). For targets of 2 and 3 CD34x10e6, ROC curve analysis confi rmed a stronger predictive power of TNC, above the collected volume, with a threshold of 7.55x10e8 (3.77x10e7/kg for a patient of 20kg; AUC 0.870 vs 0.826 for collected volume) and 8.98x10e8 (3.00 x10e7/kg for a patient of 30kg; AUC 0.880 vs 0.811 for collected volume), respectively (Fig.1) . A restricted analysis on CBU >80 ml showed similar results, indicating TNC as the best predictor but with appreciable reduction of AUC (0.81, 0.76 and 0.80 for >1, >2 and >3). ROC analysis by combining all predictors (TNC, volume, TNC2, volume2, age of mothers, types of delivery, birth weight) gave worse results than TNC alone .

body_text.text: Conclusions: This analysis carried out on a large, unrestricted (by volume criteria) CBU series shows that TNC alone is the best predictor of distinct targets of hematopoietic potential with the chance to predict banking of CBU potentially useful for distinct patients' categories or for directed allogeneic/autologous storage. Three classes of CBU might be identified with a high sensitivity and specificity (Fig.1) . Collection of all these CBU categories in a sole banking strategy would translate into the possibility to exploit the cord blood source with a success rate of 66%.

Progression or relapse occurs in the vast majority of patients with multiple myeloma (MM) who undergo up-front autologous haematopoietic cell transplantation (AHCT1), which remains a cornerstone of treatment. Limited data are available regarding the value of salvage therapy with a second AHCT (AHCT2) in patients who relapse/progress after AHCT1, and the factors that determine outcome of AHCT2. We compared our results to those observed after traditional tandem auto-RIC-allo-HSCT without bortezomib (Group2 Background: The rational design of therapeutic vaccines requires the use of sequences that can induce robust, diverse and long lasting antigen-specifi c T and B-cell responses in the majority of the patient population. We recently demonstrated that signal peptide (SP) domains have exceptionally high number of MHC class I and II epitopes per sequence length. This improved MHC binding relies on their hydrophobic nature but also bare antigen specifi city. Namely, diff erent SPs exhibit high antigenic variability with no particular sequence identity while maintaining the consensus motif needed for their original function as chaperones.

Following this rationale we developed ImMucin, a 21mer peptide, encoding the entire SP domain of MUC1, a tumor-associated antigen expressed by most solid and hematological tumors including multiple myeloma (MM). Results: A phase I/II open label study was initiated to assess the safety (as a primary end-point) and effi cacy (as a secondary end point) of ImMucin, in 15 MUC1-positive asymptomatic MM patients following autologous stem cell transplantation with residual disease or progression. Patients received 12 bi-weekly vaccination of 100mcg ImMucin plus 250mcg hGM-CSF. Interim analysis conducted on 7 patients who completed the study suggests a high safety profi le for the vaccine with only temporary (up to 24 hours) mostly local mild adverse events which resolved spontaneously. Immunomonitoring analysis by ICS-IFN-γ, tetramer and anti-SP antibodies demonstrated a unique combination of robust ImMucin-specifi c IFN-γ production by CD8+ (18-80 fold increase) and CD4+ (4-80 folds increase) T-cells with pan HLA properties in all 7 patients, as well as a 1.4-10 folds increase in anti-ImMucin serum concentration in 5/7 patients. Specifi c immunity could already be detected after 2-4 vaccinations In-addition, a decrease in soluble MUC1 levels was observed in all 4 patients who had abnormal (>300pg/ml) levels at screening. Levels dropped from 3500-10000pg/ml at screening to 50-290pg/ml in 3/7 patients and from 9000 to 3000pg/ml in an additional one. We also observed a stabilization or reduction in FLC, M-protein disease markers and in bone marrow MM cells in 4/7 patients following the treatment. Conclusions: These results confi rm a high safety profi le with robust immunodominant properties and are suggestive of clinical effi cacy for the ImMucin vaccine.

F-18-FDG positron emission tomography integrated with computed tomography (PET/CT) has been reported to be useful for screening of myelomatous lesions in multiple myeloma (MM) at diagnosis and for monitoring response to therapy and prognosis after autologous stem cell transplantation (auto-SCT). Aim of the present study was to prospectively evaluate the prognostic signifi cance of PET/CT in MM patients who received allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT). All patients were studied with PET/ CT before and within 6 months after allo-SCT. The number and the size of focal lesions (FL) were recorded and PET/CT was considered positive if it showed at least 1 FL. The outcome of PET/CT positive and negative patients was compared in term of cumulative incidence of relapse (CIR ) and OS after allo-SCT. A total of 29 patients with a median age of 54 years (44-65) were analyzed. At diagnosis 14% had renal failure and 10 % had plasma cells in peripheral blood and/or in cerebrospinal fl uid. Del (13q), t(4;14) or del(17p), detected by FISH, were present in 50%. All patients received upfront auto-SCT , followed by allo-SCT within 3 months in 11 cases, while in the other 18 cases allo-SCT was performed after failure of previous auto-SCT. Median time between diagnosis and allo-SCT was 19 months (9-129). Conditioning was with Fludarabine plus 2 Gy TBI (73%) or melphalan 140 mg/mq (27%) Sixty-nine per cent of patients were transplanted from HLA matched unrelated donors. Chemosensitive disease was present in 73% of patients before allo-SCT. Two-year PFS and OS of the entire population were 42% and 31%, respectively. Before allo-SCT , 38% of the patients had a negative PET/CT, 24% presented ≤3 FL and 38% had > 3 FL. The entity of PET/CT involvement before allo-SCT infl uenced clinical outcomes. In particular, patients with positive PET/CT had a signifi cantly higher CIR and shorter OS in comparison with patients with negative PET/CT (2-year CIR 82% vs 32%, P=0.03, 2-year OS 23% vs 52% , P= 0.04). After 6 months from ASCT, PET/CT was negative in 45% of the patients and remained positive in 55% of them. Complete FDG suppression at PET/CT after allo-SCT conferred lower CIR and prolonged OS than persistence of FL (2-year CIR 32% vs 84%, P=0.008, 2-year OS 53% vs 21% , P= 0.003).

Ruutu Helsinki University Central Hospital (Helsinki, FI) The treatment of multiple myeloma (MM) has been rapidly evolving with novel drugs, but this disease is still regarded as incurable. The place of allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) in the treatment of MM is unclear. It off ers the possibility to harness the curative potential of the graft-versus-myeloma eff ect, but high SCT-related mortality (TRM) has limited its use. We report our experience of 120 patients treated with allogeneic SCT since the year 2000. The median age of the patients was 50 (range 28-65) years and 52% were males. Forty-nine patients received a myeloablative (MAC) and 71 patients a reduced intensity conditioning (RIC the external beam radiation to be "focused" upon the site of the neoplasm, reducing the radiation dose administered to nonaff ected tissues. This conformal radiation technique increases the therapeutic window of external beam radiation. We hypothesize that IMRT will allow the selective administration of higher doses of external beam radiation to bone marrow than Total Body Irradiation (TBI) without increasing the toxicity to normal tissues beyond that induced by TBI. Herein, we report our preliminary experience. Methods: We are carrying out a Phase 1 study using a modifi ed 3+3 cohort dose escalation study where IMRT conditioning was delivered using Tomotherapy® prior to stem cell re-infusion in a second ASCT in patients with relapsed and/or refractory myeloma ( Figure 1 ). Our modifi ed dose escalation schema allows us to limit doses to specifi c organs when dose limiting toxicity is reached for a specifi c organ, while escalating the doses in other organs where dose limiting toxicity is not reached. Baseline characteristics, prior therapies and duration of prior responses were documented. Dose limiting toxicities and radiation toxicities were assessed by the Regimen Toxicity scale and LENT-SOMA respectively. Results: Seven patients (5 males and 2 females) with a mean age of 54 years received a second ASCT using IMRT conditioning, where all patients had previously received a Melphalan 200mg/m 2 ASCT. Median follow-up from 2nd ASCT is 16 months. Patient demographics, disease characteristics, therapy received as well as pragmatic clinical outcomes are summarized in Table 1 . No dose limiting toxicities were noted with IMRT ASCT at 18Gy. Conclusion: Tomotherapy® delivery of IMRT based ASCT is safe and has the potential to improve the quality and duration of responses in patients with relapsed myeloma. Background: There are considerable concerns regarding the appropriate use of health care resources to reduce costs and waiting lists associated with autologous (Auto) hematopoietic progenitor cell transplantation (HPCT). One of the strategies to reach this goal is outpatient-based. We report the results of an outpatient, home-treatment program for patients (pts) receiving high-dose chemotherapy (HDC) and stem cells support. Patients and Methods: Between July 2010 and December 2012, supportive care in the aplastic phase after HDC was transferred from the hospital to the home setting using three diff erent approaches. Eligible pts had received treatment with a single course of High-Dose Melphalan (HDM) (200 mg/mq) followed by Auto-HPCT for Multiple Myeloma. In the fi rst inpatient cohort (IN), the supportive care designed for at home use was administered in hospital until neutrophil recovery to 0.5 x 10(9)/l. In the second outpatient cohort (OUT), pts were discharged the day after HPCT, but supportive care was delivered daily in the outpatient clinic. The third home care cohort (HC) consisted of pts who were discharged the day after HPCT and then received all subsequent supportive care at home, without any check-up in hospital, with the assistance of specialized home care transplant professionals. In the OUT and HC, pts were required to have an available caregiver at home to help monitoring patient's condition, drug administration and fl uid intake. In case of refusal of outpatient treatment or lack of available caregivers, pts were included in the inpatient cohort. Results: 82 pts were treated (IN=47, OUT=24 HC=11). IN were hospitalized (as days of hospitalization after HPCT) in the aplastic phase for a median of 16 days. OUT attended the outpatient clinic in the aplastic phase for a median of 9 days. In the OUT cohort, a patient could not be discharged after stem cells infusion, due to general malaise, and readmissions to hospital were 2/24 due to chemotherapy-related toxicity and severe arrhythmia, respectively. In the HC cohort, pts were seen at home twice a day for a median of 10 days and readmission to hospital was necessary in 1 case due to fever. No infectious deaths or unexpected emergencies occurred in the OUT or HC cohort. Neither was there any suggestion of an increased number of fevers, infections, or other complications.

body_text.text: The Extramedullary plasmocytoma (EP) is a plasma cell tumor which involves soft tissues, without any signs of systemic spread. EP have an incidence of 7%-17% in patients (pts) at the time of diagnosis and 6%-20% during the course of the disease. It can be found at any body sites. Response to conventional treatments is poor. Objective: in our study we wanted to test the hypothesis that standard US could detect EM and that contrast-enhanced ultrasound sonography (CEUS) could detect microvascular changes (MC) and possibly suggest response to treatment. Methods: we prospectively examined patients (pts) who were admitted on our BMT ward to undergo either ASCT or allo-BMT. All pts received abdominal and soft tissues (ST) US and all lesions detected were biopsied. All lesions were assessed with CEUS which utilizes a second generation sulfur-exafl uoride-based contrast media. CEUS allows for real-time imaging of the microcirculation. Results: out of 115 pts (enrolled in the last 3 years) we found 11 pts having EP (9.6% incidence). Sites involved were : retroperitoneum (N=3 pts), liver (N=2 pts), pancreas (N=3 pts), ST (N=3 pts), pleural (N= 1 pts), lung (N= 1), spleen (N=1). Disease status at EP diagnosis: VGPR (8) or SD (2) Introduction: Autologous hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (AHSCT) has established itself as the preferred therapy for younger patients diagnosed with multiple myeloma. Throughout its history, one of the main challenges of AHSCT has been the difficulty in mobilising the necessary stem cells. In 2002 a scoring system was introduced in order to reduce the apheresis procedures needed (Table 1 ). Under this system, the patient is evaluated premobilisation in an attempt to detect patients with a risk of poor mobilisation (poor mobilisers). The patient is thus 'scored' and this score is then used to outline the treatment. Target: Evaluate the infl uence of the mobilisation system score on the stem-cell apheresis process, based on the study of the processed volemia ratio and the number of performed aphereses. Study Design and Methods: A total of 77 patients with multiple myeloma treated with ASHCT, aged between 47 and 66 were evaluated. 23 underwent ASHCT before the scoring system was established ( Group 1, 1996 Group 1, to 2002 , while 54 were treated with the scoring system already in place ( Group 2, 2003 Group 2, -2011 . The analyzed parameters were the volemia ratio (blood volume processed in the apheresis (liters) / patient volemia) and the number of apheresis procedures. G-CSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor) was used for mobilisation, dosed at 10 μg/kg for 4 to 5 days. If the pre-treatment score was over 2.5 points the patient was categorised as a poor mobiliser and the C-GSF dose was doubled.

Results: The reduction in both the volemia ratio (Table 2 ) and number of extractions (Table 3) in post-score treatments was statistically signifi cant. New pre-transplant regimes such as vincristine, doxorubucin and dexamethasone (VAD), other thalidomide-bortezomib combinations or the disuse of melphalan may have had eff ects on the measured improvements. In our study, only 5 Group 2 patients had received melphalan as induction treatment. In this 5 patients, both observed parameters are inferior to the mean values obtained in Group 1. Conclusion: The study shows that the score-based prediction system facilitates obtaining the hematopoietic stem cells needed in AHSCT. The number of apheresis procedures as well as the volemia ratios fell signifi cantly using the prediction score.

In total, 392 patients screened for trial participation did not enter the study. 73 patients failed to meet criteria with regard to eligibility of whom the largest group were 13 patients who had early relapsed disease that did not meet the trial entry criteria together with 9 patients who were relapsing but symptom free and a further 4 patients whose relapse was not confi rmed on bone marrow aspirate taken for this study. 35 patients were inappropriately referred to participating centres having had no previous transplant and a further 34 patients had relapsed within the time stipulated for remission post fi rst transplant. 25 patients were referred inappropriately at the time of diagnosis while 15 were in second or subsequent remission. 85 patients declined to take part in the study, of these 13 patients did not want to undertake the travel to the centre performing the study and wished to have treatment closer to home. 32 patients did not want to have a second transplant; in contrast 15 patients declined as they wished to ensure they did receive a transplant as part of their relapse therapy, 3 patients opted to enroll in alternative studies. 15 patients screened for the trial were not recommended to take part by their doctors and a further 12 were considered too unwell to participate. These data highlight problems in undertaking clinical studies, and serves to underline the importance of careful patient selection, especially in relation to perceived patient choice.

Successful combined haemopoietic stem cell and kidney transplantation from HLA-identical sibling donor in patient with multiple myelomas L. Lengyel (1), P. Remenyi (1), A. Barta (1), A. Batai (1), Z. Csukly (1),

(2)National Institute of Oncology (Budapest, HU) ; (3)University of Semmelweis (Budapest, HU) Introduction: Very few cases of double transplantation from the same donor (haemopoietic stem cell and kidney) are reported in multiple myeloma patients. Methods: In our patient aged 43 multiple myeloma (κ light-chain, t,11,14) was diagnosed on the background of chronic renal insuffi ciency in Nov.2008. Very good partial remission was achived with bortezomib-thalidomide-dexamethasone (VTD) therapy and hemodialysis. The patient underwent autologous periferal blood stem cell (PBSC) transplantation after single melphalane (140 mg/m>2) conditioning regimen. Complete remission (CR) was achived, but the anuria remained, so we decided to do double transplantation, as he had a HLA-identical brother. G-CSF mobilized allogeneic PBSC was collected from the sibling donor, and the allo-graft was cryopreserved. After this stem cell collection the kidney transplantation was carried out from the same donor, on 21 Apr.2011 succesfully. Rapamune and tacrolimus were applied as immunosuppressive (ISU) treatments. Seven months following the successful kidney transplantation the allogeneic PBSC transplantation was done at the incipient relapse of the underlying disease on 24 Oct.2011. Conditioning regimen for the allogeneic transplant included total body irradiation (with the protection of the new kidney in the low pelvic region) + melphalane 140 mg/ m>2. Rapamune and tacrolimus were continued for graft versus host disease (GVHD) prevention. Several complications developed, as severe oro-pharyngeal mucositis, neutropenic fever, sepsis with acute renal insuffi ciency. Acute GVHD (gut) gr.II. was verifi ed with colon biopsy on 28 post-transplant day and treated with 2 mg/kg methylprednisolone successfully. Result: This "double" transplantation was successful: our patient is well, living in CR of multiple myeloma, his renal functions are normal and he has got a complete donor chimerism, no GVHD activity 20 months following kidney and 14 months following the allogeneic PBSC transplantation. He receives only tacrolimus as ISU treatment in decreasing dose since Sep.2012.

body_text.text: Thiotepa/melphalan as conditioning regimen for multiple myeloma patients not achieving complete remission after the reinfusion of autologous HSC. Preliminary data from a multicentre study M. Musso (1), A Crescimanno (1), M Martino (2), G Messina (2), G.

Thiotepa is widely used in the conditioning regimens for autologous and allogeneic transplants, due to its acceptable toxicity profi le also in association with other chemotherapic agents, and of proven eff ectiveness. The objective of our experience is the assessment of feasibility and effi cacy of Thiotepa / melphalan association as conditioning in patients already undergoing reinfusion of autologous peripheral blood stem cells, which have not achieved complete response; other eligibility criteria include age between 18 and 70 years, ECOG ≤ 2, adequate cardiac function (FEV> 45%), hepatic (bilirubin ≤ 2mg/dl and / or AST / ALT <3 times normal) and renal function (creatinine <1.6 mg / dl, and / or creatinine clearance 65mlmin), serology for hepatitis B and C negative or absence of viral replication, signing the informed consent.

The treatment schedule consists of Thiotepa 225mg/mq on day -5 and Melphalan 140 mg / sqm on day -2, followed by infusion of peripheral blood stem cells on day 0. Our experience includes 15 multiple myeloma patients , median age 58 (range 24-70), M / F 8/7. We infused a median of 5,1x106/Kg CD34 + cells (range 3,25-7,06); haematological recovery were observed on day 12 (range [10] [11] [12] [13] [14] [15] [16] [17] and 12 (range 0-22) for ANC / mmc and PLT> 20000/mmc, respectively. The transfusion requirements stood at 1 (range 0-5) and 1 (range 0-3) for RBC and PLT units, respectively. Extraematological toxicity consisted mainly in CINV and mucositis up to grade 3 CTC ( only in one patient there was liver toxicity grade 2), febrile episodes occurred in 9 patients (5 microbiologically documented infections), the lenght of hospitalization was of 20 days (range 20-30).

The above data have shown comparable to those seen in patients undergoing conditioning with melphalan. Our preliminary experience demonstrates the safety and feasibility of the proposed scheme in terms of toxicity, a larger series of patients and a longer follow-up time will be able to provide data on the eff ectiveness (EFS and OS). Background: allogeneic haematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) is a potentially curative therapeutic approach for patients with hematologic malignances, including multiple myeloma (MM). However, the role of allo-HSCT in MM is controversial due to the high attributable procedure-related mortality previously reported. Objective: to analyze the outcome of patients with MM undergoing allo-HSCT vs. others hematological diseases in a single center. Patients and method: we retrospectively studied 102 patients (pts) with a median age of 48 years (range 2-64), who underwent allo-HSCT in our institution between January 2007 and November 2012. The patients› baseline diseases were: MM 30 pts (29%), AML/ MDS 33 pts (32%), ALL 19 pts (18%), and NHL/HL 20 pts (21%). 43% of pts had undergone a previous transplant. 51% pts received allo-HSCT from siblings, and 49% from unrelated donors. The source of HSC was peripheral blood in 55%, bone marrow in 39% and umbilical cord blood in 6% cases. All pts with MM received conditioning with fl udarabine (150 mg/m 2 ), melphalan (140 mg/m 2 ) and thymoglobulin (1.5-3 mg/kg). The rest of the cases received conditioning with standard (61 pts; 85%) or reduced intensity (11 pts; 15%) regimens. Median follow-up of the series was 24 months (range: 1-72). Results: median hospital stay was 35 days (range: 24-79), with no diff erences among diseases. Peritransplant mortality was 5% (0% for pts with MM, and 7% for the rest). Overall survival (OS) at day +100 was 88 % (93.4% for pts with MM, and 87.5% for the rest). The rate of progression/relapse was 30% for pts with MM, and 29.2% for the rest. The OS rate at 2 years was 77 % for MM pts, and 58.3% for the rest. Progression-free survival at 2 years was 58% for MM pts, and 67% for the rest. There were no signifi cant betweengroup diff erences in OS and PFS. Conclusions: in our experience, allo-HSCT for pts with MM is a potentially curative and feasible therapeutic approach, with a procedure-associated morbimortality similar to that of other hematological malignances. Introduction: Autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) is standard approach for initial or treatment of relapses for multiple myeloma (MM) pts younger then 65 years. ASCT is connected with better overall survival (OS) and progression free survival (PFS)in comparison with conventional therapy. Aim: We retrospectively analyzed pts with MM treated with ASCT in our center from 1998. till 2010. Methods: Ninety nine procedures of ASCT in 85 de novo MM pts were performed after one or two lines of initial treatment. Male/ female ratio in our group was 49/ 36, average age was 52 years (37-64). Majority of pts, 56 (66%) were in III clinical stage. Pts have received 3-6 cycles of induction (VAD, CTD or TAD). Prior to ASCT, 31 pts (36%) were in CR+VGPR, 38 pts (45%) in PR, 9 pts (10,58%) were in less then PR and 5 pts (5,88%) had PD. Median time from diagnosis till ASCT was 13,9 months . Single ASCT was done in 85 pts (86%), tandem in 4 (4,7%) and secondary in 10 (11,76%) pts. Mobilization was combination of Cyclophosphamide (Cy) and Etoposide with G-CSF in 77 pts (91%) or Cy alone with G-CSF in 8 pts (9%). Seventy one pts (86%) were conditioned with Melphalan (Mel) (200mg/m 2 ), while 14 pts (16%) were conditioned with Buslulphan (16 mg/kgBW), Cy (120 mg/kgBW) and Mel (140 mg/m 2 ). MNC were collected mostly with one "high volume" apheresis and median number was 9,85x10 8 /kgBW (range 3,8-28x10 8 ). OS and duration of response were showed with Kaplan Meier method. Results: Engraftment was observed on +12. day after ASCT (range 8-36), respectively. In 2 pts there were no reconstitution and in 3 pts it was delayed. Overall response rate (ORR) is achieved in 73 (91%) pts. After ASCT, 46 pts (54%) have achieved CR+VGPR, while 27 pts (32%) were in PR. Nineteen (24%) pts have died and 61 pts (76%) are still alive. Median PFS for 32 pts (40%) after ASCT was 13 months. In 10 of those pts, we have done secondary ASCT. Median OS in 80 pts (2 have died during the procedure and 3 were lost from following) is 40 months with maximal follow up for 57 months. Conclusion: Achievements of CR+VGPR before and post ASCT are important predictive factor for OS and PFS. Better OS and PFS were achieved in those pts in whom ASCT was performed early. Transplant related mortality (TRM) is observed in heavily pretreated pts who were transplanted more then 12 months after diagnosis. TRM in our group is 5%. New agents and better supportive therapy together with ASCT with well defi ned maintenance will improve treatment results even more. Introduction: MM is the main indication for high dose chemotherapy with ASCT The recent development of novel agents like bortezomib, thalidomide, has improved response rates.There is concern about their possible deleterious eff ects on PBSC (peripheral blood stem cell) collection and engraftment following ASCT. We analyzed retrospectively our experience with conventional chemotherapy (VBCMP/VBAD) induction and a novel regimen (VTD) in newly diagnosed MM patients and compare their infl uence on stem cell yield and engraftment effi ciency. Patients and Methods: We reviewed 31 newly diagnosed, symptomatic MM patients treated with ASCT as part of frontline therapy from November 2003 to November 2012. They received: group A: VBCMP/VBAD alternating regimen,6 cycles (4 before PBSC collection) 22 patients (pts) and group B: VTD 6 cycles (9 pts). Pts characteristics were homogeneous in both groups (see table 1 ). All patients were mobilized with GCSF 10mcg/kg/d for 5 days after induction treatment for PBSC collection. Stem cells (SC) were frozen to -80ª C by non-controlled rate freezing with DMSO 5%. All patients underwent ASCT with Melphalan 200 as conditioning regimen and received GCSF 5mcg/kg/d from day +5. Results: The response rate prior to ASCT for group A was 13.6% CR(complete response), 86.4% PR (partial response); in group B it was 66.7% CR, 11.1% VGPR (very good partial response) and 22.2% PR. Median number of CD34 in PB (peripheral blood) prior to apheresis was 30 (10-66)/mcl in group A and 53 (10-70)/mcl in group B. In both groups the median number of apheresis performed was 2. The median number of CD34 was 2.9x106/Kg in group A and 3.05x106/kg in group B; median number of MNC (mononuclear cells was 8.42x108/kg and 5.73x108/kg in group A and B respectively. No patient developed adverse events during the mobilization and apheresis procedure. One patient in group A (4.7%) failed (< 2x10e6 CD34/Kg) the fi rst mobilization attempt and received Cyclophosphamide+G-CSF with successful collection. All patients received ASCT as planned and achieved engraftment. Median time to neutrophil and platelet recovery was 11 days(d) 9-15) and 11d(11-30) respectively in group A and 11d(10-13) and 10(9-13)in group B. Median number of packed red blood cells (PRBC) and platelets transfusions were 2(0-10) and 2 in group A and 2(0-2)and 2(0-3) in group B. Conclusion: In our experience VTD is an eff ective induction regimen for MM with an appropriate stem cell yield and time to engraftment after ASCT, not inferior to our previous chemotherapy regimen. No eff ective treatment exists for neuroinfl ammatory and neurodegenerative disorders. Future treatment of multiple sclerosis (MS) aims at restoring myelination and neurological functions as well as re-induction of self-tolerance. Mesenchymal stromal stem cells (MSC) are known to be anti-infl ammatory and multi-potent.

Using MSCs from green fl uorescent donors for treatment of autoimmune encephalitis in mice, we documented that MSCs can cross the blood-brain barrier, regulate autoimmunity and control paralysis. Based on these observations we pioneered a phase I/II open clinical trial using autologous bone marrow derived MSCs in 13 patients with severe MS failing all conventional modalities and14 patients with very advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We confi rmed that treatment with MSCs is feasible, safe and potentially eff ective. Based on our published preliminary study, a total of >250 patients were similarly treated at our center, mostly patients with MS, ALS, autism, stroke, each treated with 106 MSC/ Kg intrathecally and additional 0.5-1x106 MSC/Kg intravenously. Treatment was uneventful with self-limited headache due to lumbar puncture being the most frequent complaint (70%). A total of 60% of patients with MS reported improved outcome, some with very signifi cant objective improvement of EDSS score. No major side eff ect were developed or reported during a follow up period of nearly 6 years. In ALS treatment seemed to delay disease progression although further prospective studies are needed to confi rm effi cacy of treatment. Treatment seemed to be eff ective in autism with objective signs of improvement confi rmed by pediatric neurologist in one of 5 children and by the parents in other 4. More recently, we discovered a new technology for diff erentiation of bone marrow, adipose tissue and cord/placenta derived MSCs into neural stem cells, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, dopaminergic neurons and also to motor neurons. We conclude that treatment with multi-potent undiff erentiated MSCs is safe and potentially eff ective for immune regulation of MS possibly also for facilitation of remyelinization. Treatment with MSCs should be investigated prospectively in MS and additional neurodegenerative disorders. In the future diff erentiated MSCs may provide better opportunities for more eff ective regeneration of neurological defi cits caused by destructive neurological diseases. Pre-clinical investigations are underway to confi rm effi cacy of diff erentiated MSCs. Objective: Endothelial-colony forming cells (ECFCs) can be readily expanded from human umbilical cord blood and can facilitate repair of endothelial injury. E-selectin and SDF-1α are produced following endothelial injury and can regulate endothelial progenitor homing. Mechanisms of vascular repair specifi c to the mode of injury have not been well described in homogenous cell populations such as ECFCs and are needed for development of more eff ective vascular repair strategies. Methods and Results: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced endotoxic injury to mature human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) was compared with hypoxic and radiation injury. E-selectin expression in HUVEC cells is markedly increased (208-fold) following LPS-induced injury and facilitates increased ECFC adhesion and migration function in vitro. SDF-1α expression remains unchanged in LPS-treated HUVEC cells but increases more than 2 fold in fi broblasts undergoing similar endotoxic injury. SDF-1α induces expression of E-selectin ligands on ECFCs and facilitates greater E-selectin-mediated adhesion and migration of ECFCs in a CXCR4-dependent manner. Induction of E-selectin expression in HUVECs following hypoxic or radiation injury is negligible, however, while SDF-1α is increased markedly following hypoxia, highlighting injury-specifi c interactions between mediators of vascular repair.

Conclusion: E-selectin mediates adhesion and migration of ECFCs following endotoxic endothelial injury. SDF-1 α augments E-selectin mediated ECFC adhesion and migration in a CXCR4-dependent manner, highlighting the importance of injury-specifi c mediators in the coordination of vascular repair.

body_text.text: Cord blood embryonic-like stem cells are a heterogeneous population that lack self-renew capacity C. Alvarez-Gonzalez (1) It is now clear that human umbilical cord blood (hUCB) can be a source of not only Haematopoietic Stem Cells but also a range of diff erent stem cells populations, including a very rare embryoniclike stem cell (ELSC) population. This fraction has been described as lacking CD45 expression but expressing markers typical for pluripotent stem cells. The aim of this work was to characterise, isolate and expand this stem cell fraction for future regenerative medicine purposes. Methods: Cord blood mononuclear cells (CBMC) were prepared by lysing red blood cells (BD PharmLyse), or by density gradient centrifugation (Ficoll-Paque PREMIUM). The CBMCs were enriched for ELSC cells by negative selection by biotin-conjugated antibodies (Ab) to CD235a, CD11b, CD123, CD45, and CD61 and passage through an LD column following incubation with anti-microbead conjugated Ab. The resulting population was characterized for surface and intracellular markers by fl ow cytometry, fl uorescence microscopy and RT-PCR and plated into diff erent stem cell culture conditions. Results: We isolated a small population with high density and nuclei/cytoplasm ratio and expressing the stem cell markers CD34 and CXCR4, but in opposition to some reports, not CD133. Despite the expression of pluripotent markers such as Sox2, Oct3/4, and Nanog at the mRNA level, these cells did not shown any expansion in vitro using a variety of culture conditions frequently used to grow embryonic and/or adult stem cells. Further analysis by Flow Cytometry of the lineage-(mature leukocyte markers) CD45population, showed the presence of a new Lineage-CD45-Nestin ± population that has not described previously in hUCB.

Conclusions: The Lineage-CD45-stem cell fraction is a heterogeneous population representing a very low percentage of the stem cells present in the hUCB. The presence of this heterogeneity could explain the diff erences among reports. Groups could be sorting diff erent subpopulations by the use of distinct methods. The presence of Nestin could correspond to a previously described mesenchymal progenitor called small-sized nestin-positive bone marrow stem cell (S-BMSC); nevertheless more work is needed to clarify this correlation. Finally, the fact they did not show any capacity for self-renewal might indicate a quiescent population and could cast doubt on their defi nition as ELSC. However, only by identifying a homogenous population is this likely to be resolved.

Conclusions: To our knowledge this is the largest series reporting results on mobilizations for GCT. Results prompt a preemptive harvest for high risk pts and/or a potential new indication of plerixafor in a subset of pts for whom multiple HDCT courses are still a potentially curable option (3rd-4th line setting). Iukhta (2), S. Safonova (2), Y. Punanov (2), O. Goloschapov (1) (N=5), germinoma (N=4), pineoblastoma (N=2) and atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumor (N=3) received HDCT with auto-HSCT after induction chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgical treatment. At the moment of HDCT 13 patients were in complete remission (CR), 14 patients were in partial remission (PR) and 3 patients had stable disease (SD). The conditioning regimen for single auto-HDCT consisted of cisplatin, etoposide, and ifosfamide, or carboplatin, etoposide and thiotepa, or thiotepa and temozolomide. In tandem HDCT, the fi rst conditioning regimen was carboplatin and etoposide with intraventricular/intrathecal metotrexat, the second was thiotepa and cyclophosphamide with intraventricular/intrathecal metotrexat. Bone marrow (N=20), peripheral blood stem cells (N=5) or both (N=5) were used for stem cell sources. The mean transplanted CD34+ cell dose was 5.27 x 10 6 /kg (range, 1.0-8.9 x 10 6 /kg). Results: The median follow-up is 12 months (range, 1-82). The median time to engraftment was 16 (range 12-30) and 17 (range 13-86) days after the fi rst and second auto-HSCT, respectively. All patients with SD at the moment of auto-HSCT died of disease progression. Eight of 27 patients with CR or PR relapsed 1-11 months after HDCT, the other 19 patients are currently in CR. The following therapy toxicity was observed: liver toxicity grade 2-3 (N=21), skin toxicity grade 3-4 (N=6), severe mucositis grade 3-4 (N=15), nausea/vomiting grade 3-4 (N=10), infectious complications grade 3-4 (N=18). Two patients died of toxicity. Overall survival (OS) in all groups was 44% and disease free survival (DFS) was 35%. OS was signifi cantly better among high-risk patients in 1st CR compared to patients in 2nd or following CR: 69% and 30%, respectively (p=0,05). The same correlation was observed in DFS: 46% and 26%, accordingly (p=0,04). Conclusions: HDCT with auto-HSCT in pediatric patients with high-risk CNS tumors may be a feasible option for patients in CR or PR after induction chemotherapy. It is ineff ective as a salvage therapy in refractory patients. Objectives: Over the last few years, several targeted agents (TA) have proven, within large randomized trials, to improve survival in advanced renal cell carcinoma (aRCC), thus establishing new standards for both fi rst and subsequent lines of treatment. Despite the improvements achieved with TA, immunotherapy still remains the only treatment which is able to induce long-lasting complete responses in aRCC. More recently, the activity of more sophisticated immunotherapeutic agents reinforced the idea that the manipulation of the immune system could play a key role in this setting. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility and safety of adoptive immunotherapy with ex vivo-generated autologous cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) in patients with advanced RCC. Materials Aand Methods: CTLs were generated by stimulating CD8-enriched lymphocytes with dendritic cells pulsed with apoptotic autologous tumor cells in the presence of IL-12 and IL-7. Anti-tumor CTLs thus obtained were rapidly expanded in an antigen-independent way and then reinfused after lymphodepleting chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and fl udarabine, followed by subcutaneous administration of low dose IL-2. Disease status was assessed after every second infusions. Eight patients, median age 51, have been enrolled so far, after signing informed consent, 6 with clear cell RCC, 1 with papillary RCC and 1 with mixed papillary and collecting ducts RCC. The median number of metastatic sites was 4 (2-7) and the median time between diagnosis of RCC and biopsy was 55 months Antibody-mediated in-vivo T-cell depletion is common prior to unrelated (URD) or mismatched allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT) and optional in HLA-identical sibling (FAM) alloSCT. While anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG) is the current standard, alemtuzumab is an alternative. The optimal dose of alemtuzumab has not been defi ned. This retrospective analysis compares low-dose alemtuzumab with ATG in URD alloSCT and with no antibody in FAM alloSCT. Twenty-eight patients treated with alemtuzumab (10mg, HLAmismatch: 20mg) were matched to 28 patients who have either received ATG (URD) or no antibody (noAB) according disease, disease stage, age, transplant type, and risk state. Both groups were compared for engraftment, outcome, disease-free (DFS) and overall survival (OS), GvHD, freedom from GvHD (ff GvHD) and transplant-related mortality (TRM).

No signifi cant diff erences were found between the groups for leukocyte engraftment, GvHD, ff GvHD, TRM, DFS and OS. There was a trend for reduction of cGvHD by alemtuzumab (p=0.05). A transplant-type stratifi ed subanalysis consolidated equivalency of alemtuzumab and ATG in URD-SCT and indicates possible superiority of low-dose alemtuzumab compared to noAB in FAM-SCT. Low-dose alemtuzumab as part of conditioning regimen prior to alloSCT is safe and comparable to standard ATG. Allogeneic SCT is curative approach in AML and MDS. Reducedintensity conditioning (RIC) is feasible in patients (pts) not eligible for myeloablative conditioning (MAC), however relapse rates are increased, especially in pts not in remission. Fludarabine-treosulfan (FT) is an eff ective regimen with limited toxicity. A small dose-fi nding study recommended treosulfan 14 gr/m2 x3 for further studies based on a trend for lower relapses and similar low toxicity compared to lower doses. To better defi ne the outcome after FT and the role of diff erent doses, we analyzed a cohort of 216 pts with AML (n=137) or MDS (n=79) given treosulfan 12 gr/m2x3 in one institution (FT12, n=123) or 14 gr/m2x3 in a second (FT14, n=93 Allogeneic SCT is potentially curative therapy for patients (pts) with lymphoid malignancies. The combination of fl udarabine and treosulfan (FT) has been introduced over the last few years as a relatively dose-intensive, reduced toxicity regimen. It was predominantly explored in myeloid malignancies but there is only limited data in lymphoid malignancies. We studied 54 pts with diff use large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL, n=17), Hodgkin lymphoma (HL, n=11), T-cell lymphomas (n= 12), follicular/ mantle cell lymphoma (n=9) and CLL with Richter's transformation (n=5). The median age was 53 years (range, 23-70), 31 had chemo-sensitive disease at SCT (CR-23, PR-8) and 23 were chemo-refractory (SD-7, PD-16). 33 pts had a prior autologous SCT. The donor was an HLA-matched sibling (n= 28) or unrelated (n=26). The median follow up is 13 months (range, 1-38). 12 pts had non-relapse mortality (NRM), 3 died of infections, 5 of GVHD (3 acute, 2 chronic), 4 of organ toxicities. The cumulative incidence of NRM was 27% (95%CI 16-46% were predictive of shortened PFS. In conclusion, FT is a promising preparative regimen for allogeneic SCT in pts with lymphoid malignancies. Similar to the experience in myeloid malignancies, NRM rates are reasonable, considering the relatively heavily pretreated and high-risk pt group (43% chemo-refractory, 61% with prior autologous SCT). This is also a dose intense regimen as refl ected by the relatively low relapse rate. Outcome was favorable in pts with chemosensitive disease, but a subset of pts with chemorefractory disease at SCT could also be salvaged. This regimen merits further study in larger comparative studies.

Uppungunduri (1) The genes that code for these enzymes contain potential functional variants that may slow down elimination of Bu (GSTA1*B and CTHser403Ile), or increase the activation of Cy (via CYP2C9*1). Individually GSTA1*B and CTHser403Ile have been found to be associated with the occurrence of VOD, whereas the presence of CYP2C9*1 has shown a trend with VOD occurrence. Our objective: To investigate the occurrence of VOD in relation to these genotypes in a gene-gene interaction model. Sample and Methods: Sixty-seven children (50% males, median age 6.5yrs) receiving iv Bu/Cy based myeloablative conditioning regimen were included in this study. Ursodeoxycholic acid was provided as a prophylaxis for VOD. A TaqMan based assay was used for genotyping the chosen SNPs: GSTA1 rs3957356, CTH rs1021737 and CYP2C9 rs1799853. The occurrence of VOD at day 50 was analyzed in relation to the risk genotypes using a Multifactor dimensionality reduction (MDR) analysis. We used the presence of GSTA1*B and CTHser403Ile in a recessive model, and the presence of CYP2C9*1 in a dominant model. Results: Incidence of VOD (Seattle criteria) was 12.1%. The MDR analysis results are shown in table 1, where the last model was chosen as the best by the MDR program. Conclusion: The MDR analysis chose the three gene variant combination, as the best model to predict VOD in children taking a Bu/ CY conditioning regimen before undergoing HSCT, thus there is a gene-gene interaction occurring between these genes. However, caution must be taken because we did not have any individuals with all three risk genotypes, thus the program inferred the risk by observing the data from the other patients which had the two risk genotype combinations. Nonetheless, these results show that either of the models shown in table 1 could be used to predict the occurrence of VOD, some with more sensitivity than others. The consequences of these predictions could give clinicians the option for providing additional prophylaxis or alternative treatments to these patients. Pesaro risk class 3 patients treated with standard protocols continue to have an increased rejection rate which could be as high as 17% to 38%. In 1997 we adopted a new treatment protocol (Pc26) for class 3 patients which lead to reduced rejection and improved DFS (Blood 2004; 104:1201) . However, our subsequent experience with Pc26 showed an elevated rejection rate in class 3 patients which prompted us to modify Pc26 to overcome this complication. A total of 48 class 3 patients with median age of 11 years (range, 5-16) were treated: 26 patients with original Pc26 and 22 with modifi ed Pc26 (Pc26m). Patients had severe iron overload with median serum ferritin of 2626 ng/mL (range, 777-10222) and liver iron concentration of 20,8 mg/g (range, 5-40.7). Median liver fi brosis score was 2 (range, [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] . Median number of RBC transfusions was 140 units (range, 25-307). Treatment regimen involved an intensifi ed preparation with 3 mg/kg of azathioprine and 30 mg/kg hydroxyurea daily from day -45 from the transplant, fl udarabine 30 mg/m 2 from day -16 through day -12, followed by conditioning with iv busilvex, thiotepa 10 mg/kg and CY 160 mg/kg. GVHD prophylaxis was with CSA/methylprednisolone/MTX. Graft rejection occurred in 4 patients treated with Pc26 and none in patients given Pc26m with a cumulative incidence (CI) of 16% (95% CI 5%-32%) and 0% respectively (p=0.06).The probability of OS for patients treated with Pc26 and Pc26m was 85% (95% CI, 67%-94%) and 85% (95% CI 64%-94%), respectively. Respective probabilities of DFS were 73% (95% CI, 52%-88%) and 85% (95% CI 64%-94%) (p=0.52). The CI of grade II-IV acute GVHD was 46% (95% CI 26%-64%) and 28% (95% CI 11%-49%) (p=0.25) in Pc26 and Pc26m arms, respectively. Median follow-up for surviving patients was 77 months (range, 70-10) in Pc26 and 48 months (range, 1-67) in Pc26m arms. There were 4 deaths in Pc26 and 3 in Pc26m groups. Treatment protocol was well tolerated without any signifi cant toxicity. None of the patients had grade 4 toxicity. Most frequent grade 3 toxicity was AST and ALT elevations. Three patients in Pc26 and 2 in Pc26m groups had grade 2 hemorrhagic cystitis. One patient in each group had moderate liver VOD resolved with supportive care.

In conclusion, this novel treatment protocol eff ectively prevented graft rejection and increased DFS in class 3 patients who usually have preexisting organ damage because of iron overload and/or hepatitis while avoiding excessive nonhematologic toxicity.

Sebert (1) Although reduced intensity conditioning regimen (RIC) has been used for over a decade in older patients (pts), the benefi t of this approach in younger pts with AML compared with the standard regimen (MAC) is still discussed. We compared the outcomes for pts with AML over 35 years (yrs) using RIC or MAC HSCT. From 01/2000 to 12/2010, 132 consecutive pts older than 35 yrs with AML received HSCT in our center, either from siblings (n=87) or HLA 10/10 matched unrelated donors (n=45). MAC (n=72) and RIC (n=60) regimens were defi ned as previously described (Bacigalupo, 2009 Conclusions: These results suggest that OS is infl uenced by stem cell source rather than the use of ATG in AHSCT with MSD and 10/10 MUD. ATG has no impact on OS for patient who received CSP and its use should be discussed. Autologous HSCT is a standard treatment of multiple myeloma. High-dose melphalan alone or in combination with TBI is most frequently used for conditioning. In our center we initially applied TBI (12 Gy) alone followed by melphalan monotherapy in two subsequent transplant procedures. In the current prospective trial, TBI is substituted by total marrow irradiation (TMI, total 12 Gy, 4 Gy fractions on days -3, -2, -1) applied with the use of helical tomotherapy, in order to reduce toxicity. In addition, patients are examined with FDG-PET and in case of evidence of active sites of the disease they receive additional 'boosts' (total 24 Gy, 4 Gy

S223 fractions on days -9 to -4). Second HSCT with melphalan (total 200 mg/m2 on days -3, -2) is performed after 100 days. Out of 50 subjects planned as a total study population, 20 patients were included between March and August 2012 and could be evaluated for early safety and effi cacy of TMI, which was the goal of this scheduled interim analysis. Median age was 57 (44-65) years and disease status as follows: CR (n=1), VGPR (n=6), PR (n=10), SD (n=3). Three patients received TMI + additional 'boosts' . All patients experienced absolute agranulocytosis (ANC<0.1x10e9/ L) and all recovered neutrophils >0.5 x10e9/L after 11 (10-13) days and PLT >50 x10e9/L after 12 (11-16) days. Neutrophil engraftment was signifi cantly faster for TMI compared with the historical control of 50 patients treated with TBI alone (p=0.01). Four (20%) patients treated with TMI experienced grade 2-4 adverse events, including grade 2 infection + neutropenic fever (n=1), grade 2 nausea (n=3), grade 2 (n=1) and 3 (n=1) diarrhea. The incidence of grade 2-4 toxicities was signifi cantly lower compared to TBI group (50%, p=0.03). Disease status was evaluated on day +100 after autoHSCT with TMI. All three patients with SD prior to HSCT achieved PR, two PR patients achieved VGPR, one VGPR patient converted to CR. In the remaining 15 cases the response status did not change, except for one patient who progressed. All subjects proceeded to the second autoHSCT with conditioning based on melphalan and all engrafted.

Conclusions: Results of this interim analysis indicate excellent tolerance with preserved myeloablative potential of TMI at the dose of 12 Gy. The toxicity profi le appears favorable in comparison with TBI at the same total dose. The trial will be continued to evaluate effi cacy and long-term safety of the double autoHSCT incorporating TMI ± PET-guided 'boosts' , as a personalized treatment approach.

Impact of ATG-containing myeloablative conditioning on patient outcome after single-unit allogeneic cord blood transplantation L. Pascal (1) Purpose: Previous studies suggested that ATG-containing myeloablative conditioning for allo-SCT from an unrelated donor resulted in decreased incidence of extensive chronic GVHD without compromising survival. However, the use of ATG incorporated within the conditioning regimen prior to allogeneic cord blood transplantation (allo-CBT) is still controversial. Patients and Methods: We report on 91 consecutive patients who underwent single-unit unrelated allo-CBT in 3 French transplantation centers (Lille, Nantes and Bordeaux) for acute leukemia (n=66, 73%), myelodysplstic syndrome (n=17, 19%) and lymphoproliferative disorders (n=8; 9%). Median age at transplant was 12 years old (range, 0.7-56). CB units were fullmatched (6/6, n=18; 20%), one-antigen mismatched (n=30, 33%) or 2-antigen mismatched (n=38; 42%). The median cell dose was 4.6 107/kg (range, 0. 5-22.2) . All patients received myeloablative conditioning including 51 with TBI. In this series, 46 received ATG ('ATG' group), whereas 45 did not ('no-ATG' group). Only patients receiving the ATG brand Thymoglobuline® (Genzyme Corporation, Cambridge, USA) were included because this was the only ATG brand approved in France for use in allo-SCT. In the ATG group, the drug was given at the dose of 5 mg/kg (n=27) and 7.5 mg/kg (n=15). Two patients received less than 5 mg/kg for intolerance. ATG was discontinued at a median of 5 days before transplant with a median number of 2 days of perfusion (range [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] .

Results: The two groups were comparable for patient characteristics and transplantation modalities. OS, EFS, relapse, NRM, acute grade 3-4 GVHD and chronic GVHD were 47%, 30%, 48%, 23%, 19% and 21%, respectively. In multivariate analysis, the use of ATG was the strongest parameter associated with a decreased OS and EFS rates with [HR = 1.99, 95% CI: Conclusion: Unlike what has been reported in allo-CST from unrelated donor, the addition of ATG to preparation regimen seems to have a detrimental impact on survivals in patients undergoing single-unit myeloablative allo-CBT. However, prospective studies assessing more precisely which patients may benefi t from ATG in this setting are required.

Chevallier (2) Reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimens has allowed performing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HSCT) in previously disregarded old or unfi t patients. RIC has reduced non-relapse mortality (NRM), but post transplant morbidity and mortality as well as disease control remain a challenge. We studied the post-HSCT outcome of older or comorbid patients with 1st complete remission acute myeloid leukemia who received a RIC with fl udarabin (Flu), busulfan(Bu) and rabbit anti-thymoglobulin (rATG Fanconi's Anemia (FA) manifests clinically with progressive development of aplastic anemia (AA), myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) or acute myeloid leukemia. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only curative treatment for these hematological manifestations. Over the last few years there is convincing evidence supporting the use of fl udarabine based conditioning regimens in HSCT for Fanconi's Anemia patients. However, graft failure and rejection remains an important concern, especially in the setting of alternative donors and hyper transfusion. Many eff orts have been directed towards improving engraftment rate without increasing toxicity. We present our experience in HSCT for FA using fl udarabine-cyclophosphamide (Flu-Cy) based conditioning regimen with or without the addition of busulfex (Flu-Cy-Bu). Patients and Methods: Sixteen patients with FA who underwent Flu-Cy based conditioning HSCT in our center from 1987 till 2012 were included. Ten patients were included in the Flu-Cy group, and six in the Flu-Cy-Bu group.
Patients' characteristics are detailed in table 1.

Results: The median time to neutrophil and platelets engraftment was 19 days (range 10-37) and 19 days (range 9-56) in the Flu-Cy group and 22 days (range 9-32) and 24 (range 10-28) in the Flu-Cy-Bu group, respectively. Two patients In the Flu-Cy group (20%) and 1 patient (16.6%) in the Flu-Cy-Bu did not engraft. Acute GVHD (grade ≥2) occurred in 1/8 and 3/5 patients in the Flu-Cy group and Flu-Cy-Bu group, respectively. At the time of this report, 1/8 and 2/5 patients in these groups suff er from chronic GVHD, respectively. Veno-occlusive disease was reported in 3 patients In the Flu-Cy group and in 1 patient in the Flu-Cy-Bu group. With a median of 50 months follow up in the Flu-Cy group and 29 months in the Flu-Cy-Bu group all 10 patients and 4/6 patients, are alive and with normal blood counts (fi g. 1; p=0.055). Death causes were multi organ failure (n=1) and encephalitis (n=1) in the Flu-Cy-Bu group.

Conclusions: Fludarabine based regimen in HSCT for Fanconi's Anemia patients is a tolerable regimen with high OS and good toxicity profi le. Although the number of patients treated in the Flu-Cy-Bu group is too small to draw defi nitive conclusions, the addition of Busulfex to the Flu-Cy conditioning regimen in HSCT for FA does not seem to improve engraftment, and is associated with increased treatment related mortality and possibly GVHD. Conditioning regimens used in autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation (AHCT) for Hodgkin's (HL) and Non Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) are considered equal. During the last 2 years a new conditioning regimen was constructed in our unit consisting of intravenous Busulphan (Busilvex) (9.6mg/kg), Etoposide (800mg/m 2 ) and Melphalan (140mg/m 2 ) (BuEM). We retrospectively analysed the outcome of patients (pts) who underwent AHCT following standard BEAM and BuEM regimen in our unit. The pts were stratifi ed by age, pre-transplant disease phase and previous lines of treatment. In total, 50 pts conditioned with BuEM (group A) and 93 with BEAM (group B) were included. Group B pts were selected among 184 conditioned with BEAM during the last decade. Stratifi cation by disease risk was followed by a 1:2 selection. Fifty percent of the pts were younger than 34 years old in both study groups (range 11-68). The pts of group B more likely suff ered from HL (63) than NHL (30); whereas disease diagnosis for group A was HL in 28 and NHL in 22 pts. Disease was chemoresistant to salvage treatment in 46% of group A versus (vs) 23% of group B pts. There were no other signifi cant diff erences concerning the patients' characteristics such as age above median, pretransplantation lines of treatment (1-2: 40%, 3-4: 46%, ≥5: 14%), disease status (complete remission: 27%, primary refractory:52%, relapse: 21%, advanced stage disease: 52%). Complete remission post-AHCT was obtained in 50% of group A and 56% of group B pts. Progression free survival (PFS) at 2 years and overall survival (OS) were similar among the study groups (66% vs 63% and 80% vs 78% respectively). Given the fact that there were more pts with chemoresistant disease in group A, a second matched pair analysis was conducted upon stratifi cation by disease chemosensitivity to salvage treatment instead of age as a risk factor. Effi cacy was again similar for both regimens. In multivariate analysis favorable factors in terms of PFS were HL, chemosensitivity to salvage treatment and stage <IIB whereas in terms of OS non-bulky disease, HL and stage <IIB. Treatment related mortality (TRM) was 3.2% (3/93 pts) in group B and none in group A. There are currently no randomized studies clarifying the optimal conditioning. In this study the two regimens, BEAM and BuEM, were found to be equivalent. Additionally, the effi cacy of the newly designed BEM regimen in chemoresistant and advanced stage disease is encouraging. We conclude that this retrospective study suggests that ATG can prevent graft-versus-host disease without obvious risk of relapse resulting in similar progression-free and overall survival in HLAidentical peripheral blood stem cell transplantation which has to be confi rmed in a randomized trial. Here, we performed a single-center retrospective analysis focusing on the use of ATG and the intensity of conditioning regimen. From March 2005 until June 2011, 294 patients who underwent allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) were eligible for this analysis. In patients with ATG (ATG-group), most patients received an unrelated HSCT (92%) and in patients without ATG (non-ATG-group), most patients received a related HSCT (86%). The cumulative incidences of grade II-IV acute graft-versushost disease (GVHD) and chronic GVHD were signifi cantly lower in ATG-group compared to non-ATG-group (P=0.039 and P=0.022, respectively). There was no signifi cant diff erence in terms of nonrelapse mortality, relapse, overall survival and progression-free survival. Grouped according to the intensity of the conditioning regimen (conventional myeloablative conditioning [MAC] vs reduced-toxicity conditioning [RTC] vs reduced-intensity conditioning [RIC]), the cumulative incidences of chronic GVHD were signifi cantly lower in ATG-group in addition to a MAC or a RTC, but not in addition to a RIC, which might be due to less tissue damage in RIC and thereby less auto-antigen presentation and cytokine induction as trigger of GVHD. In summary, the benefi cial eff ect of ATG as GVHD prophylaxis was preferentially seen in patients receiving a MAC or RTC. This fi nding needs further validation in prospective trials. We report the results of a retrospective analysis on 112 patients who underwent HLA-matched sibling donor RIC HSCT receiving either ATG or alemtuzumab. All patients received a uniform protocol of fl udarabine and bulsulfan. For T-cell depletion and GVHD prophylaxis 59 patients received alemtuzumab (20mg iv x 5 days) followed by cyclosporin A post-transplant. 53 patients received ATG (Thymoglobulin, Genzyme; total 6mg/kg iv over 3 days) followed by cyclosporine A post-transplant.

All patients received PBSC with median CD34 cell dose of 5.9 x10 6 /kg (0. 7-17.5 Introduction: Obesity has considerably increased worldwide in recent years. As chemotherapy agents may not be equally distributed in adipose tissue, this raises concerns about the appropriate chemotherapy dosing in obese patients, and capping chemotherapy doses is not infrequent in this population. The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) guidelines do not recommend capping doses of standard chemotherapy, as reduction from standard doses might compromise progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) in the curative setting. However, whether this policy should be applied to patients receiving high-dose therapy (HDT) with autologous stem cell rescue (ASCR) with the potential for signifi cantly increased toxicity is unclear.

Objective: The aim of this study was to describe the dosing of HDT conditioning regimens in patients with a body surface area (BSA) >2m2 and to analyse the potential impact on outcome of capping chemotherapy doses in these patients. Results. Most of pts had lymphoma, 1 multiple myeloma, and 1 Ewing sarcoma. 6/8 patients underwent to an autologous transplant. Disease status at TR-H was: 1 complete remission, 2 progressive disease, and 5 partial remission. All but two pts had a Sorror score >2, Karnofsky score was less than 70% in 5/8 pts. Immediate tolerance was good and no pts developed nausea or vomiting nor parotid hyperplasia. No pts had oral mucositis. The median time to ANC >500/μL, and platelet recovery >20,000/μL was 23 and 26 days, respectively, and this was not diff erent from data obtained with conventional low grade TBI. Full donor chimerism was evident at day 30 in all evaluable patients (7/8). Only 1 pt developed acute GVHD ≥2. No chronic GVHD was observed. 4/8 died because of PML, invasive lung aspergillosis, liver failure, and heart failure.

Conclusion: This small retrospective analysis suggests that TMI/ TLI could substitute conventional low dose TBI, with a suffi cient degree of immunesuppression of recipient, allowing engraftment and full donor chimerism. The mortality due to toxicity was felt to be due to poor patient characteristics.

Scheid (1) Busulfan and Fludarbine (BuFlu) are currently the most widely used reduced intensity regimen (RIC) in treating malignancies with allogeneic stem cell transplantation (Allo-HSCT). The total dose of Bu is usually 12.8 mg/kg intravenously (i.v.) in myeloablative regimen, or 6.4 mg/kg i.v. in RIC, in which antithymocyte globulin (ATG) always added to enhance engraftment. We fi rst reported this new myeloablative Bu (9.6 mg/kg) Flu regimen in aged and/ or intolerable patients with severe concurrent medical condition, and to evaluate its safety and effi cacy. The regimen consisted of hydroxyurea 80 mg/kg on d -10; cytarabine 2 g/m2 on d -9; Bu 3.2 mg/kg/day iv. ×3days ( on d -8 to -6); Flu 30 mg/m 2 i.v.×5 days (on d-6 to-2) and semustine 250 mg/m2 on d -3. All 23 patients, median age 49 (6~66) years, with myeloid malignances at standard (n=6) or high risk (n=17), underwent HSCT with human leukocyte antigen (HLA) matched sibling donors. The source of stem cells was G-CSF mobilized bone marrow (G-BM) plus G-CSF mobilized peripheral blood (G-PB) in 20, G-PB alone in 2, and non-mobilized BM in 1. Graft versus host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis included cyclosporin A, mycophenolate mofetil and short term methotrexate. The median time of neutrophil recovery (>0.5×10 9 /L) and platelet recovery (>20×10 9 /L) were 16 and 14days. therapy most widely used as conditioning regimen is the BEAM protocol, which foresees the administration of Nitrumon 300 mg/sm day -6, Cytosine Arabinoside (Ara-C) 200 or 400 mg/sm and Etoposide 200 mg/sm once a day from day -5 to day -2 and Melphalan 140 mg/sm day -1. Ara-C, when used in the scheme of therapy for the treatment of lymphomas, is administered in high doses (1-2 gr/sm) because its known to be more eff ective.

With the intention to increase the effi ciency of the BEAM protocol, we modifi ed the treatment schedule accordingly: Nitrumon 300 mg/sm day -5, Ara-C 2 gr/sm and Etoposide 200 mg/sm once a day for 3 days from -4 to -2 and Melphalan 140 mg/sm day -1. The aim of the study was to evaluate the toxicity of the treatment and the resumption of the myelopoiesis in the fi rst phase, and subsequently its effi cacy. From April 2007 to March 2012 we treated 44 patients. Patients characteristics, toxicity and haematological recovery are shown on the table below. All patients received HSCs from peripheral blood with an average of 6.3 x 10 6 cells/Kg (range 3.6-14.1) and granulocyte growth factor (Filgrastim) was administered from day +6. The treatment did not cause intense nausea or vomiting, nor pulmonary, hepatic and renal toxicity. The mucositis and transfusion requirement were not high. Two patients died, one case with relapsed-resistant disease, heavily pre-treated and at high risk of infection, of sepsis at day +7, and one case with refractory disease, for its progression at day +46. The hematological resumption resulted as that of the traditional BEAM protocol. Hospital discharge was possible after 11-17 (median 13) days after the transplant. The modifi ed BEAM protocol with high dose Ara-C resulted a well tolerated treatment with no higher toxicity respect to traditional BEAM. The outcome of this conditioning regimen will be evaluated after a year since the last case treated. Allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) after myeloablative conditioning (MAC) can cure high-risk haematological malignancies but in older patients and those with signifi cant comorbidities it has high non-relapse mortality (NRM). In 1989, to enable patients unfi t for MAC with an otherwise dismal prognosis to benefi t from the graft-versus-tumour eff ect, we developed a reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) protocol: LACE. It consists of oral lomustine 200 mg/m 2 (day -7), iv etoposide 1000 mg/m 2 (day -7), iv cytarabine 2000 mg/m 2 (days -6 and -5) and iv cyclophosphamide 1800 mg/m 2 (days -4, -3 and -2 Graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) remains the major barrier to successful allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Standard prophylaxis regimens for GvHD comprise combinations of the calcineurin inhibitors cyclosporin or tacrolimus with methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil. These combination strategies are not able to prevent GvHD in a signifi cant proportion of patients. Aside from their toxic properties, continuous immunosuppression delays immune reconstitution and diminishes the desired graft-versus-tumor eff ect. Post-transplant cyclophosphamide has been used as GvHD prophylaxis in the haploidentical setting and in the context of bone marrow transplantation after myeloablative conditioning.

In this monocenter phase II trial, we attempted to test the effi cacy, safety and impact on immune reconstitution of post-transplant cyclophosphamide as sole GvHD-prophylaxis in peripheral blood stem cell transplantation following reduced-intensity conditioning (RIC) in patients with myeloma or lymphoma. Eleven patients were treated (median age 49, range 26-61 years). All patients received a RIC regimen with Fludarabin and Busulfan and T cell-replete peripheral blood stem cells followed by 50 mg/kg/d of cyclophosphamide on day 3 and 4 after transplantation (5 MRD, 4 MUD, 2 mMUD). Median engraftment occurred on day 18, 20,5 and 17 in leukocytes, neutrophils and platelets. All patients evaluable had full donor chimerism on day 28. The incidence of acute grade II-IV and grade III-IV GVHD for all patients was 45% and 27%, respectively. Non-relapse mortality at day 100 and day 365 was 18% and 45%, respectively. Overall and event-free survival at one year after transplantation was 55% and 36%, respectively, with a median follow-up of 543 days. Interim analysis after seven patients demonstrated fast T-and B-cell recovery including increased regulatory T-cell frequencies in comparison with a historical patient cohort receiving calcineurin inhibitors as GvHD prophylaxis. Updated results on immune recovery and clinical results for all eleven patients will be presented. Post-transplant cyclophosphamide can be used as single-agent GvHD prophylaxis in patients transplanted with peripheral blood stem cells and allows a fast immune recovery with respect to B-and T-cell reconstitution. Grade III-IV acute GvHD rates and NRM were comparably high for RIC transplants with the limitation of a relatively small patient number. Three out of eleven patients did not require any systemic immunosuppression until day+100 and further on.
