More recently CMV reactivation has been associated with a GVL eff ect. This analysis describes impact of CMV reactivation with regard to outcomes and GvL in 198 consecutive patients with MDS and AML who received a uniform protocol consisting of fl udarabine, busulfan and alemtuzumab(100mg). CMV reactivation was detected by qPCR on peripheral blood. OS, DFS, TRM and CIR was performed according to Donor/Recipient(D/ R)CMV IgG sero-status and reactivation post-HSCT. Time to reactivation defi ned as early or late(>day+45) was reviewed to determine eff ect on outcomes. D/R serostatus showed better outcomes for Neg/Neg group 5yrOS of 53%(p=0.035), 5yrCIR of 33% (p=0.04) and trend to better 5yr DFS of 48%(p=0.08) with no diff erence in TRM. Comparing neg/ neg group with the Non-Neg/Neg, diff erences were found in DFS and CIR (p=0.05 and 0.079, Figure 1 and 2). No diff erences were seen for matched vs mismatched serostatus. Groups were not different with regard to IPSS score, cytogenetic risk, donor, remission status pre-HSCT or GVHD.

Of the 198 patients analysed, 47% had at least 1 CMV reactivation after transplant (59% in high risk). Median time of reactivation was 38 days. Interestingly 17% of the Neg/Neg group had detectable DNA viraemia the majority of which were late infections(60%). For CMV reactivation global analysis of OS, DFS, TRM and relapse did not show diff erences comparing the reactivated vs non-reactivated group. However for patients with late CMV reactivation compared with those with early reactivation and the non-reactivated group outcomes showed improved OS(p=0.060), DFS(p=0.047), and CIR(p=0.046), (Fig 3 and 4 )without diff erences in TRM(p=0.706).

To our knowledge this represents the largest analysis of CMV reactivation using an Alemtuzumab based protocol. Importantly D/R CMV. IgG serostatus or the presence of CMV reactivation aff ected TRM. We confi rm the results of other groups demonstrating less relapse and potential GvL eff ect for CMV reactivation however the timing of reactivation was important. The eff ect of decreased CIR in the Neg/Neg group appears contradictory however is explained by the occurrence of primary CMV viraemia in this group. Prospective analyses should be performed to support these fi ndings.

Safety and immunogenicity of high dose infl uenza vaccine compared to standard dose in allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients N. Halasa, B. Savani, M. Grigsby, R. Simons, C. Summers, J. Bourgeois, L. Wang, M. Jagasia Vanderbilt University (Nashville, US) Background: Recipients of allogeneic stem cell transplants (allo-SCT) do not respond to trivalent inactivated infl uenza vaccine (TIV) as well as healthy controls; therefore, alternatives are needed. Since high dose (HD) TIV is now available, it may elicit better immune responses than standard dose (SD) infl uenza vaccine. Objective: To determine the safety and immunogenicity of HD-TIV compared to SD-TIV in allogeneic hematopoietic SCT recipients.

body_text.text: Methods: This was a randomized, double-blind, phase I safety and immunogenicity trial comparing HD to SD TIV in adult allo-SCT recipients at least 6 months post-transplant and not on immunosuppressive therapy for treatment of active GVHD. Subjects were randomized in a 2:1 fashion to receive 2010-11 or 2011-2012 TIV as either 0.5 mL of HD (60 ug per antigen) or SD (15ug per antigen). Hemagglutination inhibition (HAI ) titers to infl uenza virus antigens as well as complete blood count, quantitative CD4, CD8, and CD19 and serum IgG were measured prior to the fi rst TIV dose and 28-35 days later. Results: Forty-four subjects were enrolled (19 in year 1 and 25 in year 2) at a median of 7.9 m after allo-SCT (range, 5.7-105.6 m). The median age was 50.1 y (19.6-72.8), 61.4% were male, 100% white. The most common reasons for transplant included AML, ALL, and MDS. 29 subjects were given HD and 15 SD. No diff erences in demographic or lab data between the two groups were noted, except the HD dose group had higher median IgG level (676 vs. 469, p=0.025). Selected safety data are shown in Table 1 , with more reports of any local symptoms in the HD group compared to SD. No SAEs were attributed to vaccination. Immunogenicity results are shown in Table 2 , with the HD group having a higher percentage of individuals with titer >1:40 and higher geometric mean titers (GMT) after TIV for H3N2 antigen. Conclusions: No diff erences were noted for systemic reactions between the HD and SD groups; however, the HD dose had higher frequency of any local reactions. The HD group had higher percentage of individuals with post-vaccination >1:40 titer and GMT for H3N2 antigen. These data support a phase II immunogenicity trial.

Varicella zoster virus disease after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Incidence, risk factors and complications G. Fjaertoft, J. Winiarski, P. Ljungman, M. Uhlin, M. Remberger, J. Mattsson Karolinska Institutet (Stockholm, SE) Objective: To study the incidence, possible risk factors and complications of Varizella-zoster virus (VZV) disease after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT).

cite_spans.text: G. Fjaertoft, J. Winiarski, P. Ljungman, M. Uhlin, M. Remberger, J. Mattsson Karolinska Institutet (Stockholm, SE)

body_text.text: Patients: A total of 860 patients were studied retrospectively for the occurrence of VZV disease after allo-HSCT. The median age was 38 years (<1-71). The majority of patients had a malignant disease (n=737, 86%). The donor was as follows: HLA-identical related: 311, MUD: 437, mismatched: 112. Myeloablative conditioning was given to 431 patients and 429 received reduced intensity conditioning. The stem cell source was: Bone marrow (233), peripheral blood stem cells (572) and cord blood (55). A total of 85 (10%) of the patients had been given mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC) as treatment for graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) or hemorrhagic cystitis (HS). Results: 194 (23%) of the 860 patients studied had a history of VZV disease. The median time from allo-HSCT to the appearance of VZV disease was 177 days (range 0-2510 days). According to multivariate analysis risk factors for VZV disease was: Day of engraftment >d16 (RH 1.51, p<0.01), TBI ≥6Gy (RH 1.55, p=0.004) and MSC (RH 1.49, p<0.01).

For 24 (2,8%) of the patients the VZV disease was generalized. 25 patients suff ered from "post-herpetic neuralgia" defi ned as pain continuing more than 1 month after the VZV-disease. 11 patients (1,3%) experienced other more severe complications to their VZV disease: Visceral zoster (2), encephalitis (1), meningitis (1), facial palsy (1), endophtalmitis (2), keratitis (1)and blepharitis (1) . Two patients were hospitalized because of secondary bacterial infections necessitating i.v. antibiotics. The overall 5 year survival did not diff er between patients with and without VZV disease (68% in both groups). Conclusion: VZV disease represents a rather frequent, most often painful and sometimes severe complication after allo-HSCT. In our opinion a safe and eff ective regime for the prevention of VZV disease after allo-HSCT is well motivated at least for patients with risk factors. Background: Blood stream infection (BSI) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is a well-known complication during the pre-engraftment phase. Knowledge of trends in etiology and antibiotic susceptibility of BSI are important as the time to eff ective antibiotic treatment is closely associated with survival in bacteremic patients with septic shock. Methods: BSI during pre-engraftment phase was studied retrospectively in 521 patients undergoing HSCT at our center in 2001-2008. Incidence, risk factors, outcome and microbiology fi ndings were investigated and compared with BSI in a cohort transplanted 1975-1996. Results: The incidence of at least one episode of BSI was 21% and the total attributable mortality 3.3%. The rate of gram positive and gram negative BSI was 80% and 13%, respectively. Gram negative BSI was more frequent both in 2001-2004 and in 2005-2008 compared to 1986-1996 (p=0.023 for 2001-2004, p=0.001 for 2005-2008) , with fl uoroquinolone resistant E. coli as the predominant fi nding. BSI with viridans streptococci and E. coli occurred signifi -cantly earlier after HSCT than BSI with Enterococci spp, median time 4, 8 and 11 days, respectively (p<0.01 both for viridians streptococci verus Enterococci spp. and E. coli versus Enterococci spp.). Risk factors for BSI in multivariate analysis were transplantation from unrelated donor and cord blood as stem cell source, while peripheral blood as stem cell source was protective. Conclusions: BSI remains a cause of morbidity and mortality in HSCT recipients. The risk for gram-negative BSI increased over time in parallel with an increased rate of quinolone resistance. However, the incidence and attributable mortality of gram negative BSI remained low why continued prophylaxis with ciprofl oxacin is appropriate.

Adenovirus surveillance and pre-emptive treatment lead to low virus-related mortality despite frequent viraemia in a paediatric stem cell transplantation unit M, Mynarek, T, Ganzenmueller, A. Mueller-Heine, C. Mielke, A. Gonnermann, R. Beier, M.G. Sauer, B. Eiz-Vesper, U. Kohstall, K.W. Sykora, A. Heim, B. Maecker-Kolhoff Hannover Medical School (Hannover, DE) Human adenovirus (HAdV) infection is associated with signifi cant morbidity and mortality after pediatric hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). The optimal surveillance and treatment strategies are under discussion. Recently, screening of fecal samples has been promoted in addition to blood screening for earlier identifi cation of infected individuals. We performed a retrospective analysis of HAdV PCR results and clinical outcomes in 238 consecutive pediatric HSCT recipients transplanted at Hannover Medical School between Jan 2003 and Feb 2012. All patients underwent prospective weekly quantitative HAdV PCR testing from blood; 111 patients had additional prospective weekly stool PCR screening. The incidence of HAdV-DNAemia was high (50%), and HAdV blood loads >1,000 copies/ml were detected in 15.5% of all patients. 26 patients (11%) displayed HAdV-related symptoms. The mortality rate directly attributed to HAdV seemed low (2 patients; 0.8%), accounting for 5.1% of all deaths (n=39). Blood HAdV load >10,000 copies/ml was a signifi cant and independent risk factor for poor survival. Detection of HAdV-DNAemia before day +50 after HSCT was a major risk factor for the development of HAdV blood loads >10,000 copies/ml. Detection of HAdV in stool correlated with blood loads, but preceded blood loads >10,000 copies/ml only by a median of fi ve days. Therefore, it marginally contributed to early recognition of patients at risk of high blood load HAdV-reactivation. However, routine monitoring of HAdV in stool samples may have contributed to early recognition of symptomatic HAdV-mediated enteritis, which is likely to be underdiagnosed early after HSCT due to frequent non-specifi c diarrhea. Moreover, transmission precautions were initiated after detection of HAdV in stool, which may have helped to control nosocomial spread. Preemptive treatment with cidofovir led to stable or reduced viral loads in 70% of patients. Our data suggest that routine PCR-monitoring for HAdV and preemptive treatment of high-risk patients result in a low HAdVrelated mortality. We recommend preemptive treatment with cidofovir in pediatric HSCT-recipients after detection of HAdV blood loads >10,000 copies/ml or persistent HAdV blood loads >1,000 copies/ml, even in the absence of symptoms. Moreover, we suggest treatment of every symptomatic infection, both localized and systemic. Invasive fungal infection (IFI) has emerged as a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among HCT recipients. In this study we report an overview on the incidence of IFI by analyzing 10year data collected prospectively on 350 consecutive patients who received an allogeneic HCT in our center between 2001 and 2011. Patient, donor and transplant characteristics are described in Table 1 . We included only IFI defi ned as probable or proven in accordance with published guidelines. We identifi ed 39 cases of IFI (prevalence 11,1%), of which 30 were due to invasive aspergillosis (IA) (22 probable and 8 proven (Aspergillus fl avus 5, Aspergillus fumigatus 3)), 1 to Fusarium solanis infection, and 8 to Candidemia (C. albicans 3, C. krusei 4, C. parapsilosis 1). The median day of onset for IA and Candidemia was day 55 (12-3023) and day 35 (11-187) respectively, whereas the Fusariosis infection occurred on day 140 post-transplant. IA involved lung in 29 cases and brain in 1; Fusariosis involved skin and blood; Candemia occurred in blood (n=6) or in blood, liver and spleen (n=2). Imaging fi ndings in pulmonary IA on CT scan included: macrododules > 1 cm in 13 patients, consolidation in 7, clusters of small nodules in 7, cavitary lesion in 2, and non specifi c ground-glass opacifi cation in 2. The 5-yr and 10-yr cumulative incidence (CI) of IFI was 11.3% (IA 8.9%, Candidemia 2.4%) and 12.5% (IA 10.1%, Candidemia 2.4%) respectively. In univariate analysis there was no signifi cant correlation between recipient factors (age, gender, ferritin, underlying disease, previous transplant, disease risk) or transplant factors (type and intensity of conditioning regimen, stem cell source), and occurrence of IFI, whereas the use of antithymocyte globulin (ATG) and the development of both acute and chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) were signifi cantly associated with an higher CI of IFI. In multivariate analysis we found 4 risk factors signifi cantly associated with an higher CI of IFI: recipient age > 50 years (Hazard Risk (HR) 1.65 (p=0.05); acute GvHD (HR 1.59, p=0.01); chronic GvHD (HR 1.62, p=0.001; CMV infection (HR 1.37, p=0.003). Five of the 39 patients with IFI died for this complication, in all cases from IA. The 10-yr overall survival for the 311 patients with no evidence of IFI was 42% as compared to 17% of the 39 patients with IFI (p=0.006). These results emphasize that IFI represent a signifi cant complication in HCT recipients. Background: computed tomography (CT) guided bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is widely used for the diagnosis S303 of pulmonary infections, but its diagnostic value and safety in children after allo-HSCT is not suffi ciently studied. The purpose of this study was to evaluate effi ciency and safety of BAL in diagnosis pulmonary infections in this cohort. Materials and methods: 189 BAL samples from 127 pediatric allo-HSCT recipients were analyzed in 2009-2012. Median age was 8,5 y.o. We performed high-resolution CT guided bronchoscopy with endoscopic video system EVIS EXERA II Olympus with an external diameter of the distal end tubes of the 3.6 mm and 4.9 mm in a specialized endoscopy room or ICU (12%) . Diff erent methods of anesthesia were performed, depending on the age and the degree of respiratory failure of patients with mandatory monitoring of vital functions of the body and oxygen levels. The samples obtained were sent immediately to the laboratory for classic and molecular detection methods. Results: Signifi cant pathogens were detected in n=149(78%) of BAL (bacteria -n=57(39%), fungi -n=56(37%), viruses -n=36(24%), mixed infections -n=34(22%). In 52% of samples from 36 patients with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis fulfi ll EORTC/MCG 2008 criteria the results of galactomannan (GM) tests in BAL fl uid were positive despite negative results of GM tests in serum and microscopy and culture of BAL. P.jiroveci infection was revealed in three patients (2%), mycobacterial infection -in two (1,3%) . No major complications occurred during bronchoscopy. Transitory hypoxemia was observed in 28% of patients, nasal bleeding -5%, and bradyarrhythmia -2%. Conclusion: CT guided bronchoscopy with BAL remains a very important procedure for the diagnosis of pulmonary infections. Complex investigation of BAL fl uid can reliably detect signifi cant pathogens. The use of the indirect diagnostic tests (GM, PCR) signifi cantly increases the diagnostic value of BAL. Bronchoscopy performed with modern video endoscopy equipment and adequate anesthetic can safely be used in children after allo-HSCT.

body_text.text: Objectives: The Invasive fungal disease (IFDs) remains a major concern in patients received hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). We conducted this study to better understand the epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment practice of IFDs in HSCT recipients.

body_text.text: Methods: This is a multicenter, prospective observational study for IFD in HSCT patients in China. All patients receiving HSCT from Jan 2011 to Oct 2011 in 32 sites were enrolled and observed to 6 months after transplantation. Uniform case report form was used to collect patient characteristics, IFD diagnosis, antifungal agents used during hospitalization and survival status. The diagnosis of IFD was based on the 2008 EORTC/MSG criteria. Results: A total of 1401 HSCT patients were enrolled. The median age of patients was 30 years (1~66yrs); 62% were male. 75% of them received Allogeneic-HSCT and 25% for Autologous-HSCT. 65.7% of patients' stem cell source was peripheral blood, 3.5% were from marrow and 28.2% were from both of them. 9.6% of patients had previous IFD. 384 IFD episodes were identifi ed among 1401 patients, 100 episodes were proven/probable IFD. The 6 months cumulative incidence, based on the fi rst IFD (proven/probable), was 6.7% overall, and was 2.8% in auto-HSCT, 8.0% in allo-HSCT (12.5% in haplo-HSCT, 11.1% in unrelated matched HSCT, 3.1% in sibling matched HSCT). Lung is the most commonly observed infection site (76.5%, 166/317). 83.9% of recipients received antifungal prophylaxis; Fluconazole (61.4%) was the most used agent. The incidence of proven/probable/possible IFDs in patients with/without prophylaxis was 20.3% and 48.2% respectively. Among 516 patients who received antifungal therapy, empirical therapy (82.0%) was the most common strategy for initial antifungal treatment. Itraconazole (38.6%) and voriconazole (31.6%) were the most common fi rst-line agents.

body_text.text: Identifi cation of an HLA-A*24:02-restricted adenovirus serotype 11 epitope recognized by cytotoxic T-cells N. Imahashi (1) Subgroup B adenovirus (AdV) serotype 11 (Ad11) is the prominent pathogen for hemorrhagic cystitis, and occasionally causes disseminated infection with fatal outcome in immunocompromised patients. Due to the limited effi cacy of antiviral drugs, adoptive T cell therapy for AdV has been explored. Although previous studies have identifi ed several T-cell epitopes of subgroup C AdV, those of Ad11 have not been identifi ed. Here, we describe a novel Ad11 hexon epitope restricted by HLA-A*2402, the most common HLA class I molecule in Japanese population, that could be used for adoptive T cell therapy. Ten synthetic Ad11 hexon protein-derived nonamer peptides which bound to HLA-A*24:02 were selected by a computer algorithm and MHC stabilization assay. Weekly stimulation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells from HLA-A*24:02+ healthy donors for three weeks with each of these ten peptides induced INF-γ producing CD8+ T-cells specifi c for three peptides, referred to as peptides X, Y, and Z. Of these three peptide-specifi c CD8+ Tcells, only peptide X-specifi c CD8+ T-cells produced signifi cant quantities of IFN-γ against Ad11 infected K562 cells which were transduced with HLA-A*24:02 (K562/A*24:02 cells). Furthermore, peptide X-specifi c CD8+ T-cells eff ectively lysed peptide X loaded K562/A*24:02 cells, but not peptide unloaded K562/A*24:02 cells or peptide X loaded K562 cells, in 51Cr release assays. These results indicate that peptide X is naturally processed in Ad11 infected cells, presented in the context of HLA-A*24:02, and recognized by CD8+ CTLs.

In conclusion, we have identifi ed a novel HLA-A*24:02-restricted Ad11 hexon epitope X that could be used for adoptive T cell therapy for Ad11 infection and to monitor CTL responses to Ad11 among HLA-A*24:02+ patients using MHC tetramers. Background: Pre-emptive therapy of cytomegalovirus (CMV) , has signifi cantly reduced, if not eliminated, the risk of progressing to CMV disease. The question we addressed in this study, is whether CMV viral load , is a predictive factor for outcome. Aim of the study: Test whether maximum CMV load is predictive of survival; if so whether this has changed with transplant eras, or is associated with specifi c donor types. Patients: We therefore studied 940 patients allografted 1990-2010. The donor was a matched sibling (SIBS) (n=468) , a family mismatched donor (n=152), an unrelated donor (UD) (n=247) or an unrelated cord blood (UCB) (n=73). All patients had developed a positive antigenemia, at a median interval of 45 days from transplant. The median number of pp65 antigen positive cells (Ag+) at diagnosis of CMV was 2/10 4 PBMC, and the maximum number of AG+ cells was 7. The median age was 40 years. The conditioning regimen was myeloablative (MA) in 615 and reduced intensity (RIC) in 325. Results: The overall actuarial 10 year survival of the 940 patients with CMV Ag-emia was 43%. It was 45% vs 41% for patients presenting with < /> 2 Ag+ cells (p=0.01) and 50% and 35% for patients with a maximum number of AG+ cells < /> 7 x10 4 (p<0.0001). The diff erence in OS was seen also when selecting patients grafted more recently (2000 -2012) . The diff erence in OS is due to a higher transplant related mortality (TRM) in patients with a high viral load (35% vs 22%, p<0.0001), whereas the cumulative incidence of relapse related death (RRD) is identical 23% vs 21% (p=0.4). The eff ect was evident only in patients grafted from SIBS (50% vs 24%m p<0.0001), and not in patients grafted from alternative donors (42% vs 41% p=0.6) (Fig.1) . It was also more pronounced in older patients (> 40 years of age) as compared to younger patients.

In multivariate Cox analysis on OS, age <40 (RR 0.4), low CMV load (RR 0,7) and early disease phase (p=0.7) were very strong favourable predictors. Conclusions: We confi rm that the maximum number of CMV Ag+ is a strong predictor of outcome, in patients grafted from SIBS and not in patients grafted from alternative donors. It is unclear whether this is due to a diff erent prophylaxis strategy in the latter, in whom we have always used foscarnet, whereas high dose acyclovir is used for SIBS.

body_text.text: Infl uenza is an important infection in patients after allogeneic HSCT. Peripheral blood lymphocytes were collected prior to and a month after seasonal infl uenza vaccination during two seasons (2010-11 and 2011-12) . 30 patients from two centers were included in the study. The median time after transplant to vaccination was 239 days (97 to 818 d). A whole blood assay was used to quantify IFN-γ production responses directed against several diff erent infl uenza antigens. IFN-γ levels of >10 pg/ml above the mean level of the medium control was chosen as indicating a specifi c T-cell response before vaccination. An increase of 10 pg/ml was chosen to indicate a vaccination response. Most of the recipients showed strong IFN-γ production in response to PHA (positive control) both prior to and after vaccination. Before vaccination, IFN-γ production to the diff erent infl uenza strains was very diverse and could be observed between 2 and 14 patients. 11

patients had no detectable IFN-γ production to any strain, while 7 patients responded to fi ve or more antigens. There was no correlation between the likelihood of having a specifi c response against at least one strain and the time from HSCT. After vaccination, between 4 and 9 patients exhibited increases in IFN-γ production, depending on the viral strain tested. No diff erence was seen in the INF-γ response rates and time after HSCT. There was no diff erence between the response rates to the major infl uenza strains (H1N1, H3N2, or B). PBMCs from 12 HLA-A*02 individuals were additionally analyzed by FACS for infl uenza specifi c CD8 T-cells using two infl uenza specifi c dextramers A*02 GILGFVFTL Matrix 1 protein, A*02 RLATGLRNV hemagglutinin [HA] . A median increase from 0.13 to 0.325% of A*02 RLATGLRNV HA specifi c CD8 T cells was observed (p= 0.04) one month after vaccination. 5/12 individuals responded with at least doubling of the % HA specifi c CD8 T-cells, 5/12 individuals had measurable activity but no increase, and 2/12 individuals had no HA specifi c reactive CD8 T-cells, 10/12 individuals who had HA specifi c CD8 T cells also had an increase in IFN-γ production tº at least one of the infl uenza A strains, no increase in A*02 GILGFVFTL matrix1 specifi c CD8 T cells or CMVpp65 specifi c CD8 cells (median % 0.26 to 0.22) was observed. We conclude that IFN-γ production and an increase in infl uenza specifi c CD8 T cells can be elicited by vaccination with tri-valent infl uenza vaccine.

The clinical relevance needs to be determined. Background: Adenovirus (Adv) infections are a major cause of morbidity in hematopoietic stem cells transplantation (HSCT). The aim of the study was to determine risk factors for Adv infection and disease in pediatric HSCT patients to defi ne the patients who should benefi t of a screening for Adv. Methods: Between September 2010 and December 2011, 65 pediatric HSCT patients were prospectively followed for 12 months and were weekly tested for adenovirus in blood and stool. Shedding was defi ned as a positive detection in stool only, systemic infection as positive detection in blood, and disease as infection with Adv associated symptoms. Univariable and multivariable Cox models were used to defi ne predictive factors for shedding in stool, systemic infection and disease with estimated hazard ratio (HR) of event as a measure of association. Results: Cumulative incidence of shedding in stools, infection and disease at 3 months post-HSCT were 39%, 21% and 17% respectively. There was a strong predominance of the subgenus C (55.6%) whereas other species were far less observed: A (11.1%) B (7.4%) D (3.7%) and F (7.4%). Risk factors were age under 6 years,

cord blood transplantation, mismatch unrelated donor and corticosteroids in preventing GvHD for shedding in stool (HR=2.6, HR= 4.0, HR=9.1, HR= 3.6, respectively); the same factors were selected for predicting disseminated infection (HR=8.3, HR =4.2; HR=11.1, HR=4.3 respectively) as well as grade 3-4 GvHD (HR=3.0). Risk factors for Adv disease were cord blood transplantation (HR=3.8) and grade [3] [4] . Based on multivariable models, mismatch unrelated donor (HR=3.4) and age below 6 (HR= 2.9) remained associated with shedding in stool, while grade 3-4 GvHD and cord blood transplant remained associated with infection or disease (HR=2.9, HR= 4.1; HR=3.5, HR= 3.7 respectively). Association of AdV detection with presence of other viruses and association between AdV load in stool with viremia will be given. Conclusions: Age<6 years, mismatch unrelated donor, cord blood transplant appear the most appealing risk factors for Adv infection and should be considered to initiate a molecular screening for Adv. Adv infected patients with cord blood transplant and/or grade 3-4 GvHD must be considered for early anti-Adv intervention.

Objectives: To assess the predictive value of quantitative determination of blood BK virus (BKV) load for the occurrence of hemorrhagic cystitis (HC) in the fi rst 100 days after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Methods: From April 2005 to December 2011, patients (pts), aged<18 years and undergoing a fi rst allogeneic-HSCT were assessed weekly by blood quantitative PCR for BKV, until day + 100. To investigate if the cut-off for HC of BKV-load varied according to the time from HSCT, we considered the maximum value up to two weeks prior to the following time-points: day + 30, day + 45, day + 60 and day +100. A receiver-operator characteristic (ROC) curve was plotted to detect the value with higher sensitivity and specifi city > 80%. Follow-up data are as at June 2012. Results: 107 pts, 66 males (62%) and 41 females (38%), with a median age at HSCT of 7.7 years (range 0.7-17.3), were enrolled. The underlying disease was leukaemia or lymphoma in 82 (77%), solid tumours in 1 (1%) and non malignant disease in 24 (22%). The donor origin was: sibling, 32 (30%); matched unrelated donor, 32 (30%); and mismatched unrelated donor, 43 (40%). The stem cell source was bone marrow, 73 (68%), peripheral blood, 13 (12%), and cord blood, 21 (20%). The conditioning regimen was based on total body irradiation in 43/107 patients (40%). At a median time of 25 days from HSCT (range 7-98), 20 pts developed grade II-IV hemorrhagic cystitis (HC): the 100-day cumulative incidence being 19.2% (95% CI 13-29). The 90% of pts had symptoms: dysuria and strangury (83%), pollakiuria (72%), and abdominal pain (67%). The median duration of macrohematuria was 13 days (range 2-71). The BK virus was positive on blood in the 75% (15) of pts, with a median value of 14,151 genomic copies/ml (range 7,661-3,159,500).

body_text.text: Since that the majority of the HC episode occurred by day + 30, a ROC curve was plotted only for this period. A BKV load of 1023 genomic copies/ml had a sensitivity of 100%, a specifi city of 86%, a NPV of 100% and a PPV of 39%. After a median follow-up of 3 years, the overall survival was 69% (CI 58-77). Among the 32 deaths, 13 were due to progression disease and 19 to transplant related causes. Three patients died with bleeding but none of them had suff ered from HC. Conclusion: A BKV load of 1023 genomic copies/ml had the highest sensitivity and a good specifi city to predict HC occurrence by day + 30. The low PPV is consistent with the multifactorial pathogenesis of HC. The most common dsDNA virus infections (whether single or multiple) were CMV (54%), AdV (31%), BKV (23%) and EBV (7%). By transplant type (HCT vs SOT), the most common infections (single or multiple) were CMV (56% vs 68%), AdV (36% vs 20%) and BKV (28% vs 10%). Approx. 30% (95/320) of pts had evidence of multiple (2) (3) (4) (5) dsDNA virus infections; the most common coincident infections in the same pt were CMV+BKV at 34/95 (36%), AdV+BKV at 28/95 (29%) and AdV+CMV 22/95 (23%). Younger age (p=0.0004), black race (p=0.047) and HCT (p=0.039) were significantly associated with multiple dsDNA virus infections. Conclusions: A signifi cant proportion of expanded-access and EIND pts qualifying for CMX001 therapy had evidence of multiple dsDNA infections. Pts enrolled post-HCT, particularly children, appear to have an increased likelihood of multiple dsDNA virus infections. The potential for broad-spectrum clinical benefi t with CMX001 is being evaluated in these pts and will be further explored in future clinical studies.

Multimer monitoring to detect cytotoxic T cells (CTL) directed against latent viruses (e.g. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)) in patients after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) has been reported earlier. We reason that successful immune reconstitution of CMV-and EBV-CTL depends on a functional immune response in the donor. Thus, the number of CTL transferred with the graft was investigated. We established multimer monitoring in grafts prior to transplantation and investigated infl uences of (1) sample storage conditions, (2) the apharesis procedure including G-CSF-stimulation and (3) correlation of multimer staining with CMV and EBV serostatus and CTL functionality. We analysed the number of CMV-and EBV-CTL using 6 HLA class I multimers (A*01:01, A*02:01, A*24:02, B*07:02, B*08:01, B*35:01). Functional activity was tested by IFN-γ ELISpot. Antiviral CTLs were analysed in whole blood (WB) prior to and after G-CSF mobilisation (WBM) before apheresis, in samples from the apheresis tubing fi lter (R) and in the graft (G). To detect eff ects of sample storage time and temperature, we repeatedly measured WB samples from patients after HSCT. Staining results in samples after 24 h, 48 h and 72 h, stored either at room temperature or 4°C, were compared to results obtained from fresh samples. Storage at 4°C for up to 48 h yielded reproducible results. Analysis of 163 samples from stem cell donors showed that the unspecifi c background was signifi cantly higher in R and G samples compared to freshly collected samples. After subtraction of background, percentages of cells stained with specifi c multimer lay within the same range for all sample types. Using a threshold of ≥0.1% multimer positive events in the CD3CD8 subpopulation to identify antigen-experienced individuals, multimer staining results correlated with CMV serostatus in 127/157 and with EBV-serostatus in 61/110 samples analysed. Multimer staining and ELISpot results correlated for 41/62 samples and 16/51 samples after restimulation with CMV or EBV antigens, respectively. Immunodominance of pp65 versus IE-1 (A*02-epitopes) and of BZLF1 versus EBNA3A (B*08-epitopes) was analysed, pp65 epitope yielded higher numbers of CTL in 23/31 patients, BZLF1 in 8/13 patients. Our results show that multimer monitoring can be readily used to quantify antiviral CTL in stem cell donors and grafts. The frequency of CTL is not aff ected by the mobilization and apharesis procedure. Tables I and II summarize the response data. A comparison of reported practices with the expert recommendations is provided in both tables. Similar clinical practice patterns are reported among the majority of PBMT centers with regard to (1) the use of intravenous immune globulin (2) indications to initiate therapy for cytomegalovirus (CMV), adenovirus and BK virus;

(3) criteria used to test for/ change therapy when CMV resistance is suspected; (4) use of inhaled ribavarin for respiratory syncitial virus (RSV); (5) prophylactic antibiotic coverage; (6) use of voriconazole in the setting of aspergillosis; (7) hospital visitation and home environment precautions. Clinical practice patterns regarding surveillance for late onset CMV was the least consistent and varied from the recommendations of the joint guidelines. 57% of PBMT centers do not monitor voriconazole levels (the lack of recommendation in the joint guidelines and associated clinical practice is incongruent with emerging data). Conclusion: Similar clinical practice patterns regarding infectious diseases, are reported among the majority of PBMT centers which are accredited by FACT in the United States. However, there is reported variation among PBMT centers regarding surveillance for late onset CMV. There also appears to be an evidence-gap regarding the need for monitoring of voriconazole levels among PBMT patients. Introduction: Catheter-related infections (CRI) account for a considerable amount of treatment related morbidity and mortality during allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Central venous catheters (CVC) impregnated with antibiotics are considered to reduce CRI, but little is known about the impact in the setting of allogeneic HSCT. Even though this setting is characterized by an accumulation of risk factors for CRI, with long duration of catheterization, high frequency of manipulations (blood samplings, injections, etc.), frequent administration of parenteral nutrition and blood products and neutropenia. Materials and Methods: This retrospective cohort study evaluated 117 allogeneic HSCT recipients of whom the fi rst 58 were provided with CVC impregnated with silver zeolite (S-CVC) and the following 59 with CVC impregnated with minocycline/rifampin (AB-CVC). The analysis included all patients receiving the fi rst allo-geneic HSCT in our unit between 05/11 and 07/12 using a nontunneled triple lumen CVC implanted to the jugular vein. Results: The baseline characteristics concerning patient, donor and disease were comparable between the two groups except for the ECOG performance status found to be signifi cantly poorer in the AB-CVC group.

In the AB-CVC group we found a signifi cant reduction of catheter-related local infection (10.2 vs. 41 .4%, p<0.01), patients with bacteremia (6.8 vs. 34.5%, p<0.01) and catheter colonization (5.2 vs. 29.8%, p<0.01). Additionally the frequency of fever in neutropenia was signifi cantly reduced in the AB-CVC group, as we found a reduced percentage of days with fever in neutropenia per patient [11.5 vs. 18.3%, p=0.034; fever due to in vivo T-cell depletion (mainly ATG) was not considered and only days with inserted CVC were analyzed]. The frequency of days with fever during the whole period with inserted CVC was not signifi cantly diff erent between the groups (9.0 vs. 9.5%, p=0.385), but the onset of fever occurred later after CVC insertion in the AB-CVC group: after 15.2 vs. 12.8 days (p=0.055).
Conclusion: The application of minocycline/rifampin impregnated central venous catheters in allogeneic HSCT leads to a signifi cant reduction of infectious complications.

US allowed an early recognition of pts with CRIM progressing to NEC, showing abrupt BWT >4 mm, always accompanied by a sudden increase of AP. All pts with NEC were promptly treated conservatively but 1/32 who underwent a small bowel surgical resection and 87% survived. US monitor of intestinal BWT allowed to fi nd progression from CRIM to NEC. The improvement of symptoms during persistent neutropenia indicates that an early US-guided diagnosis of NEC is mandatory to initiate a prompt treatment to reduce mortality. US follow up in ASCT patients is a cheap, not-radiation-based, bedside technique useful to diff erentiate CRIM form a life threatening complication such as NEC. Weissinger Hannover Medical School (Hannover, DE) Adoptive transfer of CMV-specifi c cytotoxic T cells (CMV-CTL) may be a potent therapeutic tool to control CMV infection in immunocomprised patients. However, wide application is hampered by (1) the lack of CMV-CTL in seronegative donors, (2) low frequencies of CMV-CTL in CMV-seropositive donors may lead to insuffi cient numbers of CMV-CTL for direct adoptive transfer and (3) extensive in vitro expansion of CMV-CTL may lead to T cell exhaustion. We aim to optimize in vitro stimulation and expansion of CMV-CTL by generating self-diff erentiating DC (smartDC) expressing CMV-antigens using lentiviral vectors (LV) instead of conventional DC (moDC) diff erentiated and loaded with antigen ex vivo. Two tricistronic self-inactivating lentiviral vectors were constructed expressing the human GM-CSF and IL-4 genes as well as the CMV antigens pp65 or IE-1. Expression of transgenes was verifi ed by lentiviral transduction of 293T cells followed by ELISA and western blot assays. For generation of smartDCs, CD14+ cells were pre-stimulated with IL-4 and GM-CSF and transduced overnight. SmartDCs were phenotyped by FACS for CD14, CD209, CD83 and HLA-DR expression, ex vivo diff erentiated moDC from the same donor served as controls.

Bckground: An ineff ective immune response may contribute to HBV persistence. The hypothesis was that persistent HBV positive individuals would prone to other virus infection in allogeneic transplant setting. Based on HBV serological marks, the enrolled patients were classifi ed into 2 groups. A group was HBsAg positive,B group was anti-HBs positive. Design and Methods: A retrospective cohort study of patients between February 2010 and August 2011 was followed up at June 2012.We investigated the effect of HBV serological marks on early CMV DNAemia following haplo-identical allo-HSCT. Both of donors and recipients with CMV-IgG negative were excluded. All the patients were conditioned with a GIAC protocol.The occurrence of aGVHD,cGVHD and early CMV DNAemia were calculated by Kaplan-Meier curves, respectively. Cox regression analysis was performed to identify the risk factors for early CMV DNAemia.

Results: The total number of patients was 135 cases including 44 (A group) and 91 (B group). Median age was 30 years (range: 14-56). Both of 2 cohorts showed similar hematological recovery. Signifi cant higher occurrence of early CMV DNAemia(<100 days) were observed among A group compared to B group (77.3% and 28.2%, respectively; P=0.000). Culmulative incidences of acute GVHD in 2 groups were similar for grades I-IV (50.0% and 55.8%, respectively; P=0.261) and grades II-IV (27.3% and 30.3%, respectively; P=0.649). 2 cohorts showed similar cumulative incidences of chronic GVHD and 1-year overall survival (67.9% and 79.6%, respectively; P=0.529). We analyzed possible factors correlated with the occurrence of early CMV DNAemia, including recipient age (≤30 years, >30 years), recipient sex, HBV serological marks (A and B group), diagnosis, risk stratifi cation, MNC dose, CD34+ cell dose, CD3+ cell dose, early neutrophil engraftment, early platelet engraftment, absolute lymphocyte count on day 30(ALC30) and the occurrence of acute GVHD before CMV DNAemia. Multi variate analysis identifi ed HBsAg positive mark (P=0.006; OR=3.614; 95% CI=1.441-9.067) and the occurrence of acute GVHD before CMV DNAemia (P=0.000; OR=9.216; 95% CI=3.518-24.144) as high risk factors for early CMV DNAemia following haplo-identical allo-HSCT. Conclusions: Our data showed HBV persistent recipients was at high risk for active CMV infection following haplo-identical Allo-HSCT. The host immusurvilence seems altered by HBV persistence and leads to an increased risk for CMV infection after haplo-identical Allo-HSCT.

Micafungin was given from admission until azole initiation. All patients received voriconazole with a 90% Sirolimus and 67% Tacrolimus reduction at Voriconazole initiation. Results: Voriconazole was coadministered for a median of 114 days .

Invasive fungal infections (IFI) such as candidiasis and mold infections cause signifi cant morbidity and mortality among immunocompromised patients in recent years. Micafungin, a new echinocandin, inhibits fungal cell wall β-glucan synthesis, with potent activity against most species of Candida and Aspergillus. The aim of this observational study was to investigate the effi cacy and safety of Micafungin in prophylaxis of invasive fungal infections (IFI) in high risk adult patients with various haematological diseases receiving haplo-identical allogeneic stem cell transplantation (Allo-SCT). 26 patients were identifi ed. Only 2 patients had a history of possible aspergillosis before transplant treated by voriconazole. The patients received a median of 4 lines (2-7) of chemotherapies before Allo-SCT. Thirteen patients (50%) received at least one prior auto-SCT; and 8 patients (31%) received a previous Allo-SCT. 24 patients (92%) received a reduced intensity conditioning regimen (RIC), with Fludarabine, Cyclophosphamide and Total body irradiation (TBI) 2 Gy based (80%), or Fludarabine, Busulfan, and Cyclophosphamide based (8%) or other (4%). while two patients (8%) received a myeloablative conditioning regimen with thiotepa. The treatment was initiated at the beginning of the transplant conditioning regimen until the hospital discharge. Patients received a median of 29 infusions (range, 15-85) of Micafungin (50 mg/day i.v. as a 1h infusion). Results: None of our patients discontinued the treatment for drug-related adverse events. Results: HC occurred in median 14 days after allo-SCT (range -4 to 330). Median duration of symptoms was 34 days (range 6 to 166). At treatment onset 13 pts had grade 0-I HC, 13 grade II, 24 grade III and 9 grade IV. In 55 cases (93%) high BK viral load was detected in urine (BK virus median load 10 7 cp/ml) before treatment.

After treatment the reduction of BK viruria was documented in 29 out of 33 evaluable cases (87%). Improvement of HC grade was observed in 41 pts (70%) and a complete clinical response within 7 days from last CDV dose was observed in 30 cases (51%). Worsening of HC leading to urological intervention occured in 5 treated pts. Four pts died with an ongoing uncontrolled HC: 2 of acute Graft-versus Host Disease, 1 of pneumonia and 1 of relapse. CDV treatment 22 pts (54%) had a viral reactivation (Cytomegalovirus n=14, Epstein-Barr Virus n=8, Herpes Simplex-1 n=3, Herpes Simplex-6 n=4) and 2 pts developed acute renal failure requiring drug discontinuation. Conclusions: CDV treatment after allo-SCT is associated with a reduction of BK viruria load and HC clinical responses in more than half of cases. Viral reactivations under CDV treatment should be better investigated in the allo-setting, since the long-half life of the drug and its potential nephrotoxicity limits the possibility of concomitant antiviral therapy with other agents. Our data warrant prospective randomized trials to investigate the role of CDV in allo-SCT.

We have previously shown that human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) reactivation infl uences NK cell reconstitution in adults receiving intrabone umbilical cord blood transplantation (UCBT). With this rationale, we designed a study to compare NK cell reconstitution in pediatric patients undergoing haploidentical (after depletion of both α/β+ T cells and CD19+ B cells) hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (haplo-HSCT) for hematological malignancies who did or did not experience HCMV reactivation. These patients were also compared to a group of patients who were given either intrabone or iv UCBT. Twelve children given i.v. UCBT, 26 children given haplo-HSCT and 14 adults receiving intrabone UCBT were included in this study and analyzed up to 1 year after HSCT. Peripheral blood samples were collected at 1, 3, 6 and 12 months after transplantation. In agreement with the fi ndings observed in adults given intrabone UCBT, also in haplo-HSCT patients, NK cells achieved a fully diff erentiated stage of maturation more rapidly when a HCMV reactivation occurred. Indeed, a relevant fraction of NK cells expressed a mature phenotype characterized by the KIR+NKG2A-signature 3 months after transplantation in patients undergoing HCMV infection/reactivation (see fi g. 1). However, since in haplo-HSCT patients the graft contains donor-derived NK cells, we cannot exclude that a fraction of mature NK cells found in the recipients represents long-lived NK cells derived from the donor. At diff erence with UCBT patients, in haplo-HSCT recipients we did not observe a signifi cant expansion of the CD56-CD16+ NK cell subset, which represents an aberrant and usually hyporesponsive subset. Remarkably, in all cohorts of patients, we detected the emergence of highly diff erentiated NK cells characterized by the NKG2C+CD57+ phenotype, when HCMV infection occurred. This NK cell subset, that has already been described in both HSCT and solid organ-transplant recipients after HCMV reactivation, could harbour "memory" or "long-lived" NK cells.

body_text.text: Objective: The spectrum of infections that develop among patients who receive unmanipulated, G-CSF-primed bone marrow transplantation from a haploidentical family donor has not been described. Therefore, we evaluated incidence and type of infections occurring in this setting during the fi rst 100 days after transplantation. Methods: Data regarding infectious episodes and outcome during the fi rst 100 days after transplantation were retrospectively analyzed for 53 consecutive patients (30 in complete remission and 23 in refractory or recurrent active disease) undergoing haploidentical BMT. Results: The probability of overall survival for patients at 100 days post-haploBMT was 83%(s.d.+5). The 100-day cumulative incidence of grade II-IV acute GVHD was 30, 2% (s.d.+4). We observed 63 viral infections in 43 patients, 60 bacterial infections in 53 patients and 10 fungal infections in 8 patients. Furthermore, 40 out of 53 patients (75%) reactivated Cytomegalovirus infection, and 20 patients (38%) showed BK viruria. Encephalitis occurred in 2 patients due to JCV and BKV, respectively. A vesicular rash due to adenovirus was documented in 1 patient. Twenty-six (49%) patients had septicemia with or without septic shock, 30 (56%) patients had catheter-related infections, 17 (32%) patients had pneumonia (2 due to infection with a K. pneumoniaecarbapenemase producer and 1 with Chlamydia pneumoniae) and 1 patient had meningitis. One proven, 4 probable, and 3 possible fungal infections were documented in 8 (15%) patients. Overall, 9 of 53 (17%) patients died within 100 days after transplant. For 8 of these 9 patients (4/30 in the complete remission group, 4/23 in the active disease group) an infectious disease (1 hepatic abscess, 3 cases of septicaemia, 2 cases of encephalitis, 1 case of pneumonia, and 1 case of haemorrhagic cystitis) was the main cause of death. The infection-free survival at 100 days was 85%. Conclusion: Fifteen per cent of the patients studied died from infections during the fi rst 100 days post-transplant. No diff erences in the percentage of subjects died for infection were observed between standard and high risk group of patients.

body_text.text: Predictors for invasive fungal infection in paediatric allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation recipients J. A. Hol, T.F.W. Wolfs, M.B. Bierings, C.A. Lindemans, A.B.J. Versluys, A. De Wildt, C.E. Gerhardt, J.J. Boelens UMC Utrecht (Utrecht, NL) Background: Invasive fungal infection (IFI) remains an important cause of transplant-related mortality amongst hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) recipients. To improve outcome after HSCT, we need to identify patients who are most at risk. This study was aimed to fi nd predictors of IFI after pediatric allogeneic HSCT. Patients and methods: All children who received allogeneic HSCT in the Wilhelmina Children's Hospital Utrecht between January 2004 and July 2012 were included. HSCT data were prospectively collected. Probable and proven IFI were classifi ed according to EORTC/MSG criteria. We retrospectively classifi ed all patients into high or low risk groups for developing IFI using pre-and post-HSCT criteria, based on available literature. We analyzed predictors for the occurrence of IFI, our main endpoint, using Cox regression models. We used logistic regression models to analyze the association between other HSCT related complications and IFI. Other outcomes were overall survival (OS) and treatment related mortality (TRM). Results: 209 patients were included: 105 malignant and 104 nonmalignant. Donors were 98 cordblood, 54 family/sibling donor and 57 unrelated marrow. Median age was 6.6 years (range 0. 2-22.7) . The cumulative incidence of proven and probable IFI was 12% (n=25). Within patients classifi ed into the high risk group to develop IFI (n=88), 15 patients (17.0%) developed IFI. 52 patients became high risk during post-HSCT course, of which 9 patients (17.3%) developed IFI. In patients classifi ed as low risk (n=69), only 4 (5.8%) developed IFI (OR 0.325; p 0.047). In multivariate analysis, predictor for the occurrence of IFI was an a priori TRM risk >20% (based on EBMT-risk score). Logistic regressive results showed an association between the administration of high dose steroids and the occurrence of IFI (OR 4.458; p 0.010). Patients who developed IFI showed an increased risk of treatment related mortality (TRM) (OR 6.299; p 0.00), and subsequently the overall survival (OS) was lower (p=0.006). Conclusion: We demonstrated that risk group stratifi cation for developing IFI using criteria based on available literature, correlated well with the actual occurrence of IFI in children after HSCT. Pre-HSCT predictor was an a priori TRM risk >20%. Post-HSCT the use of high dose steroids was strongly associated with development of IFI. Risk group stratifi cation should guide intensity of monitoring for IFI and use of anti-fungal prophylaxis.

We have previously reported the use of posaconazole antifungal prophylaxis in a small series of 33 early phase alloHCT [BMT2011; 46(5):733-9]. Now, we present our experience on the effi cacy and clinical management of primary antifungal prophylaxis with posaconazole in 262 consecutive high-risk episodes (161 AMLchemotherapy, 79 alloHCT and 22 grade II-IV GVHD) from 123 hematology patients prospectively included in a single-center study (2007) (2008) (2009) (2010) (2011) ; CEIC Bellvitge; EPA 008/08). Our management algorithm included a comprehensive diagnostic approach for patients with persistent fever (CT scans, microbiological samples and cultures from urine, blood, BAL and other infected sites), as well as preemptive serum galactomannan (GM) tests twice weekly from the start of the risk episodes. Breakthrough IFD as per EORTC criteria occurred in 10 episodes (3.8%, Table 1 ): 5 invasive candidiasis (1.9%; 3 glabrata, 2 tropicalis) and 5 invasive aspergillosis (IA=1.9%; 1 proven, 4 probable), 8 after AML-chemotherapy and 2 in alloHCT/GVHD, leading to 4 IFD-related deaths (1.5%). Of note, 2 cases of IA occurred during an outbreak and co-infection with H1N1. Posaconazole was substituted for IV antifungal therapy in 34 additional episodes (13.0%) based on an individualized clinical judgment for persistent fever, intolerance or side-eff ects. The vast majority of episodes (218, 83.2%) completed posaconazole prophylaxis as planned. body_text.text: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a clonal disorder associated with chromosomal translocation t (9; 22). The fusion gene encodes for the chimeric oncoprotein BCR-ABL, associated with deregulated constitutive tyrosine kinase (TK) activity, leading to leukemogenesis. The second generation TK inhibitor (TKI) Nilotinib (Novartis, East Hanover, NJ) is an aminopyrimidine derivative of imatinib with an increased binding affi nity to the chimeric p210 BCR-ABL, recently approved for upfront use in CML. Allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) is currently reserved for patients (pts) in CP after the failure of second line TKI or for patients in advanced phase disease. SCT remains the treatment of choice in patients with Ph+ALL. TKIs can be used successfully pre -SCT as a bridge to SCT in advanced disease and post-SCT in order to prevent disease recurrence. HCMV is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality post SCT in particular in pts transplanted for advance CML and pts with graft vs. host disease (GVHD) While, preemptive antiviral therapy has reduced the occurrence of HCMV disease post SCT, the use of all currently available antiviral drugs is often limited by toxicity, low oral bioavailability, and drug resistance. The mechanisms facilitating HCMV entry into the host cells are not clearly understood. Blocking the platelet -derived growth factor receptor-α (PDGFRα) has been shown to inhibit HCMV internalization and gene expression. Recently, Imatinib has been shown to inhibit PDGFRα phosphorylation. As Nilotinib is a more potent PDGFR inhibitor, we assessed the in vitro antiviral activity of Nilotinib against HCMV. Nilotinib exhibited a signifi cant dosedependent inhibition of the virus upon pre-incubation with the drug. Moreover, Nilotinib demonstrated a ~4.5-fold higher antiviral activity against HCMV when compared to imatinib, with IC50 values of 0.39 μM and 1.75 μM, respectively. No viral inhibition was found upon addition of the drugs after viral adsorption -compatible with inhibition of an early step of infection, invoving viral binding/entry into the cell. These fi ndings identify a promising new target for antiviral therapy, representing an alternative paradigm for treatment with compounds combining anti-cancer and antiviral activity. The potent anti-HCMV activity demonstrated for Nilotimib may be of clinical relevance in patients with advanced CML undergoing SCT. Yang (1) An increasing number of nucleic acid based drugs achieved FDA approval and entered clinical trails (e.g. "antisense" or "immunostimulatory CpG" oligodeoxynucleotides (ODNs), aptamers, ribozymes, RNA interference or defi brotide). But so far, no or not much information is available whether these compounds might i) compete with chemically and structurally related drugs, e.g. nucleoside analogues (NA) widely used in cancer or antiviral therapy, or ii) interfere with the intracellular nucleic acid metabolism.

In the present report we provide evidence that defi brotide (DF), a polydisperse mixture of single-stranded oligodeoxyribonucleotides (15 to 30 kD), e.g. used for treatment of hepatic veno-occlusive disease and other endothelial disorders, antagonizes antivirals (e.g. acyclovir or ganciclovir) in vitro and in vivo. In standard drug resistance assays, using either an acyclovir sensitive herpes simplex virus (HSV) strain (V0631508) or the ganciclovir sensitive murine γherpesvirus 68 (MHV68), 4 μM of DF restored viral replication in the presence of 25-50 μM acyclovir and ganciclovir, respectively. This was confi rmed by quantitative PCR of viral DNA. In case of acyclovir, deoxythymidine turned out to be the main competitor for intracellular phosphorylation mediated by virus thymidine kinase. To further extent our fi ndings, MHV-68 infected mice were treated with ganciclovir (25mg/kg/day) in presence or absence of DF (10mg/kg/day). After 4 days of treatment, mice were sacrifi ced and the genomic load of MHV 68 was determined. Here, a signifi cant increase (p > 0,05) of viral replication in the presence of DF was observed. Taken together, these data strongly suggest that treatment with nucleic-acid-based drugs might interfere with concomitant antiviral therapy.

Background: Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) disease is a well-known complication in the transplant setting. Routine monitoring of EBV DNA-emia (referred to as viremia) by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and pre-emptive Rituximab therapy are recommended in high-risk patients. We conducted a study to analyse the results of EBV monitoring in a consecutive cohort of these high risk patients. Methods: We prospectively monitored all patients considered at high risk for EBV reactivation and Post-trasplant Lymphoproliferative Disease (PTLD) during the fi rst 6 months after SCT (alternative-donors, T-cell depletion (TCD) and/or severe refrac-tory acute graft versus host disease (aGVHD) by quantitative PCR between 2006 and 2012. Rituximab was given as pre-emptive therapy (375mg/m2 intravenously) for EBV viremia (>1000 copies/ml in whole blood). Results: After a median follow-up of 609 days, 27 of the 131 patients included (21%) developed EBV viremia, for a 1-year incidence of 28.5% (95% CI:18.7-38.3) at a median of day +72 and 12 (9%) developed PTLD for a 1-year incidence of 13% (95% CI:5.8-20.2) at a median of day +90. Factors associated with EBV reactivation and EBV-PTLD in univariate analysis were the same: absence of Rituximab administration before haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) (p=0.1 and p=0.01), prior HCT (p=0.02 and p=0.03) and TCD (Campath or ATG) in the 6 months before HCT (p=0.03 and p<0.01), respectively. In multivariate analysis, the factors associated with higher risk of EBV reactivation and PTLD were: prior HCT [HR 4.9 (95% CI:1.2-19.9; p=0.03) and HR 2.5 (95% CI:1.2-5.5; p=0.02)] and TCD during the 6 months pre-HCT [HR 3.4 (95%CI: 0.9-13) p=0.07) and (HR 6.4 (95%CI:2.3-18) p=0.01], respectively. The 2-year overall survival (OS) was 41% (95% CI: 32-50) and EBV reactivation was not associated with impaired survival (p=0.4). EBV-PTLD was considered the primary cause of death in 4 patients. Comments: The incidence of EBV reactivation and PTLD in our high risk population was 28.5% and 13% respectively. The risk factors associated with their appearance were previous HCT and use of T-cell depletion during the 6 months pre-HCT. Hrabankova-Navratilova (8) Introduction: HEPA fi ltration is designed to minimize airborne microbial contamination and is generally recommended for HSCT. Because probably not every transplant center is able to provide it and because more data about the incidence of pneumonia and mortality are warranted, we decided to conduct the following survey. Methods: Prospective observation. Specifi c monitoring cards distributed within Central and East European transplant centers in cooperation with the East Forum EBMT-Nurses Group. Results: In 1/2012-6/2012, total 689 consecutive patients were included into the observation. In the autologous HSCT group (n= 400) the pneumonia developed in 14/400 (3,5%) till day +100 post-transplant (median day +9 (-3 ±50)), and was the cause of death in 2/14 (14%) of aff ected patients. There were 239/400 (59%) HSCT performed in single-bed rooms (190/239 HEPA fi ltered) and 161 (41%) in two-beds room (28/161 HEPA fi ltered). There was no diff erence in general mortality till day +100: 4,5% in HEPA vs. 4,9% in non-HEPA fi ltered rooms (p=1,0). In the allogeneic HSCT group (n=289) the pneumonia developed in 24/289 (8,3%) till day +100 post-transplant (median day +11(-2 ±75)), and was the cause of death in 11/24 (45%) of aff ected patients. There were 281/289 (97%) of the Allogeneic HSCT performed in singlebed rooms (254/281 HEPA fi ltered) and 8 (3%) in two-beds room (without HEPA fi ltration). The only important and almost statistically signifi cant risk factor for pneumonia development (p=0,05) was corticosteroids treatment for GVHD. There was no diff erence in general mortality till day +100: 14% in HEPA vs. 17% in non-HEPA fi ltered rooms (p=0,6). Conclusion: incidence of pneumonia till day +100 in the autologous HSCT setting is generally very low and autologous HSCT may safely be performed in two-beds rooms and in rooms without HEPA fi ltration. Twice more pneumonia infections were observed in the allogeneic HSCT, especially in patients on corticosteroids, with high mortality rate and predominant fungal etiology. No signifi cant impact of HEPA fi ltered rooms on mortality rate was observed in both autologous and allogeneic HSCT. The limitation of our observation include various antimicrobial prophylaxis used, no data on air-fl ow direction and air-pressure positivity in the rooms, and low presence of non-HEPA rooms in allogeneic HSCT setting in general. Introduction: Invasive fungal infections cause signifi cant morbidity and mortality in HSCT recipients. Although fl uconazole has been widely used for antifungal prophylaxis in these patients, it is not eff ective against invasive aspergillosis. Micafungin provides antifungal activity against Candida and Aspergillus species, and previous studies have demonstrated its effi cacy when used as a prophylactic agent for fungal infection in neutropenic patients.

body_text.text: Here, we evaluated and compared the incidence rate of proven or probable invasive fungal infections (IFIs) with antifungal prophylaxis using micafungin or fl uconazole. Methods: This is a prospective, single center, phase II, ongoing study involving adult patients who receive allogeneic or autologous HSCT. Patients were randomly assigned to micafungin (50mg/day i.v) or fl uconazole arms (400mg/day p.o.) in the ratio of 2:1. The treatment was initiated within 24 hour of stem cell infusion, and lasted for up to 21 days of post-transplantation. Results: Between March 2010 and August 2012, a total of 74 patients were enrolled (micafungin, n=54; fl uconazole, n=20). The main underlying disease for allogeneic transplantation (n=64) were acute myeloid leukemia (39%), acute lymphoid leukemia (27%) and myelodysplastic syndrome (11%); and multiple myeloma was the most common reason (60.0%) for autologous transplantation (n=10). Baseline characteristics were compared, and there was no signifi cant diff erence in gender, transplantation type (allo vs auto), donor (sibling vs unrelated) and conditioning intensity (myeloablative vs reduced intensity) between two treatment arms. During study period, proven or probable IFIs were identifi ed in 7 of 54 for micafungin arm (13%), and 3 of 20 for fl uconazole arm (15%) (p=1.0). Overall mortality at 100 days after transplant was 14.9% (11/74), and patients who experienced proven or probable IFIs showed signifi cantly higher mortality (6/10, 60%) than patients who did not (5/64, 7.8%) (p<0.001). Among treatment arms, 100-day mortality following HSCT was higher in fl uconazole arm (4/20, 20%) compared to micafungin arm (7/54, 13%), although there was no statistical signifi cance (p=0.474). Conclusion: In this preliminary result, the incidence of proven or probable invasive fungal infections (IFIs) in HSCT recipients with micafungin prophylaxis was comparable to that of fl uconazole prophylaxis.

Objectives: Invasive aspergillosis (IA) is a frequently lifethreatening complication of allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Recent epidemiologic studies suggest an incidence of 5-10%. It is now recognised that in addition to cases occurring during the neutropenic post-transplant phase there is a late peak of cases who have chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and are receiving steroid or other immunosuppressive therapy. There has been an increasing focus on what host immune factors may account for individuals' susceptibility to IA. We investigated circulating monocytes from this cohort of patients compared with circulating monocytes from healthy controls in a pilot study to determine their ability to phagocytose A. fumigatus (Af ) conidia. Methods: After providing informed consent 7 adult patients with grade II-III chronic GVHD, requiring steroid or other immunosuppression, and 7 healthy volunteers respectively donated 30ml blood each from which monocytes were harvested using the method described by Serbina NV et al, J Immunology 2009, vol 183,pp 2678-87. Briefl y, monocytes were purifi ed and selected using MACS reagents and CD14 magnetic beads and next stained with anti-CD14 label. Af were diff erentially labelled with Alexa-Fluor 647 succinimidyl ester dye. Conidia and monocytes were co-incubated for 3 hours in a ratio of 2:1 following which the numbers of conidia ingested was determined using FACS analysis and confocal microscopy. Viability of the ingested conidia was determined by standard plating on agar medium and counting the number of colony forming units (CFU). Supernatants from each interaction were collected at times 0h and 3h, frozen, and later analysed for pro-infl ammatory cytokines using a 7-plex assay (Meso Scale Discovery).

body_text.text: Although infection rate remains low in our unit we have noted a dramatic change in the timing of occurrence of documented IA compared to our earlier observations (median of 66 days v 13 days resp.). Children with late onset IA (>50days post ) were more likely to have undergone unrelated donor HSCT and have associated graft dysfunction (i.e. failure or delayed engraftment). In contrast to earlier observations, survival is no longer limited to those children undergoing identical related bone marrow transplantation. Two patients received preemptive granulocyte transfusions (GT) to facilitate a successful transplant, a treatment not readily available in the previous era. Three patients developed proven azole resistant IA and as testing was not available in the previous study no comparisons can be made. DTM revealed the majority of children required dose adjustment to achieve therapeutic prophylactic doses of either itraconaozole of voriconazole. Again no comparison can be made with earlier observations. Conclusion: Proven IA remains an uncommon event in our unit and mortality is low (2%). Changes in clinical practice have seemingly aff ected the timing of presentation. Patients with leukemia and aplastic conditions receiving azole prophylaxis prior to referral, with dose optimization by DTM, may have reduced early HSCT infection. Our study shows that graft dysfunction is a risk factor together with GVHD for the occurrence of IA. We recommend close microbiological monitoring and prophylaxis with rigorous DTM control in this specifi c post transplant group. Azole resistance and its impact on survival remain unclear and is presently being closely monitored on a national basis.

body_text.text: Considering that brain infections in oncohaematologic patients undergoing chemotherapy or a transplant of haemopoietic stem cells (HSC), and therefore seriously immunosuppressed, are those with the worst prognosis, it is very important to make the interpretation of the diagnostic imaging techniques currently in use easier and more homogeneous, thus making it possible to apply targeted treatments in the shortest time possible. The Brain Supporters Project aims at creating an international data base capable of gathering an extensive collection of radiologic images of brain lesions together with the relevant clinical, laboratory and microbiological data. Starting from this data base the possibility is envisaged to develop an "intelligent" software that through the use of multi-dimensional analysis techniques, variational methods and classifi cation procedures taking advantage also of neural networks and Bayesian forecasting models, can detect, highlight and diff erentiate the minimal and yet peculiar diff erences in the "radiologic footprint" connected with the local alterations of brain tissue produced by each individual pathogen, thus becoming an objective diagnostic aid not infl uenced by the individual interpretation given by the operator. An internet site will be created, www.brainsupporters.eu, freely accessible to oncohaematologic centres world-wide. The radiologic images with confi rmed diagnosis collected in the data base will then be subject to a blind evaluation (without knowing the microbiologic diagnosis) by a team of specialists belonging to at least two of the Centres taking part in the project, so as to obtain an independent confi rmation of the diagnosis. The images will then be classifi ed by aetiologic agent and subsequently by age group and by clinical characteristics of the patients. It will thus be possible to evaluate if and how the "radiologic footprint" of lesions due to the same pathogen is modifi ed depending on the diff erent characteristics of the host. All the images collected, suitably classifi ed by pathogen and subdivided in accordance with the diff erent host characteristics, will become part of a gallery, accessible on line, having advanced research and image comparison functions. Vianelli University of Bologna (Bologna, IT) Background: Serum galactomannan (GM) antigen is routinely used to aid the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis, but the sensitivity of the test is reduced in recipients of allogeneic HSCT (allo-HSCT) and with antifungal prophylaxis. Methods: We examined the sensitivity and specifi city of a pulmonary vascular occlusion sign visualized by CTPA in allo-HSCT patients with a diagnosis of possible, probable or proven invasive mold disease (IMD) according to EORTC/MSG defi nitions. Patients who received allo-HSCT (n=20) for AML/MDS (n=8), ALL (n=7), lymphoma (n=1), or chronic myelodysplastic syndromes (n=4) underwent CTPA if they had a lesion on initial CT scans suggestive of IMD. IMD diagnosis was subsequently confi rmed on the basis of culture, histopathology and/or antigen results. Results: CTPA was positive in 16/20 of patients, 13 of whom eventually met EORTC/MSG defi nitions for proven or probable IMD (12 Aspergillus, 1 Mucormycosis + Aspergillus). The remaining 3/20 of CTPA positive patients had possible IMD. Among the 4 CTPA negative patients, 3 had bacterial pneumonia, and 1 patient had probable IMD based on GM antigen and CT. In CTPA positive patients, GM antigen was positive in serum of 12/16, and in the bronchial alveolar lavage (BAL) fl uid of 4/4 patients. Considering only proven or probable IMD, a positive CTPA fi nding had a sensitivity (92%), specifi city (50%), positive predictive value (81%) and negative predictive value (75%) for IMD. Conclusions: CTPA may be an alternative to serum or BAL GM antigen testing for establishing the diagnosis of probable or proven IMD in allo-HSCT patients. The control of persistent pathogens such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), adenovirus (ADV) and Epstein-Barr-virus (EBV), will ultimately depend on the restoration of adequate T-cell immunity.

The virus-specifi c T-cell responses in peripheral blood have been shown to be a good marker of immunological protection, but have not been used for clinical decision making and the guidance of drug plasma levels. Therefore, we performed a prospective clinical trial in and tested 95 samples from adult and pediatric patients after SCT receiving pharmacologic immunosuppression with steroids, Cyclosporin A, Tacrolimus or Mycophenolate. T-cell responses were compared to patients without immunosuppression. T-cell responses were analyzed ex vivo against pp65 (CMV), hexon (ADV) and EBNA, LMP (EBV) using intracellular cytokine staining and CFSE. The T-cell responses in vitro under low, high and supraphysiologic plasma concentrations of the respective drugs were investigated. Under the direct infl uence of steroids, activated, virus-specifi c T-cells underwent apoptosis. Cyclosporin had the strongest inhibition on virus-specifi c T-cell immunity, whereas low therapeutic levels allowed T-cell responses to develop. Relevant diff erences in the frequencies of virus-specifi c T cells could be detected in correlation to the level of immunosuppression. The use of multiple immunosuppressive drugs leads to a reduction in the number of patients with detectable antiviral T-cell responses whereas the strength of T-cell responses (if present) was neither infl uenced by the type nor by the number of immunosuppressive drugs. Therefore detection of virus-specifi c T-cell responses but not the amount of IFN-γ production could be used to guide the level of immunosuppression in case of viral complications after SCT. In conclusion we could show that detection of virus-specifi c T-cells could be used to guide the level of immunosuppression in case of viral complications after allogeneic SCT, since emergence of in vivo T-cell responses was closely associated with a clearance or reduction of the viral load. Schmitz Asklepios Klinik St. Georg (Hamburg, DE) Patients with severe acute or chronic GVHD undergoing intense immunosuppressive therapy have a high risk of severe opportunistic infections frequently determining outcome. Invasive fungal infections (IFI), especially invasive aspergillosis, are frequent and often fatal in such patients. In recent years substantial progress has been made in prophylaxis and treatment of IFI. Posaconazole given prophylactically in patients with severe GVHD has been shown to decrease the incidence of IFI and death attributed to fungal disease in a prospective randomized study. We retrospectovely analyzed whether posaconazol prophylaxis was eff ective in reducing fungal infections in a large allogeneic program. From January 2008 to July 2011 we treated 80 episodes of either acute GVHD grade II-IV or chronic GVHD in 53 patients who received prednisolone at doses of more than 0.5 mg/kg BW. The median age was 52.5 years (19.8 -73.7 years), the median duration of corticosteroid application was 44.5 days (3 -308 days), the median duration of inpatient treatment was 19.2 days (4 -98 days) Our institutional standard operating procedures recommend the use of prophylactic posaconazole (200 mg tid) which was given in 52 of 80 cases. In 28 cases we decided against posaconazole because a less intensive immuno-supression was anticipated at start of prednisolon treatment. In fact this group showed showed a shorter duration of treatment(median 36 vs 46 days) and a lower number of patients with of prolonged usage ( > 44 days) of prednisolone (39 vs 56%) as compared to the other patients . In 16 of 52 cases (30.8%) with posaconazole prophylaxis an interventional treatment with either caspofungin ( 7 cases) or voriconazole (9 cases) was started. FUO / sepsis were the main reasons to start treatment in 8 cases, pneumonia was the leading condition in other 8 cases. Two patients received second-line treatment ( 1 case caspofungin after voriconazole, 1 case voriconazole after caspofungin). In 5 out of 52 cases (9.6%) the EORTC criteria of a possible IFI were fulfi lled. There were no cases of a probable or proven IFI. There was no death attributable to IFI. In patients with severe GVHD and intensive immunosuppression, prophylaxis of IFI by posaconazole results in a very low specifi c morbidity and mortality.
