body_text.text: Characterization of mixed and full donor chimeras post reduced-intensity fl udarabine, melphalan, alemtuzamab conditioned peripheral blood haematopoietic stem cell transplantation F.A.M Kinsella (1) , J.E Croudace (1), C.F Inman (1), S. Nagra (2) , J. Nunnick (2) , E. Nikolousis (3), R. Malladi (2) , M. Griffi ths (4), C. Craddock (2) Mixed chimerism (MC), the presence of residual recipient and donor derived haematopoietic cells, can be observed in patients following reduced intensity conditioned allogeneic stem cell transplantation (RIC-SCT) for haematological malignancy. Whilst some studies reported MC to be a risk factor for disease relapse, others have observed that persistent stable MC does not correlate with relapse, suggesting that durable graft versus tumour eff ects (GvT) can exist without achieving full donor chimerism (FC). In addition, many studies associate MC with robust immune tolerance, suffi cient to sustain solid organ transplantation without the need for supplementary immunosuppression. Such tolerance is thought to involve central and peripheral processes, but the mechanisms regulating immune tolerance and alloreactivity in MC remain unclear. We identifi ed patients with stable mixed and full donor chimerism following RIC-SCT and studied the phenotype and function of peripheral blood T cells. The only signifi cant clinical diff erence between the two cohorts was an increased incidence of aGvHD in the FC population, which has been observed in other studies. Flow cytometric analysis showed that T cell number in MC patients was twice that of FC patients, whilst the number of naïve cells increased 4 times. The highest T cell number was seen in patients in whom MC was selectively observed in the T cell compartment. This supports a theory that continued interactions between donor DC and both donor and host T cells are of importance maintaining MC. To assess the function of FC and MC T cells, they were cultured in vitro with PHA or recipient (host) APC derived pre-transplant. Diff erences between FC and MC responses to host APC in vitro were only observed early post transplant where a signifi cantly lower proportion of MC CD4+25-T cells were present post culture. In this scenario, MC CD4+25-T cell cytokine production was suppressed, consistent with the induction of an adaptive tolerance. However, CD4+25-T cells derived from MC late post transplant were present at higher proportions than the same cohort derived early post transplant, and produced more IL-10 in particular. In corollary, CD4+25+ T cells derived from MC late post transplant produced less IFNg and IL-10. Overall, these fi ndings are consistent with a proposed theory that tolerance to host is not reliant upon dominant peripheral mechanisms (which would require antigen educated regulatory T cells), but is ensured by adaptive and later central tolerogenic mechanisms.

Tryptophan catabolism attenuates alloreactivity of donor T cells by inhibiting dendritic cell activation W. Lee (1) Objectives: Indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO) is an intracellular enzyme that catalyzes the fi rst and rate-limiting step in tryptophan catabolism. Generation of tryptophan metabolites by IDO is an eff ective mechanism in IDO-mediated T cell suppression. Our previous study reported that exogenous administration of 3-hydroxyanthranilic acid , the most potent metabolite, into the allogeneic bone marrow transplanted mice reduced acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) lethality by inhibition of alloreactive T cell expansion . In addition to aff ecting donor T cells, we investigated whether 3-HAA indirectly suppresses alloreactivity of donor T cells through inhibiting dendritic cell (DCs) activation. Methods: We generated bone marrow-derived DCs and treated them with various concentration of 3-HAA for 6 hrs before LPS stimulation. Phenotype of the cell for maturation was analyzed by fl ow cytometry. Cytokine levels were measured in the cell culture supernatants using Flex-Set analysis. Allo-stimulatory capacity of BMDCs was measured on allogenenic mixture-lymphocyte reaction (MLR).

Concomitantly, CH50 (Mayer technique), C3d deposition on red blood cells, C3 and C4 circulating levels were also studied. Complete C5 blockage was defi ned by a CH50 activity ≤10% (as for pts with hereditary complete C5 defi ciency). Before starting eculizumab, 21 pts were transfusion-dependent with a mean of 7 red blood cell (RBC) transfusions per year and 9 pts had a signifi cant PNHrelated complication (9 thrombosis and 7 with a previous history of aplastic anemia). During the study period, 6 pts received at least one transfusion (mean of 3 RBC transfusions per year) and 1 patient presented a deep vein thrombosis. CH50 measurements (412 samples; median 19 per patient; range, 4 to 31) showed substantial variability for most pts ( Figure 1A ). Residual CH50 activity (>10%) was signifi cantly associated with higher LDH levels (p=0.002) and reticulocyte counts in the 14 patients with pure hemolytic PNH (p=0.038). C3 and C4 circulating levels were in the normal range during the study period in all but one patient (pts#15, Fig. 1B) , who carry a complement factor H (CFH) mutation, leading to a quantitative Factor H defi ciency. Systematic screening was positive for 2 other pts (CFH, pts#1; C3 mutation, pts#14). Type III PNH red blood cell C3d deposition (assessed in all but 1 patient; 277 samples; median 14 per patient; range, 2 to 21) was found in all pts evaluated during the study period (Fig. 1C) , with no correlation with clinical or biological signs of hemolysis. Our results confi rm the excellent overall response of hemolytic PNH pts to eculizumab. Unblocked CH50 activity, refl ecting the residual C5 activity, was signifi cantly associated with residual intravascular hemolysis and may be of particular interest in the management of PNH patients under Ecuizumab. We also identifi ed mutations in C3 and factor H genes suggesting new unknown pathophysiological insights in this disease.

Blood, 2011) . Although the detection of 6pUPD by the SNP array may be useful for predicting a response to immunosuppressive therapy (IST) in AA patients, the assay cannot be performed promptly enough to use the results to choose the optimal therapy for newly diagnosed patients and may not be suffi ciently sensitive to detect small populations of 6pUPD(+) cells. The effi cacy of detecting leukocytes lacking HLA-A alleles using fl ow cytometry as a SNP array substitute was examined to overcome these problems. Patients and methods: HLA-A alleles of 114 (28 newly diagnosed and 86 pretreated) patients with AA were determined and the HLA-A allelic expression by leukocytes of the patients that were found to be heterozygous for the HLA-A allele were assessed using fl ow cytometry with monoclonal antibodies specifi c to A24, A2, A26, and A31. Results: 68 (59.6%) patients were assessable for the presence of HLA-A allele-lacking leukocytes due to their heterozygosity in two of the four alleles. Leukocytes lacking one of the two HLA-A alleles were detected in 6 (46.5%) newly-diagnosed and 19 (34.5%) pretreated patients with 3.9%-61.1% (median 8.4%) and 10.3%-99.4% (median 54.2%) of total granulocytes, respectively. The percentages of HLA-A allele-lacking monocytes derived from cryopreserved mononuclear cells were similar to those of HLA-A allele lacking granulocytes in each patient. Of the 23 patients with HLA-A allele lacking leukocytes, 9 and 14 were treated with antithymocyte globulin plus cyclosporine or cyclosporine alone. The response rates to each therapy were 88.9% and 78.6%, respectively. Conclusion: Flow cytometry using commercially available monoclonal antibodies specifi c to HLA-A alleles enabled the detection of as few as 3% of leukocytes lacking HLA-A alleles in 21.9% of patients with newly diagnosed AA. Rapid typing of HLA-A alleles followed by screening of granulocytes or cryopreserved monocytes for the presence of HLA-A allele-lacking cells may be useful for predicting a response to IST in patients with AA heterozygous for the HLA-A allele.

Haematopoietic stem cell transplantation for secondary myeloid malignancy after immunosuppressive therapy in patients with aplastic anaemia A. Yoshimi (1), B. Strahm (1) , M. Führer (2) , C. Niemeyer (1) (1)University of Freiburg (Freiburg, DE) ; (2)Dr. von Haunersches Kinderspital, University of Munich (Munich, DE) Introduction: Previous reports show that 2-16% of patients with aplastic anemia (AA) following immunosuppressive therapy (IST) develop secondary myelodysplastic syndrome /acute myeloid leukemia (2nd MDS/AML). However, there is limited data on the outcome of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in these patients. We report here the outcome of HSCT in 19 German patients with 2nd MDS/AML following AA, who were registered to the SAA-94 and/or EWOG-MDS 96/06 studies. Patients and methods: The diagnosis of 2nd MDS/AML was made in 21 patients (03/1995-11/2009 ) at a median of 2.9 years (0.5-13.0 years) after the diagnosis of AA. Excluding 2 patients given intensive chemotherapy only, the remaining 19 transplanted patients were included in this analysis. The median age at diagnosis of 2nd MDS/AML (9 refractory cytopenia(RC), 5 RAEB, 2 RAEBt and 3 AML) was 13.1 (3.3-26.2) years. Eight patients had a normal karyotype, 10 patients -7 and 1 patient +19. HSCT was performed at a median of 5.3 (0.4-26) months after diagnosis of 2nd MDS/AML. Donor was a matched sibling donor in 2 patients, a mismatched family member in 2 patients and an unrelated donor in 15 patients. Stem cell source was BM in 7 patients and peripheral blood in 12 patients. The preparative regimen consisted of busulfan, cyclophosphamide and melphalan (BU/CY/MEL) in 13 patients and other combinations in 6 patients. Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis was cyclosporin A and methotrexate in most patients. Results: All patients engrafted (med. 15 days). Grade II-IV and III-IV acute GVHD was observed in 9 and 7 patients, respectively. Eight of 13 evaluable patients developed chronic GVHD (3 limited, 5 extensive) . Overall survival at 6 years after HSCT was 50.1 % with no diff erence according to karyotype (-7 vs. others; 47% vs. 53 %), morphological subtype (RC vs. others; 44% vs. 54 %) or conditioning regimen (BU/CY/MEL vs. others 46% vs. 63%). Cause of death was relapse of MDS in one patient and transplant related mortality (TRM) in 9 patients. Conclusion: The outcome of HSCT in patients with 2nd MDS/AML following AA was unfavorable. The major problem was a high rate of TRM. Based on the high TRM and the occurrence of 2nd MDS/ AML it can be speculated that some of these patients have an underlying congenital bone marrow failure. The outcome may be possibly improved by earlier indication of HSCT and by a reduced toxicity regimen.

Favourable outcome of patients with 13q deletion and severe aplastic anaemia A. Holbro (1) Objective: The prognostic signifi cance of cytogenetic abnormalities in aplastic anemia (AA) are controversial. Del(13q) has been reported to occur in patients with MDS and other hematologic malignancies. Additionally, cases of patients with bone marrow failure syndrome with del(13q), who showed good response to immunosuppressive therapy have been reported. Methods: We retrospectively analyzed outcome of patients diagnosed as AA with del(13q) at our institution. Results: For 86/353 (24%) patients cytogenetic analysis at any time during the disease course was available. We identifi ed six patients (7%) with del(13q). Table 1 shows patients characteristics. Median age at diagnosis was 50.5 years (range: 22-71 years), half were male. One patient was diagnosed with very severe AA, three patients with severe AA and two with AA. Del(13q) was detected at diagnosis in four patients. One patient (UPN 936) had a normal karyotype at diagnosis and developed del(13q) after a fi rst course of antithymocyte globuline (ATG), and cyclosporine A (CYA). Two years later this patient relapsed and received a second course of ATG and CYA with disappearance of the del(13q) clone. She reached a partial response (PR) and remains under immunosuppression with CYA, free of transfusions 86 months after last ATG. One patient diagnosed in 1987 with SAA (UPN 410) was treated with ATG in 1990, cytogenetics at diagnosis were not available. She reached a complete response with persisting macrocytic anemia. Del(13q) was documented 10 years after ATG. She remained hematologically stable for 276 months until her death in a car accident. In two patients, del(13q) was no longer detectable at last follow-up. All patients except one are still alive after a median follow-up of 105 months (range: 84-276 months). None of the patients showed progression to acute myeloid leukemia or MDS. Conclusion: Patients with bone marrow failure without dysplasia and isolated del(13q) should be classifi ed as AA and treated accordingly as they represent a subgroup of patients with favorable outcome.

body_text.text: Aim of the study was to evaluate the role of mixed chimerism in outcome of children with the aplastic anemia after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (alloHSCT). One hundred patients, diagnosed as having aplastic anemia and underwent alloHSCT were identifi ed in 5 Polish Pediatric HSCT centers, between 2005 and 2011. There were 74 children with severe aplastic anemia, 17 with Fanconi anemia and 9 with Blackfan-Diamond anemia. Median age of the patients at diagnosis was 9, 5 years and median age at HSCT was 11 years. Donors were siblings in 32 cases whereas 65 children were transplanted from match unrelated donor and 3 from mismatched donors. Source of stem cells were bone marrow stem cells in 49 patients, peripheral blood stem cells in 47, cord blood in 2 and in 2 children combined stem cell sources were used. The most common conditioning regiments were : fl udarabin, cyclophosphamide and ATG (29 pts) and cyclophosphamide and ATG (23 pts). GvHD prophylaxis consisted of CsA and MTX in majority of patients (80%). Median time from diagnosis to HSCT was 10 months. To the fi nal analysis we included 74 patients who survived at least 3 months after HSCT and having at least 3 assessment of chimerism within fi rst 2 years post transplantation. Qualitative chimerism was evaluated in all centers in peripheral blood, using variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) PCR method. We considered as full donor chimerism patients with less than 1% of recipient cells (DC) and as mixed chimera (MC) those having more than 1% of recipient cells in two consecutive evaluation. Median follow-up was 3 years. Overall survival of whole group was 0,8. Twenty eight of seventy four evaluable patient were found to be MC, forty fi ve DC and one autologous recovery was noted. Survival of patients with MC was signifi cantly better than those with DC -0,96 vs 0,79 respectively (p=0,04). No statistically significant diff erence in survival was found between children with DC and MC in respect to diagnosis, donor type or stem cell source. Only one patient with MC died from infection whereas 9 patients with DC died of complication: 5 GvHD, 2 toxicities, 1 infection and 1 PTLD. None patient with MC lost their graft and experienced aplasia relapse. We concluded that in our material mixed chimerism in children with the aplastic anemia may improve survival probably due to less severe transplant related complications. However follow up of the study population is short and data requires further confirmation.

body_text.text: In aplastic anaemia, immunosuppression with purine analogues leads to good engraftment rates of grafts immunodepleted with alemtuzumab N. Novitzky, V. Thomas, C. du Toit University of Cape Town (Cape Town, ZA) Introduction: Immunodepletion with alemtuzumab is an eff ective method to prevent graft vs. host disease but may be associated with graft failure. We tested the eff ectiveness of a purine analogue based reduced intensity conditioning combination in patients with marrow aplasia. Patients and Methods: Patients with severe marrow aplasia who had tissue compatible siblings were conditioned with fl udarabine 30 mg/m2 for 5 days and cyclophosphamide 120 mg/kg. Stem cells from HLA identical sibling donors were mobilized with fi lgrastim and the harvested blood concentrates incubated ex vivo with alemtuzumab. Following graft infusion patients received therapeutic levels of cyclosporine until day 90. Chimerism studies were performed by standard cytogenetic, FISH and STRs at 3 months after transplantation and thereafter when graft failure was suspected. Primary objective was to study the proportion of patients achieving engraftment and overall survival. Secondary

S418 objectives were rate of graft vs. host disease, post-transplant infections and graft failure. Results: Thirty three patients received 36 cytokine mobilized blood stem cell transplants and were studied. Median CD34+ cell infused was 5.38 x106/kg. All patients engrafted at a median of 12 days. Four patients had delayed graft failure at 3, 6, 7 and 7 months and required re transplantation (n=3) or donor lymphocyte infusion (n=2) to re-establish full donor chimerism or for the treatment of pure red cell aplasia unresponsive to immunosuppression. One patient had graft failure at 7 months and died of neutropenic sepsis before referral to our unit. At 3 months chimerism studies showed >90% donor cells in each case. At median of 2302 days thirty two (97%) patients survive transfusion free with normal blood parameters. Conclusions: We confi rm that the combination of purine analogue and cyclophosphamide is adequate for engraftment of a graft that was immunodepleted with alemtuzumab. This strategy is associated with excellent outcomes. However patients should continue being closely followed up for the fi rst year as delayed graft failure remains a problem.

Fludarabine, cyclophosphamide and ATG, with or without low doses of total body irradiation for unrelated donor transplants in children with severe aplastic anaemia. Long-term follow up from a single centre experience F. Vendemini, P. Gasperini, R. Masetti, D. Zama, C. Di Leo, M. Franzoni, A. Prete, A. Pession Sant'Orsola-Malpighi Hospital, University of Bologna (Bologna, IT) Objectives: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation from unrelated donor (UD-HSCT) has become a frequent therapeutic alternative in children diagnosed with severe aplastic anemia (SAA), due to the low rate response to immunosuppressive therapy (IST) along with the frequent absence of a matched sibling donor (MSD). In UD-HSCT setting, treatment-related mortality, graft versus host disease (GVHD) and graft rejection have been major cause of treatment failure. We report the long-term outcome of 10 children with SAA undergone to UD-HSCT after reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimen based on Fludarabine (FLU), Cyclophosphamide (CY) and ATG. Methods: Between 1997 and 2010, 10 pts (4 M), median age 10 (range 5-18) ys, underwent HSCT from UD for SAA after failure to repsond to IST. RIC regimen consisted of FLU 30 mg/sqm/day X 4, CY 300 mg/mq/day X 4, ATG 3.75 mg/kg X 3 in 9/10 cases. Low dose Total Body Irradiation (200 cGy) was added in 2 pts>14 ys. GVHD prophylaxis consisted of Cyclosporine (5 mg/kg/die iv on day -1, 3 mg/kg/die iv from day 0, 6-10 mg/kg/die orally for at least 6 months) and short term Methotrexate. Monitoring of chimerism (complete, CC or mixed, MC), was performed on BM samples by using short tandem repeat (STR)-PCR analysis starting from the day of neutrophils (PMN) engraftment and then every 3 months. Results: The median interval from diagnosis to HSCT was 24 months (range 7-46). HSCs source was bone marrow (BM) in 8 pts and peripheral blood in 2. 6/10 donors were full matched, 4/10 were mis-matched in 1 or more loci. The median number of infused BM nucleated cells was 5.7x10 8 /kg and 7x10 6 /kg CD34+ PBSC. PMN and platelets engrafment was reached in all pts after a median time of 14 and 23 days, respectively. One pt experienced secondary graft failure with autologous reconstruction. aGVHD occurred in 2 pts (20%, 1 grade II and 1 grade IV); 4 pts (40%) developed limited chronic GVHD. After a mean follow up of 7.9 ys (range 2-15.9), 9/10 pts are alive and disease free: amongst them 8/9 showed CC. The patient with secondary graft failure is alive and transfusion independent: BM samples show MC with autologous prevalence. One patient died because of grade IV aGVHD. Conclusion: UD-HSCT is an eff ective and low toxic treatment for children with SAA: the long term outcomes following UD-HSCT are similar to those obtained in MSD setting. Careful selection of HLA matched UD, RIC regimen and chimerism monitoring by STR analysis have improved the outcome of UD-HSCT.

Doisaki, H. Muramatsu, K. Nakanishi, A. Hama, S. Kojima Nagoya University Graduate School of Medicine (Nagoya, JP) Background: For children who urgently need stem cell transplantation (SCT), a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) haploidentical family donor could be considered as one of alternative donor sources because it's 1) easy to fi nd the donor in parents, 2) fast to engraft and 3) possible to use donor cell derived cell therapies such as virus specifi c cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs). We analyzed children with aplastic anemia (AA) who underwent HLA haploidentical SCT for an urgent need of SCT. Materials and Methods: Four children with AA underwent unmanipulated HLA haploidentical SCT in urgent need of SCT in our center. Bone marrow taransplantation (BMT) was conducted on day0 and G-CSF mobilized peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) were infused on day6 to boost numbers of stem cells. GVHD prophylaxis consisted of tacrolimus and short term MTX while antithymocyte globulin (ATG) were given at 10mg/kg prior to BMT and at 5mg/kg one day before PBSCT. Patients received a conditioning treatment consisting of fl udarabine 30 mg/m2 i.v. x 4 days, melphalan 70 mg/m2 i.v. x 2 day and total body irradiation 5Gy in two fractions. Results: The reasons of urgent SCT were very severe aplastic anemia with a neutrophil count of zero cells/mm3 with infections in two patients and graft failure after fi rst SCT in other two patients. The ages of the patients were 5, 10, 15 and 15 years old. Donors were two fathers, one mother and one brother. HLA disparity between patients and donors were all 2/6 HLA (HLA-A, B and DRB1) mismatched at antigen level. All patients engrafted and the duration of neutropenia (ANC <500) was 15, 21, 25 and 29 days respectively. Two patients developed acute GVHD grade II and III. One received infl iximab for steroid refractory GVHD. One patient developed extensive chronic GVHD. CMV reactivations were observed in all four patients and ganciclovir and/or foscavir were given. EBV reactivations were observed in one patients and the patient were treated by rituximab. The follow-up time was 6, 41, 76 and 103 months. All patients are alive. Discussion: Unmanipulated haploidentical SCT was useful option for children with aplastic anemia who don't have HLA matched related donor and need urgent SCT.

For these advanced patients, however, the relapse rate is still high after ALLO. The aim of this study was to describe the outcome of HL patients relapsing after ALLO in a single institution. Patients and methods: Since 1999, 55 HL patients were treated by ALLO in our institution. All patients received NMA/RIC regimens. Inclusion criteria were relapse after HDC, refractoriness to salvage chemotherapy in a program with HDC followed by ALLO. Diff erent NMA/RIC has been used (table 1). The response rate was high after each CT lines because was 44% after fi rst line, 30% after the second, and 40% after the third. DLI ± radiotherapy seemed to be the more eff ective therapy, probably linked to the fact that patients treated by RT had a less extensive relapse. The 1y OS, PFS, and relapse incidence were 65%, 27%, and 73%, respectively. The median PFS was 5 months and the median OS was 13 months. Conclusions: This retrospective analysis showed that survival for patients relapsing or progressing after ALLO is quite high, as patients continued to respond to therapy. The histology included diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in four patients and plasmablastic lymphoma in one patient. The tumour was EBV-positive in three patients and two patients had EB-viremia at the time of diagnosis. All patients received a combination chemotherapy and rituximab. One patient was included into high-dose therapy protocol at the time of the fi rst relapse and four other patients due to initial poor prognostic features/poor response to therapy; one of these patients showed a clear progression prior to high-dose therapy. Blood stem cells were mobilized with chemotherapy plus G-CSF. Three out of fi ve patients needed plerixafor to augment mobilization. With median of two aphereses a median of 2.7 CD34+ cells/kg (1.8-4.1) were collected. Four patients received BEAM followed by stem cell graft infusion plus pegfi lgrastim. One patient died due to septic shock and multiorgan failure on d +13, another patient shortly after stem cell collection due to rapidly progressive disease. Three patients are alive and well 1, 2 and 26 months from ASCT. Conclusions: Lymphomas appearing late after solid organ transplantation appear to behave aggressively and are diffi cult to treat. Perhaps based on chronic immunosuppression these patients have more problems with standard-dose chemotherapy and may perhaps also have more problems with high-dose therapy. Many of these patients appear to be poor stem cell mobilizers. More experience is clearly needed to optimize treatment of these patients. (1) It is now clearly established that cure or control of the underlying malignancy is not necessarily accompanied by full restoration of quality of life (QoL) in long-term survivors. Thus, information about QoL in long-term lymphoma survivors is worthwhile. We aimed to examine QoL in lymphoma patients in complete remission after AHSCT at long-term follow-up and provide comparison with population norms. A total of 34 lymphoma patients (Stage IIA-IVB) with the follow-up period more than 12 months were enrolled in the study: non-Hodgkin's lymphoma -18; Hodgkin's lymphoma -16. Mean age -37 years old, SD-11.2; male/female -17/17. All the patients were in complete remission after AHSCT. Median follow-up was 19.5 months (range 15-54 months). QoL was assessed using generic questionnaire SF-36. To compare patient population with normative data the sample from population norm (PN) data base adjusted to age and gender (n=72) was used. Distribution of patients according to the grades of QoL impairment was analyzed: no QoL impairment (Integral QoL index similar to the one in normative population sample), mild (25% decrease from a PN), moderate (25-50% decrease), severe (50-75% decrease) and critical (>75% decrease). For comparisons t-test for independent samples or Mann-Whitney test was used. QoL parameters in lymphoma patients in complete remission were similar to the ones in population norms for the majority of scales: role-physical functioning -72.1 vs 78.5, bodily pain -87.8 vs 79.7, general health -65.1 vs 65.4, vitality -66.6 vs 68.3, social functioning -85.7 vs 77.8, role-emotional functioning -72.5 vs 74.1 and mental health -71.4 vs 65.8. Physical functioning scale was significantly lower in patients as compared to PN: 81.5 vs 92.2 (P<0,05). The majority of patients had no QoL impairment (24 patients); 1 patient -mild QoL impairment, 4 -moderate QoL impairment; 4 -severe QoL impairment; and 1 -critical QoL impairment.

In conclusion, lymphoma survivors in complete remission at the follow-up of more than 1 year after AHSCT had QoL parameters similar to normative data except decreased physical functioning. The vast majority of patients exhibited either no or mild to moderate QoL impairment. At the same time 15% of patients have either severe or critical QoL impairment. Careful examination of longterm lymphoma survivors after AHSCT is needed to improve treatment outcomes in this patient population.

body_text.text: Early response by 18F-fl uorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) during salvage chemotherapy in relapsed/refractory Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) patients (pts) could predict the outcome after high dose chemotherapy (HDC) S. Bramanti (1) Background: HDC is the gold standard in HL relapsing/refractory after fi rst line chemotherapy (CT). Pre-HDC FDG-PET can predict the outcome. Few data have been reported about the value of an interim FDG-PET during salvage CT. In a previous small cohort of patients, we suggested that PET2 was predictive of outcome, independently from PET4. In the present analysis, we aimed to confi rm these results in a more consistent number of patients. Patients and Methods: From March 2003 to July 2011, 67 pts with relapsed/refractory HL received 4 courses of IGEV (ifosfamide, gemcitabine, and vinorelbine) and HDC. FDG-PET was performed at relapse/progression, after the 2nd (PET2) and 4th (PET4) salvage CT. The progression free survival (PFS) and Overall survival (OS) were calculated. Univariate and multivariate analysis were performed. Results: Median age was 33 years. 31 pts (49%) were refractory after fi rst line treatment and 32 (51%) were relapsed. Pts characteristics were reported in table 1. The overall response rate after IGEV was 74% (n= 47). High-dose therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation in Hodgkin's disease. The value of pre-transplant PET/TC assessment S. Capria, A. Polino, S. Mallano, F. De Angelis, S. Panfi lio, A. Piciocchi, C. Stefanizzi, S.M. Trisolini, R. Foà, G. Meloni Sapienza University (Rome, IT) Clinical management of advanced Hodgkin's disease (HD) currently involves the use of high-dose therapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT). PET/CT imaging is becoming the standard tool to assess treatment response before ASCT and recent data suggest a high negative predictive value of this procedure. Aim of the study was to analyze retrospectively the value of pre-ASCT PET/TC in poor risk HD patients consecutively autografted at our Institution since 2002, focusing in particular on the prognostic signifi cance of the presence of measurable disease pre-ASCT in PET negative patients. A cohort of 83 patients with a median age of 29 years (12-61) was analyzed. The M/F ratio was 45/38. Poor risk disease was defi ned as sensitive relapse (23 pts), response to 2nd line treatment (28 pts), more advanced disease (>2 lines of treatment, refractory relapse) (32 pts). The median number of chemotherapy lines received was 3 (2) (3) (4) . Bulky disease at diagnosis was present in 53% (44/83) of patients, while extranodal disease at baseline or at relapse was detected in 33% (28/83). In 36 cases, pre-tranplant PET/TC was positive and in 47 it was negative. Within the latter group, 19/47 patients had measurable disease (≥4cm). The conditioning regimen varied during the years: BEAM was the treatment of choice until 2011 (74 pts); thereafter, Carmustine was replaced by Bendamustine 400 mg/m2 (3 pts) and Fotemustine 300 mg/m2 (6 pts). The two-year projected Kaplan-Meyer estimate of overall survival (OS) of the whole population was 87% (95% CI: 78-97), and pre-ASCT PET evaluation had no infl uence on OS (p: 0.2). The two-year projected progression-free-survival (PFS) was 73% overall (95% CI:63-83). Pre-ASCT PET negativity was the only factor infl uencing PFS both in univariate (85% vs 58%; p: 0.002) and multivariate analysis including in the model disease status, lines of treatment, bulky disease and extranodal involvement as covariates. Within PET negative patients, the presence of residual measurable disease was not associated with a worse outcome (p: 0.71). In our series, pre-transplant negative 18FDG-PET identifi ed patients with a better outcome and was a useful prognostic factor, independently of disease status before ASCT. Patients undergoing transplant with a persistent PET positivity still have a worse prognosis and for them alternative therapeutic strategies combined with ASCT should be considered.

A single centre intent-to-treat analysis S Rohlfi ng, S. Dietrich, M. Witzens-Harig, U. Hegenbart, S. Schönland, T. Luft, A.D. Ho, P. Dreger University of Heidelberg (Heidelberg, DE) The role of autologous stem cell transplantation (autoSCT) as consolidating treatment for peripheral T cell lymphoma (PTCL) is unsettled. The aim of this retrospective single center analysis was to investigate the feasibility and effi cacy of autoSCT in the upfront setting by intent-to-treat, and to study salvage strategies in case of relapse. Eligibility criteria: all patients with PTCL aged 18-70 years, diagnosed from 2002 through 2011. Results: 106 patients could be identifi ed. 7 were not treated, 1 was lost to follow up, 4 died within the fi rst month and 17 patients had ALK+ PTCL. These groups were excluded from further analysis. Of the remaining 77 patients, diagnosis was ALCL ALK-in 21, AITL in 16, EATCL in 10, and other PTCL in 30. Disregarding 15 patients whose initial treatment was performed externally, 1st-line autoSCT was not intended in 19 patients due to comorbidity, refusal, or unknown reasons (non-ITT), while intent-totransplant (ITT) was documented in 43 patients. Of these, 22 were autografted, whereas 19 (44%) could not proceeded to autoSCT usually due to progression, toxicity or refusal. By multivariate analysis adjusting for age, IPI and PTCL subtype, ITT vs non-ITT was not associated with signifi cant benefi ts for progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). Altogether, 58 (75%) of all 77 patients relapsed. Median OS after PTCL recurrence was only 10 months with no signifi cant impact of the time interval from 1st-line therapy to relapse, but higher IPI and age as well as subtype EATCL had a negative infl uence on the OS after relapse. increased uptake (SUV<3.5). A homogenous pattern with normal FDG distribution and absence of focally increased uptake was also considered as negative. Active disease was considered when the defi nition of controlled disease was not fulfi lled. Results: Eighteen patients (55%) had controlled disease before transplantation. With a median follow up of 9 months (IQL 5-34), the median OS of patients with active disease is 7.5 months (IC 95% 4.7-10.3) and it has not been reached in patients with controlled disease (p<0.001). At 2 years OS is 23% and 78% respectively (p<0.001). Nine patients did not respond and 5 patients relapsed after transplantation. In patients with previous active disease, the probability of relapse at two years is 100%, while it is lower than 20% in patients with controlled disease. PFS at 2 years is 15% and 78% respectively (p<0.001). Conclusion: In our experience, disease status evaluated by PET before reduced intensity allogeneic SCT is strongly predictive of outcome in patients with lymphoma. Patients with active disease have long-term dismal results and should follow a diff erent strategy.

body_text.text: High-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplantation in the treatment of patients with diff use large B-cell lymphoma with bone marrow involvement A. Gavrilina, E. Zvonkov, G. Gabeeva, K. Morozova, A. Sidorova, A. Bariakh, I. Vorobyev, K. Mangasarova, G. Gemdjian, K. Kravchenko, U. Magomedova, V. Savchenko National Research Center for Hematology (Moscow, RU) Background: Bone marrow involvement occurs in 10-20% of cases of diff use large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). According to its morphological characteristics bone marrow involvement can be concordant (CBM) or discordant(DBM). DLBCL with bone marrow involvement (BM) is characterized by aggressive course and poor response to standard chemotherapy (CT), and the worst results were obtained from the group of patients with CBM: 5-yrs OS rate of less than 10%. Application of the modifi ed NHL-BFM-90 program in treatment of DLBCL BM patients(pts) resulted in only partial remission. In these cases it seems reasonable to apply consolidating high-dose sequential chemotherapy(sHDT) with autologous stem cells transplantation (ASCT). Aim: To evaluate the effi cacy of the mNHL-BFM-90 program with sHDT with ASCT in the treatment of patients with DLBCL BM. Patients and Methods: Since Feb 2005 14 untreated DLBCL BM pts (median age 43(23-57), the M/F ratio 3,67; IPI: IH 50%, H 50%; bone marrow involvement: CBM 36%, DBM 64%) were enrolled in the mNHL-BFM-90 with sHDT with ASCT treatment program. All pts underwent 4 courses of CT mNHL-BFM-90 blocks A and C. After 4 courses the pts continued receiving treatment according to the sHDT scheme, including 2 DHAP courses and 3 high-dose courses with the mobilization and collection of hematopoietic stem cells (HSC): cyclophosphamide 8 g day 1, methotrexate 16 g and vincristine 2 mg day 15, etoposide 1 g q 12 hrs days 21-24. With enough CD 34+ cells collected the BEAM conditioning and the ASCT were carried out. Out of 14 pts included in the study, full therapy scheme was implemented in 6(43%) pts (arm 1). There had not been enough HSC collected from the remaining 8(57%) pts and therefore the ASCT was not carried out (arm 2). In arm 2, in case the complete remission (CR) was achieved only after sHDT, one additional Dexa-BEAM course was carried out (4 pts). The other 2 arm pts completed the therapy after the sHDT (4 pts). Results: A median follow-up is 44 months (19-95). All 14 pts achieved CR. There were 2(14%) pts with the early recurrence: 1 with CBM and 1 with DBM. One case of recurrence was registered in each arm. CR is maintained in 4 out of 5 patients with CBM. The 5-year OS and RFS were 79% and 85%, respectively. Conclusions: For the fi rst time the application of the primaryintensive mNHL-BFM-90 program with the sHDT with ASCT in the treatment of DLBCL BM pts, including pts with CBM, demonstrated high effi cacy.

Methods: Single centre, retrospective cohort study based on the data in the unit's ECP database. 219 consecutive patients were included who were steroid dependent, steroid refractory or intolerant to them. The response was measured at 3months, 6 months, 1 year and 2 years. Patients who showed ≥ 50% improvement in organ score and/or ≥ 50% reduction in steroid dose were classifi ed as responders. Extracorporeal photopheresis for treatment of GvHD after donor lymphocyte infusion C Del Fante (1) , L Scudeller (1), G Viarengo (1), M Cervio (1), L. Castagna (2) , C Perotti (1) (1)Fondazione IRCCS Policlinico S.Matteo (Pavia, IT); (2)Istituti Clinici Humanitas (Rozzano, Milan, IT) Objectives: Donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI) is often used after allo-SCT for treating diff erent oncohaematologic diseases to exploit the graft-versus-tumor eff ect in pts receiving T-celldepleted grafts, early after relapse or as a prophylactic strategy of relapse. However, more than 1/3 of patients develop acute and/or chronic GvHD and need an increase of immunosuppressive therapy (IST) thus entailing higher risk of disease relapse. Extracorporeal photochemotherapy (ECP) is a cell therapy, used to treat GVHD after allo-SCT. We here detail the results of 11 pts with chronic GvHD (NIH classifi cation) after DLI, treated with ECP with the aim of reducing or avoiding the need for IST. Methods: ECP consists in mononuclear cell collection, their UV-A irradiation in presence of 8-methoxypsoralen and reinfusion of the cells to the pts. The ECP treatment schedule consisted of three rounds of two procedures per week, three rounds of two procedures every other week, and fi nally two procedures every month until clinical improvement and/or IST tapering. Description of the whole cohort has been recently published (Transfusion 2012; 529:2007-15) . Results: Out of 102 patients treated with ECP at our Centre for chronic GvHD, 11 (10.8%) had received DLI. Of these, 7 (63.6%) were males. ECP was second line treatment for 3 (27.3%) pts and third line for 8 (72.7%) pts. Table 1 details pts' characteristics at ECP initiation. 8 (72.7%) pts showed a satisfactory response to ECP: 3 (27.3%) were complete responders, 5 (45.4%) partial responders; 2 (18.2%) minimal responders and 1 (9.1%) no responder. Rate of response was 2.6 (95%CI 1. 2 -5.6, p-value=0.02 ) higher than the rest of our cohort. 3 pts (27.3%) died (1 for disease relapse and 2 for infection). Of the 7 pts with steroid at baseline, 5(71.4%) discontinued steroid at the last ECP; other IST was tapered in 6 (54.5%) pts ( Table 2) . Conclusion: ECP proved to be eff ective in treating patients with GVHD after DLI. Compared to the whole cohort, these patients had a higher chance of complete or partial response; most patient could taper or even suspend IST even if ECP represented third line treatment for most patients. If these results will be confi rmed, ECP could be proposed as fi rst line treatment to reduce cGVHD severity in patients receiving DLI.

Methods: All consecutive patients diagnosed with cGvHD manifestations involving the joints and fascia and/or the skin with deep sclerotic features or impaired mobility (skin organ Score 3) were asked to participate in the Basel prospective physiotherapy cohort study. Huang Zhejiang University School of Medicine (Hangzhou, CN)Objectives: Relapse remains the most challenging obstacle in allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). There is an intense ongoing investigation of biologic factors of hematologic malignancies responsible for the risk of relapse post-HSCT. However few studies focus on inter-patient variability in graft-versus-leukemia (GVL) reaction. To explore key informative predicators from donor and patient genetic basis, we investigated the infl uence of genetic variations in GVL response pathways on the risk of relapse post-HSCT. Methods: We analyzed 40 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 21 genes involved in GVL reaction including NK cell activating receptor gene (NKG2D), cytokine genes (TNF-α, TNF-β, TGF-β and their receptors, IL6, IL10), T-cell co-stimulatory molecule genes (CD28, ICOS, CTLA-4), T-cell eff ector pathway genes (Granzyme B, Fas and Fas Ligand), innate immunity genes (TLR1, TLR2, TLR3, TLR8, TLR9) and immunosuppressive drug pharmacorelated genes (MTHFR, IMPDH1). The study included 240 pairs of patients and their donors. Results:

Cyclosporine A was used in all patients as a graft versus host (GvHD) prophylaxis . In MSD group, 8 patients received "short" methotrexate. Patients transplanted from MUD received additionally anti-thymocyte globulin and "short" methotrexate.

Koh (2) (1)National University Health System (Singapore, SG); (2)National University Cancer Institute, National University Health System (Singapore, SG) Introduction: Invasive fungal disease (IFD) remains an important cause of transplant related mortality in allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (alloHCT) recipients. Posaconazole has recently been approved for primary antifungal prophylaxis in patients with prolonged neutropenia after AML induction chemotherapy and patients with GvHD. The effi cacy of posaconazole in the setting of alloHCT remains unclear. We retrospectively reviewed our data with the aim of comparing the effi cacy and safety of posaconazole vs fl uconazole as primary antifungal prophylaxis in the early phase of alloHCT. Methodology: Medical records of alloHCT recipients between the period of January 2006 and November 2012 were reviewed and relevant data collected. Patients undergoing alloHCT were either given fl uconazole capsule 200mg once daily (prior to September 2010) or posaconazole oral suspension 200mg three times daily (after September 2010) beginning on the same day as hematopoietic cell infusion until engraftment, suspected drug-associated toxicity, or systemic fungal infection occurred. Therapeutic doses of systemic antifungal agents were started for proven, probable or possible breakthrough fungal infections as defi ned according to standardized EORTC/MSG criteria.

HHV infection developed at a median of 16 days post-HSCT (range: 9-180 days). Patients manifested with fever (100%), rash (90%), hepatitis (80%), pneumonitis (60%), CNS manifestations (40%), and graft failure (10%). Nine patients had concomitant infections. Two patients received foscarnet and ganciclovir treatment. Six patients cleared HHV after a median of 23.5 days (range: 16-44 days). Four patients died, 3 due to relapse of malignancy and 1 due to severe acute graft-versus-host disease. Conclusion: Reactivation of HHV infection is not uncommon in post-HSCT children in Hong Kong, especially after allogeneic HSCT. The clinical manifestations are protean, with fever and rash being the commonest. Flow cytometric detection of residual TcRα/β+ cells is challenging and requires optimization of multiple analysis parameters.Background: Graft failure (GF) after allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is a serious condition with high mortality.Whereas the initial treatment options are use of hematopoietic growth factors and infection prophylaxis, the ultimate treatment is a second transplant. Furthermore, the second graft can be administered without conditioning, since the recipient immune system is of donor origin. Methods: From 2002 to 2011, we identifi ed 18 patients at our institution with the following clinical features: 1) GF not caused by medications or infection, 2) full donor chimerism in bone mardays. Death causes were infections and organ failure, no patients experienced relapse. Chronic GVHD developed in 8 cases (44%), of these 7 were considered extensive and one limited. Conclusion: In GF patients, a second transplant with a CD34selected graft from the original donor can be safely administered without conditioning in case of full donor chimerism, with longtime survival as a possible outcome.Kurnikova, E. TABREF36.text: Introduction: Granulocyte colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) fi lgrastim is standard of care in hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) mobilization either as monotherapy or in combination with chemotherapy. Biosimilars such as Zarzio can be used in the setting of neutropenia and HSC mobilization, however, their clinical experience is limited. Methods: We performed autologous HSC transplant for advanced heart failure into myocardium in eligible patients on waiting list for the heart transplant. Biosimilar Zarzio was used for HSC according to standard protocol 10 μg/kg body weight daily for fi ve days. On day fi ve CD34+ cell level above 15x10 6 /l was considered adequate for the start of apheresis. Peripheral HSC collection was performed using Amicus cell separator. Results: Sixteen patients (men=13) with ischemic cardiomiopathy were mobilized with Zarzio. Their median age was 54.8 (36.4-68.2) years. Zarzio was administered for fi ve days. On day fi ve the median white blood cell count, CD34+ cell count and their percentage were 54.84 (36.40-68.22) x10 9 /l, 32.00 (16.94-189.76) x10 6 /l and 0.19% (0.07-0.38), respectively. None of the patients was a poor mobilizer not reaching 15x10 6 /l CD34+ cells level. No serious adverse event was observed. Conclusion: Use of biosimilar Zarzio in HSC mobilization is feasible with success rates similar to fi lgrastim as observed by others. There were no serious side eff ects and all patients proceeded to apheresis. Further studies using Zarzio and long term follow up are necessary.Background: Delayed engraftment or graft failure can induce delayed immune reconstitution, which increases the risk of infection and transplant related mortality (TRM), and decreases overall survival (OS) after allogenic stem cell transplantation (AlloSCT). According to prior studies, the number of CD34+ cells is the most reliable measure for predicting the kinetics of hematopoietic reconstitution. However, the impact of donor T-cells and clinical factors on engraftment kinetics in peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT) has not been wellinvestigated. The aim of our study is to investigate predictive factors for rapid engraftment after PBSCT in patients with acute leukemia. Methods: Two hundred and sixty-two patients receiving PBSCT between September 1998 and November 2011 were analyzed in this study. Subset analyses of donor stem cells were conducted by using a fl ow-cytometric method. The correlation between rapid engraftment of neutrophils, platelets, and donor stem cellsdoses [hematopoietic stem cells (CD34+ cells), T-cells (CD3+), helper T-cells (CD3+/CD4+), cytotoxic T-cells (CD3+/CD8+), NK cells (CD56+)] as well as other recipient and donor clinical factors were analyzed.Results: In univariate analysis, factors correlated with neutrophil engraftment (≥ 0.5x109/L) by day 12 were: short duration from diagnosis to hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT), achievement of complete remission (CR) after fi rst induction chemotherapy (CR1) before HCT, and high numbers of mononuclear cells (MNCs), CD34+ cells, CD3+ T-cells, CD3+/CD4+ T-cells, and CD3+/CD8+ T-cells. Factors correlated with platelet engraftment (≥ 20 x109/L) by day 14 were: female gender, achievement of CR1 before HCT, younger donor age (> 30 years), and high numbers of MNCs, CD34+ cells, CD3+ T-cells, CD3+/CD4+ T-cells, CD3+/CD8+ T-cells, and CD56+ NK cells. In multivariate analysis, independent predictive factors for rapid neutrophil and platelet engraftment were CR1 before HCT, high number of donor CD34+ cells, and high number of CD3+ T-cells. Conclusion: In our study, we found that achieving CR1 before HCT, as well as larger quantities of donor CD34+ and CD3+ T-cells may predict rapid neutrophil and platelet engraftment after PBSCT. However, further studies are needed to determine the appropriate doses of CD3+ T-cells and CD34+ cells necessary for rapid engraftment.P690Alemtuzumab in the stem cell bag provides favourable outcomes in patients receiving myeloablative unrelated donor allografts for myeloid malignancies P.Nicolson, S. TABREF38.text: Introduction: It is known that absolute lymphocyte count at day following autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT) is predictive of long term outcome in terms of overall survival (OS) and progression free survival (PFS). Objectives: Our objective was to see if there is a correlation between ALC-15 and the absolute lymphocyte count in the stem cell harvest (A-ALC) and, subsequently, whether this was predictive of outcome after ASCT in patients with myeloma. Methods: we performed a retrospective analysis of 37 patients with myeloma who had undergone autologous stem cell transplant with conditioning using high dose melphalan and peripheral blood mobilised stem cells in our unit over the last 3 years since December 2009. Median follow up was 12 months. Outcome measures used were OS, PFS and length of stay (LOS). Multple regression analysis of apheresis bag CD34 count (A-CD34), total nucleated cell count (A-TNC), white cell count (A-WCC) and A-ALC with ALC-15, absolute lymphocyte count at day 30 (ALC-30), OS, PFS and LOS was performed. Results: Median OS and PFS were 12 and 11 months respectively. Multiple regression analysis revealed that that only A-ALC correlates with ALC-15 (r =0.514, p=0.001), whereas there was no correlation between A-CD34, A-TNC, A-WCC with ALC-15 or ALC-30 and there was no correlation between A-ALC and ALC30. ALC-30 was predictive of better OS. There was no correlation between A-ALC and LOS.

TABREF39.text: Introduction: It is known that absolute lymphocyte count at day following autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT) is predictive of long term outcome in terms of overall survival (OS) and progression free survival (PFS). Objectives: Our objective was to see, in patients with myeloma, if there is a correlation between ALC-15 and the absolute lymphocyte count in the cells collected in the stem cell harvest (A-ALC) and, subsequently, whether this was predictive of outcome after ASCT and whether there were any factors predictive of A-ALC. Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of 37 patients with myeloma who had undergone autologous stem cell transplant with conditioning using high dose melphalan and peripheral blood mobilised stem cells in our unit over the last 3 years since December 2009. Median follow up was 12 months. Outcome measures used were OS and PFS. Multiple regression analysis of apheresis bag CD34 count (A-CD34), total nucleated cell count (A-TNC), white cell count (A-WCC) and A-ALC with ALC-15, absolute lymphocyte count at day 30 (ALC-30), OS and PFS was performed. Factors predictive of A-ALC were analysed were mobilisation regime, disease stage prior to transplant and prognostic score. Results: Median OS and PFS were 12 and 11 months respectively. Multiple regression analysis revealed that that only A-ALC correlates with ALC-15 (r =0.514, p=0.001), whereas there was no correlation between A-CD34, A-TNC, A-WCC with ALC-15 or ALC-30 and there was no correlation between A-ALC and ALC30. ALC-30 was predictive of better OS. Whether a chemotherapy (CBR) or non-chemotherapy based mobilisation regimen (NCBR) was used was predictive of A-ALC with the A-ALC achieved being lower for CBR (for CBR: Mean A-ALC: 35.83 x10 9 /l and for NCBR: Mean A-ALC: 65.54 x10 9 /l, p=0.0008). Age, prognostic score and disease stage at transplant were not predictive of A-ALC. Conclusion: A-ALC is predictive of ALC-15. ALC-30 is predictive of better OS following autologous stem cell transplant. Post chemotherapy mobilisation is associated with lower A-ALC which may be due to direct cytotoxic eff ects on lymphocyte progenitors resulting in a lower lymphocyte harvest yield. Higher lymphocyte dose in the stem cell bag may lead to better lymphocyte engraftment with superior anti-tumour eff ect.

Garderet  on behalf of the Intergroupe Francophone du Myélome and of the Plasma Cell Disorders Subcommittee of the Chronic Malignancies Working Party of the EBMT Background: IMiDs are associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic events (TE) in MM. TE remained despite LMWH use.We studied the incidence and risk factors of TE in MM IMiDs-based regimen while on LMWH TE prophylaxis. Method: The MMVAR/IFM 2005-04 trial is a large multicenter, prospective, randomized open-label, phase 3, comparing VTD to TD for MM patients in fi rst progression after autologous transplantation. In both arms, oral thalidomide was administered at 200 mg/ day for 1 year with high dose dexamethasone every 3 weeks for 1 year. VTD arm included bortezomib. Enoxaparin 40 mg/day during one year was mandatory in both arms. Results: There were 24 (8.9%) TE recorded, 12 in each arm; we pooled the 2 groups for the subsequent analysis. The characteristics of the MM with TE were not diff erent from the overall population, 14 male / 10 female, median age (range) was 63 (42-76) with 25% patients older than 65. The median (min-max) time from start of therapy to occurrence of TE was 3.4 months (0.3-11.9), not different in either arm. TE occurred in 16 (66%) vs. 8 (33%) patients in the fi rst 4 months and after 4 months, respectively. 15 (62.5%) pts had at least some tumor burden reduction (minor response and better) at time of occurrence of TE, while 12.5% had progression of MM, 12.5% stable disease, and 12.5% were non evaluable. All TE occurred while pts were on LMWH prophylaxis since the initiation of the study treatment but one. The occurrence of TE impacted the treatment of MM as 16 (67%) pts did stop their IMiDs-based treatment, either transiently for 8 (33%) or defi nitely for 8 (33%) pts. The doses of the IMiDs were reduced for 5 pts when IMiDs were reintroduced. Overall only 5 pts had no change applied to their MM treatment while TE occurred. Conclusion: Although LMWH is recommended to patients with high risk of TE, the optimal dose and duration of TE prophylaxis remains to be determined. Background: Although usually confi ned to the bone marrow, extramedullary (EM) involvement has been reported in up to 15-20% of patients with multiple myeloma (MM) at diagnosis. The clinical course of EM cases treated with conventional therapy is often aggressive and associated with early progression and short survival. Aim: To evaluate high-dose therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation (HDT/ASCT) effi cacy and long-term outcomes in a cohort of MM patients with EM manifestation. Methods: EM spread of plasma cell myeloma in our study is defi ned as plasma cell tumor extending from the intramedullary spaces of the bone marrow through the cortical bone as well as spread to organs. Hematogenous dissemination into blood vessels resulting in plasma cell leukemia was not included. From September 2001 to September 2012, 138 patients with MM were transplanted in the department of Chemotherapy of Hemoblastosis and Bone Marrow Transplantation. Within this group 39 (28%) had EM involvement, which was palpable or radiographically detected. Among them there were 20 pts with myeloma G, 8 with myeloma A, 7 with light-chain myeloma, 2 with myeloma D, 1 with myeloma M and 1 with non-secretory myeloma. In 99 (72%) cases EM disease was not detected. In this group 55 pts had myeloma G, 25 -myeloma A, 18 -light-chain myeloma and 1 -non-secretory myeloma. Pts received VAD chemotherapy and/or bortezomib + dexamethasone ± doxorubicin ± cyclophosphamide. In mobilization procedure the pts received cyclophosphamide followed by daily administration of G-CSF 5 μg/kg until the peripheral stem cell harvest. HDT/ASCT entailed conditioning with melphalan 200 mg/m 2 . Response was defi ned according to IMWG criteria. Results: The median time of follow-up after ASCT was 28 months(2,. The median of overall survival was 98 months, PFS at5-year was 46,9%, at 7-year -27,1%. 114 pts (83,2%)  are still alive. There was no signifi cant diff erence in PFS and OS in pts with or without EM involvement at the time of diagnosis. The median of PFS was 43 months in the group of pts with EM disease and 45 months in pts without EM involvement. The probability of 5-y OS was 68% in the fi rst group and 77% in the second group (p=0,8). Conclusion: These results suggest that HDT/ASCT is able to overcome the poor prognostic impact of EM involvement at the time of diagnosis, allowing pts to do at least as well as those without EM disease.

Patients with preserved left ventricular systolic function can be treated using highdose melphalan (HD MEL) with autologous hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation. However, such a treatment is impossible in patients with manifest heart failure. The impaired left ventricular systolic function should be at fi rst resolved by orthotopic heart transplantation (OHT) and, consequently, amyloidosis could be treated by chemotherapy. Patients and methods: Three patients with manifest heart failure caused by amyloidosis underwent OHT. HSCs collections from peripheral blood after G-CSF 10 μg/kg/day were followed by HD MEL 100 mg/m 2 with autologous HSC transplantation (ASCT). Results: Patient A (1955) underwent endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) 4/2010 with diagnosis of cardiac amyloidosis. He did not tolerate chemotherapy because of heart failure. OHT was performed 8/2010 and he underwent HD MEL with ASCT 3/2011, without signifi cant toxicity. However, CR was not achieved and free light chain concentrations slowly increased. Multiple myeloma criteria was completed 12/2011. The patient started BDD therapy and after 7 cycles reached CR. The function of the heart graft is good with no presence of amyloid from the latest EMB 29 months afterOHT. Patient B (1962), with severe heart failure and monoclonal gammopathy, but negative EMB, underwent OHT 7/2010. Non-homogenous deposits of amyloid were found in the explanted heart. Control EMB showed new amyloid deposits in transplant. Therefore, HD MEL with ASCT was performed 1/2011, but with minimal response. CVD 8 cycles given 3-11/2011 resulted in PR. Using 3rd line therapy(RAD, 11/2011(RAD, 11/ -7/2012) stable VGPR was reached. The heart graft function is good, with no presence of amyloid from the latest EMB 31 months afterOHT. Patient C  (1949): Cardiac amyloidosis was diagnosed from EMB 12/2011 and she underwentOHT 5/2012. ASCT was also planned, but the patient surprisingly reached CR -probably because of immunosuppression (tacrolimus, MMF, prednison). The patient is in a stable condition with no evidence of amyloid in the heart graft from the latest EMB (7 months after OHT). Conclusions: OHT in amyloid cardiomyopathy is the only way how to enable a curative hematologic treatment with signifi cant survival improvement. TABREF58.text: Objective: The intensive chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) is, currently the treatment of choice in multiple myeloma (MM). However the timing of ASCT in the era of novel agents suchs bortezomib or thalidomide is unknown. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the outcome of MM patients who received bortezomib and thalidomid based induction treatment and received fi rst ASCT within 12 months of diagnosis (early ASCT, N = 45), or at a later date (late ASCT, N = 28). Results : Median time to ASCT was 7 months vs. 16 months in the early vs. late ASCT. The 3 and 5 yr overall survival (OS) from diagnosis was 89 and 88% versus 88 and 67% in early and late ASCT respectively (P=0.38). 10 and 4 patients in the early and late ASCT have relapsed or progressed with median time to relapse of 26 and 15 months (P=0.17). Our results are the same as those published recently by Dunavin et al. We conclude, that time to autograft before or after 12 months has no impact on survival for MM patients receiving induction treatment with Bortezomib and thalidomid.

Prete on behalf of the Bone Marrow Transplantation Working Group of the AIEOP Introduction: Busulphan (BU) has been employed for over 30 years in a variety of conditioning regimens for HCST. It has marked neurotoxicity,specifi cally causing seizures. Hence, seizure prophylaxis is routinely utilized during BU administration for HSCT. The risk of seizures is higher with intravenous administration, higher dose and adult age. Most of the available knowledge in this fi eld has been gained on adult patients. In this study we collected data on the incidence of seizures among children undergoing SCT in Italy. Methods: Twelve pediatric transplant centers agreed to report data on all children receiving a BU as part of the conditioning regimen for SCT, between 2005 and 2012. Data on route of administration, drug monitoring, seizure-specifi c risks factors, neurological associated conditions, seizure prophylaxis, and occurrence of seizures were collected. Results: 580 pediatric patients were evaluated; all of them received seizure prophylaxis with very diff erent schedules and drugs. Of them, 61% received BU per os. A total of 12 patients developed seizures (2%). Of them, 3 had a history of epilepsy (or other seizure-related pre-existing condition); 3 had a documented brain lesion potentially causing seizures per se; 1 had seizures during plasma hypo-osmolarity; only in 5 patients seizures were considered not explained by concurrent factors and thus potentially related to BU administration. Conclusion. The incidence of seizures in children receiving BUcontaining regimen is very low. Furthermore, most of the patients who developed seizures had at least one factor which could be considered as a specifi c risk-factor. Thus, universal prophylaxis of seizures in all children receiving BU-containing regimen appears to be not justifi ed. A prospective trial for assessment of seizures in children receinving BU-containing regimen without prophyxis appears warranted. The median follow-up for survivors was 763 days (range 296-1950). Results: The median pre-HSCT ferritin was 623 ng/ml (range 17-4468), and 38.3% patients had ferritin >1000 ng/ml. The median Sorror and PAM scores were 2 (range 0-9) and 21 (range 11-32), respectively. Patients with higher ferritin levels (≥ median value; HFL group, n=47) had more acute leukemia (55.3% vs. 4.2%, p=0.004) and less multiple myeloma (10.6% vs. 48.9%, p=0.02) compared to patients with lower ferritin levels (< median value; LFL group, n=47). The ferritin levels refl ected the transfusion load and the patient comorbidity, as HFL group had more frequently been transfused and showed more adverse risk scores than LFL group (≥20 PRCB units: 53.2% vs. 2.1%, p<0.001; Sorror ≥2: 61.8% vs. 38.2%, p= 0.008; PAM score ≥24: 46.8% vs. 21.1% p= 0.01). The day 100 non-relapse mortality rate was 8.7%(2.1% in LFL group  and 19.1% in HFL group; p=0.02). The 2-year overall survival (2-y OS) was 63% (75% in LFL group and 45% in HFL group; p= 0.002). Non-relapse and relapse mortalities accounted for 17.4% and 14.8% of the whole series, respectively. LFL and HFL groups had similar risk of: bacteriemias until day 100, aGVHD, cGVHD and grade III-IV hepatic and renal toxicities. The comorbidity scores showed association with HSCT outcome. A Sorror index ≥2 and a PAM ≥24 score correlated with a lower 2-y OS (r2=1.020, p= 0.026 and r2=1.076, p= 0.045, respectively). In multivariate analysis, ferritin levels showed predictive value for 2-y OS (p=0.011), while transfusion history of ≥20 RBC units, Sorror index ≥2, and PAM score ≥24 did not. Conclusion: In our cohort of pts, comorbidity scores (HCI-CI, PAM) and, particularly, high ferritin levels are good predictors of HSCT outcome. Transplant-related complications and quality of life monitoring: suggestions from the Rome Transplant Network Quality of Life Working Party A.Tendas, A. Pignatelli, F. Sollazzo, L. Cupelli, B. Veggia, E. Conte,  A. Di veroli, V. Molinari, M. Mauroni, O. Annibali, V. Pilozzi,  S. Cacciaraichi, C. Viggiani, P. Niscola, T. Dentamaro, P. De Fabritiis,  W. Arcese On behalf of Rome Transplant NetworkIntroduction: Quality of life (QoL) during and after stem cell transplantation could be infl uenced by both transplant (SCT) related complications, disease complications and co-morbidities. Transplant-related complications are frequent and well-known events, although data about their eff ect on QoL are scarce. Purpose: To identify a pattern of post-transplant QoL monitoring having the highest chance to intercept QoL variations. Methods: By analyzing available scientifi c literature data about transplant related complications, we addressed the following variables: onset period, clinical course, duration, frequency and risk of QoL reduction; for the latter, we measured 3 elements for each complication: complication-related symptom burden, treatmentrelated symptom burden and risk of hospitalization (considered to be key factors on inducing a reduction in quality of life). Results: We analyzed 38 complications, early (<30 days), intermediate (30-100 days) and late (>100 days) in 12, 7 and 19 complications respectively. Clinical course: acute in 20 and chronic in 18; among acute complications, duration was: <30 and >30 days in 19 and 1 respectively; duration of all the chronic complications was >30 days in all the cases. Frequency was high (>30%), moderate (10-20%), low (5-10%) and very low (<5%) in 11, 9, 12 and 6 complications, respectively. We calculated the risk of QoL reduction as very high, moderately high and low in 15, 17 and 6, respectively. Among the high/moderate frequency (>20%) groups (20/38), we chronologically located complications as: early in 6 (all acute, duration <30 days in 5/6), intermediate in 3 (all acute, lasting <30 days) and late in 11 complications (all chronic, lasting >30 days). Conclusions: In the early phase, we suggest QoL monitoring at least once a week (in order not to miss many of the complications, due to their short duration, usually <30 days) even with daily monitoring of certain parameters (eg CINV, mucositis, pain); in the intermediate-late phase indeed, complications are more diluted over time, but many of them can heavily impact on qol; their duration, however, usually exceeds 30 days; for this phase, therefore, we suggest both to monitor QoL upon a fi xed rarefi ed schedule (eg. quarterly) and to intensify monitoring at the onset of the complication, anchoring intensifi ed QoL assessment to the date of complication diagnosis and carrying on until resolution and treatment discontinuation.P1027Management of mucositis in adult patients after haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: adherence to guidelines A.Tendas, A. Elez, B. Balint, O. Tarabar, S. Marjanovic,  Z. Tatomirovic, M. Strnad, A. Zivanovic Ivic, Lj. Tukic  Military Medical Academy (Belgrade, RS)    Introduction: Approximately 20-40% of all HLA matched allogeneic stem cell transplants (HSCT) are ABO incompatible. Persistent anti-donor isoagglutinins after major ABO blood group incompatible HSCT may cause delayed red blood cell (RBC) engraftment and post transplant pure red cell aplasia (PRCA). Appropriate treatment of PRCA is not well established. The therapeutic approaches that might be eff ective in some patients with post transplant PRCA include: plasma exchange and immunoadsorption, erythropoetine, donor lymphocyte infusion, steroids or induction of Graft-versus-Host-Disease (GvHD) by Cyclosporine A (CsA) discontinuation, anti CD20 antibody. Aim: We are representing two patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) successfully treated with anti CD20 antibody for PRCA after ABO incompatible HSCT. Cases: Two patients, one 18 years old male and one 24 years old female with AML were transplanted in our center after initial treatment and achievement of complete remission. Donors were HLA identical siblings with ABO major incompatibility in both cases. They were conditioned with Busulphan (16 mg/kg) and Cyclophosphamide (120 mg/kg) and stem cell sources were peripheral blood. In each case, plasma exchange was performed before myeloinfusion in order to overcome ABO incompatibility. GvHD prophylaxis was consisted of CsA and short course Methotrexate. Engraftments of polymorphonuclears and platlets were achieved on +13. and +17. day, respectively. Complete chimerism in both cases was documented by accepted methods. Bone marrow aspirate on day +28. showed complete absence of erythroid precursors, while neutrophils and megakariocytes were present. Diagnosis of PRCA was established according to hematological parameters (anaemia and reticulocytopoenia) and exclusion of relapse, Parvo B19, other viral infections and RBC alloantibodies. Treatment approaches with plasma exchange, corticoteroids and intravenous immunoglobulins together with tapering of CsA were without response. Afterwards, patients have received monoclonal anti CD20 antibody 200 mg/m 2 . Even after fi rst dose, RBC have arised promptly. Both patients were still in complete remission for 42 and 32 months after transplant. One of them have mild form of chronic GvHD. Conclusion: Immunotherapy with monoclonal anti CD 20 antibody may be eff ective in the treatment of PRCA after ABO incompatible HSCT, but future analysis are necessary. ), A. Giulivi(1), E. TABREF172.text: Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) is a clinicoradiological entity represented by characteristic magnetic resonance image (MRI) findings of subcortical-cortical hyperintensity inT2-weighted and FLAIR sequences, accompanied by clinical neurologic alterations. Ciclosporine (CsA), tacrolimus, cytotoxic drugs, steroid and hypertension are causative factors known to be associated with PRES. Symptoms occur in 3-23% patients following allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (aHSCT). Clinical symptoms include headache, decreased alertness, mental abnormalities, changed behavior, seizures, vomiting, and visual abnormalities. We reviewed the medical records of 162 patients who underwent aHSCT for hematologic disease in our center in 1995-2012. All patients received CsA for GVHD prophylaxis. PRES was diagnosed in 3 patients (1.8%).

Patients & Methods: Twenty-one patients underwent auto-transplant and were daily followed for electrolyte problems. Five had neuroblastoma (NB), 5 Ewing sarcoma (Ew), 3 non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) and 8 medulloblastoma (MB). Conditioning regimens included busulfan + melphalan for NB and Ew patients and BCNU, etoposide, cytosar and melphalan for NHL patients. Four MB patients received 3 tandem transplants (conditioned with carboplatin + thiotepa) and 4 patients -4 tandem transplants (conditioned with cisplatin, vincristine and cyclophosphamide). Measures of number of days out of normal range, for each electrolyte, were counted. Results: Out of normal range was mainly documented for K, P and Mg but not for Na and T.Bili., with no diff erences between patients getting tandem transplants and those receiving only one transplant, across all protocols and diagnoses. NB patients suff ered more comparing to Ew patients though receiving the same conditioning. No diff erences were seen between MB patients receiving 3 or 4 tandem transplants, but in Mg where it was 10 times more frequent in patients getting 4 transplants. Moreover, no deterioration was documented during proceeding from transplant to transplant. NHL patients demonstrated the higher number of days with electrolyte disturbances. No change in T. Bili. level was acknowledge between busulfan-containing regimen and patients not receiving busulfan, refl ecting also the fact that none of the patients suff ered from veno-occlusive disease of the liver. Conclusions: Electrolytes levels must be taken and followed during auto-transplants. Some of them, especially K, P and Mg may show disturbances for a signifi cant number of days potentially harming the patient. TABREF182.text: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) driven lymphomas associated with immunosuppression are a signifi cant problem, particularly after transplantation. Conventional treatment (withdrawal of immunosuppression, administration of rituximab/chemotherapy) is often eff ective but risks organ rejection and causes signifi cant side eff ects. EBV specifi c cytotoxic T cells (CTL) generated in vitro from autologous lymphocytes can be eff ective with few side eff ects, but take months to prepare so are diffi cult to use in clinical practice. We have established a bank of EBV CTLs derived from platelet/ plasma donors for issuing 'off the shelf product' to partially Human Leucocyte Antigen (HLA) matched patients on a named patient basis. Donors from the New Zealand platelet / plasma panel were sourced to reduce the risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). The current panel of donors selected was EBV positive, Blood Group O, and met all current requirements for mandatory virology markers. The panel was also chosen to maximize the probability of HLA class I and II matches and minimize the number of mismatches. We estimated that this initial panel of 25 donors should provide a partial match for at least three (HLA-A, -B, -DRB1) loci for ~80% of Caucasian patients. So far, lymphoblastoid cell lines have been made from 25 donors ready for use in stimulating CTLs and 18 CTLs have been manufactured and cryopreserved for clinical use. Since the bank was granted a 'Specials' license by the MHRA for this Advanced Therapy Medicinal Product in January 2012, there have been enquiries about 14 patients: 4 improved on conventional therapy without requiring CTLs, 3 died before any cells could be issued and 6 cell lines have been released. The indications for issue have been: 3 cases of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (1 CD20-rituximab resistant, 1 with concomitant graft versus host disease precluding reduction of immunosuppression, 1 unfi t for chemotherapy), 2 cases with congenital immunosuppression as a bridge to allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant and 1 case of EBV-associated leiomyosarcoma post-cardiac transplant (related donor). Clinical improvement has been seen in 4 out of 6 assessable patients. A 3rd party donor-derived anti-EBV CTL cell bank can be operated under current legislation and is a valuable addition to existing therapies for selected patients.P1047 Frequent chromosomal instability in somatic and tumour cells after haematopoietic cell transplantationM. De Geest(5) (1)University Hospital Basel (Basel, CH); (2)University Hospital Zurich (Zurich, CH); (3)Oncology Institute of Southern Switzerland (Bellinzona, CH); (4)KU Leuven (Leuven, BE); (5)Insitute of Nursing Science, University Basel (Basel, CH)Background: Stem cell transplantation (SCT) requires adequate self-management (SM) (i.e. medical, role and emotional SM) which might have the potential to reduce the risk for complications. Knowledge on SM in SCT is limited. Aims:(1)  to examine the prevalence of SM (i.e. Medical-SM i.e. smoking, alcohol consumption, vaccination, physical activity, dietary habits, sun protection, medication adherence; Role-SM i.e. professional employment; Emotional SM i.e. depression & anxiety in SCT survivors; and (2) to compare the prevalence of specifi c health behaviours with health recommendations by the Swiss Federal Offi ce of Public Health (FOPH) and with normative data of the Swiss population. Methods: This multi-centre cross-sectional study (2 Swiss SCT centres) included a convenience sample of 374 patients [54.6% males; mean age 50.3 years (SD=12.8); median 7 years post allogeneic SCT (IQR=8.7), chronic Graft versus Host Disease=40.6%]. SM dimensions were assessed by self-report items derived from large cohort studies or national surveys. Medication adherence was measured with the BAASIS® and depression and anxiety by the Hospital Anxiety Depression Scale. FOPH Health recommendations in regard to physical activity, diet, smoking, and alcohol consumption and normative data from the Swiss Health survey (2007) were used for comparison. Frequencies/% were calculated to describe SM behaviours. Results: SM assessment revealed following fi ndings: actual smoking (13.5%), alcohol use (81.4%), no fl u vaccination in past year (41.9%), medication non-adherence (67% for immunosuppressants and 42.9% for other medications), depression (11.3%) and, anxiety (14.8%). 73.7% of patients were employed (37.7% fulltime/36% part-time). Large discrepancies with Swiss National health recommendations were observed; only 17.6% of SCT patients vs. 38% in normative sample were moderately physically active for at least 30 minutes/ day. Fewer SCT patients compared to the normal population ate the recommended daily 5 pieces of fruits and vegetables (17.6% vs. 29%), one dairy product (12.3% vs. 62%), and at least once weekly fi sh (31.2% vs. 58%). Conclusions: This study reveals considerable room for improvement in SM post-SCT. Compared to the normal population less SCT patients were physically active and had a balanced diet.
