back_matter.text: Feasibility and early outcome of clofarabine induction followed by allogeneic transplant using haploidentical donors in relapsed/refractory lymphoma J. Tischer (1), S. Fritsch (1) , D. Prevalsek (1) , N. Engel (1) , T. Herold (1) , C. Schulz (1), A.K. Zoellner (1) , V. Buecklein (1) , R. Reibke (1) , W. Hill (1), G. Ledderose (1) , M. Dreyling (1) , A. Hausmann (2) (1)LMU-Klinikum der Universität München -Großhadern (Munich, DE) ; DE) Background: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is a valuable treatment option for patients (pts) with advanced or refractory aggressive lymphoma. However, outcome in non-remission pts is still poor. Therefore, we set out to evaluate the feasibility of a protocol using the concept of sequential therapy with clofarabine as induction chemotherapy followed by haploidentical HSCT. Methods: Since March 2010 ten adult pts (6 male, median age: 56 years) with MCL (n=5), transformed CLL (n=2) or DLCL (n=3) were included. All pts were classifi ed as high risk according to the age-adjusted IPI. Four pts were primary refractory and 6 pts had relapsed after autologous HSCT. The mean number of prior chemotherapy regimens was fi ve. After a rituximab (n=8) or ofatumumab (n=2) containing salvage chemotherapy prior to HSCT a partial remission (PR) or stable disease was achieved in 3 and 2 pts, respectively. Five pts had progressive disease. Chemotherapy with clofarabine (5x30 mg/m2 IV) was followed -after three days of rest-by a reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimen consisting of fl udarabin/cyclophosphamide (Flu/Cy) plus either melphalan 110 mg/m2 IV (n=9) or TBI 2 Gy (n=1). High-dose Cy post-transplant was applied for post-grafting immuno-suppression. Results: Neutrophil and platelet engraftment was achieved in 9/10 and 8/10 pts within a median of 21 and 31 days. No primary graft rejection and only one early death were observed. Complete remission (n=4) and PR (n=3) could be induced by day +100 in 7/10 pts. Full donor chimerism by day +100 was achieved in 7/10 pts. After a median follow up of 6 month (range 3-27) the cumulative incidence of non-relapse mortality at day +100 was 10%. Rate of grade II-IV acute GvHD was 40%. Exceptionally mild chronic GVHD was seen in 4 pts. Three pts died from infection (n=1), toxicity (n=1) or relapse (n=1). Accordingly, overall survival and progression free survival after one year from haploidentical transplantation were both 70%. Regimen related grade III-IV toxicity (non-hematologic) was reported in 5/10 pts with mucositis and transient elevation of transaminases as the most common seen toxicities. Conclusion: Haploidentical HSCT following initial induction with clofarabine, RIC and high-dose Cy post-transplant is feasible with an acceptable toxicity profi le in patients with relapsed/refractory aggressive lymphoma. Our preliminary results are promising, but long-term results are required.

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation for lymphoma: role of conditioning with treosulfan and fl udarabine R. Niittyvuopio, J. Heiskanen, V. Lindstrom, E. Juvonen, A. Nihtinen, H. Uotinen, T. Ruutu, L. Volin Helsinki University Central Hospital (Helsinki, FI) The use of allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) in lymphoma has been limited by high transplant-related mortality (TRM) in heavily pre-treated patients. However, the potentially curative graft-versus-lymphoma eff ect is well established, and TRM can be reduced with less toxic conditioning. We report our single centre experience of 35 patients treated with allogeneic SCT using treosulfan-based conditioning since the year 2001, showing low TRM and a good relapse-free survival (RFS). The median age of the patients was 47 (range 19-63) years. The diagnoses were mantle cell lymphoma 9, Hodgkin's disease 8, follicular lymphoma 7, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma 6, T-cell lymphoma 3, Waldenstrom's disease 1, and small B-cell lymphoma 1. The conditioning consisted of treosulfan 42 g/m 2 (10 patients) or 30 -36 g/m 2 (25 patients)We present the analysis of allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) in Hodgkin´s lymphoma which summarizes the results of all transplant centers in the Czech Republic. In the period from june 1998 to june 2011, overall 45 patients (pts) were transplanted; 23 men / 22 women, median age was 31.5 years (range; 10.5-56.2) . As a graft, PBPC were used in 37 (82%) pts, thirty-six (80%) pts were transplanted after RIC, thirty-one pts (70%) were transplanted from an unrelated donor. Thirty-nine pts (87%) were previously treated with autologous transplant. At time of allo-SCT, twenty-one (47%) pts had chemoresistant disease. The median time from diagnosis to allo-SCT was 44 months ( range; 14-144), the majority (93%) of allo-SCT were performed after 2000. Median follow-up was 17 months (range; 1-125) for all patients and 70 months (range;14-125) for survivors. All but one patient engrafted, the median time to neutrophils engraftment was 15 days (range; 8-31). Acute GVHD grade 1-2 developed in 7 cases, grade 3-4 in 7 cases. Overall incidence was 33%. Thirty-seven patients could be evaluated for chronic GVHD and its incidence was 49% (18 patients; eight had extensive and ten had limited form). Twenty-fi ve (56%) patients relapsed after a median time of 13 months (range; 3-50), ten out of them were treated with DLI. At the last follow-up, fi fteen pts (33%) were alive, thirty pts (67%) died: seven (16%) of NRM and 23 (51%) of disease progression. Estimated 3-and 5-years OS and PFS were 42% and 30% and 23% and 16%, respectively. Median survival was 22 months. Cumulative incidence of NRM was 7%, 21% and 21% at 100 days, 3 years and 5 years resp. Cumulative incidence of relapse at 1 year, 3 years and 5 years was 32%, 69% and 79% resp. OS after relapse was signifi cantly better for pts receiving DLI (median survival 29 vs 6,5 months, p= 0.048), moreover OS of relapsed pts treated with DLI was comparable with pts who never relapsed. Conclusion: Despite the fact that this is an unfavourable prognostic group of heavily pretreated patients, a third of them are longterm survivors. Undoubtedly, the main problem of allo-SCT failure is disease recurrence. Optimal timing, and the eff ort to achieve maximum of GVL eff ect using DLI provide the possibilities of further improvement of allo-SCT outcomes. The study was supported by IGA of the Czech Ministry of Health -grant No. NT 11299.

back_matter.text: Granulocyte-colony stimulating factors (G-CSFs) are commonly used to accelerate bone marrow recovery and reduce the duration of severe neutropenia after chemotherapy. Some metaanalysis demonstrate that pegylated fi lgrastim is more eff ective than fi lgrastim in reducing chemotherapy induced neutropenia. The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of pegfi lgrastim (PEG-G-CSF) administration on haematopoietic reconstitution and supportive care in patients with lymphoproliferative malignancies after autologous peripheral stem cell transplantation (autoPBSCT). We analyzed 139 patients including 61 with multiple myeloma, 38 with Hodgkin's lymphoma and 40 with non-Hodgkin's lymohoma. Patients received a single 6 mg dose of PEG-G-CSF on day +1 after transplantation (n=39) or fi lgrastim (n=70) at a dose 5 μg/kg/d on day +1 posttransplant and continued to an absolute neutrophil count (ANC)>1,5x109/L. The median consumption of fi lgrastim vials a 0,3 mg was 19 (range 1-30). The control group consisted of 30 patients who did not receive G-CSF. The median time to ANC>0,5x109/L was signifi cantly shorter in PEG-G-CSF group than in the control group (10 vs 15 days, p<0,0001) and also between patients receiving fi lgrastim and control (11 vs 15, p<0,0001). We did not fi nd diff erences in time to ANC recovery between PEG-G-CSF and fi lgrastim groups. There was also diff erence in the median time to platelet engraftment (PLT>20 x 109/L), which was signifi cantly shorter in control compared to groups receiving fi lgrastim (12 vs 13 days, p=0,04). The median number of platelet transfusions in PEG-G-CSF, fi lgrastim and control group was 12 vs 15 vs 5 units, respectively. The diff erence was signifi cant between PEG-G-CSF and control (p=0,001) and between fi lgrastim and control (p=0,001). No statistical diff erences in the number of red blood cells transfusions and duration of febrile neutropenia were seen between all groups. The length of hospitalization was signifi cantly shorter in patients receiving PEG-G-CSF compared to fi lgrastim (30 vs 37 days, p<0,0001) but longer relative to control group (30 vs 28 days, p=0,047). PEG-G-CSF signifi cantly reduce the duration of severe neutropenia but has no impact on the time of hospitalization in patients with lymphoproliferative malignancies after autoPBSCT. According to the median number of G-CSF vials used, PEG-G-CSF administration may be more cost eff ective compared to fi lgrastim (1 vs 19 vials). Our study support some previous observations that use of G-CSF can delay platelets recovery. (1) Hematologic malignancy currently represents the main indication for HSCT. Clearly, autologous and allogeneic HSCT are established therapies in many of hematologic malignancies. High dose therapy (HDT) supported by autologous HSCT are the preferred choice for relapsed/refractory Hodgkin lymphoma. Between Jan 2004 and Nov 2011, 68 patients with diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HD) underwent autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation in our center in Shiraz University of with medical sciences. Patients were treated by intensive chemotherapy followed by reinfusion of non-cryopreserved autologous stem cells. The pretransplant conditioning chemotherapy regimen was CEAM (lomustin150-200mg/m2, etoposide 1000mg/ m2, cytarabine 1000-1200mg/m2 and melphalan 140mg/m2). All apheresis products were kept in a conventional blood bank refrigerator at 4°C for 3 days before infusion. During 7 years 68 patients with relapsed or refractory HD, underwent autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation. Median age of patients was 28 years (range; 16-50). The median time to platelet count > 20×109/L was 15 days (range; 9-35). The median time to ANC > 0.5×109/L was 12 days (range; 8-27). All patients have engrafted and there were not graft failure in this study group. 100 days transplant related mortality rate was 2.9%. The mean number of MNCs collected and transfused was 3.8 × 108/kg (range, 1.9 × 108-9 × 108/kg). All patients in our study showed hematopoietic engraftment after receiving the CEAM conditioning regimen, with neutrophil and platelet recovery times comparable to those reported for most carmustine-based regimens.Our data refl ects the important role of HDT followed by HSCT in improvement of outcome for a Hodgkin's lymphoma patients of in our center. We concluded high dose therapy with this modifi ed conditioning regimen rescued with non-cryopreserved auto SCT is safe and eff ective method that is feasible in our patients. The eff ectiveness of high-dose chemotherapy (HDT) followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) as a frontline treatment in peripheral T cell lymphomas (PTCLs) is still unclear. We retrospectively investigated the clinical outcomes of HDT/ASCT as an intensifying frontline treatment in 31 patients with newly diagnosed PTCLs. The conditioning regimen of HDT/ASCT consisted of busulfan, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide (BuCyE). At diagnosis, fi ve (16.1%) patients were classifi ed as high risk according to the prognostic index for PTCL (PIT). The disease status of the patients before HDT/ASCT consisted of 23 patients (74.2%) with complete response (CR) and eight patients (25.8%) with partial response (PR). Six (75%) out of eight patients with PR at pretransplantation were improved in terms of the response to CR after HDT/ASCT. At a median follow-up of 32.4 months, the three-year probability of overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS) was 64.5 ± 8.6%. Transplant-related mortality occurred in three patients (9.7%), due to septic shock, hemorrhage and delayed pneumonia respectively. Bone marrow involvement of PTCL at diagnosis was a poor prognostic factor for OS. In conclusion, frontline HDT/ASCT with a conditioning regimen of BuCyE may be an eff ective and tolerable intensifying therapeutic option to improve outcomes in patients with PTCLs.

back_matter.text: Disease status evaluated by PET before allogeneic reduced-intensity stem cell transplantation in patients with lymphoma is a strong predictor of overall and progression-free survival G. Martin, L. Yañez, A. Bermudez, C. Richard, E. Conde, A. Insunza Hospital Marques de Valdecilla (Santander, ES) Introduction: Allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) is an alternative therapy for patients with relapsed lymphoma, but the role of positron emission tomography (PET) scanning before allogeneic SCT is uncertain. Objective: To investigate whether disease status evaluated by PET before reduced intensity allogeneic SCT predicted outcome. Patients and Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 33 patients transplanted between 2004 and June 2012. Twenty-two were male and median age was 46 years (IQL, 36-55). The diagnoses were Hodgkin lymphoma (n=15), diff use large B-cell lymphoma (n=5), follicular lymphoma (n=3), transformed follicular lymphoma (n=3), mantle cell lymphoma (n=3), peripheral T-cell lymphoma (n=3) and angioimmunoblastic lymphoma (n=1). Eighteen patients underwent HLA-matched sibling donor transplantation, 8 matched unrelated donor transplantation, 6 mismatched unrelated donor transplantation and 1 haploidentical transplantation. Except in 3 patients, fl udarabine (160 mg/m2) and melfalan (70 mg/m2) was used as the conditioning regimen. Controlled disease was defi ned by a negative PET or a unique area of weakly human cytomegalovirus immediate early promoter. FACS-sorted and cloned GFP+ cells displayed a constitutive and specifi c downregulation of HSP105, as the expression of the two major molecular chaperones, HSP90 and HSP70, was not aff ected. Despite no increase in cell death, the two best-silenced clones showed a signifi cant reduction in their in vitro proliferation rate due to a signifi cant extension in their doubling time (P= 0.04, < 0.001, and P= 0.03, 0.001). Accordingly, the tumour-forming capability of these clones, subcutaneously injected into severe combined immunodefi cient mice, was signifi cantly hampered compared with that of the MOCK-infected cells (P= 0.0009, 0.019), to the point of the complete loss of tumorigenicity when 10 4 HSP105silenced cells were inoculated (Fig 1) . Western blot analysis of 6 silenced clones showed that BCL-6 and c-Myc were both downmodulated in function of HSP105 knockdown levels. In two diff erent aggressive B-NHL cell lines, HSP105 co-immunoprecipitated with BCL-6 and c-Myc, suggesting that it may favour the stabilization of these oncoproteins. Along this line, immunohistochemistry analysis of 50 primary human aggressive B-NHLs revealed that HSP105 expression is signifi cantly higher in c-Myc+ Burkitt's (P= 0.0264) or BCL-6+ diff use large B-cell lymphomas (P= 0.0068) than in other aggressive histotypes that do not overexpress these oncoproteins. In addition, we found a signifi cant positive correlation between HSP105 and BCL-6 expression in these cases (Pearson r= 0.8537, P< 0.0001). Conclusions: Overall, these results point to HSP105 as a per se non-oncogenic molecule that can contributes to lymphomagenesis by fostering the expression of key oncoproteins. They equally provide the rationale for developing HSP105 inhibitors as a new strategy to improve the treatment of aggressive B-NHLs.

back_matter.text: High-dose chemotherapy and autologous stem cell transplantation for relapsed and refractory Hodgkin lymphoma: long term follow-up and interim evaluation of bone marrow transplant centres of Tuscany, Italy

High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (HD-ASCT) is an accepted therapy for most patients with relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma that is not controlled by conventional multiagent chemotherapy and can result in long-term progression-free survival (PFS) in a signifi cant proportion of patients. We are presenting the interim experience of the three Bone Marrow Transplant Centers of Tuscany, Italy (University of Florence, University of Pisa and University of Siena) in the effi cacy of HD-ASCT for relapsed and refractory Hodgkin lymphoma patients. Data are updated at the time of submission and Siena's data are actually under evaluation.[P1181]

High-dose chemotherapy BEAM followed by autologous peripheral stem cell transplantation in Hodgkin's lymphoma in chemo-sensitive relapse: no signifi cant diff erence in longterm outcome for patients autotransplanted in fi rst relapse or subsequent relapses A. Ibrahim (1), M. El-Saifi (2), G. Nsouli (2), R. Jalloul (2) , N. Droubi (2) , F. Farhat (2) , M. Haydar (2) , I. Chehadeh (2) , W. Mokaddem (2), H. Sadek (2) High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) is considered the gold standard of care for patients (pts) with Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) in chemosensitive relapse. In spite of this consideration, the pts autotransplanted after multiple relapses have poorer long-term outcome than those autotransplanted after a fi rst chemo-sensitive relapse. Between June, 2000 and June 2011, 35 consecutive pts with HL in chemo-sensitive relapse underwent ASCT. Median age at ASCT was 33 years (y) (18-57). There were 26 males and 9 females. All the pts received a fi rst line chemotherapy (CT) which was combined to radiotherapy in 15 pts. First line CT was ABVD in 33 pts, BEA-COPP in one patient (pt), and MOPP in one pt. Among the 35 pts, 27 underwent ASCT in fi rst chemo-sensitive relapse (2ndCR/PR) after one line of salvage CT which was ICE in 25 pts and DHAP in 2pts. Eight pts underwent ASCT after subsequent chemosensitive relapses including 7 after 2 relapses (in 3rd CR/PR) and one after 3 relapses (in 4th PR). High-dose CT consisted in BEAM protocol (carmustine, etoposide, cytarabine, melphalan). Source of transplant was peripheral stem cells in all the pts. Median follow-up was 40 months. Overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS) rates at 10y were 60% and 57%, respectively. There was no signifi cant diff erence in DFS and OS at 10y between the two groups of pts undergoing ASCT after a fi rst and subsequent sensitive relapses. Disease-free survival rates at 10y were 55.4% and 55.6% for pts autotransplanted in fi rst and subsequent sensitive relapses, respectively (p=0.933) (fi g 1), and OS rates at 10y were 58% and 66%, respectively (p=0.51)(fi g2).This study conducted in a developing country showed that if ASCT for HL in sensitive relapse is not feasible after the fi rst relapse for non medical reason, it could be performed after subsequent sensitive relapses with no diff erence in long-term outcome.

Park (7) The addition of rituximab to CHOP has resulted in signifi cant improvement in the overall survival (OS) of CD20+ diff use large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). However, OS and progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with high-intermediate or high IPI DLBCL was not satisfactory, and the upfront autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) was reported to improve the survival in these patients subset. Therefore, we retrospectively evaluated the survival rates in patients with DLBCL with CD20+, who were treated with R-CHOP followed by ASCT. We analyzed 48 DLBCL patients who underwent an ASCT, reported to the Korean Blood and Marrow Transplant Registry between 2005 and 2011 by 12 centers. The patients treated with the upfront ASCT had either stage II with bulky disease (4.2%) or stage III/IV disease (95.8%). Patients characteristics at diagnosis: median age, 48 years(range, 23-66); male, 60.4%; high LDH, 77.1%; high-intermediate or high risk by IPI score and age-adjusted IPI score, 64.6% and 79.2%, respectively. Patients characteristics at the time of ASCT: 81.3% of patients received ≥6 cycles of R-CHOP; response to R-CHOP, 77.1% CR and 22.9% PR; 12.5% of patients received involved fi eld radiotherapy prior to ASCT for bulky disease or residual lymphoma; median time from diagnosis to ASCT was 7.85 months (range, 4.4-16.1) . Median CD34+ cell count infused for ASCT was 5.0x106/kg (range, 1.10-50.47). Median time to ANC ≥500/μL and platelet ≥20,000/μL without platelet transfusion were 12 days (range, 8-25) and 18 days(range, 2-559) posttransplant, respectively. One patient died from transplantation, and lymphoma relapsed after ASCT in 11 patients. Median followup period from diagnosis was 37.4 months (range, 6.3-88.5). 3-year estimates of PFS, OS and relapse from diagnosis were 72.6±6.8%, 82.7±6.0% and 25.8±6.8%, respectively. 5-year estimates of PFS, OS and relapse from diagnosis were 72.6±6,8%, 74.4±9.5% and 25.8±6.8%, respectively. 3-year estimates of PFS and OS according to IPI score were not signifi cantly diff erent among 4 risk groups (P=0.688 and P=0.949, respectively). 3-year estimates of PFS and OS according to aaIPI score were not signifi cantly diff erent among 4 risk groups, either (P=0.890 and P=0.417, respectively). The upfront ASCT following R-CHOP induction therapy may improve survival for patients with advanced high risk DLBCL. Prospective evaluation of the treatment outcome of R-CHOP followed by ASCT is warranted for high risk DLBCL on a large scale. Background: Diff use large B-cell lymphomas (DLBCL) account approximately 30% of non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL). Their curse is aggressive but the cure is the only option that we should look for. The role of high-dose therapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (HDT/ASCT) in fi rst complete remission (CR1) is not clearly established, although several groups propose this alternative in young and fi t patients (pt) with intermediate/high or high risk features. We show our experience about HDT/ASCT in a cohort of DLBCL pt in our hospital. Patients and methods: We analyzed retrospectively 61 consecutive adult pt with DLBCL transplanted for a period of 16 years (y), (1996) (1997) (1998) (1999) (2000) (2001) (2002) (2003) (2004) (2005) (2006) (2007) (2008) (2009) (2010) (2011) (2012) . They had a median age of 49 y [18-69 y]. Thirty-six pt were transplanted in CR1, 12 pt in second or more complete remission (CR2), 10 pt in partial remission (PR) and 3 pt in refractory or progressive disease (Rf/Pg). Pt were risk-stratifi ed using International Prognosis Index (IPI). There were 26 extranodal DLBCL (42%), and 20 pt (32,8%) did not received rituximab-based therapies before HDT/ASCT. All of conditioning therapies were non-radiotherapy contained (i.e. BEAC and BEAM). Results: After a median follow-up time of near 5 y, median overall survival (OS) and relapse-free survival (RFS) was not reached. Nineteen pt (31%) dead: relapsed or progressive lymphoma in 13 pt (21%), transplant-related mortality (TRM) in 1 (1,6%) and other causes in 5. We did not observe signifi cant diff erences in OS or RFS rate considering regimens before ASCT (rituximab-contained therapies or not), site (nodal or extranodal), or response before ASCT (CR1 or PR/CR2) ( Figure 1 ). In addition, OS rate were higher considering IPI (low/intermediate-low or intermediate-high/high, p=0,021). Four pt were diagnosed of epithelial neoplasm in a median time after ASCT of 4,5 y [2-13y].

back_matter.text: Discussion: Our results are based in a series from a single centre during long-term follow-up. HDT/ASCT in DLBCL is a non-toxic proceeding with low TRM in this series. ASCT in CR2 pt showed the same OS and RFS rates than CR1, so these results suggest that proceeding might be delayed until then. Otherwise, no signifi cant diff erences were observed in RFS rates between pt with lower or higher IPI. We think that pt with lower IPI showed other risk fi gures, as bulky disease, relapsed lymphoma or higher purely extranodal lymphoma rate. These reasons were considered in clinical decisions to indicate HDT/ASCT in front-line therapy in these pt.

Prognostic factors, clinical outcome and survival of patients with relapsed or refractory Hodgkin's lymphoma after autologous stem cell transplantation F. Gaudio, D. Pastore, M. Delia, T. Perrone, P. Curci, F.E. Laddaga, G. Specchia University of Bari (Bari, IT) No standard treatment exists for relapsed or refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL) following autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT) failure, and prognosis is poor. The natural history of recurrent HL in this setting ranges from a rapidly progressive to a more indolent course. We performed a retrospective analysis of 25 adult patients (15 females/10 males) with cHL relapse/progression after ASCT in order to analyze prognostic factors, response rate and survival. Disease status at transplant was complete remission in 7 patients (28%), sensitive disease in 14 (56%), and refractory disease in 4 (16 %). Median time from ASCT to relapse was 7 months (range 0.5-72), and 44% of the patients relapsed <6 months after ASCT; 12 patients (48%) had stage 3-4 at relapse/progression. Forty percent of the patients had B symptoms, 8% bulky disease and 56% extranodal involvement. Treatment following relapse/progression consisted of the standard BEACOPP regimen in 11 patients (44%), 2nd ASCT in 5 (20%), and Bendamustine in 9 (36%). Results: Overall response rate was 64%, including 36% complete remission and 28% partial response. Thirty-four percent experienced progression and 12% had stable disease. No diff erence in response rate was found between the three treatment regimens. Factors aff ecting the response were: refractory disease, early relapse (<6 months) and more than 3 previous chemotherapy lines. Seven patients (5 in complete remission and 2 in partial remission), underwent non myeloablative allogeneic stem cell transplant (NMT) and 6 of them are still in complete remission at a median follow-up of 11 months (range 3-60). After a median follow-up of 39 months (range 1-80), PFS at 3 years from relapse/progression after ASCT was 18% and OS was 40%. To date, 15 patients (60%) are alive, nine (29%) still in complete remission (67% of them underwent NMT). All patients treated with BEACOPP and with 2nd ASCT experienced hematologic toxicity (WHO 3-4) and two deaths occurred due to septic shock. In patients treated with bendamustine, drugrelated toxicity WHO 3-4 grade was documented in 2/9 (22%) of patients, with no toxic death. Conclusions: Patients with cHL who fail ASCT have a very poor prognosis and the ultimate goal of treatment should be to refer them for NMT. New agents, including monoclonal antibody are useful in order to reduce disease burden before allo-SCT. Hodgkin lymphoma (HLy) is one of the frequently and potentially curable hematological neoplasm, most patients (pts) are curable with chemo -and radiotherapy but the rests achieve only partial remission or have relapse after treatment. High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation (AutoHCT) can off er the chance to obtain long-term survival for some patients with refractory form of HLy. In Department of Hematology and BMT Medical University of Silesia until November 2012, 390 AutoHCT in HLy patients were performed. Most of Chronic graft versus host disease (cGvHD) remains a major complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). A number of pre-clinical and clinical studies support a role for B cell involvement in the pathogenesis of cGvHD. A unique population of CD21-CD20hiCD27-B cells with features of exhaustion was recently described in patients with chronic HIV viremia. In this study we describe a similar population of CD21-B cells in the peripheral blood of cGVHD patients. Using multicolor fl ow cytometry we performed an extensive analysis of B phenotype and function in 16 patients with active cGvHD compared to 14 age-matched HSCT recipients without clinical evidence of cGVHD and 11 healthy controls. Chronic GvHD patients had signifi cantly higher frequencies of CD21-B cells in the PB compared with patients without cGvHD and HC (median 12.2% vs. 2.12% vs. 3%; p<0.01). Multi-parameter fl ow cytometry revealed that the majority of these cells were CD10-CD27-CD21 CD20hi, reminiscent of the recently described exhausted B cells in HIV patients with chronic viremia. We did not observe increased transitional (CD24hi-CD38hi-CD19+) or immature B cells (CD10+CD21-CD27-CD19+) in cGvHD patients compared with patients with no cGVHD (median transitional 3.4% vs. 6.3%; p=0.08) and [median immature (out of total CD21-B cells) 3.15 vs.9.34%; p=0.045)]. As reported in chronic HIV viremia, expanded CD21-B cells in cGVHD patients also expressed higher inhibitory receptors namely FCRL4, CD22 and CD85J, chemokine receptors CD11c, CXCR3 and lower CD62L and CCR7 compared with naïve (CD27-CD21+CD19+) and classical memory (CD27+CD21+CD19+) B cells. Moreover, B cells in patients with cGVHD had a lower proliferative potential following B-cell receptor crosslinking compared with B cells from patients with no GvHD or HC, a feature of exhaustion associated with high expression of inhibitory receptors. The frequencies of CD21-B cell were predictive for the severity of cGVHD with an OR for severe, moderate and mild cGVHD of 1.31 (p=0.001), 1.22 (p=0.005) and 1.17 (p=0.02) respectively. In multivariate analysis, previous history of aGvHD (p=0.01) and CD21-B cell frequencies > 5% (p=0.001) were the only variables found to be independently associated with cGVHD. These data suggest that CD21-B cells may play a role in the pathogenesis of cGVHD and could be used as as a marker of disease severity.

back_matter.text: Prognostic factors for survival of graft-versus-host disease occurring later than 100 days after allogeneic stem cell transplantation F. Ayuk, T. Zabelina, R. Veit, L. Bussmann, C. Wolschke, H. Lellek, U. Bacher, A.R. Zander, N. Kröger University Medical Center Hamburg (Hamburg, DE) Introduction: Chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT). Only few studies addressing survival of patients who developed cGVHD used the recently introduced NIH consensus criteria. Methods: We retrospectively analysed 495 consecutive adult patients who underwent allo-SCT at our center between 2005 and 2009. GVHD occurring ≥ 100 days after allo-SCT was classifi ed as late acute or chronic GvHD. cGVHD was retrospectively categorized according to NIH consensus criteria and considered progressive onset if diagnosed ≤ 2 weeks of end of steroid treatment for aGVHD or quiescent onset if diagnosed > 2 weeks after end of steroid treatment for aGVHD. GVHD was categorized as overlap syndrome if cGVHD and acute gastrointestinal GVHD were present. Survival was estimated from time of diagnosis of cGVHD. Results: In all 412 patients were evaluable for GVHD ≥ 100 days after allo-SCT of whom 179 (43%) developed no GVHD, 32 (8%) developed late acute GVHD, 182 (44%) classic cGVHD and 19 (5%) overlap syndrome. Of the 201 patients with cGVHD 66 (33%) were categorized de novo onset, 123 (61%) quiescent onset and 12 (6%) progressive onset. Late acute GVHD was associated with worse 3 yr. survival (38%) compared to classic cGVHD (73%) and overlap syndrome (76%) p < 0.001. In patients with cGVHD platelet counts less than 100.000/ul at time of cGVHD diagnosis was associated with worse 3 year survival 51% vs. 80% (p< 0.001). 3 year survival according to NIH overall stage was 58% for severe, 69% for moderate and 79% for mild cGVHD (p= 0.174). After excluding patients with myeloma, low IgG level at diagnosis also negatively impacted survival with 3 year survival rates of 74% for normal, 79% for decreased and 47% (7 months) for increased IgG level (p= 0.04). In multivariate analysis only platelet counts at diagnosis (RR = 3.24; 95% CI = 1.81-5.80; p< 0.001) and patient age (RR = 1.03; 95% CI = 1.01-1.06; p= 0.01) signifi cantly impacted survival of patients with cGVHD. Conclusion: Our results confi rm the negative prognostic impact of low platelet counts and late acute GVHD and indicate that these are still the parameters with strongest impact and highest consistency even in the era of the NIH classifi cation. We suggest a prognostic role of serum IgG level that merits further investigation. S438 P1193 Successful use of autologous platelet rich plasma (PRP) in the management of ocular chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) F. Zallio (1) Purpose: Allogeneic (allo)-SCT represents a potentially curative treatment option for many hematological malignancies; the widespread use of this procedure has, however, a number of important limitations. Ocular chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) is one of the most frequent complications after allo-SCT and is often associated with signifi cant morbidity and reduced quality of life. The main therapeutic aim in the management of ocular cGVHD is the treatment of infl ammation and dryness in order to decrease patients' symptoms and to maintain ocular integrity and function. Unfortunately conventional medical treatments, represented by systemic immunosuppressive and local therapies (mainly artifi cial tears and corticosteroids), off er unsatisfactory results. Methods: We investigated the safety and effi cacy of autologous platelet rich plasma (PRP) to treat ocular cGVHD unresponsive to standard medications. From 2007 to 2012 we treated with PRP eye drops 18 patients who underwent to allogeneic SCT and aff ected by ocular GVHD refractory to local steroid therapy. PRP eye drops were used six times/day for one year. PRP eye drops are prepared under laminar fl ow hood, in sterile single dose, stored at -20°C. Patients were evaluated through subjective (symptoms pointed out in a self-assessment questionnaire) and objective tests (Schirmer test, FBUT, BVA, anterior segment score, fl uorescein score, lissamine score) by the same ophthalmologist at time 0, 30, 180 and 365. Results: Patients were defi ned as "responders" if they had showed at least one sign: at 30 days 86% and 57% of the patients had an improvement of symptoms (S) and ocular signs (T), respectively and 0% had corneal damage; these response was kept on throughout the treatment period: in fact after one year of treatment 86% and 43% continued to have an amelioration of their symptoms (S) and ocular signs (T), respectively, while 7% had corneal damage. Conclusions: Therapy with autologous PRP eye drops is easy to use, safe and low cost; this procedure shows an improvement of symptoms and corneal damage already since 30 days of treatment, with a progressive improvement in quality of life and return to daily activities; in addition it is worthwhile to demonstrate that the effi cacy is maintained throughout the year of treatment. Therefore autologous PRP eye drops could represent a valid alternative option to conventional therapy in the management of ocular cGVHD. Introduction: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is the leading complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and causes signifi cant morbidity and mortality. CD4+ T-cells play a critical role in mediating GVHD, and much eff ort has been devoted to studying the eff ect of CD4+ T-cells during the pathophysiology process of GVHD. Even though just accounting for 5% of the total CD4+ T-cell population, the most promising candidates are naturally occurring CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells (Tregs), which are one of the regulators of immune responses. TH17 is a newly identifi ed T-cell lineage that secretes IL-17, a proinfl ammatory cytokine. However, the functional role of TH17 cells in the development of GVHD has not been well characterized in humans. The aim of our study was to characterize the expression of Treg (FOXP3) and TH17-related (RORγt) genes in peripheral blood of patients undergoing HSCT and correlate them with the development of GVHD in allogeneic HSCT.Patients and Methods: Samples were collected from the peripheral blood of 50 patients before and after HSCT and at the time of GVHD onset. Thirty patients were diagnosed as acute leukemia/myelodysplastic syndrome, eleven as chronic myeloid leukemia and ten with lymphomas. Seven healthy donors were used as controls. All patients received an HLA-identical related donor graft.Expression of FOXP3 and RORγt were assessed by Real-Time quantitative PCR (qPCR) using the 7500 Fast Real Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems), by Taqman method. Results: Median age for the 50 analyzed patients was 36 years-old (range: 17-60), 52% were female. 50% had GVHD, with an average onset of 39 days after HSCT for acute GVHD (range: 12-93) and 182 days for chronic . No signifi cant association was observed between FOXP3 expression and patients with or without GVHD. On the other hand, RORγt showed significantly higher expression in patients with chronic GVHD compared to samples before HSCT (p<0.0001), without GVHD (p<0.0001) and acute GVHD (p=0.0006). Both FOXP3 and RORγt showed signifi cant statistical decreased expression in patients compared to healthy controls, except for RORγt expression in patients with chronic GVHD (p=NS). Conclusion: RORγt showed signifi cantly higher expression in patients with chronic GVHD compared to samples before HSCT, without GVHD and acute GVHD, suggesting that a proinfl ammatory state is involved in chronic GVHD pathophysiology.

The device was designed to supersede the UVAR XTS TM , introduced in 1998. The newer device off ers simultaneous blood collection and return via continuous fl ow modality resulting in reduced extracorporeal volumes compared to single-needle confi guration. We and others have reported diff erences in the leucocyte harvests generated by the 2 devices. To examine whether the introduction of the Cel-lex™ device has impacted on clinical and steroid dose response we compared patients treated with either device. Methods: cGvHD patients treated either exclusively with the Cellex (n=50) or the XTS device (n=51) for a minimum period of 6 months, were included. Clinical assessment of organ involvement and then response was taken prior to ECP start and at 3,6 and 12 rates in our cohort. However, the Cellex device may off er shorter median in-treatment time for patients due to continuous fl ow technology.

back_matter.text: The Impact of lung chronic GVHD on survival after cord blood transplantation S. Kato (1) Chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) is major cause of mortality and impairs patient's quality of life after allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Especially, the prognosis of patients suff ered from lung cGVHD is poor. Although incidence and severity of cGVHD after cord blood transplantation (CBT) is lower than those after bone marrow transplantation, impact of cGVHD on survival has not been analyzed enough in CBT. We have investigated the eff ects of cGVHD on outcomes of CBT. One-hundred-eighty adult patients with various hematological diseases underwent CBT after myeloablative conditioning containing 12Gy total body irradiation in the Institute of Medical Science, University of Tokyo between August 1998 and August 2012. Among them, we have analyzed 153 patients who survived more than 100 days after CBT. Eighty-six patients (56%) were categorized as standard risk (CR1,CR2,CML-CP,NHLCR-u,MDS-RA, MDS-RCMD, AA) and 67 (44%) were high risk(others)in disease status. All patients received single cord blood unit and acute GVHD prophylaxis with cyclosporine plus short-term methotrexate . Median age was 41(range:18-55years, median weight was 57(37-104) kg, median numbers of cryopreserved nucleated and CD34 positive cells were 2.5(1.3-3.7)×107/kg and 0.9(0.2-7.8)×105/kg, respectively. Variables considered in statistical analyses were age,weight,disease risk,total nucleated and CD34 positive cell dose, positivity of CMV, sex ,ABO and HLA mismatches.The impact of cGVHD was assessed as a time-dependent covariate using Cox models. Median follow up period of survivors (N=124) was 80(3-174) months after transplant.Cumulative incidence of extended type cGVHD (extGVHD) and lung cGVHD at 5 years after CBT were 34 (95% confi dence interval [CI], 26-41)and 20(95%CI, 13-26)%, respectively. The 5years probabilities of overall survival of patients with/without extGVHD and with/without lung GVHD were 73 (95% CI, 57-84) %/85 (95% CI, 75-91) % (p<0.05) and 67 (95% CI, 44-82) %/84 (95% CI, 76-90) % (p<0.05). The cumulative incidences of relapse between patients with/ without extGVHD or those of lung GVHD were similar. However, the 5-years cumulative incidences of non-relapse mortality (NRM) was higher in patients with both extGVHD [1 (0-3) %vs 18 (7-30)%; P<0.05] and lung GVHD [3 (0-5) % vs 25 (8-43)%; P<0.01]. It is suggested that patients developing lung GVHD had significantly poor survival due to increasing NRM. This is the fi rst analysis evaluating the impact of lung GVHD on patients after CBT. derived MP levels. However there was no signifi cant diff erence in plasma levels of MPs in patients with and without chronic GVHD. In a previous study by Pihusch R et al patients with chronic GVHD demonstrated seven fold increased levels of circulating platelet derived MPs. In that report blood samples were analysed when patients showed signs of chronic GVHD, however our patients were already on immunosupressive treatment for chronic GVHD. Objective: To analize BO as a severe complication of allo-SCT in order to identify risk factors, response to specifi c treatment and overall survival. Material And Methods: Retrospective study in 439 patients who have undergone allo-SCT between 2002 and 2012 in our centre. From the 350 analizable ones for chronic GVHD,41 were diagnosed of BO (11,7%): probable BO when they only showed clinical, radiologic and spirometric characteristics (19 patients), and proven BO if they also met histological criteria (22 patients). The median age at SCT was 52 and 22/19 were men/ women. Allo-SCT was related in 22 patients and unrelated in the other 19, with a missmatched donor in 10 cases (24%). Conditioning regimen was ablative in 28(68%), including radiotherapy in 7 cases, and 6 patients had undergone a SCT before. GVHD prophilaxis was based on calcioneurin inhibitors (Ciclosporine in 88%), with Methrotexate in 21patients and Micofenolate in 18.ATG was employed in 6 cases. Stem cell source was peripheral blood in 10 (24%). >grade1 acute GVHD was observed in 26 patients (63%), and 23 were good responders to corticosteroids (15CR and 8PR). Extensive chronic GVHD, basically mucocutaneous, was observed in 35 patients (85%) before the onset of BO. Median time from allo-SCT to chronic GVHD was 9 months and, from the 15 patients (37%) with pulmonary tests, the median FEV1 decrease was 35% [0-69]. Median time from chronic GVHD to BO was 2 months [0-31]. All patients were treated with bronchodilators and corticosteroids: 9 (22%) at high doses, and 21 (51%) in combination with another immunosupressor. 15 patients (37%) needed outpatient oxygen support. Results: Estimated overall survival (OS) was 56% at 2 years and 47% at 5 years,with a median follow-up of 19 months [8-115] from the diagnosis of BO. 22 patients are alive by now (54%), half of them without treatment and with ECOG0. 19 patients died, 12 of them (63%) because of BO. We found signifi cant diff erences in 2 variables: need of treatment (OS if independent: 100% at 2 years, and if dependent: 39%, p<0.001) and time to develop BO (OS if < 1 year: 48% at 2 years and if > 1year: 77%, p=0.008). Conclusions: BO related to GVHD involves high mortality in our series. Early BO onset and high dose corticosteroids/ immunosuppressive therapy seem to decrease the OS. Pulmonary tests could help with an earlier diagnosis of BO.

Background: Extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP) is recognised as a second-line treatment option for chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD). There are few reports of the eff ect of ECP on patients' quality of life. Objective: To prospectively assess the impact of ECP on healthrelated quality of life in patients with chronic GvHD using two validated questionnaires. Methods: We report a single-centre prospective study of patients undergoing fortnightly ECP. Response was assessed after 6 months of treatment using National Institutes for Health scoring criteria and reduction in immunosuppression. Patients completed a formal assessment of quality of life at baseline and after six months of treatment using the chronic GvHD symptom scale (cGvHD SS) and dermatology life quality index (DLQI). Results: Eighteen patients (8 male, 10 female) completed the cGvHD SS at baseline and after six months of ECP. 14 patients had received a transplant from an unrelated donor and 4 from a sibling donor. 15 patients had moderate GvHD and 3 had severe GvHD. 15 had classic chronic GvHD, 2 had overlap syndrome and 1 had developed GvHD post donor lymphocyte infusions. 14 patients had cutaneous GvHD. Other organs involved were: mouth (9), liver (4), ocular (9), gastrointestinal tract (3), lung (2), musculoskeletal (4), gynaecological (1). Ten patients were receiving 2 immunosuppressive drugs at start of ECP, 4 were receiving one drug, 3 were receiving 3 drugs and one patient was not receiving any immunosuppression. Baseline cGvHD SS scores ranged from 8/120 to 64/120 with a median score of 38/120. 17/18 (94%) showed an improvement in scores. The mean cGvHD SS was signifi cantly lower after 6 months of ECP (22 compared to 36, p=0.012). Sixteen patients completed the DLQI at both time points. Baseline scores ranged from 0/30 to 15/30 with a median of 7/30. The mean score was signifi cantly lower after 6 months of ECP treatment (3.4 compared to 6.9, p=0.009). 13/18 (72%) patients had a partial clinical response and 1 had a complete response. Two patients had a mixed response, one a minimal response and one patient had progressive disease. All the patients who had a complete or partial response had an improvement in both scores except for one. 9/15 (60%) patients receiving steroid therapy at baseline had a > 50% dose reduction. Conclusion: ECP may lead to an improvement in quality of life in patients with GvHD in addition to clinical response and reduction of immunosuppression.

back_matter.text: The chronic GVHD Symptom Bother Scale, known as the Lee cGVHD Scale is a patient reported instrument developed and validated in English to measure symptoms and functional losses in patients with chronic GVHD. Lee cGVHD Scale includes 30 questions with 7 subscale containing 2 to 7 symptoms items representing domains of skin, mouth, respiratory system, gastro intestinal system, energy and pshychological status. This study objectives include translate S445 and validate the Lee cGVHD Scale in Portuguese among Brazilian patients with chronic GVHD and to assess the correlation with other quality of life (QoL) instruments. Inclusion criteria was adult patients with chronic GVHD diagnosed according to the 2005 NIH consensus criteria. Exclusion criteria included inability to answer the questionnaires, less than six months of life expectancy due to co-morbidity or relapse of primary disease. The study was approved by the institutional review board of all participating centers and all patients signed an Informed Consent for the study. Methods: A cross-sectional multicenter study was conducted by the Brazil-Seattle chronic GVHD Consortium (Grupo de Estudos da Doença do Enxerto versus Hospedeiro Crônica Brasil-Seattle, GeDECHc Brasil-Seattle) between April 2011 to August 2012. Methodology used to translate into Portuguese and validate Lee cGVHD instrument was according to the American Association of Orthopedic Surgeons (AAOS) Outcome Committee guideline. All patients answered the Brazilian version of the Lee cGVHD Scale questionnaire and also completed two QoL questionnaires: the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36 (SF-36) and the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy with Bone Marrow Transplant subscale (FACT-BMT). Spearman's correlation coeffi cient was used to measure construct validity. Reliability was assessed using Cronbach's α and intraclass correlation coeffi cients. Results: A total of 47 patients from fi ve Brazilian Institutions participated in this study. The cohort median age was 48 years (23-69) and 29 (61.7%) were male. Lee cGVHD Scale reliability was adequate (Cronbach's α 0.62-0.83). Spearman's correlations between similar dominium's of Lee cGVHD Scale, SF-36 and FACT-BMT were moderate and high, as expected. Brazilian Portuguese version of Lee chronic GVHD Scale is valid, reliable, and may add value to assess treatment response and quality of life in clinical trials of patients with chronic GVHD in Brazil.

back_matter.text: Background: Tacrolimus is an established immunosuppressant for the prevention and treatment of graft-versus-host disease (GvHD). The aim of this study was to determine the effi cacy and safety in allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) patients converted from continuous infusion tacrolimus (TAC cont. IV) or twice-daily tacrolimus (TAC BID) to once-daily prolonged release of tacrolimus formation (TAC OD). Patients and Methods: We have retrospectively analyzed the records of 51 adult patients who underwent allo-HSCT and have treated with TAC OD in our hospital before December 2011. The dose conversion ratio between TAC cont. IV and TAC OD was 1:5, TAC BID and TAC OD was 1:1. Tacrolimus trough level has checked day0 and day7. Laboratory parameters (total cholesterol, triglyceride, fasting blood sugar, brain natriuretic peptide, estimated glomerular filtration rate) and adverse events were assessed. Results: The underlying disease was Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in 11 patients, Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) in 13, MDS overt AML in 10, Acute lymphoblastic leukemia in 8, Malignant lymphoma in 7, Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma in 2. The conditioning regimen was myeloablative regimen in 26 and non-myeloablative in 25. The donor source was sibling-donor in 16, unrelated-donor in 31, cord blood in 4. In all patients, tacrolimus was started at 0.02mg/kg/day as continuous infusion from day -1 or -3. All patients were combined with short-methotrexate and 2 patients with anti-thymocyte globulin. After engraftment, 11 patients were first changed to TAC OD from TAC cont. IV, and 40 patients to TAC BID and changed to TAC OD from TAC BID at the TAC concentration stable. GvHD status when converted to TAC OD was no sign of GvHD in 24, and acute or chronic GvHD in 27. After one week, TAC concentrations were lower in 20 patients (7 patients from TAC cont. IV) and higher in 9 patients when compared with baseline. By changing TAC BID to TAC OD, there were only 3 patients to GvHD got worse, but TAC cont. IV, 5patients got worse. All laboratory parameters were not significantly different. Adverse events were consistent with the safety profile known from previous studies with TAC BID. In 32 patients, chronic GvHD has been improved gradually during treated with TAC OD, but in 5 patients, lung GvHD has not improved. Conclusion: Conversion to TAC OD is eff ective and safe, enhances immunosuppressant adherence and should be accompanied by a close tacrolimus level monitoring during the initial period.

back_matter.text: Introduction: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is a curative treatment for many hematological disorders. Chronic graft-versushost disease (GVHD) is a serious complication that appears in 20-70% of the patients. There are some described cases of patients with nephrotic syndrome after bone marrow transplantation(BMT) as an expression of GVHD.The objective of our study is to analyze patients with allogenic BMT who developed a glomerular pathology as an expression of GVHD. Material and methods: We analyzed all patients who underwent allogenic BMT in our hospital from October 1995 to June 2011 who developed a glomerular pathology after the transplant. Chronic GVHD was defi ned in patients who survived >100 days after allogenic BMT.The diff erent clinical and analytical variables of patients with chronic kidney GVHD were studied. Results: Five hundred and ten allogenic BMT patients were analyzed. The age range was 1-69 years old ( Table 1 ). The prevalence of chronic kidney GVHD was 0.784%. All patients with renal GVHD, were patients with BMT of peripheral blood, identical HLA. GVHD prophylaxis was administered with methotrexate and ciclosporin, and in 1 patient, this treatment was replaced by tacrolimus due to neurological toxicity. Chronic kidney GVHD appeared after removal of the GVHD prophylaxis with proteinuria levels of 2.65-15.46 g/day secondary to membranous glomerulonephritis, focal segmental glomerulonephritis and lupic nephropathy class III. After the start of the immunosuppressant treatment with corticoids in all patients and anti-calcineurin drugs in 3 patients,complete remission was achieved.In 3 patients under complete remission, recurrence of the glomerular pathology was observed when the immunosuppressant therapy was removed, which led to the re-introduction of the treatment. Conclusions: Chronic GVHD with renal involvement is a rare entity associated to the removal of immunosuppressant therapy which usually appears with proteinuria. Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most common histology. It can be useful to monitor proteinuria levels in these patients.-In our population,we identifi ed the following risk factors for GVHD of the kidney: donor/recipient gender disparity, positive results for CMV, peripheral blood BMT, and the presence of previous acute or chronic GVHD.-Complete remission was achieved in all cases of chronic GVHD of the kidney, but some outbreaks appeared after removal of the immunosuppressant therapy. We must consider a diff erent therapeutic approach for glomerular pathology secondary to chronic GVHD.

Purpose: Montpellier University Hospital performs therapeutic apheresis since 1978. In 2011, 1217 procedures were performed with 40% plasma exchanges (TPE), 32% extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP), 16% Stem cells collection and lymphocyte collection.[P1210] S447 Two Spectra (Terumo BCT), one Com.Tec (Fresenius) and one Optia (Terumo BCT) are currently used. We evaluated the Amicus Separator (Fenwal) as an alternate platform to collect lymphocytes for off line ECP. The objective was to assess procedure performance, safety and compatibility with off -line technique. Methods: A total of 21 procedures to collect Mononuclear cells (MNC) for ECP were evaluated between June and August 2012 in patients with GVHD (14), cutaneous T-cell lymphomas (4), lichen planus (2), systemic lupus erythematosus (1). One total blood volume was targeted to process. Maximum whole blood fl ow rate was 60 ml/min. The software version was 4.3. The procedure settings were MNC off set 1.5ml, RBC off set 5.0 ml, plasma fl ush 8ml, WB per cycle 2000ml for patient with WBC count < 5 x 10E9/l and 1400ml for patient with WBC count > 5 x 10E9/l. The illumination procedure post collection was performed after addition of 8-MOP (Macopharma) using a UVA PIT System device (Med Tech Solution). The 21 Amicus procedures were compared with historical data for Spectra (N=260), Optia (N=174) and Com.Tec (N=198). The performance was evaluated based on 1) lymphocyte collection yield and purity; 2) patient PLT depletion; 3) procedure time (reinfusion included) and 4) adverse events during the collection procedure. Results: The average blood volume treated was 1.02 for Amicus, 1.04 for Spectra, 0.95 Optia and 0.95 for Com.Tec. Yield and purity of collected products are presented in table 1. Adverse events with Amicus were mild. No citrate related reaction was observed. Conclusions: Monocytes and lymphocytes collection effi ciency with Amicus was satisfactory and comparable to other platforms with signifi cantly lower platelet depletion from the patient. Yield and purity of the Amicus collected product are predictable and show less variability than with Optia. The full automation of the Amicus machine was well appreciated by the operators who keep the opportunity to adjust parameters during the procedure.

back_matter.text: Treatment and outcome of bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome following allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation S. Fritsch (1)

Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS) is a late pulmonary complication after allogeneic stem cell transplantation and is associated with signifi cant morbidity and mortality. Unfortunately diagnosis and treatment of BOS still remain diffi cult. Extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP) has shown effi cacy in treatment of chronic graft versus host disease (cGvHD) as well as BOS. According to the National Institute of Health (NIH) Consensus Criteria for diagnosis of BOS after allogeneic stem cell transplantation 26 patients (pts) at our centre were diagnosed with BOS between 2003 and 2012. All patients (median age 52 years) were treated by corticosteroids including inhalative application forms. 19 patients (73%) additionally received ECP treatment for a minimum of 3 months. Improvement of pulmonary function, clinical symptoms and outcome were analyzed. The donors were HLA identical siblings in 8 patients, HLA-mismatched siblings in 2 patients, HLAcompatible unrelated donors in 11 patients and unrelated donors with one HLA-mismatch in 5 patients. 6 Patients presented with de novo cGvHD, 6 with quiescent and 14 with progressive cGvHD. Manifestation of BOS, diagnosed by the NIH criteria for diagnosis of BOS, was in median detected at day 343 after transplantation (range day 126-1679). FEV1 and FEV1/FVC as parameters of pulmonary function were monitored continuously during treatment. At diagnosis of BOS FEV1/FVC was less than 50% in 4 pts, less than 60% in 8 pts and between 60% and 70% in 14 pts. 3 patients showed a FEV1 of less than 35% predicted, 9 between 36% and 50% and 14 between 51% and 75%. Improvement of lung function was defi ned as 10% increase of FEV1. Response to treatment measured by pulmonary function tests was observed in 10 of 26 pts (38,5%) and clinical response in 12 pts (46,2%). Overall survival (OS) after a follow up between 280 and 3469 days was 65,4% and median OS was 958 days. Additional treatment with ECP had no positive impact on survival: OS was 58% in the ECP group compared to 86% in the other group. Cause of death was progressive BOS and GvHD in 7 patients, relapse of leukemia in one and unknown in one patient. BOS and cGvHD were confi rmed as life threatening complications after allogeneic stem cell transplantation. In our patient cohort additional treatment with ECP for BOS did not improve survival. To evaluate the eff ect of ECP in BOS treatment further studies should be performed. E. Jakob, A. Knoll, K. Brandauer, B. Dobner, G. Auff arth, P. Dreger, U. Hegenbart, F. back_matter.text: S448 We hypothesized that a decrease of goblet cells in the conjunctival epithelium can serve as a predictive marker for an emerging oGvHD. To assess goblet cell density we compared the more invasive impression cytology (IC) with the less invasive in vivo confocal microscopy (IVCM). Methods: Patients who were listed for HSCT were examined before and 100 days after the transplantation. The examination included a questionnaire, slit lamp examination, Schirmer Test II, impression cytology and confocal microscopy of the conjunctiva with the Heidelberg Retina Tomograph with the Rostock Cornea Modul attachment (HRT-RCM). At least three specimen/pictures of each patient were assessed for goblet cell density and means were calculated. Approval of the Ethical Review Board Heidelberg and informed consent was obtained. Results: 44 patients were included (mean age 56 years). 18 patients were not re-examined after HSCT (4 died, 2 were pre fi nal, 2 were not transplanted, 10 repeatedly cancelled their follow-up examination due to poor health). Mean time to follow-up examination was 147 days after HSCT. Goblet cell density before and after HSCT of all patients with evaluable pre-and post HSCT -examination was 52.6±7.5 vs. 43.9±4.1 cells/mm2 (Mean±SEM, p=0.46, n=8, wilcoxon's signed rank) assessed with IC and 62.7±3.4 vs 61.6 ±4.3 Zellen/mm2 (p=0.8, n=24) assessed with IVCM. 8 healthy subjects were examined via IVCM as control (mean age 38 years), mean goblet cell density was 74.8 ± 4.3 cells/mm 2 . Conclusions: IVCM showed goblet cell numbers in similar magnitude to the standard method IC, we therefore conclude that IVCM can also reliably be used. Conjunctival goblet cells did not show a signifi cant decrease after HSCT. The time interval to follow-up examination may have been too short as most patients still were on immunosuppressants and only 2 had signs of oGvHD. Patients who present with oGvHD symptoms will be re-examined for goblet cell density in our clinic.

Low-dose methotrexate for treatment of severe and overlap chronic graft-versus-host disease G. Levati, R. Greco, E. Sala, E. Guggiari, S. Malato, S. Marktel, M.G. Carrabba, S. Claudiani, M. Marcatti, F. Lunghi, A. Assanelli, M. Bernardi, J. Peccatori, C. Corti, F. Ciceri, M. Lupo-Stanghellini San Raff aele Scientifi c Institute (Milan, IT) Background: Graft-versus-Host-Disease (GvHD) is a serious complication after allogeneic stem cell transplantation: frequent cause of late morbidity and non-relapse-mortality. Steroids are the treatment of choice to control GvHD manifestation, but for steroid-refractory GvHD alternative options are of need. In view of the anti-infl ammatory and antiproliferative properties and its successful use in patients (pts) with autoimmune disorders, low dose methotrexate (MTX) is an option mainly for skin and oral manifestations of cGVHD. Methods: We describe here the data from a retrospective study in our transplanted pts in order to assess the effi cacy of MTX in GvHD therapy. Pts were treated between Jan-2011 and Oct-2012. Results: Overall 13 pts with GvHD were treated with a starting dose of 7.5 mg/m2 weekly of MTX. Only 1 pt was treated for acute GvHD but the drug was discontinued after 2 weeks due to pancitopenia and worsening of liver function. Pts characteristics are reported in table 1, of note 11 pts had a severe chGvHD and 7 an overlap chGvHD. Three out of 13 pts had to discontinue therapy with MTX (median 2 administration) due to the onset of hepatic toxicity (grade II-III). Nine pts were able to receive a proper treatment for a median time of 9 months (range 2-20). All of them had skin involvement, 7 eye and 5 notes of scleroderma or fasciitis. After the introduction of MTX 5 pts completely resolved skin GvHD, 2 had major response, 1 partial response (reduction of sclerodermic features and reduction of Rodnam score from 19 to 5.5), 1 pt is so far stable after 2 months of treatment. In our records scleroderma/fasciitis improved with MTX in 4/5 pts, one pt shows stabilization -table 2a.At the start of MTX 6 pts were assuming steroid-therapy with a mean dosage of 0.25mg/kg/day; 3 pts succeeded in discontinuing the therapy with prednisone and the other 3 encountered a substantial reduction of the steroid dosage -table 2b. Furthermore, all pts were also receiving several lines of immunosuppressive treatment (IST): 7/9 pts reduced the IST during therapy with MTX, no case of strengthening of IST. Discussion: A global evaluation of all 9 pts shows an improvement of the chGvHD in the totality of them. As previously reported, lowdose MTX show good tolerance and easy manageability. Longterm use seems feasible. So far, from our data, we can state that MTX seems an eff ective choice as steroid-sparing agent in severe chGvHD and, of interest, in overlap chGvHD therapy.

back_matter.text: Long-term follow up of allogeneic PBSC transplantation in B-thalassemia major, with a low incidence of chronic GVHD: a single centre experience of 118 patients G. Fathy, A. El-Haddad, M. Abdel-Mooti, R. Abd El Fattah, O. Fahmy, H. Mahmoud Nasser institute hospital for research&treatment (Cairo, EG) Background: Allogeneic HSCT is the only curative approach for patients with B-Thalassemia Major (BTM). Compared to PBSCs, BM is the preferred source of engraftment with an expected lower incidence of cGVHD. Aims: Back in 1997, when we started our transplant program at Nasser Institute (Cairo, Egypt), the vast majority of our patients, including those with BTM, recieved PBSCs; and we published some of our encouraging results regarding engraftment, GVHD incidence & outcome (HK Mahmoud et al. Bone Marrow Transplant. 1999; 24:355) . Thus, in this single arm in this single arm prospective study, we investigated the same approach on a wider b-thalassemia patient scale, with a much longer follow up to, eventually, evaluate the incidence & severity of cGVHD, as well as EFS & OS (Primary end points). Patients & methods: In the time period between November 1997 and March 2010, 118 BTM patients received allogeneic HLA-Matched sibling PBSCT at the BMT unit of Nasser institute, Cairo, Egypt. Mean age of patients was 5.6(Range=15 months -18 years). The regimen consisted of Bu at a total dose of 16 mg/Kg, a total Cy dose of 120mg/kg and a total ATG dose of 110 mg/Kg.Cyclosporine & Methotrexate were used for GVHD prophylaxis.Results: The mean number of infused CD34+ve cells was 7.2 x 106 /kg recipient weight. All patients engrafted promptly at a median of 17 days for neutrophils and 19 days for platelets. The total incidence of cGVHD was 9% ,while that of grade 2-4 acute GVHD was 3.3%. Incidence of primary graft failure did not exceed 6. At a follow up period of up to 13 years (median 7.9 years), OS&EFS were 89 %, with 70% of patients having complete chimerism and 19% stable mixed chimerism, all of whom are transfusion independent. Conclusion: Allografting BTM patients using PBSCs instead of BM, is a signifi cantly easier & safer approach for the donor, with promising outcome regarding engraftment, DFS & OS. Finally, Our results showed signifi cantly lower incidence of cGVHD, compared to that reported with BM stem cells. Introduction: Interest in defi ning the role of immunomodulation of graft versus host disease (GVHD) by ultraviolet radiation has recently increased, since systemic immunosuppression (IS) is associated with high morbidity and mortality. We have been using at our institution three modalities of phototherapy -PUVA (psor-S450 alen+ ultraviolet A), UVBNB (ultraviolet B narrow band) and extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP) -to treat diff erent manifestations of cutaneous GVHD for the last 22 years. Objective: Report the applicability, indications and benefi cial eff ects of each phototherapy modality in the treatment of GVHD in a single institution. Methods: Puvatherapy was used in 55 patients to treat lichen planus like and sclerodermic chronic GVHD(cGVHD) with no visceral involvement. UVBNB was used in 15 patients for vitiligo, limited lichen planus like cGVHD, those with psoralen intolerance and children. ECP was reserved to treat 36 patients with extensive sclerodermic, fasciíte cGVHD, systemic cGVHD and 11 patients with acute GVHD (grade III and IV) as second or third line therapy. It was not feasible to evaluate median time of sessions until an answer or time for reducing IS, because there was great heterogeneity of disease severity and systemic treatment adopted.Results: From the 55 patients treated with PUVA, 23(42%) achieved complete response, 16(29%) partial response, 9(16,3%) no response and 7(12,7%) were too early to evaluate (in treatment). Immunosuppression was withdrawn in 27 patients and reduced in 12. Three patients treated with UVBNB achieved complete response, 8 partial response, 2 no response and 2 were still under treatment. In 7 patients, IS was suspended and in 4 reduced. FEC was performed in 36 cGVHD steroid refractory patients. Eight (22%) achieved complete response and 19(53%) partial response with global response in 75%. Immunossupression was withdrawn in 3 and reduced in 24. Among the 11 acute GVHD patients submitted to FEC, 6(54.5%) responded well. Conclusion: PUVA and UVBNB is a topical direct therapy and should be considered in patients in whom the increase of systemic IS leads to high risk of infection or interference with the graft-versus-tumor effect. ECP is indicated to patients not responsive to corticosteroids, those with IS toxicity or those who need early withdrawal of IS (high risk of relapse of malignant disease). Phototherapy modalities are safe, effective and should be individualized for the type of cutaneous GVHD. Introduction and objectives: Chronic graft versus host disease (GVHD) of the lung, also known as bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS), is a serious complication after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Therapy of BOS includes topical treatment and systemic treatment with corticosteroids and immunosuppressive therapy. However, when medical treatment fails, lung transplantation (LTX) may be indicated as the ultimate treatment option. Methods: We searched our institutional data base for lung and bone marrow transplantation and three patients were found with an history of both procedure performed. We collected demographic and outcome data about transplant procedures. Results: Between 1998 and 2005, 3 patients (2 females and 1 male), with a median age of 24 years (range 21-49), underwent alloHSCT because of myelodisplastic syndrome, B-precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia and multiple myeloma. In all cases, donors were HLA identical siblings while the cell source was the bone marrow for one patient and the peripheral blood for the other two. No patient presented acute GVHD and in all cases a de novo chronic GVHD developed and, eventually, respiratory failure. LTX was needed after a median time of 4 years (range 3-9) from HSCT. Bilateral LTX was performed in 2 out of 3 patients, cardiopulmonary bypass in 2 and only one of them required tracheostomy (before LTX). All patients are alive and in hematological complete remission after a median follow-up of 5 years (range 4-6) from LTX. One of them developed acute lung rejection 2 years after LTX that was successfully treated with high dose steroids even though the late follow up was also complicated by chronic rejection. At last follow up his pulmonary function tests (PFTs) by spirometry show a severe reduction of the diff using capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) and severe restrictive and obstructive changes of the lung volumes. This patient is currently being considered for a second LTX. The other two patients are leading an active life, are currently maintained on immunosuppressive therapy with tacrolimus, everolimus and prednisone and their PFTs show normal or middle reduction of DLCO and lung volumes with stable values over time. Conclusion: Our data indicate that lung transplantation may represent an eff ective treatment option of BOS with remarkable improvement of the quality of life. In selected good prognosis HSCT patients, lung transplantation should not be unnecessarily delayed or refused. (1) Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) represents an innovative therapeutical option, however data supporting the efficacy are limited. Methods: 42 months after double-lung transplantation due to cystic fi brosis a patient presented himself with BOS grade 3 with a vital capacity (VC) of 5,100 ml (BOS grade 1: VC of 5,940 ml) and a forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) of 2,120 ml (BOS grade 1: FEV1 of 4,930 ml). He showed a progressive decline in lung function despite a triple drug therapy with steroids, FK506 and mycophenolate mofetil. At our unit he was treated with two ECPs per week for 8 weeks, later at lower frequency. Multi-color fl ow cytometry was performed for naive T-cells, CD45RA+ eff ector T cells (T EMRA), memory T-cells and FoxP3+ regulatory T-cells (Treg), NK-cells, NKT-cells and BAFF-R+ B-cells. Results: 12 weeks after the start of ECP treatment no further decline of lung function with a VC of 5,070 ml and a FEV1 of 2,160 ml was measured by spirometry. In addition, the lung function improved to a VC of 5,360 ml and to a FEV1 of 2,410 ml 15 weeks later. The frequency of regulatory T cells of all CD4+ T cells increased over the time of ECP treatment from 1.2% before ECP to 6.7% after 106 days of treatment. The frequency of CD8+ eff ector T cells was reduced from 58.8% to 36.6% and of T(EM) from 10.4% to 3.2% over the time of ECP treatment, while naïve T cells increased from 27.8% to 55.6%. The B cell population presented with a very low percentage of < 2.6% over the time of therapy. The NK cell population presented with a low regular percentage of around 10% of all lymphocytes over the time of therapy, as well as NK-T cells of around 0.7% of all lymphocytes. Conclusion: ECP treatment was well tolerated and no severe infectious disease complications occurred during the therapy. Through ECP the lung function improved. Immunologically, the frequency of eff ector T cells thought to be responsible for the allograft rejection were reduced and the frequency of the regulatory T cells hampering the eff ector T cells increased. S451 Therefore, ECP therapy is an immunologically interesting and clinically promising therapeutic option for patients suff ering from allograft rejection.

back_matter.text: Sclerodermatous graft-versus-host disease successfully treated with water-fi ltered infrared A (wIRA) radiation: improved wound healing, regained range of motion and pain alleviation C.L. Marks, H. Schumann University Hospital Freiburg (Freiburg, DE) Chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) as a major post-transplant complication is responsible for increased morbidity after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Skin is the most common organ involved by chronic GvHD (cGvHD). In patients with sclerodermatous GvHD treatment of chronic wounds is challenging. Water-fi ltered infrared A (wIRA) radiation can improve the healing of acute and chronic wounds by increasing tissue temperature, oxygen partial pressure and perfusion.Here we present an impressive case report of a 52-year-old patient after allogenic HSCT for acute lymphoblastic leukemia in December 2007 who was treated later on with wIRA because of his numerous very badly-healing wounds on sclerodermatous skin due to chronic cutaneous GvHD. In 10/2008 he presented with his first symptoms of cutaneous GvHD: initially inflammatory signs changing into multifocal sclerodermatous lesions leading to restriction of motion and loss of function. Next to diverse immunosuppressive systemic therapy and physiotherapy the patient underwent extracorporeal photopheresis since 5/09 and had UV-A1 phototherapy in 11/2009. He experienced slight improvement, but no striking success by these treatment modalities. In January 2010 numerous painful ulcerations developed on the sclerodermatous skin, especially on shoulder, neck and head. The wounds measured up to 6 x 5 cm and were up to 5mm deep and purulent. Every week numerous new skin lesions developed-altogether around 30 smaller wounds. Local therapy with antiseptic agents like octenidine, fucidic acid and diverse wound dressings did not improve the situation. In 3/2010 we started wIRA. The patient was advised to perform this therapeutic procedure at home for at least 4-5 times a week for 30 minutes for each affected localisation. Only two weeks later we could observe considerably pain alleviation with substantially less need for analgesics. In addition, reduction of wound size could be observed and the patient regained range of motion. Only three months after, he showed a 50% improvement concerning wound size, after one more month he showed complete healing. Since then he no more developed any wounds on the shoulder/neck/head area. The patient is still performing wIRA twice a week with continuing improvement of his mobility. In conclusion wIRA is a promising therapy option for bad healing wounds in sclerodermatous GvHD.
