back_matter.text: Revisions to ISBT 128 nomenclature for cellular therapy I. Slaper-Cortenbach, P. Distler, P. Ashford on behalf of the Cellular Therapy Coding and Labeling Advisory Group ISBT 128 terminology has been widely adopted by cellular therapy facilities globally and its use has been an accreditation requirement by AABB, FACT and JACIE for several years. Accredited facilities are now required to put in place an implementation plan for the full use of ISBT 128 coding and labeling in addition to terminology, and many facilities are moving forward with this implementation. Responding to regulator concern about the use of TC ("therapeutic cell") terminology, the Cellular Therapy Coding and Labeling Advisory Group (CTCLAG) re-evaluated existing terminology. As a result of this review, a revision of the terminology was drafted to eliminate the "TC" class designation and to create a more consistent format for cellular therapy class terms. The revised terminology also takes into consideration consistency with nomenclature used for tissue products. Changes will not aff ect HPC terminology which represents about 65% of ISBT 128 product description codes. For class names that will change, not all nomenclature changes will result in a change to the ISBT 128 product description code ("S" code). While accepting that changing terminology will create rework for facilities that have implemented ISBT 128 and delay for those in the process of implementation, it is felt the revised terminology provides a strong foundation for consistent nomenclature as new products are developed and addresses regulatory concerns. An appropriate timescale for implementation of the revised terminology will be developed. This presentation will describe the revised terminology and explain the reasoning supporting the changes.
Cooperative programme for standard operating procedures and document preparation for JACIE accreditation. Advantages and disadvantages D. Sotiropoulos (1) (1) (

The establishment of a Quality Management System (QMS) according to FACT -JACIE standards in a BMT center is a very laborious project. Involvement of all personnel implicated in collection, processing and clinical procedures is absolutely necessary. Involvement includes strategic scheduling of QMS development, writing of SOPs and documents, and implementation of the system. Collaboration between diff erent centers could have advantages and disadvantages. We present the experience of such collaboration in our country. The four major BMT centers of the country had an agreement to collaborate in the establishment of a common QMS and apply for JACIE accreditation. The goal was all the centers to be able to communicate and collaborate in a more efficient way. Centers were located in three different cities. A common strategy was applied. A team of QM specialists was hired to work for the common project. Doctors, nurses, technicians and the QM specialists attended JACIE courses for center preparation. Writing of SOPs and documents was shared between the centers. The duration of the task from the beginning to the fi rst application for JACIE accreditation was four years. The development of the system lasted three years. SOPs and documents written by one center were distributed to the other centers for adjustments according to each center's demands. The total cost was estimated to be 30% lower compared to individual projects for each center separately. The cost was covered by a donation. In contrast, the separation of the tasks and the implication of more than one center were time-consuming. Delay of writing of SOPs in one center could aff ect the whole system. The development of the system is estimated to have lasted 50% more than the expected time. Two of the centers have already applied for JACIE accreditation. Overall, the major benefi t was that doctors, nurses and technicians from diff erent centers collaborated and shared knowledge and experience for a common task. (1), J. Baran (1) (1)Polish Stem Cell Bank (Warsaw, PL); PL) Introduction: Umbilical Cord Blood (UCB) is a widely used alternative to bone marrow and a mobilized peripheral blood source of transplantable hematopoietic stem cells in treatment of various disorders. Nowadays, two basic models of UCB banking exist: public (allogeneic donations from volunteers donors) and private (parents deciding to store UCB units in case of need by the donor-child or his/her family). In many countries public UCB banking is not developed, mainly due to insufficient funds. The Polish Stem Cell Bank (PBKM S.A.) decided to start UCB banking for public use in April 2011. In the autumn of the same year some public resources were raised (POLGRAFT -Program for Transplantation Medicine Development). In this paper we present the results of public UCB banking at our company. Materials and methods: Donations were collected from donors, after they mothers had given informed consent. The UCB were transported to the PBKM S.A. After preliminary assessment and qualifi cation, the UCB were processed by volume reduction and red blood cells depletion, followed by controlled-rate cryopreservation in the presence of 10% DMSO as a cryoprotectant. Units were stored in the vapour phase of liquid nitrogen at the monitored temperature of below -150 °C. The following assay were performed: total nucleated cell number (TNC), CD34+ cell, nucleated red blood cell, viability, as well as blood group, microbial culture, the presence of infectious agents, and HLA typing using molecular methods (PCR-SSP) at low resolution level (loci HLA-A,B and DR). Obtained HLA data were transferred to the database of the Polish Central Potential Unrelated Bone Marrow Donor and Cord Blood Registry and published on Bone Marrow Donor Worldwide websites, making them accessible for physicians all over the world. Results: After two years of UCB banking for public use, we have collected over 900 UCB units. 65% of collected UCB units were qualifi ed for processing, and fi nally more than 400 units were reported. The mean fi nal TNC count and CD34+ count were 101 x 10 7 and 3.2 x 10 6 respectively. Conclusions: The PBKM S.A. is a good model of combined public/ private umbilical cord blood banking. In 2 years, more than 400 UCB units were registered. The costs of these units were covered equally by public resources of POLGRAFT and the PBKM S.A. The quality of UCB units banked for public and private purposes revealed the same quality features, despite the diff erences in the processing for long-term storage.

The number of HCST made in the last fi ve years was 380, of these, 146(38%) were peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC). Since november 2010, both centres are accredited by Comité Conjunto de Acreditación(CCA:JACIE+CAT+ONT) for HCST activity. Aim: Knowing the degree of satisfaction of our clients, in this case, PBSC patients and donors, to be able to detect attitudes or incorrect cares by staff of BSTC during the collection and to be able to resolve them, in order to meet with our policy of continuous improvement. Material And Methods: Since june 2009, every patient and PBSC donor received, just after collection end, one opinion survey with 6 questions about issues like "information", "cares", "security" and "privacy" provided by staff of BSTC during apheresis processes. The fi ve possible answers vary from "very unfavourable(VU)" to "very favourable (VF)". The survey was delivered in stamped envelops intended to answer anonymously. Results: The percentage of opinion surveys answered was 47%(65/139). Of total valid answers (390), 83%(322) were "VF" and 15%(58) "favourable(F)". Only 2%(8) and 0.5%(2) were valued as "correct(C)" and "unfavourable(U)" respectively. There were no "UF" answers. Related to the specifi c issues, more favourable were "attention" and "security"(VF: 92%), followed by "information"(VF: 80%). "Privacy" was the issue than achieved "VF" in fewer times(VF: 71%). Conclusions: The opinion surveys are useful tools that allow easily know the satisfaction degree of the users on important issues as attention and security provided to apheresis patients and donors, allowing recognise the weakest points, to establish corrective or improvement actions.

Gilleece The Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust (Leeds, GB) Conditioning incorporated fl udarabine in 55/65 patients & was given for the fi rst 3 days of conditioning as a single cytotoxic agent. CMV reactivation risk was high in 9(14%), intermediate in 27(41.5%) & low risk in 29 (44.5%) There were a total of 90 readmission episodes of which 21 (23.3%) were due to CMV reactivation requiring ganciclovir which in our unit requires in-patient admission. The median number & duration of admissions/patient for CMV reactivation were 1(0-2) & 15 days respectively. CMV reactivation associated total number of inpatient bed days was 534. The other reasons for readmission were sepsis, 30 (33.4%); graft versus host disease, 13(14.5%); relapse, 6(6.5%) & others, 20(22.3%). Conclusion: 85% of patients received fl udarabine based conditioning. When administered as a single agent this may potentially be given in an ambulatory care setting, with resultant cost savings. CMV reactivation accounts for at least 23% of readmissions post-AlloHSCT with median duration >2w. Ganciclovir is fi rstline therapy for CMV reactivation & may be safely delivered as ambulatory care with potential cost reductions & improved patient experience. This may provide better quality of life for patients.

back_matter.text: Single centre pharmacoeconomic analysis of palifermin in autologous stem cell transplantation H.R. Johnson, A. Nooka, J. Kaufman, C. Flowers, A. Langston, M. Graiser, T. Plummer, S. Lonial, E. Waller Winship Cancer Institute (Atlanta, US) Background: Randomized clinical trials have shown palifermin reduces the incidence and severity of oral mucositis, TPN use, and use of opioid analgesics in patients with hematological malignancies receiving TBI-based conditioning regimens and autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT). However, similar outcomes data for patients receiving non-TBI conditioning is inconclusive. Our objective was to determine whether resource utilization including length of stay (LOS), analgesic use, and total transplant costs were diff erent between patients who received palifermin and those who did not in the setting of ASCT following non-TBI based conditioning. Methods: Patient data was retrospectively obtained on 829 patients with multiple myeloma (MM) or lymphoma (LY) who received ASCT following non-TBI based conditioning regimens between 1/02 and 12/10. Patients were stratifi ed by diagnosis and multiple linear regression controlled for other diff erences in baseline characteristics between the two groups (age, gender, ethnicity, and conditioning regimen). Results: 598 patients were in the palifermin-treated group (P) and 231 in the control group (C). There were 508 MM pts (389 P; 119 C) and 321 LY pts (209 P; 112 C). MM pts were conditioned with Melphalan and LY pts were conditioned with BEAM (28 P; 6 C), Bu/Cy or Bu/Cy/etoposide (174 P; 106 C), or Melphalan (7 P; 0 C). Two year survival did not diff er between P and C groups. Mean LOS was not signifi cantly diff erent between those who received palifermin and those who did not [MM: 18.7 days (P) vs. 19.1(C); LY: 23.0 (P) vs. 22 .8 (C)]. A sub-set analysis matching 24 C pts with 72 P pts (based upon diagnosis, conditioning regimen, age, and race) found no signifi cant diff erence between the P versus C groups on mean duration of PCA use (0.81 days vs. 0.88 days), mean duration of all analgesic use (8 days vs. 6 days), total PCA dose per day morphine equivalent (58.95 mg vs. 57.39 mg), or total dose of morphine equivalents (634 mg vs. 518 mg). Also, mean total charges incurred for the transplant hospitalization were not signifi cantly diff erent comparing the P vs. C groups, after adjusting for infl ation ($139K (P) vs. $135K (C); P=0.5). Conclusion: In patients receiving non-TBI conditioning regimens and ASCT, palifermin does not signifi cantly decrease length of stay, analgesic use, or total costs associated with ASCT. More detailed quality-of-life endpoints are needed to support palifermin use in the setting of non-TBI conditioning and ASCT. back_matter.text: Introduction: Autologous haematopoietic stem cell transplantation is an emerging treatment option in early diabetes type 1. The cost of transplantation raises the question to how this treatment modality compares economically with standard insulin therapy. So far this question was not addressed for this population of patients and there is only a scarce data for HSCT in autoimmune diseases Aims of the study: We analysed the cost eff ectiveness of autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation when compared to the standard insulin therapy. Methods: The retrospective analysis of the medical records of patients with early diabetes type 1 treated with autologous hematopoietic transplantation and patients with diabetes type 1 treated with insulin was performed. Then the CORE model was used for economic analysis. The CORE model is a tool that allows simulation of diabetes type 1 outcome and complications. Simulation with patient data was performed to obtain the QALY and ICER values of the treatment based on observation of patients after transplantation. Results: Series of scenarios using the real patient data were tested with CORE model. The QALY increased in all scenarios. The worst case scenarios assumed that after HSCT full doses of insulin were to be taken by patients and eff ect on HbA1c disappeared after given period of time. In that case if the observed diff erence in HbA1c between transplanted and not transplanted patients could be preserved over 10 years the ICER of the treatment would be still below the threshold value. In the more optimistic scenarios that included patients achieving remission and reduction of doses of insulin in the post transplantation period with the eff ect on HbA1c the ICER was under the threshold values in shorter time frame. Conclusion: Autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in early diabetes type 1 leads to improvement in QALY and in preliminary analysis show cost-eff ectiveness of HSCT versus standard insulin therapy if the eff ect of the treatment on HbA1c is sustained over few years. The ICER values will be positively aff ected by the reduction of doses of insulin after HSCT and increase of use of expensive long term analogues of insulin in the population of patients with diabetes type 1.

back_matter.text: Outpatient-based autologous stem cell transplantation is a safe and eff ective strategy: a single centre experience M. Robinson, M. Lawes Norfolk and Norwich University Hospital Foundation Trust (Norfolk, GB) Traditionally the inpatient stay for those undergoing Autologous Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplant (ASCT) is from initiation of conditioning chemoradiotherapy until evidence of bone marrow recovery. Given that blood products are given frequently in our outpatient department and severe neutropenia is not an immediate complication of the procedure, we have designed an outpatient based transplant protocol that allows early discharge. After conditioning and stem-cell re-infusion, patients can be discharged on day +1 if they have (i) an adequate oral intake and require no IV fl uids or medication (ii) have no clinical evidence of infection (iii) access to adequate social support which would allow immediate transport to hospital if required. Prophylactic antimicrobials were given to patients as standard, as well as emergency contact details. Supportive GCSF was not given. Follow up occurred via the specialist nurse-led day unit, three times per week for blood product support and central line care. Patients would be readmitted at any time in their recovery phase if there was evidence of infection or other complications requiring IV therapy. We retrospectively reviewed 124 patients who underwent ASCT following this protocol. The median time for marrow recovery for all patients (defi ned as a neutrophil count of >0.5x109/L) was 14 days . The majority (83.2%) required readmission for treatment of infection. A small group (8.8%) required no inpatient care; the remainder were required to remain as inpatients throughout the entire recovery period as they failed to meet the discharge criteria. After readmission, a median of only seven days (IQR 10-14) was spent as an inpatient in the recovery phase of their transplant. Following our protocol suggests that an average of 7 days in-patient care (IQR 3-12) is saved in comparison to waiting for evidence of marrow recovery before discharge. There was no transplant related mortality from any patient in this cohort, however one death occurred within 100 days due to early disease relapse. Our data suggests that outpatient based ASCT is safe and may benefi t the majority of patients undergoing the procedure. We also suggest it signifi cantly reduces the length of time that patients are required to remain in hospital following stem cell re-infusion. This may confer benefi ts in terms of psychological and nutritional support for those undergoing the procedure and produce institutional savings with regards to cost and bed occupancy. Results of alloHSCT from HLA-identical siblings performed between 2004-2008 for adults with ALL in CR1 were analyzed. Among 983 individuals treated in 27 European countries the median age was 35 (18-55) years and the interval from diagnosis to alloHSCT -158 (42-831) days. TBI was used for conditioning in 820 (83%) cases and peripheral blood was a source of stem cells in 656 (67%) cases. The following factors were studied for their impact on outcome: current HCE, HCE as % of gross domestic product, public HCE, private HCE, no. of physicians, nurses and pharmacists per population, no. of teams per country area and population, HDI and center activity (no. of alloHSCT for ALL in a study period). All variables were categorized by medians. In a univariate analysis the probability of leukemia-free survival (LFS) was positively infl uenced by current HCE > median (p=0.003), public HCE (p=0.002), higher number of nurses/population (p=0.002) and higher center activity (p=0.04). The incidence of relapse(RI) was decreased for current HCE > median (p=0.001) and higher number of nurses/population (p=0.0001). The incidence of non-relapse mortality (NRM) was reduced for HDI > median (p=0.02) while increased for higher number of teams per population (p=0.03). A tendency was found for increased NRM in centers with lower activity (p=0.06). In a multivariate analysis, adjusted for other potential prognostic factors (age, type of conditioning, CR duration, source of stem cells, donor/recipient gender), current HCE >median was associated with reduced risk of treatment failure (HR = 0.78, 95%CI = 0.62-0.97, p=0.03) and reduced risk of relapse (HR = 0.67, 95%CI = 0.5-0.89, p=0.006). Other variables could not be included in the model due to strong internal correlations. We conclude that health care expenditure and related economic factors infl uence results of alloHSCT for adults with ALL. The outcome may also be related to the distribution of transplant centers and the team experience. Our fi ndings may be useful for creating future strategies of transplant development at national levels as well as for interpretation of results of clinical analyses in the fi eld of alloHSCT. back_matter.text: Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT) is the only curative treatment for many patients with hematological disease. Unfortunately, the transplanted immune system may reacts against the recipient, inducing Graft-versus-Host Disease (GvHD). GvHD is the leading cause of treatment related mortality and morbidity following HSCT. Risk factors, human pathophysiology as well as response to immunosuppressive therapy are still largely unknown. CryoStem has been created to federate all French HSCT unit to be able to collect and store a large number of pre-and post-HSCT samples to study GvHD. The French Society for Stem Cell Transplantation and Cell Therapy (SFGM-TC) is the project promoter. CryoStem already brings together 21 HSCT Units and 14 Biological Resources Centers that will contribute to a networked, prospective, longitudinal and standardized HSCT samples collection with a concomitant well documented clinical database. CryoStem has been selected and funded to the extent of 5,5 millions € over a period of 9 years by the French Government's Investissements d'Avenir program. Patients sampling is scheduled before and after HSCT, depending on the occurrence or not of acute and/or chronic GvHD. Three types of pre-analytical products are processed and stored, according to standardized techniques: viable cells in DMSO, dried cell pellets and plasma. Samples and clinical data are anonymized and centralized in CryoStem-dedicated web-based database application. National projects are the only way to acquire the high number of samples needed for statistically signifi cant results in a reasonable time line. CryoStem thus expect to draw more than 5000 HSCT samples per year. The fi rst partner center is open and includes patients since july 2012. The other centers will open shortly on the whole French territory. Currently, about one hundred patients and related donors have been included within two centers in no more than 3 months. CryoStem represents a fundamental step toward progress in GvHD research. Cryostem will allow collaborative studies between leading French and international research organizations and foster technology transfer with potential industrial players in the near futur.

back_matter.text: A combination of lean working practices and Therakos™ Cellex® identify substantial effi ciency enhancements and a 63% productivity gain B. Linic (1) Introduction: Lean is a methodology that considers the expenditure of resources for any goal other than the creation of value to be wasteful. Value, in this context, is defined as an attribute which adds benefit to the patient. Process improvement strategies based on Lean solutions can cut costs, dramatically reduce processing times and free up valuable staff to undertake more productive work. Such gains can be directly translated into availability of extra capacity and improved patient care. Lean brings a fundamental change in working practices and the thinking behind them. It is an attitude of mind which constantly seeks to challenge and refine every aspect of working life. Study: The Dermatology Day Care Centre at St. Thomas's Hospital provides Extracorporeal Photophoresis (ECP) for patients presenting with Graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) and Cutaneous T-Cell

S456 Lymphoma (CTCL). The challenge faced in 2013 is to substantially increase the number of patients receiving ECP with no increase in staff costs. Lean tools were used to assess capacity constraints, design layout, and patient scheduling to reduce process wastage and patient waiting lists. Observations were made of variations in key parameters of the patient journey including; arrival to start delay, pre-observations, treatment times and post-observations. Data was collected from 133 ECP treatments and a statistical analysis was performed. The assessment included a review of both process and equipment and how personnel integrated within the work processes. Results: A lack of standardisation in the process resulted in substantial variation in all of the parameters assessed as illustrated below. Bottle-necks and inefficiencies were identified throughout the patient journey resulting in valuable time and capacity not being utilised efficiently. The implementation of Lean working practices, in combination with the Therakos™ Cellex® instrument, resulted in substantial efficiency and productivity gains with capacity being more fully utilised. The number of daily treatments can be increased in a two-phase approach from an average of 6 per day to 12 and then to 18 with the same number of nurses. Conclusions: Implementation of these new practices means that the number of treatments performed per annum can be increased by 63% and the department can move to a six and then a four day treatment week, compared to seven days previously. The elimination of weekend working would release funds for extra treatments.

An effi ciency study comparing Open System and Therakos™ Cellex® for extracorporeal photophoresis procedures G. Adorno (1) (1), F. Docimo (1) , A. Zizzari (1) , H. Klein (2) , P.M. Button (2) (1)RTN -Policlinico Tor Vergata (Rome, IT); (2)ProcEx Solutions Ltd. (London, GB) Introduction: The Department of Transfusion Medicine at the Policlinico-Tor-Vergata in Rome provides Extra Corporeal Photophoresis (ECP) for patients presenting with acute and chronic Graft-versus-host disease (GvHD), Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma (CTCL) and various dermatological disorders. The centre performs approximately 450 treatments per annum utilising a 5 day treatment week. Currently two processes are used for ECP; Open System (collection of buff y coat with a blood cell separator and irradiation with an external irradiator system) and Therakos Cellex (Closed System). The department desires to move all treatments to the Therakos Cellex system utilising a 2 day treatment week (currently 5 days/week) with minimal changes in cost compared to the current condition. Study: Data was collected and statistically analysed from a total of 149 routine ECP treatments performed in the period July to November 2012 (Open=75, Cellex=74). Parameters assessed included; patient arrival to start delay, pre-observations, treatment times and post-observations. Results: Therakos Cellex off ers a reduction in overall procedural times from 221 to 145 minutes with ECP treatment times reduced from a mean of 192 to 115 minutes: Treating all 447 patients on Therakos Cellex compared to all patients on Open System releases an annual capacity of 76 doctor days and 47 bed days. Conclusions: The Assessment concluded that the Therakos Cellex system off ered substantial improvements in patient treatment times improving patient Quality of Life and substantially increases capacity for more patient treatments with the same number of staff . Improvements in patient safety are off ered with the Therakos system due to the security of the closed system methodology. Activity Based Costing illustrated that a change from the current treatment regime to performing all treatments on Therakos Cellex (n=447), incorporating the application of Lean principles, added a small increase in actual cost (4.4%). A comparison of performing all 447 procedures on either system means a gain of 76 FTE days together with 47 bed days when using Therakos Cellex compared to Open System. By performing all treatments on Therakos Cellex
S457 the department is able to perform all ECP procedures 2 days/ week (currently 5 days) allowing other activities, such as stem cell collection, to be performed on the remaining 3 days/week.

A. Syrigou (1) , D. Zacharaki (1) , E. Matthaiou (2) , C. Smias (1) , M. Ganidou (1) , I. Sakellari (1) , D. Sotiropoulos (1), A. Anagnostopoulos (1) (1)George Papanikolaou Hospital (Thessaloniki, GR); (2)Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (Thessaloniki, GR) Objectives: The BMT Unit and the Post-Transplant Unit (PTU) of Hematology Clinics are major consumers of blood products: red blood cells (RBCs), platelets (PLTs) and fresh frozen plasma (FFP). We estimated the total consumption of blood products in the 328 patient admissions to the BMT Unit and the PTU of our Hospital for 2011. We tried to identify the parameters aff ecting the consumption needs of blood products in both Units. Methods: We evaluated all patients' admissions in relation to the following parameters: days of hospitalization, diagnosis, disease status, transplantation type, conditioning and number of RBCs, PLTs and FFPs consumed. All measurements of blood products follow the rule: Mean blood product unit (MBPU) consumption per day= [Number of blood product units consumed/Total days of hospitalization] x 100. Statistical analysis was performed. Results: 328 admissions corresponded to 4291 hospitalization days. MBPU in the BMT unit were 13. 5 RBCs, 18.2 PLTs, and 15.6 FFPs versus 19.9 RBCs, 26.3 PLTs and 50.6 FFPs in the PTU. Allo-transplanted patients had the highest consumption of RBCs and PLTs vs autoand allo-RIC-transplanted (Kruskal-Wallis test, p<0.001), whereas allo-RIC had the highest consumption of FFPs (p=0.045). No statistically signifi cant diff erence was shown between MBPU of lymphomas and multiple myelomas in the BMT Unit (Mann-Whitney test). Again, no signifi cant diff erence was recorded between MBPU of Hodgkin and NHL in the BMT Unit (Mann-Whitney test). In the PTU, the type of transplantation aff ected the consumption of RBCs (auto: 8.2%, allo: 91.8%, p<0.001) and FFPs (auto: 7.1%, allo: 92.9%, p=0.002, Mann-Whitney test). In the PTU AML patients consumed more RBCs and PLTs, but less FFPs compared to ALL patients (no stat. signifi cant diff erence, Mann-Whitney test). Conclusion: In this study we identifi ed which groups of hematological patients undergoing BMT and which types of diseases require most blood product units in order to minimize the amount of units given to recipients. Such a survey can serve as a tool to estimate in advance the mean annual needs of the BMT Unit and PTU patients and coordinate accordingly the Blood Bank's donations.

back_matter.text: Cost analysis of allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation C. Martínez-Múgica, C. Alarcón, A.J. González, C. Pardo, M. Alaguero, A.P. González, P. Palomo, R. Fernández, S. González, C. Rayón, C. Vallejo University Central Hospital of Asturias (Oviedo, ES) Objective: to evaluate the pharmacy costs of the allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). Materials and methods: all patients who underwent allo-HSCT due to hematological diseases at the Hematopoietic Transplant Unit of University Central Hospital of Asturias (Spain) between February 2008 and October 2012 were included in this study. The period analyzed is from the moment of admission to hospital for HSCT to discharge from hospital. Total charges for the hospitalization were obtained from medical charts and from the Pharmacy-dispensing software. Medications included: preparative regimens, immunosuppressive therapy, prophylactic treatments and drugs for comorbidities and complications. Fluid therapy was not included.Total costs were calculated using laboratory sale prices (without taxes). Results: a total of 116 patients were transplanted during the period of the study. Characteristics of the series of patients and procedures are shown in table 1. The median hospitalization stay was 33 days (range 8-69), during which 338 different pharmaceutical specialities were prescribed. Nineteen of those specialities accounted for 80% of costs, including thymo globulin (16 % of total prescription cost), busulphan (11 %), voriconazole (6 %) and non-specific immunoglobulins (5 %). The breakdown analysis of drug cost by therapeutic groups showed that group J (anti-infectives for systemic use) was the most expensive category, accounting for 30,9 % of the total cost, followed by group L (anti-neoplastic and immunomodulating agents), accounting for 30,5 % of the total cost. The total median and average costs per patient were 7.722,5 € and 10.108,8 €, respectively (range: 1.438-61.805 €) . Costs of unrelated donor and family donor transplants were similar, while UCBT was more expensive (figure 1). Conclusions: our fi ndings show that allo-HSCT for patients with hematological diseases is a cost-eff ective choice. These fi ndings provide useful information regarding costs of allo-HSCT to physicians, highlighting the challenge faced in the effi cient management of therapeutic resources. S458 P1236 Filgrastim XM02 (Tevagrastim) after autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT): favourable cost-effi cacy eff ect in comparison with lenograstim A. Gardellini, F. Gigli, A. Babic, G. Andreola, D. Radice, G. Martinelli, D. Laszlo European Institute of Oncology (Milan, IT) Granulocyte colony-stimulating factors (G-CSF), filgrastim and lenograstim, are recognized to be useful in accelerating engraftment after ASCT. Studies comparing the efficacy of filgrastim and lenograstim demonstrated no difference in this setting. Recently, several forms of biosimilar non-glycosylated G-CSF have been approved by the EMA, with limited published data supporting the clinical equivalence in peripheral blood stem cell mobilization and recovery after ASCT. With the aim to compare the cost-effective strategy in the use of G-CSF after ASCT, we retrospectively evaluated 32 patients cosecutively treated at IEO with biosimilar filgrastim XMO2 (Tevagrastim) and 26 with lenograstim between November 2010 and December 2011. Median age, sex, diagnosis, conditioning regimen and median number of CD34+ reinfused were similar in the two groups. All patients received G-CSG (biosimilar or lenograstim) at the dosage of 5mcg/Kg/day subcoutaneously from day +5 to absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of 1500/mm3 for three consecutive days. Engraftment was defined as ANC > 500/mmc and platelets count > 20.000/mmc. Results: median days to ANC engraftment was 11 days (range 10 -11) for filgrastim XM02 group and 12 days (range 10 -12) for lenograstim group (p 0.055). As for platelets recovery, median days was 12 in both groups with a range of 7-22 for filgrastim XM02 group and 9 -30 for lenograstim group. Median number of G-CSF vials used was 9.5 for Tevagrastim and 10.5 for lenograstim, reflecting a mean estimated cost of about 556.1 (± 20.0) euros for Tevagrastim versus 932.2 (± 54.4) euros for lenograstim (p < 0.001). Median days of febrile neutropenia was 1.5 (range 0 -5) and 1 (range 0 -10) for filgrastim XM02 and lenograstim respectively. With a median follow-up of 14 months (range 3 -23) no adverse event related to the use of XM02 filgrastim was recorded. With the growing importance of managing limited healthcare resources, biosimilar G-CSFs may represent a cost-effective strategy; for this reason, clinical results confirming the efficacy of biosimilar G-CSF in any indications as the reference filgrastim are needed. To our knowledge, this is the first experience comparing biosimilar G-CSF to lenograstim after ASCT. In our experience filgrastim XM02 and lenograstim showed comparable efficacy to shorten the period of neutro penia after cytoreduction and ASCT with a favourable cost-effect profile for filgrastim XM02.
